But he replied, "Why do you ask my name?" Then he blessed him there.

So Jacob called the place Peniel, saying, "It is because I saw God face to face, and yet my life was spared." The sun rose above him as he passed Peniel, and he was limping because of his hip. Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the socket of Jacob's hip was touched near the tendon.

Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming with four hundred men. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two female servants. He put the female servants and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph in the rear. He himself went on ahead and bowed down to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.

But Esau ran to meet Jacob and embraced him; he threw his arms around his neck and kissed him. And they wept. Then Esau looked up and saw the women and children. "Who are these with you?" he asked.

Jacob answered, "They are the children God has graciously given your servant."

Then the female servants and their children approached and bowed down. Next, Leah and her children came and bowed down. Last of all came Joseph and Rachel, and they too bowed down.

Esau asked, "What do you mean by all these droves I met?"

"To find favor in your eyes, my lord," he said.

But Esau said, "I already have plenty, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself."

"No, please!" said Jacob. "If I have found favor in your eyes, accept this gift from me. For to see your face is like seeing the face of God, now that you have received me favorably. Please accept the present that was brought to you, for God has been gracious to me and I have all I need." And because Jacob insisted, Esau accepted it.

Then Esau said, "Let us be on our way; I'll accompany you."

But Jacob said to him, "My lord knows that the children are tender and that I must care for the ewes and cows that are nursing their young. If they are driven hard just one day, all the animals will die. So let my lord go on ahead of his servant, while I move along slowly at the pace of the flocks and herds before me and the pace of the children, until I come to my lord in Seir."

Esau said, "Then let me leave some of my men with you."

"But why do that?" Jacob asked. "Just let me find favor in the eyes of my lord."

So that day Esau started on his way back to Seir. Jacob, however, went to Succoth, where he built a place for himself and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place is called Succoth.

After Jacob came from Paddan Aram, he arrived safely at the city of Shechem in Canaan and camped within sight of the city. For a hundred pieces of silver, he bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, the plot of ground where he pitched his tent. There he set up an altar and called it El Elohe Israel.

Now Dinah, the daughter Leah had borne to Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land. When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the ruler of that area, saw her, he took her and raped her. His heart was drawn to Dinah, daughter of Jacob; he loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.Shechem, deeply in love with Dinah, spoke to his father Hamor, asking him to arrange a marriage with her. When Jacob heard that Shechem had violated his daughter, he remained silent until his sons returned from the fields. Hamor approached Jacob to discuss the matter, and Jacob's sons, upon hearing what happened, were outraged.

Hamor proposed that their families intermarry and live together in peace. Shechem offered to pay any bride price for Dinah. Jacob's sons deceitfully agreed, on the condition that all the men in Shechem's city be circumcised. Hamor and Shechem agreed and convinced the men of their city to comply.

On the third day, while the men were still in pain from the circumcision, Jacob's sons Simeon and Levi attacked the city, killing all the males, including Hamor and Shechem. They rescued Dinah and plundered the city, taking livestock, wealth, women, and children.

Jacob rebuked Simeon and Levi, fearing retaliation from neighboring tribes. They defended their actions, arguing that their sister should not be treated like a prostitute.

God then instructed Jacob to move to Bethel and build an altar. Jacob told his household to discard their foreign gods and purify themselves. They journeyed to Bethel, where Jacob built an altar and named the place El Bethel. God appeared to Jacob again, reaffirming his new name, Israel, and promising that nations and kings would descend from him.

Rachel, Jacob's wife, went into labor and gave birth to Benjamin but died during childbirth. Jacob buried her and set up a pillar on her grave. Israel (Jacob) continued his journey, and his son Reuben committed a grave sin by sleeping with Bilhah, Jacob's concubine.

Jacob's twelve sons were Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Joseph, Benjamin, Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. Jacob reunited with his father Isaac in Hebron, where Isaac later died and was buried by his sons Esau and Jacob.

Esau's descendants settled in the hill country of Seir, becoming the Edomites. Esau's sons included Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. The descendants of Esau became leaders and established their own clans in Edom.The descendants of Seir in the land of Edom included Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. Lotan's children were Hori and Hemam, and his sister was Timna. Shobal's children were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam. Zibeon's children were Ajah and Anah, the latter of whom discovered mules in the wilderness while tending his father's donkeys. Anah's children were Dishon and Aholibamah. Dishon's children were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran. Ezer's children were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan. Dishan's children were Uz and Aran. These were the leaders of the Horites: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan, who ruled in the land of Seir.

Before any king ruled over the Israelites, the kings of Edom were Bela son of Beor, who ruled in Dinhabah; Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah; Husham from the land of the Temanites; Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in Moab and ruled in Avith; Samlah from Masrekah; Saul from Rehoboth by the river; Baalhanan son of Achbor; and Hadar, who ruled in Pau, with his wife Mehetabel, daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Mezahab.

The leaders of Esau's descendants, according to their families and locations, were Timnah, Alvah, Jetheth, Aholibamah, Elah, Pinon, Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar, Magdiel, and Iram. These were the leaders of Edom, the descendants of Esau, who lived in their respective territories.

Jacob lived in the land of Canaan, where his father had been a foreigner. Joseph, at seventeen, was tending the flock with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father's wives. Joseph reported their misdeeds to their father. Israel (Jacob) loved Joseph more than his other children because he was born in his old age, and he made Joseph a special coat of many colors. This favoritism caused Joseph's brothers to hate him and speak harshly to him.

Joseph had a dream and shared it with his brothers, which made them hate him even more. In the dream, they were binding sheaves in the field, and Joseph's sheaf stood upright while their sheaves bowed down to it. His brothers asked if he intended to rule over them and hated him even more for his dreams and words. Joseph had another dream where the sun, moon, and eleven stars bowed down to him. When he told this dream to his father and brothers, his father rebuked him, asking if they were all to bow down to him. His brothers envied him, but his father pondered the dream.

Joseph's brothers went to graze their father's flock in Shechem. Israel sent Joseph to check on them and report back. Joseph found them in Dothan after a man directed him there. When his brothers saw him approaching, they plotted to kill him, calling him "the dreamer." Reuben intervened, suggesting they throw Joseph into a pit instead of killing him, intending to rescue him later. They stripped Joseph of his coat and threw him into an empty pit.

As they ate, they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead, carrying spices, balm, and myrrh to Egypt. Judah suggested selling Joseph to the Ishmaelites instead of killing him, as he was their brother. The brothers agreed and sold Joseph for twenty pieces of silver. The Ishmaelites took Joseph to Egypt. Reuben returned to the pit and, finding Joseph gone, tore his clothes in distress. The brothers dipped Joseph's coat in goat's blood and sent it to their father, who recognized it and believed a wild animal had killed Joseph. Jacob mourned deeply, refusing to be comforted, saying he would mourn until he joined Joseph in the grave. Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard.

At that time, Judah left his brothers and stayed with a man named Hirah in Adullam. Judah married a Canaanite woman named Shuah, and they had three sons: Er, Onan, and Shelah. Judah arranged a marriage for Er with a woman named Tamar. However, Er was wicked in the Lord's sight, and the Lord put him to death. Judah then told Onan to marry Tamar and produce offspring for his brother. Onan, knowing the offspring would not be his, spilled his semen on the ground to avoid providing offspring for his brother. This displeased the Lord, so He put Onan to death as well. Judah told Tamar to live as a widow in her father's house until Shelah grew up, fearing he might die too. Tamar obeyed and lived in her father's house.

After some time, Judah's wife Shuah died. After mourning, Judah went to Timnath to shear his sheep, accompanied by his friend Hirah. Tamar, hearing this, disguised herself as a prostitute and sat by the road to Timnath, as she saw that Shelah had grown up but she had not been given to him as a wife. Judah saw her, thought she was a prostitute because she had covered her face, and propositioned her. She asked for a pledge until he sent her a young goat. He gave her his signet, bracelets, and staff. They slept together, and she conceived. Tamar then returned home, removing her disguise and resuming her widow's garments. Judah later sent the goat through his friend Hirah to retrieve his pledge, but Hirah could not find her.Judah's friend, the Adullamite, went to retrieve the pledge from the woman but couldn't find her. He asked the locals about the prostitute who had been by the roadside, but they said there was no such woman. When he reported back to Judah, Judah decided to let her keep the items to avoid further embarrassment, acknowledging that he had sent the goat but she wasn't found.

About three months later, Judah was informed that Tamar, his daughter-in-law, had acted as a prostitute and was pregnant. Judah ordered her to be brought out and burned. As she was being brought out, Tamar sent a message to Judah, revealing that she was pregnant by the man who owned the signet, bracelets, and staff she had. Judah recognized them and admitted that she was more righteous than he was because he had not given her to his son Shelah. He did not sleep with her again.

When Tamar gave birth, she had twins. During the delivery, one baby put out his hand, and the midwife tied a scarlet thread around it, declaring him the firstborn. However, he pulled his hand back, and his brother came out first. The midwife exclaimed at the unexpected turn of events and named him Perez. The baby with the scarlet thread was born afterward and was named Zerah.

Meanwhile, Joseph was taken to Egypt and sold to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard. The Lord was with Joseph, and he prospered in Potiphar's house. Potiphar saw that the Lord was with Joseph and made him the overseer of his household, entrusting him with everything he owned. Because of Joseph, the Lord blessed Potiphar's house and fields. Potiphar left everything in Joseph's care, only concerning himself with the food he ate. Joseph was handsome and well-built.

After some time, Potiphar's wife tried to seduce Joseph, but he refused, explaining that he couldn't betray his master or sin against God. Despite her daily attempts, Joseph did not give in. One day, when Joseph was alone in the house, she grabbed his garment and demanded he sleep with her. Joseph fled, leaving his garment in her hand. She then accused Joseph of trying to assault her, showing the garment as evidence. When Potiphar heard her story, he was furious and had Joseph imprisoned.

Even in prison, the Lord was with Joseph, showing him mercy and granting him favor with the prison warden. The warden put Joseph in charge of all the prisoners and everything that happened there. The warden trusted Joseph completely because the Lord made Joseph successful in all he did.

Sometime later, Pharaoh's chief butler and chief baker offended him and were imprisoned in the same place as Joseph. The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to attend to them. Both men had dreams on the same night, and Joseph noticed their distress the next morning. When they explained that they had no one to interpret their dreams, Joseph told them that interpretations belong to God and asked them to share their dreams.

The chief butler described his dream of a vine with three branches that budded, blossomed, and produced ripe grapes. He pressed the grapes into Pharaoh's cup and handed it to Pharaoh. Joseph interpreted the dream, saying the three branches represented three days, and within three days, Pharaoh would restore the butler to his position. Joseph asked the butler to remember him and mention him to Pharaoh to help get him out of prison, explaining that he had been wrongfully imprisoned.

Seeing the favorable interpretation, the chief baker shared his dream of three baskets of baked goods on his head, with birds eating from the top basket. Joseph interpreted that the three baskets also represented three days, but in three days, Pharaoh would execute the baker, and birds would eat his flesh.

On Pharaoh's birthday, he held a feast and restored the chief butler to his position but executed the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted. However, the chief butler forgot about Joseph.

Two years later, Pharaoh had a dream where he stood by the river, and seven healthy cows came out to graze. Then, seven thin, ugly cows came out and ate the healthy cows. Pharaoh woke up but fell asleep again and dreamed of seven healthy ears of corn on one stalk, followed by seven thin ears scorched by the east wind. The thin ears swallowed the healthy ones. Pharaoh woke up troubled and called for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt, but none could interpret his dreams.

The chief butler then remembered Joseph and told Pharaoh about him.Joseph was quickly brought out of the dungeon. He shaved, changed his clothes, and went to see Pharaoh. Pharaoh told Joseph, "I had a dream, and no one can interpret it. But I've heard you can understand dreams and interpret them." Joseph replied, "I can't do it, but God will give Pharaoh the answer he desires."

Pharaoh then described his dream to Joseph: "I was standing by the river, and seven healthy, well-fed cows came out and grazed in the meadow. Then, seven other cows, sickly and thin, came out of the river and stood beside the healthy cows. The thin cows ate the healthy ones, but even after eating them, they looked just as bad as before. Then I woke up. In my second dream, I saw seven full, good ears of corn growing on one stalk. After them, seven thin ears, scorched by the east wind, sprouted and swallowed the good ears. I told this to the magicians, but none could explain it to me."

Joseph said to Pharaoh, "Both dreams mean the same thing. God is showing Pharaoh what He is about to do. The seven healthy cows and the seven good ears of corn represent seven years of abundance. The seven thin cows and the seven scorched ears of corn represent seven years of famine. There will be seven years of great abundance in Egypt, followed by seven years of severe famine that will consume the land. The reason the dream was given to Pharaoh in two forms is that the matter has been firmly decided by God, and He will do it soon.

"Therefore, Pharaoh should look for a wise and discerning man and put him in charge of the land of Egypt. Let Pharaoh appoint commissioners to take a fifth of the harvest during the seven years of abundance. They should collect all the food of these good years and store up the grain under Pharaoh's authority, to be kept in the cities for food. This food will be a reserve for the country, to be used during the seven years of famine that will come upon Egypt, so that the country may not be ruined by the famine."

Pharaoh and all his officials approved of Joseph's plan. Pharaoh said to his officials, "Can we find anyone like this man, one in whom is the spirit of God?" Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you. You shall be in charge of my palace, and all my people are to submit to your orders. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you."

Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I hereby put you in charge of the whole land of Egypt." Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his finger and put it on Joseph's finger. He dressed him in robes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck. He had him ride in a chariot as his second-in-command, and people shouted before him, "Make way!" Thus, he put him in charge of the whole land of Egypt.

Pharaoh told Joseph, "I am Pharaoh, but without your word, no one will lift hand or foot in all Egypt." Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-Paneah and gave him Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife. Joseph traveled throughout Egypt.

Joseph was thirty years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh king of Egypt. During the seven years of abundance, the land produced plentifully. Joseph collected all the food produced in those seven years of abundance in Egypt and stored it in the cities. In each city, he put the food grown in the fields surrounding it. Joseph stored up huge quantities of grain, like the sand of the sea; it was so much that he stopped keeping records because it was beyond measure.

Before the years of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On. Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh, saying, "It is because God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father's household." The second son he named Ephraim, saying, "It is because God has made me fruitful in the land of my suffering."

The seven years of abundance in Egypt came to an end, and the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in all the other lands, but in the whole land of Egypt, there was food. When all Egypt began to feel the famine, the people cried to Pharaoh for food. Then Pharaoh told all the Egyptians, "Go to Joseph and do what he tells you."

When the famine had spread over the whole country, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe throughout Egypt. And all the world came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph because the famine was severe everywhere.

When Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, "Why do you just keep looking at each other? I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may live and not die." Then ten of Joseph's brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt. But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph's brother, with the others, because he was afraid that harm might come to him. So Israel's sons were among those who went to buy grain, for there was famine in the land of Canaan also.

Now Joseph was the governor of the land, the person who sold grain to all its people. So when Joseph's brothers arrived, they bowed down to him with their faces to the ground. As soon as Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them, but he pretended to be a stranger and spoke harshly to them. "Where do you come from?" he asked.

"From the land of Canaan," they replied, "to buy food."

Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not recognize him. Then he remembered his dreams about them and said to them, "You are spies! You have come to see where our land is unprotected."

"No, my lord," they answered. "Your servants have come to buy food. We are all the sons of one man. Your servants are honest men, not spies."

"No!" he said to them. "You have come to see where our land is unprotected."

But they replied, "Your servants were twelve brothers, the sons of one man, who lives in the land of Canaan. The youngest is now with our father, and one is no more."

Joseph said to them, "It is just as I told you: You are spies! And this is how you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here. Send one of your number to get your brother; the rest of you will be kept in prison, so that your words may be tested to see if you are telling the truth. If you are not, then as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies!" And he put them all in custody for three days.

On the third day, Joseph said to them, "Do this and you will live, for I fear God: If you are honest men, let one of your brothers stay here in prison, while the rest of you go and take grain back for your starving households. But you must bring your youngest brother to me, so that your words may be verified and that you may not die." This they proceeded to do.

They said to one another, "Surely we are being punished because of our brother. We saw how distressed he was when he pleaded with us for his life, but we would not listen; that's why this distress has come upon us."

Reuben replied, "Didn't I tell you not to sin against the boy? But you wouldn't listen! Now we must give an accounting for his blood." They did not realize that Joseph could understand them, since he was using an interpreter.

He turned away from them and began to weep, but then came back and spoke to them again. He had Simeon taken from them and bound before their eyes. Joseph gave orders to fill their bags with grain, to put each man's silver back in his sack, and to give them provisions for their journey. After this was done for them, they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left.

At the place where they stopped for the night, one of them opened his sack to get feed for his donkey, and he saw his silver in the mouth of his sack. "My silver has been returned," he said to his brothers. "Here it is in my sack." Their hearts sank, and they turned to each other trembling and said, "What is this that God has done to us?"

When they came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him all that had happened to them. They said, "The man who is lord over the land spoke harshly to us and treated us as though we were spying on the land. But we said to him, 'We are honest men; we are not spies. We were twelve brothers, sons of one father. One is no more, and the youngest is now with our father in Canaan.' Then the man who is lord over the land said to us, 'This is how I will know whether you are honest men: Leave one of your brothers here with me, and take food for your starving households and go. But bring your youngest brother to me so I will know that you are not spies but honest men. Then I will give your brother back to you, and you can trade in the land.'"Joseph's brothers returned home and told their father, Jacob, everything that had happened. They explained that the man in charge of Egypt, who was actually Joseph, had accused them of being spies and demanded they bring their youngest brother, Benjamin, to prove their honesty. Jacob was distressed, feeling he had already lost Joseph and Simeon, and now feared losing Benjamin too. Reuben offered to take responsibility for Benjamin, even pledging his own sons' lives if he failed to bring Benjamin back safely. Jacob reluctantly agreed, sending gifts and double the money to Egypt, hoping for mercy.

When the brothers returned to Egypt with Benjamin, Joseph saw them and arranged for them to dine at his house. The brothers were afraid, thinking they were in trouble because of the money found in their sacks. They explained the situation to Joseph's steward, who reassured them and brought Simeon out to join them. Joseph, deeply moved upon seeing Benjamin, had to leave the room to weep. He then composed himself and joined them for the meal, seating them according to their ages and giving Benjamin a portion five times larger than the others.

The next morning, Joseph instructed his steward to fill their sacks with food and secretly place his silver cup in Benjamin's sack. After they left, Joseph sent his steward to confront them about the "stolen" cup. The brothers were shocked and offered to become Joseph's slaves if the cup was found with any of them. When the cup was discovered in Benjamin's sack, they tore their clothes in despair and returned to Joseph's house. Judah pleaded with Joseph, explaining their father's deep attachment to Benjamin and the devastating impact it would have on him if Benjamin did not return.Judah continued to plead with Joseph, explaining that he had promised their father to take full responsibility for Benjamin. He offered to stay as a slave in Benjamin's place, fearing the heartbreak it would cause their father if Benjamin did not return.

Joseph could no longer contain his emotions and ordered everyone else to leave the room. He revealed his identity to his brothers, weeping so loudly that even the Egyptians and Pharaoh's household heard him. Joseph asked if their father was still alive, but his brothers were too shocked to respond. He reassured them, explaining that it was God's plan for him to be in Egypt to save lives during the famine.

Joseph instructed his brothers to return quickly to their father and bring him and their families to Egypt, where they would be provided for during the remaining years of famine. He embraced Benjamin and wept, and then kissed and wept with all his brothers, who finally spoke with him.

News of Joseph's brothers' arrival reached Pharaoh, who was pleased and instructed Joseph to bring his family to Egypt. Pharaoh promised them the best land and provisions for their journey. Joseph gave his brothers wagons, supplies, and new clothes, with extra gifts for Benjamin and their father. He sent them off, reminding them not to quarrel on the way.

When the brothers returned to Canaan and told Jacob that Joseph was alive and ruling Egypt, he was initially in disbelief. But when he saw the wagons and heard Joseph's message, his spirit revived, and he decided to go see Joseph before he died.

Jacob, also known as Israel, set out for Egypt with his entire family and possessions. God spoke to him in a vision, reassuring him not to fear going to Egypt, as He would make Jacob's descendants a great nation there and bring them back again. Jacob's sons carried him, their children, and their wives in the wagons provided by Pharaoh.

They arrived in Egypt with all their livestock and belongings. Joseph went to meet his father in Goshen, and they embraced and wept. Jacob expressed his contentment at seeing Joseph alive. Joseph then informed Pharaoh about his family's arrival and their occupation as shepherds, which was detested by the Egyptians, ensuring they would live separately in Goshen.

Joseph presented some of his brothers to Pharaoh, who asked about their occupation. They explained they were shepherds seeking pasture due to the famine in Canaan. Pharaoh welcomed them and offered them the best land in Egypt, even suggesting they oversee his own livestock if they were capable.

Joseph brought Jacob to meet Pharaoh, who asked about his age. Jacob replied that he was 130 years old and that his life had been difficult compared to his ancestors.Jacob blessed Pharaoh and left his presence. Joseph settled his family in the best part of Egypt, as Pharaoh had commanded, and provided them with food. The famine was severe, and there was no bread in the land. Joseph collected all the money in Egypt and Canaan in exchange for grain and brought it to Pharaoh's house. When the money ran out, the Egyptians asked Joseph for bread, offering their livestock in exchange. Joseph agreed and provided them with food for their animals.

The following year, the people, having no money or livestock left, offered themselves and their land to Pharaoh in exchange for food. Joseph bought all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh, except for the priests' land, which was provided for by Pharaoh. Joseph then gave the people seed to plant, with the agreement that they would give one-fifth of their harvest to Pharaoh and keep the rest for themselves.

The people were grateful and agreed to be Pharaoh's servants. Joseph established this as a law in Egypt, which remained in place. Meanwhile, Jacob's family thrived in Goshen, growing in number and wealth. Jacob lived in Egypt for 17 years, reaching the age of 147.

As Jacob's death approached, he asked Joseph to promise to bury him in Canaan with his ancestors. Joseph agreed and swore to do so. Later, when Jacob fell ill, Joseph brought his sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, to see him. Jacob blessed them, claiming them as his own, and recounted God's promise to make his descendants a great nation.

Jacob blessed Joseph's sons, placing his right hand on the younger Ephraim's head, despite Joseph's attempt to correct him. Jacob explained that Ephraim would become greater than Manasseh. He then blessed Joseph and his descendants, promising God's continued presence and eventual return to Canaan.

Before his death, Jacob called his sons together to tell them what would happen in the future. He addressed each son, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses, and prophesied their destinies.Jacob blessed his sons, giving each a unique blessing. He then instructed them to bury him in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite, in Canaan, where Abraham, Sarah, Isaac, Rebekah, and Leah were buried. After giving these instructions, Jacob passed away. Joseph mourned deeply, had his father embalmed, and the Egyptians mourned for seventy days.

After the mourning period, Joseph asked Pharaoh for permission to bury his father in Canaan, as promised. Pharaoh agreed, and Joseph, along with a large entourage, went to Canaan to bury Jacob. They mourned for seven days at the threshing floor of Atad, which was observed by the Canaanites.

Jacob's sons buried him in the cave of Machpelah, as he had instructed. After the burial, Joseph and his brothers returned to Egypt. Joseph's brothers, fearing retribution for their past wrongs, asked for forgiveness. Joseph reassured them, saying that although they intended harm, God used it for good to save many lives. He promised to take care of them and their families.

Joseph lived in Egypt for 110 years, seeing his descendants to the third generation. Before his death, he reminded his brothers of God's promise to bring them out of Egypt and asked them to carry his bones with them when they left. Joseph died, was embalmed, and placed in a coffin in Egypt.

The descendants of Jacob, now called the Israelites, grew in number and strength in Egypt. A new Pharaoh, who did not know Joseph, saw them as a threat and enslaved them, forcing them to build cities and work under harsh conditions. Despite the oppression, the Israelites continued to multiply.

Pharaoh ordered the Hebrew midwives to kill all newborn Hebrew boys, but they disobeyed, fearing God. When questioned, they explained that Hebrew women gave birth before they arrived. God blessed the midwives for their actions, and the Israelites continued to grow.

Pharaoh then commanded all his people to throw every newborn Hebrew boy into the Nile River. During this time, a Levite woman gave birth to a son and hid him for three months. When she could no longer hide him, she placed him in a basket and set it among the reeds by the riverbank. The baby's sister watched from a distance.

Pharaoh's daughter found the basket, felt compassion for the crying baby, and recognized him as a Hebrew child. The baby's sister offered to find a Hebrew woman to nurse him, and Pharaoh's daughter agreed. The baby's mother was brought to nurse him, and later, he was adopted by Pharaoh's daughter and named Moses, meaning "drawn out of the water."

When Moses grew up, he saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew and killed the Egyptian, hiding the body in the sand. The next day, he saw two Hebrews fighting and tried to intervene, but they questioned his authority and mentioned the murder. Fearing for his life, Moses fled to Midian, where he sat by a well.Moses was sitting by a well when the priest of Midian's seven daughters came to draw water for their father's flock. Some shepherds tried to drive them away, but Moses stood up, helped them, and watered their flock. When the daughters returned home early, their father, Reuel, asked why. They explained that an Egyptian had helped them. Reuel asked them to invite Moses to eat with them. Moses agreed to stay with Reuel and married his daughter Zipporah. They had a son named Gershom, meaning "I have been a stranger in a foreign land."

Over time, the king of Egypt died, and the Israelites groaned under their slavery, crying out for help. God heard their cries and remembered His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He looked upon the Israelites and was concerned for them.

Moses was tending the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian, when he led the flock to Horeb, the mountain of God. There, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a burning bush that was not consumed by the fire. Moses approached to see this strange sight, and God called to him from the bush, instructing him to remove his sandals because he was standing on holy ground. God introduced Himself as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Moses hid his face, afraid to look at God.

God told Moses that He had seen the suffering of His people in Egypt and heard their cries. He planned to rescue them from the Egyptians and bring them to a land flowing with milk and honey, the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites. God commanded Moses to go to Pharaoh and lead the Israelites out of Egypt. Moses questioned his ability to do this, but God assured him that He would be with him and that the sign of their success would be their worship of God on that mountain.

Moses asked what he should say if the Israelites asked for God's name. God replied, "I AM WHO I AM," instructing Moses to tell them that "I AM" had sent him. God further instructed Moses to tell the Israelites that the Lord, the God of their ancestors, had appeared to him and promised to bring them out of Egypt to a prosperous land. God assured Moses that the elders of Israel would listen to him and that they should request a three-day journey into the wilderness to worship God. God warned that Pharaoh would not let them go easily, but He would perform wonders in Egypt, and eventually, Pharaoh would let them go. The Israelites would leave with favor from the Egyptians, taking valuable items with them.

Moses expressed doubt that the Israelites would believe him, so God gave him signs to perform: turning his staff into a serpent and back, making his hand leprous and then healing it, and turning river water into blood. Moses still hesitated, citing his lack of eloquence. God reassured him that He would help him speak and teach him what to say. When Moses continued to resist, God appointed his brother Aaron to speak for him, promising to guide both of them.

Moses returned to Jethro and asked to go back to Egypt to see if his people were still alive. Jethro gave his blessing. God instructed Moses to perform the wonders before Pharaoh but warned that He would harden Pharaoh's heart. God told Moses to tell Pharaoh that Israel was His firstborn son and to let them go, or He would kill Pharaoh's firstborn son.

On the way to Egypt, God sought to kill Moses, but Zipporah circumcised their son and touched Moses' feet with the foreskin, saving his life. God then instructed Aaron to meet Moses in the wilderness. They reunited, and Moses shared God's message and signs. Together, they gathered the elders of Israel, and Aaron conveyed God's words and performed the signs. The people believed and worshipped when they heard that God had seen their suffering.

Moses and Aaron then approached Pharaoh, relaying God's command to let the Israelites go to hold a feast in the wilderness.Pharaoh responded, "Who is the LORD that I should obey Him and let Israel go? I don't know the LORD, and I will not let Israel go." Moses and Aaron replied, "The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us take a three-day journey into the desert to offer sacrifices to the LORD our God, or He may strike us with plagues or the sword." 

Pharaoh retorted, "Why are you distracting the people from their work? Get back to your labor!" He then commanded the taskmasters and foremen, "Do not supply the people with straw for making bricks. Let them gather their own straw, but require them to make the same number of bricks as before. They are lazy; that's why they are asking to go and sacrifice to their God. Make the work harder for them so they keep working and pay no attention to lies."

The taskmasters and foremen told the people, "Pharaoh says, 'I will not give you straw. Go and find your own straw wherever you can, but your work quota will not be reduced.'" So the people scattered throughout Egypt to gather stubble to use as straw. The taskmasters kept pressing them, "Complete your daily quota of bricks, just as when you had straw." The Israelite foremen, appointed by Pharaoh's taskmasters, were beaten and asked, "Why haven't you met your quota of bricks yesterday or today, as before?"

The Israelite foremen went to Pharaoh and pleaded, "Why are you treating your servants this way? No straw is given to us, yet we are told to make bricks. Your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people." Pharaoh replied, "You are lazy! That's why you keep saying, 'Let us go and sacrifice to the LORD.' Now get to work. You will not be given any straw, yet you must produce your full quota of bricks."

The Israelite foremen realized they were in trouble when they were told, "You must not reduce the number of bricks required each day." When they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting for them. They said, "May the LORD judge you! You have made us obnoxious to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us."

Moses returned to the LORD and said, "Lord, why have you brought trouble on this people? Why did you send me? Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all."

Then the LORD said to Moses, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh. Because of my mighty hand, he will let them go; because of my mighty hand, he will drive them out of his country." God also said to Moses, "I am the LORD. I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name the LORD I did not make myself fully known to them. I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, where they resided as foreigners. Moreover, I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I have remembered my covenant.

"Therefore, say to the Israelites: 'I am the LORD, and I will bring you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians. I will free you from being slaves to them, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with mighty acts of judgment. I will take you as my own people, and I will be your God. Then you will know that I am the LORD your God, who brought you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians. And I will bring you to the land I swore with uplifted hand to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob. I will give it to you as a possession. I am the LORD.'"

Moses reported this to the Israelites, but they did not listen to him because of their discouragement and harsh labor. Then the LORD said to Moses, "Go, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the Israelites go out of his country." But Moses said to the LORD, "If the Israelites will not listen to me, why would Pharaoh listen to me, since I speak with faltering lips?"

Now the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron about the Israelites and Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he commanded them to bring the Israelites out of Egypt. These were the heads of their families: The sons of Reuben, the firstborn son of Israel: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. These were the clans of Reuben. The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the clans of Simeon. These were the names of the sons of Levi according to their records: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived 137 years. The sons of Gershon by clans: Libni and Shimei. The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years. The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These were the clans of Levi according to their records. Amram married his father's sister Jochebed, who bore him Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years. The sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri. The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri. Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. The sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These were the Korahite clans. Eleazar son of Aaron married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These were the heads of the Levite families, clan by clan.

It was this Aaron and Moses to whom the LORD said, "Bring the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions." They were the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing the Israelites out of Egypt—this same Moses and Aaron.

Now when the LORD spoke to Moses in Egypt, he said to him, "I am the LORD. Tell Pharaoh king of Egypt everything I tell you." But Moses said to the LORD, "Since I speak with faltering lips, why would Pharaoh listen to me?"

Then the LORD said to Moses, "See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet. You are to say everything I command you, and your brother Aaron is to tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites go out of his country. But I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and though I multiply my signs and wonders in Egypt, he will not listen to you. Then I will lay my hand on Egypt and with mighty acts of judgment I will bring out my divisions, my people the Israelites. And the Egyptians will know that I am the LORD when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring the Israelites out of it."

Moses and Aaron did just as the LORD commanded them. Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.

The LORD said to Moses and Aaron, "When Pharaoh says to you, 'Perform a miracle,' then say to Aaron, 'Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh,' and it will become a snake." So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did just as the LORD commanded. Aaron threw his staff down in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake. Pharaoh then summoned wise men and sorcerers, and the Egyptian magicians also did the same things by their secret arts: Each one threw down his staff and it became a snake. But Aaron's staff swallowed up their staffs. Yet Pharaoh's heart became hard and he would not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.

Then the LORD said to Moses, "Pharaoh's heart is unyielding; he refuses to let the people go. Go to Pharaoh in the morning as he goes out to the river. Confront him on the bank of the Nile, and take in your hand the staff that was changed into a snake. Then say to him, 'The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to say to you: Let my people go, so that they may worship me in the wilderness. But until now you have not listened. This is what the LORD says: By this you will know that I am the LORD: With the staff that is in my hand I will strike the water of the Nile, and it will be changed into blood. The fish in the Nile will die, and the river will stink; the Egyptians will not be able to drink its water.'"

The LORD said to Moses, "Tell Aaron, 'Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over the streams and canals, over the ponds and all the reservoirs'—and they will turn to blood. Blood will be everywhere in Egypt, even in vessels of wood and stone." Moses and Aaron did just as the LORD had commanded.Moses and Aaron did as the LORD commanded. Aaron raised his staff and struck the waters of the Nile in front of Pharaoh and his officials, turning the water into blood. The fish died, the river smelled terrible, and the Egyptians couldn't drink the water. Magicians of Egypt did the same with their spells, and Pharaoh's heart remained stubborn. He ignored Moses and Aaron and went back to his palace. The Egyptians had to dig around the river for drinking water. Seven days passed after the LORD struck the Nile.

The LORD told Moses to go to Pharaoh and say, "Let my people go so they can worship me. If you refuse, I will plague your land with frogs. The Nile will teem with frogs that will come into your palace, your bedroom, your bed, the houses of your officials, and your people, even into your ovens and kneading bowls." The LORD instructed Moses to tell Aaron to stretch out his hand with his staff over the waters of Egypt, and frogs came up and covered the land. The magicians did the same with their spells, bringing more frogs.

Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and pleaded, "Pray to the LORD to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let your people go to offer sacrifices to the LORD." Moses asked Pharaoh to set the time for the frogs to be removed, and Pharaoh said, "Tomorrow." Moses agreed, saying it would be done so Pharaoh would know there is no one like the LORD. The frogs died in the houses, courtyards, and fields, and the Egyptians piled them into heaps, making the land reek. But when Pharaoh saw relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the LORD had said.

The LORD then told Moses to tell Aaron to stretch out his staff and strike the dust of the ground, and it became gnats throughout Egypt. The magicians tried to produce gnats with their spells but couldn't. They told Pharaoh, "This is the finger of God." Yet Pharaoh's heart was hard, and he wouldn't listen.

The LORD told Moses to rise early and confront Pharaoh as he went to the water, saying, "Let my people go so they can worship me. If you don't, I will send swarms of flies on you, your officials, your people, and your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies, and the ground will be covered with them. But I will spare the region of Goshen, where my people live; no flies will be there. This will show that I, the LORD, am in this land. I will make a distinction between my people and your people."

The LORD did as he said, and dense swarms of flies poured into Pharaoh's palace and the houses of his officials, ruining the land. Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "Go, sacrifice to your God here in the land." Moses replied, "That wouldn't be right. The sacrifices we offer to the LORD our God would be detestable to the Egyptians. If we offer sacrifices that are detestable in their sight, won't they stone us? We must take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the LORD our God, as he commands us."

Pharaoh said, "I will let you go to offer sacrifices to the LORD your God in the wilderness, but you must not go very far. Now pray for me." Moses answered, "As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the LORD, and tomorrow the flies will leave Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. But Pharaoh must not act deceitfully again by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the LORD." Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD, and the LORD did as Moses asked. The flies left Pharaoh, his officials, and his people; not a single fly remained. But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also and would not let the people go.

The LORD told Moses to go to Pharaoh and say, "This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: 'Let my people go so they may worship me. If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them back, the hand of the LORD will bring a terrible plague on your livestock in the field—on your horses, donkeys, camels, cattle, sheep, and goats. But the LORD will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and that of Egypt, so that no animal belonging to the Israelites will die.'"

The LORD set a time and said, "Tomorrow the LORD will do this in the land." The next day, the LORD did it: all the livestock of the Egyptians died, but not one animal belonging to the Israelites died. Pharaoh investigated and found that not even one of the animals of the Israelites had died. Yet his heart was unyielding, and he would not let the people go.

The LORD told Moses and Aaron to take handfuls of soot from a furnace and have Moses toss it into the air in the presence of Pharaoh. It would become fine dust over the whole land of Egypt, causing festering boils on people and animals. They did as the LORD commanded, and boils broke out on the Egyptians and their animals. The magicians couldn't stand before Moses because of the boils, and the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, so he wouldn't listen to Moses and Aaron.

The LORD told Moses to get up early in the morning, confront Pharaoh, and say, "This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: 'Let my people go so they may worship me, or this time I will send the full force of my plagues against you, your officials, and your people, so you may know there is no one like me in all the earth. For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague that would have wiped you off the earth. But I have raised you up for this very purpose, that I might show you my power and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth. You still set yourself against my people and will not let them go. Therefore, at this time tomorrow, I will send the worst hailstorm that has ever fallen on Egypt, from the day it was founded till now. Give an order now to bring your livestock and everything you have in the field to a place of shelter, because the hail will fall on every person and animal that has not been brought in and is still out in the field, and they will die.'"

Those officials of Pharaoh who feared the word of the LORD hurried to bring their slaves and livestock inside. But those who ignored the word of the LORD left their slaves and livestock in the field.

The LORD told Moses to stretch out his hand toward the sky so that hail would fall all over Egypt—on people, animals, and everything growing in the fields. When Moses stretched out his staff toward the sky, the LORD sent thunder and hail, and lightning flashed down to the ground. The LORD rained hail on the land of Egypt; hail fell, and lightning flashed back and forth. It was the worst storm in all the land of Egypt since it had become a nation. Throughout Egypt, hail struck everything in the fields—both people and animals; it beat down everything growing in the fields and stripped every tree. The only place it did not hail was the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were.

Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "This time I have sinned. The LORD is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong. Pray to the LORD, for we have had enough thunder and hail. I will let you go; you don't have to stay any longer."Moses replied, "As soon as I leave the city, I will pray to the LORD, and the thunder and hail will stop so that you may know the earth belongs to the LORD. But I know that you and your officials still do not fear the LORD God." The flax and barley were destroyed because they were in season, but the wheat and spelt were not destroyed because they ripen later.

Moses left Pharaoh, prayed to the LORD, and the thunder, hail, and rain stopped. When Pharaoh saw this, he sinned again and hardened his heart, as did his officials. Pharaoh's heart remained hard, and he would not let the Israelites go, just as the LORD had said through Moses.

The LORD told Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the hearts of his officials so that I may perform these signs among them. This is so you can tell your children and grandchildren how I dealt with the Egyptians and performed my signs among them, so you may know that I am the LORD."

Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, "This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: 'How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go so they may worship me. If you refuse, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your territory. They will cover the ground so that it cannot be seen and will devour what little you have left after the hail, including every tree growing in your fields. They will fill your houses and those of all your officials and all the Egyptians—something neither your parents nor your ancestors have ever seen from the day they settled in this land until now.'" Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh.

Pharaoh's officials said to him, "How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go so they may worship the LORD their God. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is ruined?" Then Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. "Go, worship the LORD your God," he said. "But tell me who will be going."

Moses answered, "We will go with our young and old, with our sons and daughters, and with our flocks and herds, because we are to celebrate a festival to the LORD."

Pharaoh said, "The LORD be with you—if I let you go, along with your women and children! Clearly, you are bent on evil. No! Have only the men go and worship the LORD, since that's what you have been asking for." Then Moses and Aaron were driven out of Pharaoh's presence.

The LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over Egypt so that locusts swarm over the land and devour everything growing in the fields, everything left by the hail." So Moses stretched out his staff over Egypt, and the LORD made an east wind blow across the land all that day and night. By morning the wind had brought the locusts; they invaded all Egypt and settled down in every area of the country in great numbers. Never before had there been such a plague of locusts, nor will there ever be again. They covered all the ground until it was black. They devoured all that was left after the hail—everything growing in the fields and the fruit on the trees. Nothing green remained on tree or plant in all the land of Egypt.

Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "I have sinned against the LORD your God and against you. Now forgive my sin once more and pray to the LORD your God to take this deadly plague away from me." Moses then left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD. The LORD changed the wind to a very strong west wind, which caught up the locusts and carried them into the Red Sea. Not a single locust was left anywhere in Egypt. But the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he would not let the Israelites go.

Then the LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand toward the sky so that darkness spreads over Egypt—darkness that can be felt." So Moses stretched out his hand toward the sky, and total darkness covered all Egypt for three days. No one could see anyone else or move about for three days. Yet all the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.

Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and said, "Go, worship the LORD. Even your women and children may go with you; only leave your flocks and herds behind."

But Moses said, "You must allow us to have sacrifices and burnt offerings to present to the LORD our God. Our livestock too must go with us; not a hoof is to be left behind. We have to use some of them in worshiping the LORD our God, and until we get there, we will not know what we are to use to worship the LORD."

But the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he was not willing to let them go. Pharaoh said to Moses, "Get out of my sight! Make sure you do not appear before me again! The day you see my face, you will die."

"Just as you say," Moses replied. "I will never appear before you again."

The LORD had said to Moses, "I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt. After that, he will let you go from here, and when he does, he will drive you out completely. Tell the people that men and women alike are to ask their neighbors for articles of silver and gold." (The LORD made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the people, and Moses himself was highly regarded in Egypt by Pharaoh's officials and by the people.)

So Moses said, "This is what the LORD says: 'About midnight I will go throughout Egypt. Every firstborn son in Egypt will die, from the firstborn son of Pharaoh, who sits on the throne, to the firstborn son of the female slave, who is at her hand mill, and all the firstborn of the cattle as well. There will be loud wailing throughout Egypt—worse than there has ever been or ever will be again. But among the Israelites, not a dog will bark at any person or animal.' Then you will know that the LORD makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel. All these officials of yours will come to me, bowing down before me and saying, 'Go, you and all the people who follow you!' After that, I will leave." Then Moses, hot with anger, left Pharaoh.

The LORD had said to Moses, "Pharaoh will refuse to listen to you—so that my wonders may be multiplied in Egypt." Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he would not let the Israelites go out of his country.

The LORD said to Moses and Aaron in Egypt, "This month is to be for you the first month, the first month of your year. Tell the whole community of Israel that on the tenth day of this month each man is to take a lamb for his family, one for each household. If any household is too small for a whole lamb, they must share one with their nearest neighbor, taking into account the number of people there are. You are to determine the amount of lamb needed in accordance with what each person will eat. The animals you choose must be year-old males without defect, and you may take them from the sheep or the goats. Take care of them until the fourteenth day of the month, when all the members of the community of Israel must slaughter them at twilight. Then they are to take some of the blood and put it on the sides and tops of the doorframes of the houses where they eat the lambs. That same night they are to eat the meat roasted over the fire, along with bitter herbs, and bread made without yeast. Do not eat the meat raw or boiled in water, but roast it over a fire—with the head, legs, and internal organs. Do not leave any of it till morning; if some is left till morning, you must burn it. This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste; it is the LORD's Passover.

"On that same night I will pass through Egypt and strike down every firstborn of both people and animals, and I will bring judgment on all the gods of Egypt. I am the LORD. The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are, and when I see the blood, I will pass over you. No destructive plague will touch you when I strike Egypt.

"This is a day you are to commemorate; for the generations to come you shall celebrate it as a festival to the LORD—a lasting ordinance. For seven days you are to eat bread made without yeast. On the first day remove the yeast from your houses, for whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first day through the seventh must be cut off from Israel. On the first day hold a sacred assembly, and another one on the seventh day. Do no work at all on these days, except to prepare food for everyone to eat; that is all you may do.""On the first day of the festival, you can only do the work necessary to prepare food. You must celebrate the Feast of Unleavened Bread because it was on this day that I brought your people out of Egypt. This is a lasting tradition for all generations. From the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month until the evening of the twenty-first day, you must eat bread without yeast. For seven days, no yeast should be found in your homes. Anyone who eats anything with yeast during this time will be cut off from the community of Israel, whether they are a foreigner or a native-born. Eat nothing with yeast; wherever you live, eat unleavened bread."

Moses then called all the elders of Israel and instructed them to select a lamb for their families and slaughter it for the Passover. He told them to take a bunch of hyssop, dip it in the blood collected in a basin, and smear it on the top and sides of the doorframes of their houses. No one should leave their house until morning. The LORD will pass through Egypt to strike down the Egyptians, but when He sees the blood on the doorframes, He will pass over that house and not allow the destroyer to enter and strike you down. This is a lasting ordinance for you and your descendants.

When you enter the land the LORD has promised to give you, you must continue to observe this ceremony. When your children ask, 'What does this ceremony mean to you?' tell them, 'It is the Passover sacrifice to the LORD, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt and spared our homes when He struck down the Egyptians.' Then the people bowed down and worshipped. The Israelites did just as the LORD commanded Moses and Aaron.

At midnight, the LORD struck down all the firstborn in Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sat on the throne, to the firstborn of the prisoner in the dungeon, and the firstborn of all the livestock. Pharaoh and all his officials and all the Egyptians got up during the night, and there was loud wailing in Egypt, for there was not a house without someone dead. Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron during the night and said, 'Leave my people, you and the Israelites! Go, worship the LORD as you have requested. Take your flocks and herds, as you have said, and go. And also bless me.'

The Egyptians urged the people to hurry and leave the country, saying, 'Otherwise, we will all die!' So the people took their dough before the yeast was added and carried it on their shoulders in kneading troughs wrapped in clothing. The Israelites did as Moses instructed and asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and gold and for clothing. The LORD had made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the people, and they gave them what they asked for; so they plundered the Egyptians.

The Israelites journeyed from Rameses to Succoth. There were about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides women and children. Many other people went up with them, along with large droves of livestock, both flocks and herds. With the dough they had brought from Egypt, they baked unleavened bread. The dough was without yeast because they had been driven out of Egypt and did not have time to prepare food for themselves.

The Israelites had lived in Egypt for 430 years. At the end of the 430 years, to the very day, all the LORD's divisions left Egypt. Because the LORD kept vigil that night to bring them out of Egypt, on this night all the Israelites are to keep vigil to honor the LORD for the generations to come.

The LORD said to Moses and Aaron, 'These are the regulations for the Passover meal: No foreigner may eat it. Any slave you have bought may eat it after you have circumcised him, but a temporary resident or a hired worker may not eat it. It must be eaten inside the house; take none of the meat outside the house. Do not break any of the bones. The whole community of Israel must celebrate it. A foreigner residing among you who wants to celebrate the LORD's Passover must have all the males in his household circumcised; then he may take part like one born in the land. No uncircumcised male may eat it. The same law applies both to the native-born and to the foreigner residing among you.'

All the Israelites did just what the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron. And on that very day, the LORD brought the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions.

The LORD said to Moses, 'Consecrate to me every firstborn male. The first offspring of every womb among the Israelites belongs to me, whether human or animal.'

Then Moses said to the people, 'Commemorate this day, the day you came out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery, because the LORD brought you out of it with a mighty hand. Eat nothing containing yeast. Today, in the month of Aviv, you are leaving. When the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites—the land he swore to your ancestors to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey—you are to observe this ceremony in this month: For seven days eat bread made without yeast and on the seventh day hold a festival to the LORD. Eat unleavened bread during those seven days; nothing with yeast in it is to be seen among you, nor shall any yeast be seen anywhere within your borders. On that day tell your son, 'I do this because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.' This observance will be for you like a sign on your hand and a reminder on your forehead that this law of the LORD is to be on your lips. For the LORD brought you out of Egypt with his mighty hand. You must keep this ordinance at the appointed time year after year.

After the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites and gives it to you, as he promised on oath to you and your ancestors, you are to give over to the LORD the first offspring of every womb. All the firstborn males of your livestock belong to the LORD. Redeem with a lamb every firstborn donkey, but if you do not redeem it, break its neck. Redeem every firstborn among your sons. In days to come, when your son asks you, 'What does this mean?' say to him, 'With a mighty hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery. When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the LORD killed the firstborn of both people and animals in Egypt. This is why I sacrifice to the LORD the first male offspring of every womb and redeem each of my firstborn sons.' And it will be like a sign on your hand and a symbol on your forehead that the LORD brought us out of Egypt with his mighty hand.'

When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them on the road through the Philistine country, though that was shorter. For God said, 'If they face war, they might change their minds and return to Egypt.' So God led the people around by the desert road toward the Red Sea. The Israelites went up out of Egypt ready for battle. Moses took the bones of Joseph with him because Joseph had made the Israelites swear an oath. He had said, 'God will surely come to your aid, and then you must carry my bones up with you from this place.'

After leaving Succoth, they camped at Etham on the edge of the desert. By day the LORD went ahead of them in a pillar of cloud to guide them on their way and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel by day or night. Neither the pillar of cloud by day nor the pillar of fire by night left its place in front of the people.

Then the LORD said to Moses, 'Tell the Israelites to turn back and encamp near Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. They are to encamp by the sea, directly opposite Baal Zephon. Pharaoh will think, 'The Israelites are wandering around the land in confusion, hemmed in by the desert.' And I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and he will pursue them. But I will gain glory for myself through Pharaoh and all his army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the LORD.' So the Israelites did this.

When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his officials changed their minds about them and said, 'What have we done? We have let the Israelites go and have lost their services!' So he had his chariot made ready and took his army with him. He took six hundred of the best chariots, along with all the other chariots of Egypt, with officers over all of them. The LORD hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, so that he pursued the Israelites, who were marching out boldly."The Egyptians chased after the Israelites with all of Pharaoh's horses, chariots, and army, catching up to them by the sea near Pi Hahiroth, opposite Baal Zephon. When the Israelites saw the Egyptians approaching, they were terrified and cried out to the LORD. They complained to Moses, asking why he brought them out of Egypt to die in the wilderness, saying it would have been better to stay and serve the Egyptians.

Moses reassured them, telling them not to be afraid and to stand firm, as the LORD would deliver them. He said they would never see the Egyptians again. The LORD would fight for them, and they only needed to be still.

The LORD instructed Moses to tell the Israelites to move forward. He told Moses to lift his staff and stretch his hand over the sea to divide the waters so the Israelites could walk through on dry ground. The LORD said He would harden the hearts of the Egyptians so they would follow, and He would gain glory through Pharaoh and his army.

The angel of God, who had been leading the Israelites, moved behind them, and the pillar of cloud also moved to the rear, standing between the Egyptian and Israelite camps. Throughout the night, the cloud brought darkness to one side and light to the other, preventing the two groups from coming near each other.

Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the LORD drove the sea back with a strong east wind, turning it into dry land. The waters were divided, and the Israelites went through the sea on dry ground, with walls of water on both sides. The Egyptians pursued them, but the LORD looked down from the pillar of fire and cloud, causing confusion among the Egyptians. He made the wheels of their chariots come off, making it difficult for them to drive. The Egyptians realized the LORD was fighting for the Israelites and tried to flee.

The LORD told Moses to stretch his hand over the sea again, and the waters returned, covering the chariots, horsemen, and the entire army of Pharaoh. Not one of them survived. The Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground, with walls of water on both sides. That day, the LORD saved Israel from the Egyptians, and the Israelites saw the Egyptians dead on the shore. They witnessed the LORD's great power and feared Him, putting their trust in the LORD and in Moses, His servant.

Moses and the Israelites sang a song to the LORD, praising Him for His triumph. They sang about the LORD being their strength and salvation, and how He had thrown Pharaoh's chariots and army into the sea. They praised the LORD's power and how He had defeated their enemies. They sang about the LORD's greatness and how He led His redeemed people to His holy dwelling. They declared that the LORD would reign forever.

Miriam, the prophetess and sister of Aaron, took a tambourine, and all the women followed her with tambourines and dancing. Miriam sang, "Sing to the LORD, for He has triumphed gloriously; the horse and its rider He has thrown into the sea."

Moses led the Israelites from the Red Sea into the Desert of Shur. For three days, they traveled without finding water. When they reached Marah, they couldn't drink the water because it was bitter. The people grumbled against Moses, asking what they would drink. Moses cried out to the LORD, who showed him a piece of wood. Moses threw it into the water, and the water became fit to drink. There, the LORD made a decree and a law for them and tested them. He said if they listened to Him and did what was right, He would not bring on them any of the diseases He brought on the Egyptians, for He is the LORD who heals them.

They then came to Elim, where there were twelve springs and seventy palm trees, and they camped there by the water. The Israelites set out from Elim and came to the Desert of Sin, between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after leaving Egypt. The whole community grumbled against Moses and Aaron, wishing they had died in Egypt where they had plenty to eat, rather than being brought into the desert to starve.

The LORD told Moses He would rain down bread from heaven for the people. Each day, the people were to gather enough for that day, and on the sixth day, they were to gather twice as much. Moses and Aaron told the Israelites that in the evening, they would know it was the LORD who brought them out of Egypt, and in the morning, they would see the glory of the LORD because He had heard their grumbling. Moses said their grumbling was not against him and Aaron, but against the LORD.

Moses instructed Aaron to tell the whole community to come before the LORD, for He had heard their grumbling. As Aaron spoke, they looked toward the desert, and the glory of the LORD appeared in the cloud. The LORD told Moses He had heard the grumbling of the Israelites and would provide them with meat in the evening and bread in the morning so they would know He is the LORD their God.In the evening, quails came and covered the camp, and in the morning, there was dew around the camp. When the dew evaporated, it left behind a small, round substance, like frost on the ground. The Israelites saw it and asked each other what it was, as they didn't know. Moses told them it was the bread the LORD had given them to eat. He instructed them to gather as much as they needed, about an omer per person, for everyone in their tents. The Israelites did as instructed, some gathering more, some less. When they measured it, those who gathered much had no excess, and those who gathered little had no shortage; everyone had just enough.

Moses told them not to keep any of it until morning, but some didn't listen and kept it, and it bred worms and smelled bad. Moses was angry with them. They gathered it every morning, each person as much as they needed, and when the sun grew hot, it melted. On the sixth day, they gathered twice as much, two omers per person, and the leaders reported this to Moses. He told them this was what the LORD had said: the next day was a holy Sabbath, so they should bake and boil what they needed and save the rest for the next morning. They did as Moses instructed, and it didn't smell or have worms. Moses told them to eat it that day because it was the Sabbath, and they wouldn't find any in the field. They were to gather it for six days, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there would be none. Some people went out to gather on the seventh day but found none. The LORD asked Moses how long they would refuse to keep His commands and instructions. He reminded them that the LORD had given them the Sabbath and provided enough bread for two days on the sixth day, so they should stay in their places on the seventh day. The people rested on the seventh day.

The Israelites called the bread "manna." It was white like coriander seed and tasted like wafers made with honey. Moses said the LORD commanded them to keep an omer of it for future generations to see the bread He provided in the wilderness after bringing them out of Egypt. Moses told Aaron to take a jar, put an omer of manna in it, and place it before the LORD to be kept for future generations. Aaron did as the LORD commanded Moses and placed it before the Testimony to be kept. The Israelites ate manna for forty years until they reached the border of Canaan. An omer is one-tenth of an ephah.

The whole Israelite community traveled from the Desert of Sin, moving from place to place as the LORD commanded. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water to drink. The people quarreled with Moses, demanding water. Moses asked why they were quarreling with him and testing the LORD. The people were thirsty and complained against Moses, accusing him of bringing them out of Egypt to die of thirst. Moses cried out to the LORD, asking what to do with the people, as they were almost ready to stone him. The LORD told Moses to go ahead of the people with some of the elders and take the staff he used to strike the Nile. The LORD said He would stand before Moses by the rock at Horeb, and Moses was to strike the rock, and water would come out for the people to drink. Moses did this in the sight of the elders, and he named the place Massah and Meribah because the Israelites quarreled and tested the LORD, asking if He was among them or not.

Then the Amalekites came and attacked the Israelites at Rephidim. Moses told Joshua to choose some men and go out to fight the Amalekites. Moses said he would stand on top of the hill with the staff of God in his hand. Joshua fought the Amalekites as Moses had ordered, and Moses, Aaron, and Hur went to the top of the hill. As long as Moses held up his hands, the Israelites were winning, but when he lowered his hands, the Amalekites were winning. When Moses' hands grew tired, they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it. Aaron and Hur held his hands up, one on each side, so his hands remained steady until sunset. Joshua overcame the Amalekite army with the sword. The LORD told Moses to write this on a scroll as something to be remembered and to make sure Joshua heard it because He would completely blot out the name of Amalek from under heaven. Moses built an altar and called it "The LORD is my Banner." He said, "Because hands were lifted up against the throne of the LORD, the LORD will be at war against the Amalekites from generation to generation."

When Jethro, the priest of Midian and Moses' father-in-law, heard about everything God had done for Moses and His people Israel, and how the LORD had brought Israel out of Egypt, he took Moses' wife Zipporah, whom Moses had sent back, and her two sons. One son was named Gershom, for Moses said, "I have become a foreigner in a foreign land," and the other was named Eliezer, for he said, "My father's God was my helper; He saved me from the sword of Pharaoh." Jethro, along with Moses' wife and sons, came to Moses in the wilderness, where he was camped near the mountain of God. Jethro sent word to Moses, saying he was coming with Moses' wife and her two sons. Moses went out to meet his father-in-law, bowed down, and kissed him. They greeted each other and went into the tent. Moses told Jethro about everything the LORD had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel's sake and about all the hardships they had met along the way and how the LORD had saved them. Jethro was delighted to hear about all the good things the LORD had done for Israel in rescuing them from the hand of the Egyptians. He said, "Praise be to the LORD, who rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians and of Pharaoh, and who rescued the people from the hand of the Egyptians. Now I know that the LORD is greater than all other gods, for He did this to those who had treated Israel arrogantly." Then Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and other sacrifices to God, and Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat a meal with Moses' father-in-law in the presence of God.

The next day, Moses took his seat to serve as judge for the people, and they stood around him from morning till evening. When his father-in-law saw all that Moses was doing for the people, he said, "What is this you are doing for the people?
