If the offering is a goat, the same procedure applies. The fat belongs to the LORD and should not be eaten. This is a lasting ordinance for generations to come, wherever you live: do not eat any fat or blood.

The LORD spoke to Moses, saying, "Tell the Israelites: If anyone sins unintentionally against any of the LORD's commands, they must bring a young bull without defect as a sin offering. They must bring it to the entrance of the tent of meeting, lay their hand on its head, and slaughter it before the LORD. The anointed priest will take some of the bull's blood into the tent of meeting, dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD in front of the curtain of the sanctuary."The priest will put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of sweet incense before the LORD, which is in the tent of meeting. He will pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar of burnt offering at the entrance of the tent of meeting. He will remove all the fat from the bull, including the fat covering the internal organs, the kidneys, and the long lobe of the liver, and burn it on the altar. The rest of the bull, including its skin, flesh, head, legs, internal organs, and dung, will be taken outside the camp to a clean place where the ashes are dumped and burned on a wood fire.

If the entire community of Israel sins unintentionally and the matter escapes the notice of the assembly, but they realize their guilt later, they must offer a young bull as a sin offering. The elders of the community will lay their hands on the bull's head before the LORD, and it will be slaughtered. The anointed priest will take some of the bull's blood into the tent of meeting, dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD in front of the curtain. He will put some of the blood on the horns of the altar and pour out the rest at the base of the altar of burnt offering. He will remove all the fat and burn it on the altar, just as he did with the previous bull. The priest will then take the rest of the bull outside the camp and burn it as a sin offering for the community.

When a leader sins unintentionally against any of the LORD's commands and realizes his guilt, he must bring a male goat without defect as a sin offering. He will lay his hand on the goat's head and slaughter it at the place of the burnt offering. The priest will take some of the blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, pouring out the rest at the base of the altar. He will burn all the fat on the altar, just as with the peace offerings. The priest will make atonement for the leader's sin, and he will be forgiven.

If any member of the community sins unintentionally and realizes their guilt, they must bring a female goat without defect as a sin offering. They will lay their hand on the goat's head and slaughter it at the place of the burnt offering. The priest will take some of the blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, pouring out the rest at the base of the altar. He will remove all the fat and burn it on the altar, just as with the peace offerings. The priest will make atonement for the person's sin, and they will be forgiven.

If someone brings a lamb as a sin offering, it must be a female without defect. They will lay their hand on the lamb's head and slaughter it at the place of the burnt offering. The priest will take some of the blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, pouring out the rest at the base of the altar. He will remove all the fat and burn it on the altar, just as with the peace offerings. The priest will make atonement for the person's sin, and they will be forgiven.

If someone hears a public charge to testify and they do not speak up, they will bear the consequences of their sin. If someone touches anything unclean, whether it is the carcass of an unclean animal or human uncleanness, and it is hidden from them, they are guilty. If someone swears thoughtlessly to do anything, whether good or evil, and it is hidden from them, they are guilty when they realize it. When someone is guilty in any of these matters, they must confess their sin and bring a female lamb or goat as a sin offering. The priest will make atonement for them, and they will be forgiven.

If they cannot afford a lamb, they must bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. The priest will offer the sin offering first, wringing off its head but not severing it completely, and sprinkle some of the blood on the side of the altar. The rest of the blood will be drained at the base of the altar. The second bird will be offered as a burnt offering according to the regulations. The priest will make atonement for the person's sin, and they will be forgiven.

If they cannot afford two birds, they must bring a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a sin offering. They must not put oil or frankincense on it, as it is a sin offering. The priest will take a handful of the flour as a memorial portion and burn it on the altar. The priest will make atonement for the person's sin, and they will be forgiven. The rest of the flour will belong to the priest, just like the grain offering.

If someone sins unintentionally in regard to any of the LORD's holy things, they must bring a ram without defect and the equivalent value in silver as a guilt offering. They must make restitution for what they have failed to do and add a fifth of the value to it, giving it to the priest. The priest will make atonement with the ram, and they will be forgiven.

If someone sins and does something forbidden by the LORD's commands, even if they are unaware of it, they are guilty and must bear the consequences. They must bring a ram without defect as a guilt offering. The priest will make atonement for the person's unintentional sin, and they will be forgiven. This is a guilt offering, as they have certainly committed a trespass against the LORD.

If someone sins by deceiving a neighbor about something entrusted to them, stolen, or found, or if they swear falsely about any such sin, they must make restitution in full, adding a fifth of the value to it, and give it to the owner on the day they present their guilt offering. They must bring a ram without defect as a guilt offering to the LORD. The priest will make atonement for them, and they will be forgiven.If someone commits a sin and needs to make amends, they must bring a ram from their flock as a guilt offering to the priest. The priest will make atonement for them before the LORD, and they will be forgiven for any wrongdoing.

The LORD spoke to Moses, instructing him to tell Aaron and his sons about the regulations for burnt offerings. The burnt offering must remain on the altar's fire all night until morning, and the fire must be kept burning. The priest will wear his linen garments and remove the ashes from the burnt offering, placing them beside the altar. He will then change his clothes and take the ashes outside the camp to a clean place. The fire on the altar must be kept burning continuously; it must not go out. Every morning, the priest will add wood to the fire, arrange the burnt offering, and burn the fat of the peace offerings on it. The fire must always be kept burning on the altar; it must never go out.

The regulations for the grain offering are as follows: Aaron's sons will present it before the LORD at the altar. The priest will take a handful of fine flour, oil, and all the frankincense from the grain offering and burn it on the altar as a memorial portion, a pleasing aroma to the LORD. Aaron and his sons will eat the remainder of the grain offering as unleavened bread in a holy place, within the courtyard of the tent of meeting. It must not be baked with yeast, as it is a portion of the offerings made by fire to the LORD, and it is most holy, like the sin offering and the guilt offering. All male descendants of Aaron may eat it. This is a lasting ordinance for generations to come regarding the offerings made by fire to the LORD. Anyone who touches these offerings must be holy.

The LORD spoke to Moses, instructing him about the offering that Aaron and his sons must present to the LORD on the day of their anointing: a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a regular grain offering, half in the morning and half in the evening. It must be prepared with oil on a griddle and brought in well-mixed. The grain offering must be broken into pieces and offered as a pleasing aroma to the LORD. The priest who is anointed to succeed Aaron must offer it. This is a lasting ordinance; the entire grain offering must be burned and not eaten.

The LORD spoke to Moses about the regulations for the sin offering: It must be slaughtered in the same place as the burnt offering before the LORD, and it is most holy. The priest who offers it for sin will eat it in a holy place, within the courtyard of the tent of meeting. Anything that touches the flesh of the sin offering will become holy. If any of its blood is splashed on a garment, it must be washed in a holy place. A clay pot used to cook the sin offering must be broken, but if it is cooked in a bronze pot, the pot must be scoured and rinsed with water. Any male among the priests may eat it, as it is most holy. However, no sin offering whose blood is brought into the tent of meeting to make atonement in the Holy Place may be eaten; it must be burned.

The regulations for the guilt offering are as follows: It is most holy and must be slaughtered in the same place as the burnt offering. The priest will sprinkle its blood around the altar and offer all its fat, including the fat tail, the fat covering the internal organs, the kidneys, and the liver. The priest will burn these on the altar as a guilt offering. Every male among the priests may eat it in a holy place, as it is most holy. The same law applies to both the sin offering and the guilt offering; the priest who makes atonement with them will have a share. The priest who offers a burnt offering for anyone may keep the hide of the burnt offering. Every grain offering baked in an oven, cooked in a pan, or on a griddle belongs to the priest who offers it. All grain offerings, whether mixed with oil or dry, belong equally to all of Aaron's sons.

The regulations for the peace offering are as follows: If it is offered as a thanksgiving, it must be accompanied by unleavened cakes mixed with oil, unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes of fine flour well-mixed with oil. Along with these cakes, leavened bread must be presented with the peace offering of thanksgiving. One of each kind of bread must be presented as a wave offering to the LORD and will belong to the priest who sprinkles the blood of the peace offering. The meat of the peace offering of thanksgiving must be eaten on the same day it is offered; none of it may be left until morning. If the peace offering is a vow or a voluntary offering, it may be eaten on the day it is offered and the next day, but any remaining meat on the third day must be burned. If any meat of the peace offering is eaten on the third day, it will not be accepted, and the person who offers it will not be credited; it will be considered impure, and anyone who eats it will bear the consequences of their sin. Any meat that touches anything unclean must not be eaten; it must be burned. Anyone who is clean may eat the meat, but anyone who is unclean and eats the meat of the peace offering will be cut off from their people. Anyone who touches anything unclean, whether human uncleanness, an unclean animal, or any unclean detestable thing, and then eats the meat of the peace offering, will be cut off from their people.

The LORD spoke to Moses, instructing him to tell the Israelites not to eat any fat from cattle, sheep, or goats. The fat of an animal found dead or torn by wild animals may be used for other purposes, but it must not be eaten. Anyone who eats the fat of an animal presented as an offering made by fire to the LORD will be cut off from their people. The Israelites must not eat any blood, whether from birds or animals, in any of their dwellings. Anyone who eats any blood will be cut off from their people.

The LORD spoke to Moses, instructing him to tell the Israelites that anyone who offers a peace offering to the LORD must bring part of it as their sacrifice to the LORD. They must bring the fat with the breast, which will be waved as a wave offering before the LORD. The priest will burn the fat on the altar, but the breast belongs to Aaron and his sons. The right thigh must be given to the priest as a contribution from the peace offerings. The son of Aaron who offers the blood and the fat of the peace offerings will have the right thigh as his share. The breast that is waved and the thigh that is contributed are taken from the Israelites' peace offerings and given to Aaron and his sons as a perpetual share from the Israelites.

This is the portion of the offerings made by fire to the LORD that were allotted to Aaron and his sons on the day they were presented to serve the LORD as priests. The LORD commanded the Israelites to give this portion to them on the day they were anointed, as a perpetual share for generations to come.

These are the regulations for the burnt offering, the grain offering, the sin offering, the guilt offering, the ordination offering, and the peace offering, which the LORD gave to Moses on Mount Sinai when he commanded the Israelites to bring their offerings to the LORD in the wilderness of Sinai.

The LORD spoke to Moses, instructing him to take Aaron and his sons, their garments, the anointing oil, the bull for the sin offering, the two rams, and the basket of unleavened bread, and gather the entire assembly at the entrance to the tent of meeting. Moses did as the LORD commanded, and the assembly gathered at the entrance to the tent of meeting.Moses addressed the congregation, saying, "This is what the LORD has commanded us to do." He then brought Aaron and his sons forward and washed them with water. Moses dressed Aaron in the coat, girdle, robe, and ephod, securing the ephod with its decorative belt. He placed the breastplate on Aaron, inserting the Urim and Thummim, and set the turban on his head, attaching the golden plate, the holy crown, as the LORD had instructed.

Moses anointed the tabernacle and everything in it with oil, sprinkling the altar seven times to consecrate it. He poured the anointing oil on Aaron's head to sanctify him. Moses also dressed Aaron's sons in coats, girdles, and caps, as the LORD commanded.

Next, Moses brought the bull for the sin offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head. Moses slaughtered it, applied its blood to the altar's horns, and poured the rest at the altar's base to purify it. He burned the fat, kidneys, and liver lobe on the altar, but the bull's hide, flesh, and dung were burned outside the camp.

Moses then brought the ram for the burnt offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head. After slaughtering it, Moses sprinkled its blood around the altar, cut the ram into pieces, and burned the head, pieces, and fat. He washed the internal organs and legs with water and burned the entire ram on the altar as a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.

Moses brought the second ram, the ram of consecration, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head. Moses slaughtered it and applied its blood to Aaron's right ear, thumb, and big toe, and did the same for Aaron's sons. He sprinkled the blood around the altar and took the fat, kidneys, liver lobe, and right shoulder, along with unleavened bread, oiled bread, and a wafer from the basket before the LORD. Moses placed these in Aaron's and his sons' hands and waved them as a wave offering before the LORD, then burned them on the altar.

Moses took the breast and waved it as a wave offering, as his portion from the ram of consecration. He sprinkled anointing oil and blood from the altar on Aaron and his sons, consecrating them and their garments. Moses instructed Aaron and his sons to boil the meat at the tabernacle entrance and eat it with the bread from the consecration basket, burning any leftovers.

They were to stay at the tabernacle entrance for seven days, completing their consecration, as the LORD commanded. Aaron and his sons followed all the LORD's instructions given through Moses.

On the eighth day, Moses called Aaron, his sons, and the elders of Israel. He instructed Aaron to offer a young calf for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, both without blemish, before the LORD. The Israelites were to bring a goat for a sin offering, a calf and lamb for a burnt offering, and a bull and ram for peace offerings, along with a grain offering mixed with oil, as the LORD would appear to them that day.

The congregation brought these offerings to the tabernacle, and Moses said, "This is what the LORD has commanded, and His glory will appear to you." Aaron offered the sin offering and burnt offering for himself, then for the people, as instructed. He also offered the peace offerings, and Aaron's sons presented the blood, which he sprinkled around the altar. Aaron lifted his hands, blessed the people, and came down from offering the sacrifices.

Moses and Aaron entered the tabernacle, then came out and blessed the people, and the glory of the LORD appeared to all. Fire came from the LORD and consumed the burnt offering and fat on the altar, causing the people to shout and fall on their faces.

Nadab and Abihu, Aaron's sons, offered unauthorized fire before the LORD, contrary to His command, and fire from the LORD consumed them. Moses told Aaron that the LORD had said He would be sanctified and glorified by those who approach Him, and Aaron remained silent. Moses instructed Mishael and Elzaphan to carry Nadab and Abihu's bodies outside the camp.

Moses told Aaron and his remaining sons not to mourn publicly, lest they die and bring wrath upon the people, but to let the whole house of Israel mourn the LORD's burning. They were not to leave the tabernacle entrance, as the LORD's anointing oil was upon them, and they obeyed.

The LORD instructed Aaron not to drink wine or strong drink when entering the tabernacle, to distinguish between holy and unholy, clean and unclean, and to teach the Israelites all the LORD's statutes given through Moses.Aaron and his remaining sons, Eleazar and Ithamar, were instructed to eat the remaining grain offering without yeast beside the altar, as it was considered most holy. They were to eat it in a holy place because it was their share of the offerings made by fire to the LORD. They were also to eat the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the heave offering in a clean place, along with their sons and daughters, as these were their due portions from the peace offerings of the Israelites.

Moses then checked on the goat of the sin offering and found it had been burned. He was angry with Eleazar and Ithamar, asking why they had not eaten the sin offering in the holy place as commanded, since it was most holy and given to them to bear the iniquity of the congregation and make atonement for them before the LORD. Aaron explained that they had offered their sin and burnt offerings before the LORD, but given the day's events, he questioned if it would have been acceptable to eat the sin offering. Moses was satisfied with Aaron's explanation.

The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, instructing them to tell the Israelites which animals they could eat. They could eat any animal that has a split hoof and chews the cud. However, they were not to eat animals like the camel, the coney, the hare, and the pig, as they were considered unclean. They were also instructed not to eat any sea creatures without fins and scales, as these were deemed an abomination.

Certain birds were also listed as unclean and not to be eaten, including the eagle, vulture, raven, owl, and others. Additionally, all flying insects that walk on all fours were considered unclean, except for those that have jointed legs for hopping, like locusts, crickets, and grasshoppers.

Anyone who touched the carcasses of these unclean animals would be unclean until evening and must wash their clothes. The same applied to anyone who carried their carcasses. Specific instructions were given for handling the carcasses of unclean animals, including breaking any earthen vessels they fell into and washing any wooden vessels.

The LORD also gave instructions regarding the purification of women after childbirth. A woman who gave birth to a son would be unclean for seven days and must be purified for thirty-three days. If she gave birth to a daughter, she would be unclean for two weeks and must be purified for sixty-six days. After the days of purification, she was to bring a lamb and a young pigeon or turtledove for a burnt offering and a sin offering to the priest, who would make atonement for her.

The LORD also provided guidelines for identifying and handling skin diseases, such as leprosy. If a person had a suspicious skin condition, they were to be brought to Aaron or one of his sons, the priests, who would examine the condition and determine if it was leprosy. If the condition was deeper than the skin and the hair in the affected area had turned white, it was considered leprosy, and the person would be pronounced unclean. If the condition was not deeper than the skin and the hair had not turned white, the person would be isolated for further observation.If someone has a skin condition that might be leprosy, the priest will examine them. If the condition hasn't spread after seven days, the person will be isolated for another seven days. If it still hasn't spread, the person is considered clean and must wash their clothes. However, if the condition spreads, the person is declared unclean.

If the skin condition is deeper than the skin and the hair in the area has turned white, it is leprosy, and the person is unclean. If the condition covers the entire body but turns white, the person is clean. If raw flesh appears, the person is unclean.

For boils that heal but leave a white or reddish spot, the priest will check if the spot is deeper than the skin and if the hair has turned white. If so, it is leprosy. If not, the person is isolated for seven days. If the spot spreads, the person is unclean. If it doesn't, the person is clean.

For burns that leave a white or reddish spot, the priest will check if the spot is deeper than the skin and if the hair has turned white. If so, it is leprosy. If not, the person is isolated for seven days. If the spot spreads, the person is unclean. If it doesn't, the person is clean.

If someone has a sore on their head or beard, the priest will check if it is deeper than the skin and if there is yellow hair. If so, it is leprosy. If not, the person is isolated for seven days. If the sore spreads, the person is unclean. If it doesn't, the person is clean.

If someone has white spots on their skin, the priest will check if they are darkish white. If so, it is just a freckle, and the person is clean.

If someone is bald, they are clean. If there is a reddish-white sore on the bald area, it is leprosy, and the person is unclean. The person must wear torn clothes, keep their head uncovered, cover their mouth, and shout "Unclean, unclean." They must live outside the camp.

If a garment has a greenish or reddish spot, it must be shown to the priest. If the spot spreads, the garment is unclean and must be burned. If the spot doesn't spread, the garment is washed and isolated for seven days. If the spot remains, the garment is unclean and must be burned. If the spot fades, the garment is washed again and is clean.

For the cleansing of a leper, the priest will take two live birds, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop. One bird is killed over running water. The living bird, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop are dipped in the blood of the killed bird. The blood is sprinkled on the person seven times, and the living bird is released. The person must wash their clothes, shave off all their hair, and bathe in water to be clean.On the seventh day, the person must shave off all their hair, including their head, beard, and eyebrows. They must wash their clothes and bathe in water to be considered clean. On the eighth day, they need to bring two male lambs without defects, one year-old female lamb without defects, three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering, and one log of oil. The priest will present the person and these offerings before the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle.

The priest will take one male lamb and offer it as a guilt offering, along with the log of oil, waving them before the Lord. The lamb will be slaughtered in the holy place where sin and burnt offerings are killed. The priest will then take some of the blood from the guilt offering and put it on the right ear, right thumb, and right big toe of the person being cleansed. The priest will also pour some oil into his left hand, dip his right finger in it, and sprinkle it seven times before the Lord. The remaining oil will be applied to the right ear, right thumb, and right big toe of the person, on top of the blood from the guilt offering. The rest of the oil will be poured on the person's head to make atonement.

The priest will then offer a sin offering to make atonement for the person's uncleanness, followed by the burnt offering and grain offering. If the person is poor and cannot afford these offerings, they can bring one male lamb for a guilt offering, one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering, and a log of oil. They should also bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. The priest will follow the same procedure for these offerings.

If a house shows signs of mold, the owner must report it to the priest, who will inspect the house. If the mold is found in the walls, the house will be closed for seven days. If the mold spreads, the affected stones will be removed and discarded outside the city. The house will be scraped and replastered. If the mold reappears, the house will be declared unclean and demolished. If the mold does not spread, the house will be declared clean after a cleansing ritual involving two birds, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop.

For any discharge from the body, the person is considered unclean. Anything they touch, sit on, or lie on becomes unclean. Anyone who touches them or their belongings must wash their clothes, bathe, and remain unclean until evening. If the person with the discharge spits on someone, that person must also wash their clothes, bathe, and remain unclean until evening. Any earthenware touched by the unclean person must be broken, and wooden items must be rinsed in water. After the discharge stops, the person must wait seven days, wash their clothes, bathe in running water, and bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest for a sin offering and a burnt offering.If a man has a discharge, he must be cleansed before the Lord. If a man has an emission of semen, he must wash his entire body with water and remain unclean until evening. Any clothing or leather that comes into contact with the semen must also be washed and remain unclean until evening. If a man and woman have sexual relations, they must both bathe in water and remain unclean until evening.

If a woman has her menstrual period, she is considered unclean for seven days. Anyone who touches her during this time will be unclean until evening. Anything she lies or sits on during her period will also be unclean. Anyone who touches her bed or anything she sits on must wash their clothes, bathe in water, and remain unclean until evening. If a man has sexual relations with her during her period, he will be unclean for seven days, and any bed he lies on will be unclean.

If a woman has a discharge of blood outside of her menstrual period, she will be unclean for the duration of the discharge, just as during her period. Anything she lies or sits on will be unclean. Anyone who touches these things must wash their clothes, bathe in water, and remain unclean until evening. Once she is cleansed from her discharge, she must wait seven days, then bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance of the Tabernacle. The priest will offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to make atonement for her before the Lord.

This is how the Israelites are to be separated from their uncleanness so they do not defile the Tabernacle. These are the regulations for anyone with a discharge, anyone who has an emission of semen, a woman during her menstrual period, and anyone who touches them.

The Lord spoke to Moses after the death of Aaron's two sons, who died when they approached the Lord. The Lord instructed Moses to tell Aaron not to enter the Most Holy Place behind the curtain whenever he chooses, or he will die, because the Lord appears in the cloud over the atonement cover. Aaron must bring a young bull for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering. He must wear the sacred linen tunic, linen undergarments, linen sash, and linen turban. He must bathe himself with water before putting them on.

Aaron must take two male goats from the Israelite community for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering. He will offer the bull for his own sin offering to make atonement for himself and his household. He will then take the two goats and present them before the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle. He will cast lots for the two goats—one lot for the Lord and the other for the scapegoat. The goat chosen for the Lord will be sacrificed as a sin offering, while the scapegoat will be presented alive before the Lord to make atonement and sent into the wilderness.

Aaron will then take the bull for his sin offering and make atonement for himself and his household. He will take a censer full of burning coals from the altar and two handfuls of finely ground fragrant incense and bring them inside the curtain. He will put the incense on the fire before the Lord, and the smoke will cover the atonement cover above the tablets of the covenant law, so he will not die. He will then sprinkle some of the bull's blood with his finger on the front of the atonement cover and seven times before the atonement cover.

Next, he will slaughter the goat for the people's sin offering and take its blood behind the curtain to do with it as he did with the bull's blood. He will sprinkle it on the atonement cover and in front of it. This will make atonement for the Most Holy Place because of the uncleanness and rebellion of the Israelites, whatever their sins have been. He will do the same for the Tent of Meeting, which is among them in the midst of their uncleanness. No one is to be in the Tent of Meeting from the time Aaron goes in to make atonement in the Most Holy Place until he comes out, having made atonement for himself, his household, and the whole community of Israel.

He will then go out to the altar before the Lord and make atonement for it. He will take some of the bull's and goat's blood and put it on all the horns of the altar. He will sprinkle some of the blood on it with his finger seven times to cleanse and consecrate it from the uncleanness of the Israelites.

When Aaron has finished making atonement for the Most Holy Place, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, he will bring forward the live goat. He will lay both hands on the goat's head and confess over it all the wickedness and rebellion of the Israelites—all their sins—and put them on the goat's head. He will send the goat away into the wilderness in the care of someone appointed for the task. The goat will carry all their sins to a remote place, and the man will release it in the wilderness.

Aaron will then go into the Tent of Meeting, take off the linen garments he put on before he entered the Most Holy Place, and leave them there. He will bathe himself with water in a holy place and put on his regular garments. Then he will come out and sacrifice the burnt offering for himself and the burnt offering for the people to make atonement for himself and the people. He will also burn the fat of the sin offering on the altar.

The man who releases the scapegoat must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water; afterward, he may come into the camp. The bull and the goat for the sin offerings, whose blood was brought into the Most Holy Place to make atonement, must be taken outside the camp; their hides, flesh, and intestines are to be burned. The man who burns them must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water; afterward, he may come into the camp.

This is to be a lasting ordinance for you: On the tenth day of the seventh month, you must deny yourselves and do no work—whether native-born or a foreigner residing among you—because on this day atonement will be made for you, to cleanse you. Then, before the Lord, you will be clean from all your sins. It is a day of sabbath rest, and you must deny yourselves; it is a lasting ordinance. The priest who is anointed and ordained to succeed his father as high priest is to make atonement. He is to put on the sacred linen garments and make atonement for the Most Holy Place, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, and for the priests and all the members of the community.

This is to be a lasting ordinance for you: Atonement is to be made once a year for all the sins of the Israelites. And it was done, as the Lord commanded Moses.

The Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "Speak to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites and say to them: This is what the Lord has commanded: Any Israelite who sacrifices an ox, a lamb, or a goat in the camp or outside of it instead of bringing it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to present it as an offering to the Lord must be considered guilty of bloodshed; they have shed blood and must be cut off from their people. This is so the Israelites will bring their sacrifices they are now making in the open fields to the Lord at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting to the priest and sacrifice them as fellowship offerings. The priest is to splash the blood against the altar of the Lord at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting and burn the fat as an aroma pleasing to the Lord."The people of Israel must no longer offer their sacrifices to demons, which they have been following. This rule will last forever for all generations. Tell them that anyone from the house of Israel or any foreigner living among them who offers a burnt offering or sacrifice must bring it to the entrance of the Tabernacle to present it to the Lord. If they don't, they will be cut off from their people.

Anyone from the house of Israel or any foreigner living among them who eats any blood will be opposed by the Lord and cut off from their people. The life of a creature is in its blood, and the blood is given to make atonement for your souls. Therefore, no one among you should eat blood, nor should any foreigner living among you eat blood.

If anyone from the house of Israel or any foreigner living among them hunts and catches an animal or bird that may be eaten, they must drain its blood and cover it with dust. The life of every creature is in its blood, so you must not eat the blood of any creature. Anyone who eats it will be cut off.

Anyone who eats an animal that died naturally or was torn by wild animals, whether they are native-born or a foreigner, must wash their clothes and bathe with water and will be unclean until evening. Then they will be clean. But if they do not wash their clothes and bathe, they will bear their guilt.

The Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "Tell the Israelites: I am the Lord your God. Do not follow the practices of Egypt, where you used to live, or of Canaan, where I am bringing you. Follow my laws and be careful to keep my decrees. I am the Lord your God. Keep my statutes and my judgments, and you will live by them. I am the Lord.

No one is to approach any close relative to have sexual relations. I am the Lord. Do not dishonor your father by having sexual relations with your mother. She is your mother; do not have relations with her. Do not have sexual relations with your father's wife; that would dishonor your father. Do not have sexual relations with your sister, whether she is your father's daughter or your mother's daughter, whether born in the same house or elsewhere. Do not have sexual relations with your son's daughter or your daughter's daughter; that would dishonor you. Do not have sexual relations with the daughter of your father's wife, born to your father; she is your sister. Do not have sexual relations with your father's sister; she is a close relative of your father. Do not have sexual relations with your mother's sister; she is a close relative of your mother. Do not dishonor your father's brother by approaching his wife to have sexual relations; she is your aunt. Do not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law; she is your son's wife. Do not have sexual relations with your brother's wife; that would dishonor your brother. Do not have sexual relations with both a woman and her daughter. Do not take your wife's sister as a rival wife and have sexual relations with her while your wife is living. Do not approach a woman to have sexual relations during the uncleanness of her monthly period. Do not have sexual relations with your neighbor's wife and defile yourself with her. Do not give any of your children to be sacrificed to Molech, for you must not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord. Do not have sexual relations with a man as one does with a woman; that is detestable. Do not have sexual relations with an animal and defile yourself with it. A woman must not present herself to an animal to have sexual relations with it; that is a perversion.

Do not defile yourselves in any of these ways, because this is how the nations that I am going to drive out before you became defiled. Even the land was defiled; so I punished it for its sin, and the land vomited out its inhabitants. But you must keep my decrees and my laws. The native-born and the foreigners residing among you must not do any of these detestable things, for all these things were done by the people who lived in the land before you, and the land became defiled. If you defile the land, it will vomit you out as it vomited out the nations that were before you. Anyone who does any of these detestable things—such persons must be cut off from their people. Keep my requirements and do not follow any of the detestable customs that were practiced before you came, and do not defile yourselves with them. I am the Lord your God."

The Lord said to Moses, "Speak to the entire assembly of Israel and say to them: Be holy because I, the Lord your God, am holy. Each of you must respect your mother and father, and you must observe my Sabbaths. I am the Lord your God. Do not turn to idols or make metal gods for yourselves. I am the Lord your God.

When you sacrifice a fellowship offering to the Lord, sacrifice it in such a way that it will be accepted on your behalf. It shall be eaten on the day you sacrifice it or on the next day; anything left over until the third day must be burned up. If any of it is eaten on the third day, it is impure and will not be accepted. Whoever eats it will be held responsible because they have desecrated what is holy to the Lord; they must be cut off from their people.

When you reap the harvest of your land, do not reap to the very edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest. Do not go over your vineyard a second time or pick up the grapes that have fallen. Leave them for the poor and the foreigner. I am the Lord your God.

Do not steal. Do not lie. Do not deceive one another. Do not swear falsely by my name and so profane the name of your God. I am the Lord. Do not defraud or rob your neighbor. Do not hold back the wages of a hired worker overnight. Do not curse the deaf or put a stumbling block in front of the blind, but fear your God. I am the Lord.

Do not pervert justice; do not show partiality to the poor or favoritism to the great, but judge your neighbor fairly. Do not go about spreading slander among your people. Do not do anything that endangers your neighbor's life. I am the Lord.

Do not hate a fellow Israelite in your heart. Rebuke your neighbor frankly so you will not share in their guilt. Do not seek revenge or bear a grudge against anyone among your people, but love your neighbor as yourself. I am the Lord.

Keep my decrees. Do not mate different kinds of animals. Do not plant your field with two kinds of seed. Do not wear clothing woven of two kinds of material. If a man has sexual relations with a woman who is a slave promised to another man but who has not been ransomed or given her freedom, there must be due punishment. Yet they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed. The man, however, must bring a ram to the entrance of the Tabernacle for a guilt offering to the Lord. The priest will make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering before the Lord for the sin he has committed, and his sin will be forgiven.

When you enter the land and plant any kind of fruit tree, regard its fruit as forbidden. For three years you are to consider it forbidden; it must not be eaten. In the fourth year all its fruit will be holy, an offering of praise to the Lord. But in the fifth year you may eat its fruit. In this way, your harvest will be increased. I am the Lord your God.

Do not eat any meat with the blood still in it. Do not practice divination or seek omens. Do not cut the hair at the sides of your head or clip off the edges of your beard. Do not cut your bodies for the dead or put tattoo marks on yourselves. I am the Lord. Do not degrade your daughter by making her a prostitute, or the land will turn to prostitution and be filled with wickedness. Observe my Sabbaths and have reverence for my sanctuary. I am the Lord. Do not turn to mediums or seek out spiritists, for you will be defiled by them. I am the Lord your God.Respect the elderly and honor them. Show reverence for God. If a foreigner lives among you, treat them as you would a native and love them as yourself, remembering you were once foreigners in Egypt. Use honest measurements and weights. Follow all my laws and decrees.

Anyone who sacrifices their children to Molech must be put to death. If the community ignores this, I will turn against that person and their family. Anyone who consults with spirits or wizards will be cut off from their people. Be holy, for I am the Lord your God.

Anyone who curses their parents must be put to death. Adulterers, those who sleep with their father's wife, daughter-in-law, or same sex, and those who engage in bestiality must be put to death. Incestuous relationships are forbidden and punishable by death or being cut off from the community.

Follow my laws so the land you inhabit does not reject you as it did the previous nations. Distinguish between clean and unclean animals. Be holy because I, the Lord, am holy and have set you apart.

Anyone with a familiar spirit or who is a wizard must be put to death. Priests must not defile themselves by contact with the dead, except for close family. They must not shave their heads, cut their beards, or make cuts on their bodies. They must marry virgins, not prostitutes or divorced women. Priests with physical defects cannot offer sacrifices but can eat the holy food.

Priests must separate themselves from holy things if they are unclean. They must not eat anything that dies naturally or is torn by animals. Only priests and their households can eat holy food.If a priest's daughter marries someone outside the priestly family, she cannot eat the sacred offerings. However, if she becomes a widow or is divorced and has no children, and returns to live with her father, she may eat her father's food. No outsider is allowed to eat it. If someone eats a sacred offering by mistake, they must repay the value plus an additional fifth and give it to the priest. The sacred offerings of the Israelites must not be desecrated, as they are holy to the Lord.

The Lord spoke to Moses, instructing him to tell Aaron and his sons, as well as all the Israelites, that any offering made to the Lord must be a male without defect from cattle, sheep, or goats. Any animal with a defect is not acceptable. Peace offerings must also be without blemish to be accepted. Animals that are blind, injured, or deformed, or have sores, scabs, or other defects, must not be offered to the Lord. 

A bull or lamb with an overgrown or stunted part may be offered as a freewill offering but not for a vow. Animals that are bruised, crushed, torn, or cut must not be offered to the Lord. Offerings from foreigners are not acceptable if they have defects.

The Lord also instructed that when a calf, lamb, or goat is born, it must stay with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day onward, it is acceptable as an offering. Do not slaughter an animal and its offspring on the same day. When offering a thanksgiving sacrifice, it must be eaten on the same day; none should be left until the next day.

The Lord emphasized the importance of keeping His commandments and not desecrating His holy name. He reminded the Israelites that He is the Lord who sanctifies them and brought them out of Egypt.

The Lord spoke to Moses about the appointed festivals, which are holy gatherings. The Sabbath is a day of rest and holy assembly, observed every seventh day. The Passover is on the fourteenth day of the first month, followed by the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days, during which no work is done on the first and seventh days.

When the Israelites enter the promised land and harvest its crops, they must bring the first sheaf to the priest, who will wave it before the Lord. On that day, they must offer a year-old lamb without defect, along with grain and drink offerings. They must not eat any bread or grain until they have made this offering.

The Feast of Weeks is observed seven weeks after the first sheaf is waved. On this day, they must present a new grain offering, including two loaves of bread made with yeast, seven lambs, one young bull, and two rams, along with their grain and drink offerings. A goat is offered as a sin offering, and two lambs as a peace offering. This day is a holy assembly, and no work is done.

During the harvest, the Israelites must leave the edges of their fields and any gleanings for the poor and foreigners.

The first day of the seventh month is a day of rest and trumpet blasts, followed by the Day of Atonement on the tenth day, a day of fasting and rest. Anyone who does not fast or works on this day will be cut off from the community.

The Feast of Tabernacles begins on the fifteenth day of the seventh month and lasts for seven days. The first and eighth days are days of rest and holy assemblies. During this festival, the Israelites must live in temporary shelters to remember their ancestors' journey out of Egypt.

The Lord instructed Moses to command the Israelites to bring pure olive oil for the lamps in the tabernacle, ensuring they burn continually.The lamps in the tabernacle must be kept burning from evening until morning before the Lord continuously. This is a lasting ordinance for all generations. The priest will arrange the lamps on the pure gold lampstand before the Lord continually.

Take fine flour and bake twelve loaves of bread, using two-tenths of an ephah for each loaf. Arrange them in two rows, six in each row, on the pure gold table before the Lord. Place pure frankincense on each row as a memorial portion to be burned as an offering made by fire to the Lord. Every Sabbath, the bread is to be set out before the Lord continually, taken from the Israelites as a lasting covenant. Aaron and his sons are to eat it in a holy place, as it is most holy and part of the offerings made by fire to the Lord, a perpetual statute.

An Israelite woman's son, whose father was an Egyptian, went out among the Israelites and got into a fight with an Israelite man. The woman's son blasphemed the name of the Lord and cursed. They brought him to Moses, and his mother's name was Shelomith, daughter of Dibri, of the tribe of Dan. They put him in custody until the Lord's will was made clear to them.

The Lord told Moses to take the blasphemer outside the camp. All who heard him were to lay their hands on his head, and the entire assembly was to stone him. Moses was to tell the Israelites that anyone who curses their God will bear their sin. Anyone who blasphemes the name of the Lord must be put to death; the entire assembly must stone them, whether they are a foreigner or native-born. Anyone who takes a human life must be put to death. Anyone who takes the life of someone's animal must make restitution—life for life. If anyone injures their neighbor, whatever they have done must be done to them: fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth. The same injury they inflicted must be inflicted on them. Whoever kills an animal must make restitution, but whoever kills a human being is to be put to death. You are to have the same law for the foreigner and the native-born. I am the Lord your God.

Moses spoke to the Israelites, and they took the blasphemer outside the camp and stoned him. The Israelites did as the Lord commanded Moses.

The Lord spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai, saying, "Speak to the Israelites and say to them: When you enter the land I am going to give you, the land itself must observe a Sabbath to the Lord. For six years sow your fields, and for six years prune your vineyards and gather their crops. But in the seventh year, the land is to have a year of Sabbath rest, a Sabbath to the Lord. Do not sow your fields or prune your vineyards. Do not reap what grows of itself or harvest the grapes of your untended vines. The land is to have a year of rest. Whatever the land yields during the Sabbath year will be food for you—for yourself, your male and female servants, the hired worker and temporary resident who live among you, as well as for your livestock and the wild animals in your land. Whatever the land produces may be eaten.

Count off seven Sabbath years—seven times seven years—so that the seven Sabbath years amount to a period of forty-nine years. Then have the trumpet sounded everywhere on the tenth day of the seventh month; on the Day of Atonement sound the trumpet throughout your land. Consecrate the fiftieth year and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a Jubilee for you; each of you is to return to your family property and to your own clan. The fiftieth year shall be a Jubilee for you; do not sow and do not reap what grows of itself or harvest the untended vines. For it is a Jubilee and is to be holy for you; eat only what is taken directly from the fields.

In this Year of Jubilee everyone is to return to their own property. If you sell land to any of your own people or buy land from them, do not take advantage of each other. You are to buy from your own people on the basis of the number of years since the Jubilee. And they are to sell to you on the basis of the number of years left for harvesting crops. When the years are many, you are to increase the price, and when the years are few, you are to decrease the price, because what is really being sold to you is the number of crops. Do not take advantage of each other, but fear your God. I am the Lord your God.

Follow my decrees and be careful to obey my laws, and you will live safely in the land. The land will yield its fruit, and you will eat your fill and live there in safety. You may ask, "What will we eat in the seventh year if we do not plant or harvest our crops?" I will send you such a blessing in the sixth year that the land will yield enough for three years. While you plant during the eighth year, you will eat from the old crop and will continue to eat from it until the harvest of the ninth year comes in.

The land must not be sold permanently, because the land is mine and you reside in my land as foreigners and strangers. Throughout the land that you hold as a possession, you must provide for the redemption of the land. If one of your fellow Israelites becomes poor and sells some of their property, their nearest relative is to come and redeem what they have sold. If, however, there is no one to redeem it for them but later on they prosper and acquire sufficient means to redeem it themselves, they are to determine the value for the years since they sold it and refund the balance to the one to whom they sold it; they can then go back to their own property. But if they do not acquire the means to repay, what was sold will remain in the possession of the buyer until the Year of Jubilee. It will be returned in the Jubilee, and they can then go back to their property.

Anyone who sells a house in a walled city retains the right of redemption a full year after its sale. During that time, the seller may redeem it. If it is not redeemed before a full year has passed, the house in the walled city shall belong permanently to the buyer and the buyer's descendants. It is not to be returned in the Jubilee. But houses in villages without walls around them are to be considered as belonging to the open country. They can be redeemed, and they are to be returned in the Jubilee.

The Levites always have the right to redeem their houses in the Levitical towns, which they possess. So the property of the Levites is redeemable—that is, a house sold in any town they hold—and is to be returned in the Jubilee, because the houses in the towns of the Levites are their property among the Israelites. But the pastureland belonging to their towns must not be sold; it is their permanent possession.

If any of your fellow Israelites become poor and are unable to support themselves among you, help them as you would a foreigner and stranger, so they can continue to live among you. Do not take interest or any profit from them, but fear your God, so that they may continue to live among you. You must not lend them money at interest or sell them food at a profit. I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.

If any of your fellow Israelites become poor and sell themselves to you, do not make them work as slaves. They are to be treated as hired workers or temporary residents among you; they are to work for you until the Year of Jubilee. Then they and their children are to be released, and they will go back to their own clans and to the property of their ancestors. Because the Israelites are my servants, whom I brought out of Egypt, they must not be sold as slaves. Do not rule over them ruthlessly, but fear your God.

Your male and female slaves are to come from the nations around you; from them you may buy slaves. You may also buy some of the temporary residents living among you and members of their clans born in your country, and they will become your property. You can bequeath them to your children as inherited property and can make them slaves for life, but you must not rule over your fellow Israelites ruthlessly.

If a foreigner residing among you becomes rich and any of your fellow Israelites become poor and sell themselves to the foreigner or to a member of the foreigner's clan, they retain the right of redemption after they have sold themselves. One of their relatives may redeem them: an uncle or a cousin or any blood relative in their clan may redeem them. Or if they prosper, they may redeem themselves. They and their buyer are to count the time from the year they sold themselves up to the Year of Jubilee. The price for their release is to be based on the rate paid to a hired worker for that number of years. If many years remain, they must pay for their redemption a larger share of the price paid for them. If only a few years remain until the Year of Jubilee, they are to compute that and pay for their redemption accordingly. They are to be treated as workers hired from year to year; you must see to it that those to whom they owe service do not rule over them ruthlessly.

Even if someone is not redeemed in any of these ways, they and their children are to be released in the Year of Jubilee, for the Israelites belong to me as servants. They are my servants, whom I brought out of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.If someone sells themselves to you, treat them as hired workers, not as slaves. They will work for you until the Year of Jubilee, then they and their children will be freed and return to their family property. Israelites are my servants, whom I freed from Egypt; they must not be sold as slaves. Treat them fairly and with respect.

Do not make idols or set up images to worship. Keep my Sabbaths and respect my sanctuary. If you follow my commands, I will provide rain, fruitful harvests, and safety in your land. You will have plenty to eat and live in peace. I will remove dangerous animals and prevent wars. You will defeat your enemies, and I will bless you with prosperity and a strong covenant.

However, if you disobey, I will bring terror, disease, and sorrow. Your enemies will defeat you, and your efforts will be in vain. If you continue to disobey, I will punish you seven times more severely. Your pride will be broken, and your land will become barren. Wild animals will attack, and your population will dwindle. If you still resist, I will bring more plagues and disasters. Your cities will be destroyed, and you will be scattered among the nations.

If you confess your sins and humble yourselves, I will remember my covenant with your ancestors and restore the land. Even in exile, I will not abandon you completely. I will remember my covenant and be your God.

These are the laws and commands given by the Lord to the Israelites through Moses on Mount Sinai. If someone makes a vow to dedicate a person to the Lord, the value will be set according to age and gender. If they cannot afford the set value, the priest will determine an appropriate amount based on their ability to pay. If an animal is dedicated to the Lord, it becomes holy and cannot be exchanged. If someone wants to redeem a dedicated house or field, they must add a fifth of its value to the redemption price.If someone dedicates a field to the Lord after the Year of Jubilee, the priest will calculate its value based on the remaining years until the next Jubilee, and the value will be adjusted accordingly. If the person wants to redeem the field, they must add 20% to the estimated value. If they do not redeem it or if it has been sold to someone else, it cannot be redeemed again. During the Jubilee, the field will become holy to the Lord and will belong to the priests.

If someone dedicates a field they bought, not part of their family inheritance, the priest will determine its value up to the next Jubilee. The person must pay this value on that day as a holy offering to the Lord. In the Year of Jubilee, the field will return to the original owner. All valuations will be based on the sanctuary shekel, which is equivalent to twenty gerahs.

The firstborn of animals, which already belong to the Lord, cannot be dedicated. If it is an unclean animal, it can be redeemed at its estimated value plus 20%, or if not redeemed, it will be sold at its estimated value. Anything devoted to the Lord, whether a person, animal, or field, cannot be sold or redeemed; it is most holy to the Lord. No person devoted to destruction can be redeemed; they must be put to death.

A tithe of everything from the land, whether grain or fruit, belongs to the Lord and is holy. If someone wants to redeem any part of their tithe, they must add 20% to its value. Every tenth animal from the herd or flock that passes under the shepherd's rod will be holy to the Lord. No one may pick out the good from the bad or make any substitutions; if they do, both the original animal and its substitute become holy and cannot be redeemed.

These are the commands the Lord gave Moses for the Israelites on Mount Sinai.

The Lord spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the tent of meeting, on the first day of the second month of the second year after they came out of Egypt. He instructed Moses to take a census of the entire Israelite community by their clans and families, listing every man by name, one by one. All men twenty years old or older who could serve in the army were to be counted. Moses and Aaron were to enlist one man from each tribe to help with the census.

The chosen leaders were:
- From Reuben: Elizur son of Shedeur
- From Simeon: Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai
- From Judah: Nahshon son of Amminadab
- From Issachar: Nethaneel son of Zuar
- From Zebulun: Eliab son of Helon
- From Ephraim (Joseph's descendant): Elishama son of Ammihud
- From Manasseh (Joseph's descendant): Gamaliel son of Pedahzur
- From Benjamin: Abidan son of Gideoni
- From Dan: Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai
- From Asher: Pagiel son of Ocran
- From Gad: Eliasaph son of Deuel
- From Naphtali: Ahira son of Enan

These were the leaders of their ancestral tribes, the heads of the clans of Israel. Moses and Aaron took these men, who were named, and assembled the whole community on the first day of the second month. They registered them by their clans and families, listing every man by name, one by one, from twenty years old and up, as the Lord commanded Moses.

The number of men from each tribe who could serve in the army were:
- Reuben: 46,500
- Simeon: 59,300
- Gad: 45,650
- Judah: 74,600
- Issachar: 54,400
- Zebulun: 57,400
- Ephraim: 40,500
- Manasseh: 32,200
- Benjamin: 35,400
- Dan: 62,700
- Asher: 41,500
- Naphtali: 53,400

These were the men counted by Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of Israel, twelve men in total, each representing their ancestral tribe. The total number of men twenty years old or older who could serve in Israel's army was 603,550.

However, the Levites were not counted along with the other Israelites because the Lord had instructed Moses not to include them. Instead, the Levites were to be in charge of the tabernacle of the covenant law, all its furnishings, and everything belonging to it. They were to carry the tabernacle and all its articles, take care of it, and camp around it. When the tabernacle was to move, the Levites were to take it down, and when it was to be set up, they were to do it. Any unauthorized person who approached it was to be put to death. The Israelites were to set up their tents by divisions, each in their own camp under their standard. The Levites, however, were to camp around the tabernacle of the covenant law so that there would be no wrath on the Israelite community. The Levites were responsible for the care of the tabernacle of the covenant law.The Israelites followed all the Lord's commands given to Moses. The Lord then instructed Moses and Aaron that each man of Israel should set up camp under their family banner, at a distance around the Tabernacle. 

On the east side, the camp of Judah, led by Nahshon son of Amminadab, would set up first, with 74,600 men. Next to them, the tribe of Issachar, led by Nethaneel son of Zuar, with 54,400 men, and then the tribe of Zebulun, led by Eliab son of Helon, with 57,400 men. The total for the camp of Judah was 186,400 men, and they would lead the march.

On the south side, the camp of Reuben, led by Elizur son of Shedeur, with 46,500 men, followed by the tribe of Simeon, led by Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai, with 59,300 men, and the tribe of Gad, led by Eliasaph son of Reuel, with 45,650 men. The total for the camp of Reuben was 151,450 men, and they would march second.

The Tabernacle, carried by the Levites, would be in the middle of the camps as they moved, with each tribe in their designated place.

On the west side, the camp of Ephraim, led by Elishama son of Ammihud, with 40,500 men, followed by the tribe of Manasseh, led by Gamaliel son of Pedahzur, with 32,200 men, and the tribe of Benjamin, led by Abidan son of Gideoni, with 35,400 men. The total for the camp of Ephraim was 108,100 men, and they would march third.

On the north side, the camp of Dan, led by Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai, with 62,700 men, followed by the tribe of Asher, led by Pagiel son of Ocran, with 41,500 men, and the tribe of Naphtali, led by Ahira son of Enan, with 53,400 men. The total for the camp of Dan was 157,600 men, and they would march last.

The total number of men in the Israelite camps was 603,550, not including the Levites, who were not counted as the Lord commanded Moses. The Israelites set up camp and moved according to the Lord's instructions.

The Lord also spoke to Moses about the generations of Aaron and Moses. Aaron's sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. Nadab and Abihu died before the Lord when they offered unauthorized fire, leaving Eleazar and Ithamar to serve as priests.

The Lord instructed Moses to bring the tribe of Levi to assist Aaron. The Levites were to take care of the Tabernacle and its furnishings, and they were given to Aaron and his sons to serve in the priestly duties. Any unauthorized person approaching the Tabernacle would be put to death.

The Lord claimed the Levites as His own, instead of the firstborn of Israel, as He had spared the firstborn during the plague in Egypt. Moses was to count the Levites by their families, from one month old and up.

The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Gershon's sons were Libni and Shimei. Kohath's sons were Amram, Izehar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Merari's sons were Mahli and Mushi. The Gershonites, numbering 7,500, camped west of the Tabernacle. Their duties included the Tabernacle's coverings and hangings. The Kohathites, numbering 8,600, camped south of the Tabernacle and were responsible for the sanctuary's holy items. The Merarites, numbering 6,200, camped north of the Tabernacle and took care of its structure and accessories. Eleazar, son of Aaron, oversaw the Levites' duties.Moses, Aaron, and his sons were responsible for the sanctuary and camped on the east side of the Tabernacle. Any unauthorized person approaching the sanctuary would be put to death. The total number of Levites, counted by Moses and Aaron as commanded by the Lord, was 22,000 males from one month old and up.

The Lord instructed Moses to count all the firstborn males of the Israelites from one month old and up. The total number was 22,273. The Lord claimed the Levites and their cattle in place of the firstborn of Israel and their cattle. For the 273 firstborn Israelites exceeding the number of Levites, Moses was to collect five shekels each and give the money to Aaron and his sons. Moses collected 1,365 shekels and gave it to Aaron and his sons as commanded by the Lord.

The Lord then instructed Moses and Aaron to count the Kohathites, a subgroup of the Levites, from ages 30 to 50, who were to work in the Tabernacle. Their duties included handling the most holy items. Aaron and his sons would cover these items before the Kohathites transported them, ensuring they did not touch or see the holy objects directly, lest they die. Eleazar, Aaron's son, was responsible for the oil, incense, daily offerings, and oversight of the Tabernacle.

The Lord also instructed Moses to count the Gershonites, another subgroup of the Levites, from ages 30 to 50. Their duties included carrying the Tabernacle's curtains, coverings, and hangings. Ithamar, Aaron's son, oversaw their work.

Similarly, the Merarites, the third subgroup of the Levites, were counted from ages 30 to 50. They were responsible for the Tabernacle's structure, including boards, bars, pillars, and sockets. Ithamar also oversaw their duties.

The total number of Levites counted for service in the Tabernacle was 8,580. Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of Israel conducted the census as commanded by the Lord.Moses followed the Lord's command and counted each person according to their duties. The Lord then instructed Moses to tell the Israelites to remove anyone with leprosy, any discharge, or anyone who had touched a dead body from the camp to keep it pure. The Israelites obeyed.

The Lord also told Moses that if anyone sins, they must confess and make restitution, adding a fifth of the value, and give it to the wronged person. If the wronged person has no relative, the restitution goes to the Lord and the priest, along with a ram for atonement.

The Lord gave Moses instructions for dealing with a wife suspected of infidelity. The husband would bring her to the priest with an offering. The priest would prepare a bitter water mixture and make the woman take an oath. If she was guilty, the water would cause her harm; if innocent, she would be unharmed and able to conceive.

The Lord also provided guidelines for those taking a Nazarite vow, which included abstaining from wine, not cutting their hair, and avoiding contact with the dead. If they accidentally became defiled, they had to undergo a cleansing process and offer sacrifices.

When the vow period ended, the Nazarite would present offerings, shave their head, and the priest would perform specific rituals. The Lord instructed Moses to have Aaron and his sons bless the Israelites with a special blessing.

On the day Moses finished setting up the Tabernacle, the leaders of Israel brought offerings, including six covered wagons and twelve oxen, to be used by the Levites for their service.Moses distributed the wagons and oxen among the Levites according to their duties: two wagons and four oxen to the Gershonites, and four wagons and eight oxen to the Merarites. The Kohathites received none because they carried the sanctuary items on their shoulders.

Each tribal leader brought offerings for the altar dedication. On the first day, Nahshon from Judah offered a silver plate and bowl filled with fine flour mixed with oil, a gold spoon of incense, a young bull, a ram, a lamb, a goat for a sin offering, and various animals for peace offerings.

On the second day, Nethaneel from Issachar brought similar offerings. Each subsequent day, a different leader from each tribe presented the same types of offerings: silver and gold vessels, fine flour, incense, and various animals for burnt, sin, and peace offerings.

This continued for twelve days, with each leader from the tribes of Zebulun, Reuben, Simeon, Gad, Ephraim, Manasseh, Benjamin, Dan, Asher, and Naphtali offering the same items.

In total, the offerings included twelve silver plates, twelve silver bowls, twelve gold spoons, twelve bulls, twelve rams, twelve lambs, twelve goats for sin offerings, and numerous animals for peace offerings.

After the altar was dedicated, Moses entered the Tabernacle to speak with the Lord and heard His voice from above the mercy seat on the Ark of the Covenant.The Lord spoke to Moses, instructing him to tell Aaron to light the seven lamps so they shine in front of the lampstand. Aaron did as commanded, lighting the lamps as the Lord had instructed Moses. The lampstand was made of hammered gold, crafted exactly as the Lord had shown Moses.

The Lord then told Moses to purify the Levites. This involved sprinkling them with purifying water, shaving their bodies, and washing their clothes. They were to bring a young bull with a grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil, and another young bull for a sin offering. Moses was to gather the entire community of Israel, bring the Levites before the Lord, and have the Israelites lay their hands on them. Aaron would then present the Levites as an offering to the Lord, so they could serve Him.

The Levites were to lay their hands on the heads of the bulls, offering one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to make atonement for them. Moses was to present the Levites before Aaron and his sons as an offering to the Lord, separating them from the rest of the Israelites. The Levites would then be dedicated to the Lord and begin their service in the Tabernacle.

The Lord explained that the Levites were His, taken instead of the firstborn of all Israelites. He had sanctified the firstborn on the day He struck down the firstborn in Egypt, but now He had taken the Levites in their place. The Levites were given to Aaron and his sons to serve in the Tabernacle and make atonement for the Israelites, preventing any plague when they approached the sanctuary.

Moses, Aaron, and the Israelites did as the Lord commanded, purifying the Levites and presenting them as an offering. The Levites then began their service in the Tabernacle.

The Lord also instructed Moses that Levites aged 25 to 50 were to serve in the Tabernacle. After 50, they would retire from active service but could assist their fellow Levites in their duties.

The Lord spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, instructing the Israelites to keep the Passover at its appointed time, on the 14th day of the first month. They were to follow all the rites and ceremonies. Some men who were unclean due to contact with a dead body asked Moses if they could still observe Passover. The Lord told Moses that anyone unclean or on a journey could observe Passover on the 14th day of the second month, following the same rules. However, anyone who was clean and not on a journey but failed to observe Passover would be cut off from the community.

On the day the Tabernacle was set up, a cloud covered it, appearing as fire by night. The Israelites followed the cloud's movements, setting up camp when it rested and moving when it lifted. This pattern continued throughout their journey.

The Lord instructed Moses to make two silver trumpets for calling the assembly and signaling the camps to move. When both trumpets were blown, the entire assembly would gather at the Tabernacle. If only one was blown, the leaders would gather. Different signals indicated when the eastern and southern camps should move. The sons of Aaron, the priests, were to blow the trumpets as a lasting ordinance. The trumpets were also to be used in times of war and on special occasions, such as festivals and new moons, to remind the Israelites of the Lord.

On the 20th day of the second month in the second year, the cloud lifted from the Tabernacle, and the Israelites set out from the wilderness of Sinai, following the Lord's command. The camp of Judah, led by Nahshon son of Amminadab, was the first to set out.The leader of the tribe of Issachar was Nethaneel, son of Zuar. The leader of the tribe of Zebulun was Eliab, son of Helon. When the Tabernacle was taken down, the sons of Gershon and Merari carried it. The camp of Reuben, led by Elizur, son of Shedeur, set out next. The tribe of Simeon was led by Shelumiel, son of Zurishaddai, and the tribe of Gad by Eliasaph, son of Deuel. The Kohathites carried the sanctuary, and the Tabernacle was set up before they arrived.

The camp of Ephraim, led by Elishama, son of Ammihud, set out next, followed by the tribe of Manasseh, led by Gamaliel, son of Pedahzur, and the tribe of Benjamin, led by Abidan, son of Gideoni. The camp of Dan, which was the rear guard, was led by Ahiezer, son of Ammishaddai. The tribe of Asher was led by Pagiel, son of Ocran, and the tribe of Naphtali by Ahira, son of Enan. This was the order in which the Israelites traveled.

Moses invited Hobab, son of Raguel the Midianite and his father-in-law, to join them on their journey to the land the Lord had promised. Hobab initially refused, wanting to return to his own land and people. Moses urged him to stay, promising that he would share in the blessings the Lord would give them. They traveled for three days, with the Ark of the Covenant leading the way to find a resting place. The cloud of the Lord was over them by day as they traveled.

When the Ark set out, Moses would say, "Rise up, Lord! Scatter your enemies and make those who hate you flee." When it came to rest, he would say, "Return, Lord, to the many thousands of Israel."

The people began to complain, which angered the Lord, and His fire burned among them, consuming some at the outskirts of the camp. The people cried out to Moses, who prayed to the Lord, and the fire died down. The place was named Taberah because the Lord's fire had burned among them.

A mixed group among them began to crave other food, and the Israelites started to complain, reminiscing about the variety of food they had in Egypt. They were tired of the manna, which was like coriander seed and tasted like cakes baked with fresh oil. The manna fell with the dew at night.

Moses heard the people weeping at the entrances of their tents, and the Lord's anger was greatly kindled. Moses was also displeased and asked the Lord why he had been given the burden of all these people. He felt unable to provide meat for them and asked the Lord to relieve him of this burden, even if it meant death.

The Lord instructed Moses to gather seventy elders known to be leaders and officials among the people. The Lord would take some of the spirit that was on Moses and put it on them so they could share the burden. The Lord also promised to provide meat for the people, not just for a day or two, but for a whole month, until they loathed it, because they had rejected the Lord.

Moses questioned how this could be done, given the vast number of people. The Lord assured him that His power was not limited and that Moses would see His word fulfilled. Moses gathered the seventy elders, and the Lord came down in a cloud, took some of the spirit on Moses, and put it on the elders. They prophesied but did not continue to do so.

Two men, Eldad and Medad, who were listed among the elders but had not gone to the Tabernacle, also received the spirit and prophesied in the camp. A young man reported this to Moses, and Joshua, Moses' assistant, asked Moses to stop them. Moses replied that he wished all the Lord's people were prophets and that the Lord would put His spirit on them.

A wind from the Lord brought quail from the sea, and they fell around the camp. The people gathered quail all day and night and the next day. While the meat was still between their teeth, the Lord's anger burned against them, and He struck them with a severe plague. The place was named Kibroth Hattaavah because they buried the people who had craved other food. The Israelites then traveled to Hazeroth and stayed there.

Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of his Cushite wife. They questioned whether the Lord had spoken only through Moses and not also through them. The Lord heard this and called Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to the Tabernacle. He came down in a pillar of cloud and called Aaron and Miriam forward. The Lord explained that He spoke to prophets through visions and dreams, but with Moses, He spoke face to face. The Lord's anger burned against them, and when the cloud lifted, Miriam was leprous, white as snow. Aaron pleaded with Moses not to hold their sin against them. Moses cried out to the Lord to heal her.Moses cried out to God, "Please heal her!" The Lord responded, "If her father had spit in her face, wouldn't she be in disgrace for seven days? Let her be isolated outside the camp for seven days, and then she can be brought back." So Miriam was isolated outside the camp for seven days, and the people did not move until she was brought back. After that, they left Hazeroth and camped in the wilderness of Paran.

The Lord spoke to Moses, instructing him to send men to explore the land of Canaan, which He was giving to the Israelites. Each tribe was to send one leader.
