Moses followed the Lord's command and sent the leaders from the wilderness of Paran. These were their names: from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua son of Zaccur; from Simeon, Shaphat son of Hori; from Judah, Caleb son of Jephunneh; from Issachar, Igal son of Joseph; from Ephraim, Hoshea son of Nun; from Benjamin, Palti son of Raphu; from Zebulun, Gaddiel son of Sodi; from Manasseh (a tribe of Joseph), Gaddi son of Susi; from Dan, Ammiel son of Gemalli; from Asher, Sethur son of Michael; from Naphtali, Nahbi son of Vophsi; and from Gad, Geuel son of Machi. Moses renamed Hoshea son of Nun to Joshua.

Moses sent them to explore Canaan, instructing them to go through the Negev and into the hill country. He told them to observe the land and its people, whether they were strong or weak, few or many, and to assess the quality of the land and the cities, whether they were camps or fortified. He also asked them to bring back some of the fruit of the land, as it was the season for the first ripe grapes.

The men went up and explored the land from the wilderness of Zin to Rehob, near Lebo Hamath. They went through the Negev and reached Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, descendants of Anak, lived. Hebron had been built seven years before Zoan in Egypt. At the Valley of Eshkol, they cut a branch with a single cluster of grapes, which they carried on a pole between two men, along with some pomegranates and figs. The place was named the Valley of Eshkol because of the cluster of grapes the Israelites cut there.

After forty days, they returned from exploring the land and reported back to Moses, Aaron, and the entire Israelite community at Kadesh in the wilderness of Paran. They showed them the fruit of the land and reported, "We went to the land you sent us to. It does flow with milk and honey! Here is its fruit. But the people who live there are powerful, and the cities are fortified and very large. We even saw descendants of Anak there. The Amalekites live in the Negev; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites live in the hill country; and the Canaanites live near the sea and along the Jordan."

Caleb silenced the people before Moses and said, "We should go up and take possession of the land, for we can certainly do it." But the men who had gone up with him said, "We can't attack those people; they are stronger than we are." They spread a bad report among the Israelites about the land they had explored, saying, "The land we explored devours those living in it. All the people we saw there are of great size. We saw the Nephilim there (the descendants of Anak come from the Nephilim). We seemed like grasshoppers in our own eyes, and we looked the same to them."

That night, all the members of the community raised their voices and wept aloud. They grumbled against Moses and Aaron, saying, "If only we had died in Egypt or in this wilderness! Why is the Lord bringing us to this land only to let us fall by the sword? Our wives and children will be taken as plunder. Wouldn't it be better for us to go back to Egypt?" They said to each other, "We should choose a leader and go back to Egypt."

Moses and Aaron fell facedown in front of the whole Israelite assembly. Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh, who were among those who had explored the land, tore their clothes and said to the entire Israelite assembly, "The land we passed through and explored is exceedingly good. If the Lord is pleased with us, He will lead us into that land, a land flowing with milk and honey, and will give it to us. Only do not rebel against the Lord. And do not be afraid of the people of the land, because we will devour them. Their protection is gone, but the Lord is with us. Do not be afraid of them."

But the whole assembly talked about stoning them. Then the glory of the Lord appeared at the tent of meeting to all the Israelites. The Lord said to Moses, "How long will these people treat me with contempt? How long will they refuse to believe in me, despite all the signs I have performed among them? I will strike them down with a plague and destroy them, but I will make you into a nation greater and stronger than they."

Moses said to the Lord, "Then the Egyptians will hear about it! By your power, you brought these people up from among them. And they will tell the inhabitants of this land about it. They have already heard that you, Lord, are with these people and that you, Lord, have been seen face to face, that your cloud stays over them, and that you go before them in a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night. If you put all these people to death, leaving none alive, the nations who have heard this report about you will say, 'The Lord was not able to bring these people into the land he promised them on oath, so he slaughtered them in the wilderness.'

"Now may the Lord's strength be displayed, just as you have declared: 'The Lord is slow to anger, abounding in love and forgiving sin and rebellion. Yet he does not leave the guilty unpunished; he punishes the children for the sin of the parents to the third and fourth generation.' In accordance with your great love, forgive the sin of these people, just as you have pardoned them from the time they left Egypt until now."

The Lord replied, "I have forgiven them, as you asked. Nevertheless, as surely as I live and as surely as the glory of the Lord fills the whole earth, not one of those who saw my glory and the signs I performed in Egypt and in the wilderness but who disobeyed me and tested me ten times—not one of them will ever see the land I promised on oath to their ancestors. No one who has treated me with contempt will ever see it. But because my servant Caleb has a different spirit and follows me wholeheartedly, I will bring him into the land he went to, and his descendants will inherit it. Since the Amalekites and the Canaanites are living in the valleys, turn back tomorrow and set out toward the desert along the route to the Red Sea."

The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, "How long will this wicked community grumble against me? I have heard the complaints of these grumbling Israelites. So tell them, 'As surely as I live, declares the Lord, I will do to you the very thing I heard you say: In this wilderness, your bodies will fall—every one of you twenty years old or more who was counted in the census and who has grumbled against me. Not one of you will enter the land I swore with uplifted hand to make your home, except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun. As for your children that you said would be taken as plunder, I will bring them in to enjoy the land you have rejected. But as for you, your bodies will fall in this wilderness. Your children will be shepherds here for forty years, suffering for your unfaithfulness, until the last of your bodies lies in the wilderness. For forty years—one year for each of the forty days you explored the land—you will suffer for your sins and know what it is like to have me against you.' I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will surely do these things to this whole wicked community, which has banded together against me. They will meet their end in this wilderness; here they will die."

So the men Moses had sent to explore the land, who returned and made the whole community grumble against him by spreading a bad report about it—these men who were responsible for spreading the bad report about the land were struck down and died of a plague before the Lord. Of the men who went to explore the land, only Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh survived.The Israelites mourned deeply. Early the next morning, they went up to the top of the mountain, saying, "We are here and will go to the place the Lord promised, for we have sinned." But Moses warned them, "Why are you disobeying the Lord's command? It won't succeed. Don't go up, for the Lord is not with you, and you will be defeated by your enemies. The Amalekites and Canaanites are there, and you will fall by the sword because you have turned away from the Lord."

Despite Moses' warning, they went up to the hilltop, but neither the Ark of the Covenant nor Moses left the camp. The Amalekites and Canaanites who lived in that hill came down and attacked them, defeating them as far as Hormah.

The Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "Tell the Israelites: When you enter the land I am giving you and you make an offering by fire to the Lord, whether a burnt offering, a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, a freewill offering, or during your festivals, to create a pleasing aroma to the Lord from the herd or flock, the one presenting the offering must also bring a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of oil. Also, prepare a quarter of a hin of wine as a drink offering with the burnt offering or sacrifice for each lamb. For a ram, prepare a grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a third of a hin of oil, and a third of a hin of wine as a drink offering. For a bull, prepare a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with half a hin of oil, and half a hin of wine as a drink offering. This is how you must prepare each offering, whether for a bull, ram, lamb, or young goat. Do this for each animal you offer.

Everyone born in the land must follow these instructions when presenting an offering by fire to the Lord. If a foreigner lives among you and wants to present an offering by fire to the Lord, they must do the same. There is one law for both you and the foreigner living among you, a lasting ordinance for all generations. The same laws and regulations apply to both you and the foreigner living among you."

The Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "Tell the Israelites: When you enter the land I am bringing you into, and you eat the bread of the land, you must present a portion as an offering to the Lord. Present a loaf from the first of your dough as an offering, just as you present an offering from the threshing floor. Throughout your generations, give the first of your dough to the Lord as an offering.

If you unintentionally fail to keep any of these commands the Lord gave Moses, from the day the Lord gave them and onward, the whole community must offer a young bull as a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the Lord, along with its grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering. The priest will make atonement for the entire Israelite community, and they will be forgiven, for it was unintentional. They must bring their offering, a sacrifice by fire to the Lord, and their sin offering before the Lord for their unintentional sin. The entire Israelite community and the foreigners living among them will be forgiven, for it was unintentional.

If an individual sins unintentionally, they must bring a year-old female goat as a sin offering. The priest will make atonement for the person who sinned unintentionally, and they will be forgiven. There is one law for anyone who sins unintentionally, whether native-born or a foreigner living among you.

But anyone who sins defiantly, whether native-born or a foreigner, blasphemes the Lord and must be cut off from their people. They have despised the Lord's word and broken His command; they must be cut off, and their guilt remains on them."

While the Israelites were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day. Those who found him brought him to Moses, Aaron, and the whole community. They kept him in custody because it was unclear what should be done to him. The Lord said to Moses, "The man must be put to death; the whole community must stone him outside the camp." So the community took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as the Lord commanded Moses.

The Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "Tell the Israelites to make tassels on the corners of their garments throughout their generations and to put a blue cord on each tassel. These tassels will remind you to obey all the Lord's commands and not follow your own heart and eyes, which lead you astray. You will remember to obey all my commands and be holy to your God. I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God."

Korah, son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, along with Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab, and On, son of Peleth, from the tribe of Reuben, took men and rose up against Moses. They were joined by 250 Israelite men, leaders of the community, well-known and respected. They confronted Moses and Aaron, saying, "You have gone too far! The whole community is holy, every one of them, and the Lord is with them. Why then do you set yourselves above the Lord's assembly?"

When Moses heard this, he fell facedown. He said to Korah and all his followers, "In the morning, the Lord will show who belongs to Him and who is holy, and He will have that person come near Him. The one He chooses, He will bring near to Him. You, Korah, and all your followers are to do this: Take censers, put fire and incense in them before the Lord tomorrow. The man the Lord chooses will be the holy one. You Levites have gone too far!"

Moses also said to Korah, "Listen, you Levites! Isn't it enough that the God of Israel has separated you from the rest of the Israelite community and brought you near Himself to do the work at the Lord's tabernacle and to stand before the community and minister to them? He has brought you and all your fellow Levites near Himself, but now you are trying to get the priesthood too. It is against the Lord that you and all your followers have banded together. Who is Aaron that you should grumble against him?"

Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. But they said, "We will not come! Isn't it enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to kill us in the wilderness? And now you also want to lord it over us! Moreover, you haven't brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey or given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Will you gouge out the eyes of these men? No, we will not come!"

Moses became very angry and said to the Lord, "Do not accept their offering. I have not taken so much as a donkey from them, nor have I wronged any of them."

Moses said to Korah, "You and all your followers are to appear before the Lord tomorrow—you and they and Aaron. Each man is to take his censer and put incense in it—250 censers in all—and present it before the Lord. You and Aaron are to present your censers also." So each man took his censer, put fire and incense in it, and stood with Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the tent of meeting. When Korah had gathered all his followers in opposition to them at the entrance to the tent of meeting, the glory of the Lord appeared to the entire assembly. The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, "Separate yourselves from this assembly so I can put an end to them at once." Moses and Aaron fell facedown and cried out, "O God, the God who gives breath to all living things, will you be angry with the entire assembly when only one man sins?"Moses and Aaron pleaded with God, asking if He would punish the entire community for one man's sin. God instructed Moses to tell the people to move away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Moses warned the people to avoid anything belonging to these men to avoid being caught in their sins. The people moved away, and Dathan and Abiram stood at their tents with their families. Moses declared that if these men died naturally, then God had not sent him. But if the earth swallowed them alive, it would be a sign that they had defied God.

As soon as Moses finished speaking, the ground split open and swallowed Korah, Dathan, Abiram, their families, and all their possessions. The earth closed over them, and they were gone. The Israelites fled in fear, worried they might also be swallowed. Then, fire from the Lord consumed the 250 men who had offered incense.

God told Moses to instruct Eleazar, Aaron's son, to collect the censers from the fire and hammer them into a covering for the altar, as a reminder that only descendants of Aaron should offer incense before the Lord. The censers were considered holy because they had been offered to God.

The next day, the Israelites complained against Moses and Aaron, accusing them of killing God's people. As the community gathered against them, the glory of the Lord appeared. God told Moses and Aaron to separate themselves from the assembly so He could destroy them. Moses and Aaron fell facedown and pleaded for the people. Moses instructed Aaron to take a censer with fire from the altar and incense to make atonement for the people, as a plague had begun. Aaron did as instructed and stood between the living and the dead, stopping the plague. However, 14,700 people died from the plague, in addition to those who died because of Korah.

God then instructed Moses to collect a staff from each leader of the twelve tribes, with Aaron's name on the staff of Levi. The staffs were placed in the tent of meeting. The next day, Aaron's staff had budded, blossomed, and produced almonds, signifying God's choice of Aaron. The staffs were returned to their owners, and Aaron's staff was kept as a sign against the rebels to stop their complaints.

The Israelites expressed fear of dying if they approached the tabernacle. God told Aaron that he and his descendants would bear the responsibility for offenses against the sanctuary and priesthood. The Levites were given to assist the priests but were not to approach the sacred objects or altar. The Levites were a gift to the priests to help with the tabernacle's service. The priests were given the offerings and firstfruits as their portion, but they would have no inheritance in the land, as God was their inheritance.The Levites were given a tenth of all the produce in Israel as their inheritance for their service in the tabernacle. The Israelites were warned not to approach the tabernacle to avoid sin and death. The Levites were responsible for the tabernacle's service and would bear any iniquity. This rule was to be followed by all generations, and the Levites would have no land inheritance among the Israelites. Instead, they would receive the tithes offered by the Israelites to the Lord.

The Lord instructed Moses to tell the Levites that when they received tithes from the Israelites, they must offer a portion of it as a heave offering to the Lord, similar to the grain from the threshing floor or the wine from the winepress. This offering was to be given to Aaron the priest. The Levites were to offer the best part of their gifts as a heave offering to the Lord. Once they had done this, the remaining portion would be considered their reward for their service in the tabernacle. They would not bear sin for this as long as they offered the best part. They were also warned not to desecrate the holy offerings of the Israelites, or they would die.

The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron about the law regarding purification. The Israelites were to bring a red heifer without blemish, which had never been yoked, to Eleazar the priest. The heifer was to be slaughtered outside the camp, and Eleazar would sprinkle its blood seven times toward the tabernacle. The heifer, along with its skin, flesh, blood, and dung, was to be burned. Cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet were to be thrown into the fire. The priest would then wash his clothes and bathe, but he would remain unclean until evening. The ashes of the heifer were to be gathered and kept outside the camp for use in the water of purification for sin.

Anyone who touched a dead body would be unclean for seven days. They were to purify themselves with the water of purification on the third and seventh days. If they did not purify themselves, they would remain unclean and be cut off from Israel for defiling the Lord's sanctuary. This law applied to anyone who touched a dead body, a bone, or a grave. The ashes of the burnt heifer were to be mixed with running water and sprinkled on the unclean person, tent, and vessels. The clean person performing the sprinkling would also be unclean until evening. This statute was to be followed perpetually.

The Israelites arrived in the desert of Zin in the first month, and Miriam died and was buried there. There was no water, and the people complained against Moses and Aaron, wishing they had died earlier. They questioned why they were brought out of Egypt to die in the wilderness without food or water. Moses and Aaron went to the entrance of the tabernacle and fell facedown. The Lord instructed Moses to take his staff, gather the assembly, and speak to a rock to bring forth water. Moses struck the rock twice with his staff, and water gushed out for the people and their livestock.

However, because Moses and Aaron did not trust the Lord enough to honor Him as holy, they were told they would not lead the Israelites into the Promised Land. This place was called the Waters of Meribah because the Israelites quarreled with the Lord, and He showed His holiness among them.

Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom, asking for permission to pass through their land. The king of Edom refused, threatening to attack if they tried. The Israelites offered to pay for any water they used, but Edom still refused and came out against them with a large army. The Israelites turned away and traveled to Mount Hor. The Lord told Moses and Aaron that Aaron would die there because of their rebellion at the Waters of Meribah. Moses was to take Aaron and his son Eleazar up the mountain, remove Aaron's garments, and put them on Eleazar. Aaron died on the mountain, and Moses and Eleazar came down.When the Israelites saw that Aaron had died, they mourned for him for thirty days. 

King Arad, a Canaanite who lived in the south, heard that Israel was approaching and attacked them, taking some prisoners. Israel made a vow to the Lord, promising to destroy the Canaanite cities if He delivered them into their hands. The Lord listened and helped Israel defeat the Canaanites, and they named the place Hormah.

The Israelites then traveled from Mount Hor towards the Red Sea to go around Edom. The journey was tough, and the people complained against God and Moses, lamenting their lack of food and water. In response, the Lord sent venomous snakes among them, which bit and killed many Israelites. The people admitted their sin and asked Moses to pray for them. The Lord instructed Moses to make a bronze snake and put it on a pole; anyone bitten could look at it and live. Moses did as instructed, and those who looked at the bronze snake were healed.

The Israelites continued their journey, camping at various locations including Oboth, Ije Abarim, the Zered Valley, and the Arnon River. They reached a place called Beer, where the Lord provided water after Moses gathered the people. The Israelites sang a song of praise for the well.

They then moved to Mattanah, Nahaliel, Bamoth, and finally to the top of Pisgah, overlooking the desert. Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, asking for permission to pass through his land peacefully. Sihon refused and attacked Israel, but Israel defeated him and took over his land, including the city of Heshbon.

Moses sent spies to scout out Jazer, and Israel captured its villages and drove out the Amorites. They then turned towards Bashan, where King Og and his army confronted them. The Lord assured Moses not to fear, as He would deliver Og into their hands. Israel defeated Og and took possession of his land.

The Israelites camped in the plains of Moab near the Jordan River, across from Jericho. Balak, the king of Moab, saw what Israel had done to the Amorites and was terrified. He sent messengers to Balaam, a diviner, asking him to curse Israel. Balaam initially refused, but after further persuasion and a message from God, he agreed to go with the Moabite princes. However, God was angry with Balaam for going, and an angel blocked his path. Balaam's donkey saw the angel and refused to move, causing Balaam to beat it. The Lord opened the donkey's mouth, and it spoke to Balaam, questioning his actions. Then the Lord opened Balaam's eyes, and he saw the angel, who rebuked him for his reckless path.The angel of the Lord confronted Balaam, saying, "Why have you beaten your donkey these three times? I came to oppose you because your path is reckless. The donkey saw me and turned away three times. If she hadn't, I would have killed you and spared her." Balaam admitted his sin, saying he didn't realize the angel was blocking his way. The angel instructed him to continue with Balak's men but to only speak the words given by God.

When Balak heard Balaam was coming, he went to meet him at the border of Moab. Balak questioned why Balaam didn't come sooner, promising him honor. Balaam replied that he could only speak the words God put in his mouth. They went to Kirjathhuzoth, where Balak offered oxen and sheep. The next day, Balak took Balaam to the high places of Baal to see the Israelites.

Balaam instructed Balak to build seven altars and prepare seven bulls and rams. Balak did so, and they offered the sacrifices. Balaam then went to a high place to meet the Lord. God met Balaam and put words in his mouth, instructing him to return to Balak and speak them. Balaam returned and delivered God's message, blessing Israel instead of cursing them.

Balak was frustrated and took Balaam to another location, hoping he could curse Israel from there. They repeated the process of building altars and offering sacrifices. Again, Balaam met with God, who put words in his mouth. Balaam returned and delivered another blessing for Israel.

Balak, increasingly frustrated, took Balaam to a third location. They built more altars and offered more sacrifices. This time, Balaam didn't seek enchantments but looked toward the wilderness. The Spirit of God came upon him, and he blessed Israel again, praising their strength and prosperity.

Balak was furious and told Balaam to leave, saying he had intended to honor him, but the Lord had kept him from it. Balaam reminded Balak that he could only speak the words God gave him. Before leaving, Balaam prophesied the future victories of Israel over their enemies.

After Balaam left, the Israelites stayed in Shittim, where they began to engage in immoral behavior with Moabite women and worship their gods. This angered the Lord, who instructed Moses to execute those who had joined in idolatry. Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, took decisive action by killing an Israelite man and a Midianite woman, stopping the plague that had struck the Israelites.Phinehas, the son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest, took a spear and followed the Israelite man into his tent. He killed both the man and the Midianite woman, stopping the plague that had killed 24,000 Israelites. God told Moses that Phinehas had turned away His anger from the Israelites by being zealous for God's honor. As a reward, God granted Phinehas and his descendants a covenant of peace and an everlasting priesthood.

The Israelite man who was killed was Zimri, a leader from the tribe of Simeon, and the Midianite woman was Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite leader. God then instructed Moses to attack the Midianites because they had deceived the Israelites into worshiping Baal of Peor and engaging in immoral behavior.

After the plague, God told Moses and Eleazar, the son of Aaron, to take a census of all the Israelites aged 20 and older who could serve in the army. They conducted the census in the plains of Moab by the Jordan River near Jericho. The census included the following:

- The tribe of Reuben, with 43,730 men.
- The tribe of Simeon, with 22,200 men.
- The tribe of Gad, with 40,500 men.
- The tribe of Judah, with 76,500 men.
- The tribe of Issachar, with 64,300 men.
- The tribe of Zebulun, with 60,500 men.
- The tribe of Manasseh, with 52,700 men.
- The tribe of Ephraim, with 32,500 men.
- The tribe of Benjamin, with 45,600 men.
- The tribe of Dan, with 64,400 men.
- The tribe of Asher, with 53,400 men.
- The tribe of Naphtali, with 45,400 men.

In total, there were 601,730 men eligible for military service. God instructed Moses to divide the land among the tribes based on the number of people in each tribe, with larger tribes receiving more land and smaller tribes receiving less. The land was to be divided by lot.

The Levites, who were not included in the main census because they had no inheritance of land, were also counted. The Levite families included the Gershonites, Kohathites, and Merarites, with a total of 23,000 males from a month old and upward.

None of the men counted in this census had been part of the previous census taken in the wilderness of Sinai, except for Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, and Joshua, the son of Nun, as God had decreed that the previous generation would die in the wilderness.Zelophehad, a descendant of Manasseh, had five daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They approached Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the leaders of the community at the entrance of the Tabernacle. They said, "Our father died in the wilderness. He was not among those who rebelled against the Lord with Korah, but he died for his own sin and left no sons. Why should our father's name disappear from his clan because he had no son? Give us property among our father's relatives."

Moses brought their case before the Lord, and the Lord said to him, "The daughters of Zelophehad are right. You must give them property as an inheritance among their father's relatives and transfer their father's inheritance to them. Tell the Israelites that if a man dies and leaves no son, his inheritance should be given to his daughter. If he has no daughter, give his inheritance to his brothers. If he has no brothers, give his inheritance to his father's brothers. If his father had no brothers, give his inheritance to the nearest relative in his clan, so that he may possess it. This is to be a legal requirement for the Israelites, as the Lord commanded Moses."

The Lord then told Moses to go up Mount Abarim and see the land He had given to the Israelites. After seeing it, Moses would be gathered to his people, just as Aaron had been, because Moses had disobeyed God's command in the Desert of Zin.

Moses asked the Lord to appoint a leader over the community so they would not be like sheep without a shepherd. The Lord chose Joshua, son of Nun, a man filled with the Spirit. Moses was to lay his hands on Joshua and present him to Eleazar the priest and the entire community, giving him some of his authority so the Israelites would obey him. Joshua would consult Eleazar, who would use the Urim to seek the Lord's decision. At his command, the Israelites would go out and come in.

Moses did as the Lord commanded. He took Joshua, presented him to Eleazar and the community, laid his hands on him, and commissioned him as the Lord had instructed.

The Lord then spoke to Moses about the offerings the Israelites were to present at the appointed times. They were to offer two unblemished year-old lambs daily as a regular burnt offering, one in the morning and one at twilight, along with a grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil and a drink offering of wine. On the Sabbath, they were to offer two additional lambs, along with the corresponding grain and drink offerings.

At the beginning of each month, they were to offer two young bulls, one ram, and seven unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings. They were also to offer a male goat as a sin offering.

On the fourteenth day of the first month, they were to celebrate the Passover. On the fifteenth day, the Feast of Unleavened Bread would begin, lasting seven days. On the first day, they were to hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work. They were to offer two young bulls, one ram, and seven unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering. This pattern was to be followed for seven days, with a sacred assembly on the seventh day.

On the day of firstfruits, when they presented a new grain offering to the Lord, they were to hold a sacred assembly and do no regular work. They were to offer two young bulls, one ram, and seven unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering.

On the first day of the seventh month, they were to hold a sacred assembly, do no regular work, and commemorate the day with trumpet blasts. They were to offer one young bull, one ram, and seven unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering.

On the tenth day of the seventh month, they were to hold a sacred assembly, fast, and do no work. They were to offer one young bull, one ram, and seven unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering.

On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, they were to hold a sacred assembly and celebrate a festival to the Lord for seven days. They were to offer thirteen young bulls, two rams, and fourteen unblemished year-old lambs, along with the appropriate grain and drink offerings, and a male goat as a sin offering. This pattern was to be followed for seven days, with the number of bulls decreasing by one each day, and a sacred assembly on the eighth day.On the third day, offer eleven bulls, two rams, and fourteen one-year-old lambs without blemish. Each animal should have its corresponding grain and drink offerings. Additionally, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

On the fourth day, offer ten bulls, two rams, and fourteen one-year-old lambs without blemish, with their respective grain and drink offerings. Also, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

On the fifth day, offer nine bulls, two rams, and fourteen one-year-old lambs without blemish, with their respective grain and drink offerings. Also, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

On the sixth day, offer eight bulls, two rams, and fourteen one-year-old lambs without blemish, with their respective grain and drink offerings. Also, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

On the seventh day, offer seven bulls, two rams, and fourteen one-year-old lambs without blemish, with their respective grain and drink offerings. Also, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

On the eighth day, hold a solemn assembly and do no regular work. Offer one bull, one ram, and seven one-year-old lambs without blemish, with their respective grain and drink offerings. Also, offer one goat as a sin offering, along with the regular burnt offering and its grain and drink offerings.

These offerings are to be made to the Lord during your appointed festivals, in addition to your vows and freewill offerings, for your burnt offerings, grain offerings, drink offerings, and peace offerings.

Moses conveyed all these commands from the Lord to the Israelites.

Moses also spoke to the leaders of the tribes of Israel about vows. If a man makes a vow to the Lord or swears an oath to bind himself, he must not break his word and must do everything he said.

If a young woman makes a vow to the Lord while living in her father's house, and her father hears it and says nothing, her vow stands. But if her father disallows it when he hears it, her vow does not stand, and the Lord will forgive her.

If a woman makes a vow or binds herself with an oath after marriage, and her husband hears it and says nothing, her vow stands. But if her husband disallows it when he hears it, her vow does not stand, and the Lord will forgive her.

A widow or a divorced woman must fulfill any vow she makes.

If a woman makes a vow in her husband's house, and her husband hears it and says nothing, her vow stands. But if her husband disallows it when he hears it, her vow does not stand, and the Lord will forgive her.

These are the regulations the Lord gave Moses concerning relationships between a man and his wife, and between a father and his young daughter living in his house.

The Lord then instructed Moses to take vengeance on the Midianites before he would be gathered to his people. Moses told the Israelites to arm themselves for battle against the Midianites. Each tribe was to send a thousand men, totaling twelve thousand armed for war. Moses sent them to battle, along with Phinehas, son of Eleazar the priest, who carried the holy instruments and trumpets.

The Israelites fought the Midianites as the Lord commanded and killed all the males, including the five kings of Midian and Balaam, son of Beor. They captured the women and children, took all the livestock and goods, and burned the Midianite cities and camps. They brought the captives, spoils, and plunder to Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the Israelite community at the plains of Moab by the Jordan near Jericho.

Moses, Eleazar, and the leaders of the community went to meet them outside the camp. Moses was angry with the officers of the army for sparing the women, who had led the Israelites into sin at Peor. He commanded them to kill every male child and every woman who had slept with a man, but to keep alive the young girls who had not slept with a man. The soldiers were to stay outside the camp for seven days to purify themselves and their captives, washing their clothes on the third and seventh days.

Eleazar the priest instructed the soldiers on the purification laws for metals. Items that could withstand fire were to be purified by fire and water, while other items were to be purified with water. After washing their clothes on the seventh day, they would be clean and could re-enter the camp.

The Lord then told Moses to count the spoils of war, including people and animals, and divide them between the soldiers who fought and the rest of the community. A tribute was to be taken from the soldiers' share for the Lord, and from the community's share for the Levites who maintained the Lord's tabernacle. Moses and Eleazar followed these instructions.The remaining spoils of war, which the soldiers had captured, included 675,000 sheep, 72,000 cattle, 61,000 donkeys, and 32,000 women who had never been with a man. Half of these spoils were given to the soldiers who fought, totaling 337,500 sheep, 36,000 cattle, 30,500 donkeys, and 16,000 women. From this, the Lord's tribute was 675 sheep, 72 cattle, 61 donkeys, and 32 women. Moses gave this tribute to Eleazar the priest as the Lord commanded.

The other half of the spoils, which belonged to the rest of the Israelites, included 337,500 sheep, 36,000 cattle, 30,500 donkeys, and 16,000 women. From this half, Moses took one out of every fifty people and animals and gave them to the Levites who maintained the Lord's tabernacle, as the Lord commanded.

The officers of the army reported to Moses that none of their men were missing. They brought offerings of gold jewelry to the Lord as atonement for their souls. Moses and Eleazar the priest received the gold, which totaled 16,750 shekels, and brought it into the tabernacle as a memorial for the Israelites before the Lord.

The tribes of Reuben and Gad, who had large herds of cattle, saw that the lands of Jazer and Gilead were suitable for livestock. They asked Moses, Eleazar, and the leaders of the community if they could settle there instead of crossing the Jordan River. Moses questioned if they would let their fellow Israelites go to war while they stayed behind, reminding them of the previous generation's failure to enter the promised land, which angered the Lord and led to forty years of wandering in the wilderness.

The Reubenites and Gadites promised to build pens for their livestock and cities for their families, but they would join the Israelites in battle until everyone had received their inheritance. Moses agreed, provided they kept their promise. If they did, they could return and possess the land of Gilead. If not, they would be sinning against the Lord.

The Reubenites and Gadites assured Moses they would do as commanded. Moses then instructed Eleazar, Joshua, and the tribal leaders to give them the land of Gilead if they fulfilled their promise. The Reubenites and Gadites built cities and pens for their livestock, while the half-tribe of Manasseh also took possession of parts of Gilead.

The Israelites' journey from Egypt was recorded by Moses as commanded by the Lord. They left Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, the day after Passover, in full view of the Egyptians who were burying their firstborn. The Israelites traveled from Rameses to Succoth, then to Etham, and continued their journey through various locations, including the Red Sea, the wilderness of Sin, and Marah, where they found twelve springs and seventy palm trees.The Israelites continued their journey, moving from Rephidim to the wilderness of Sinai, then to Kibrothhattaavah, Hazeroth, Rithmah, Rimmonparez, Libnah, Rissah, Kehelathah, Mount Shapher, Haradah, Makheloth, Tahath, Tarah, Mithcah, Hashmonah, Moseroth, Benejaakan, Horhagidgad, Jotbathah, Ebronah, Eziongaber, the wilderness of Zin (Kadesh), and finally to Mount Hor on the edge of Edom. 

Aaron, the priest, died on Mount Hor at the age of 123, in the fortieth year after the Israelites left Egypt. King Arad of Canaan heard of the Israelites' approach. The Israelites then moved from Mount Hor to Zalmonah, Punon, Oboth, Ijeabarim (on the border of Moab), Iim, Dibongad, Almondiblathaim, the mountains of Abarim (before Nebo), and finally to the plains of Moab by the Jordan River near Jericho.

The Lord instructed Moses to tell the Israelites that when they crossed the Jordan into Canaan, they must drive out all the inhabitants, destroy their idols and places of worship, and take possession of the land. The land was to be divided among the tribes by lot, with larger tribes receiving more land and smaller tribes receiving less. If they failed to drive out the inhabitants, those remaining would become a source of trouble for them.

The Lord also outlined the borders of the land they were to inherit: from the wilderness of Zin along the coast of Edom, to the Salt Sea, up to the ascent of Akrabbim, through Zin to Kadeshbarnea, Hazaraddar, Azmon, the river of Egypt, and the Great Sea. The western border would be the Great Sea, the northern border from the Great Sea to Mount Hor, Hamath, Zedad, Ziphron, and Hazarenan. The eastern border would run from Hazarenan to Shepham, down to Riblah, and along the Sea of Chinnereth to the Jordan River, ending at the Salt Sea.

Moses was to assign Eleazar the priest and Joshua the son of Nun to oversee the division of the land, along with one leader from each tribe. The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh had already received their inheritance on the east side of the Jordan.

The Lord also commanded that the Israelites give the Levites cities to live in, along with surrounding pasturelands for their livestock. Six of these cities were to be designated as cities of refuge, where someone who accidentally killed another person could seek asylum until a fair trial. The total number of cities given to the Levites was to be forty-eight, distributed proportionally among the tribes based on their inheritance.If someone kills another person with a stone or a wooden weapon, they are considered a murderer and must be put to death. The person seeking revenge for the bloodshed has the right to kill the murderer when they encounter them. However, if the killing was accidental and not out of hatred, the community must judge the case. If the killer is found innocent of intentional murder, they must stay in a city of refuge until the high priest dies. If they leave the city and are killed by the avenger, the avenger is not guilty. The killer must remain in the city of refuge until the high priest's death, after which they can return to their land.

These rules are to be followed by all generations. A murderer must be put to death based on the testimony of multiple witnesses; one witness is not enough. No ransom can be accepted for the life of a murderer—they must be executed. Similarly, no ransom can be accepted for someone who fled to a city of refuge; they must stay there until the high priest dies. The land must not be polluted by bloodshed, as it can only be cleansed by the blood of the murderer. The Lord dwells among the Israelites, so they must not defile the land.

The leaders of the families of Gilead, descendants of Manasseh, approached Moses and the leaders of Israel. They were concerned that if the daughters of Zelophehad married men from other tribes, their inheritance would be transferred to those tribes. Moses, following the Lord's command, instructed that the daughters of Zelophehad could marry anyone they chose, but only within their father's tribe. This ensured that each tribe's inheritance remained within the tribe. The daughters of Zelophehad married their cousins, keeping their inheritance within the tribe of Manasseh.

These are the commandments and judgments given by the Lord through Moses to the Israelites in the plains of Moab by the Jordan River near Jericho.

In the fortieth year, on the first day of the eleventh month, Moses spoke to the Israelites, recounting all that the Lord had commanded. After defeating Sihon, king of the Amorites, and Og, king of Bashan, Moses began to explain the law. The Lord had told them at Horeb that they had stayed long enough at the mountain and should journey to the land of the Amorites and beyond, to the land promised to their ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

Moses reminded the people that he could not bear the burden of leading them alone, as they had become numerous. He appointed wise and respected men from each tribe as leaders and judges to help him. These judges were instructed to hear cases fairly, without partiality, and to bring difficult cases to Moses.

The Israelites journeyed from Horeb through the wilderness to Kadeshbarnea, where Moses told them to go up and take possession of the land the Lord had given them. However, the people were afraid and refused to go, despite Moses' assurances that the Lord would fight for them as He had in Egypt. They doubted the Lord's promise and complained that He had brought them out of Egypt to be destroyed by the Amorites.The Lord guided you with a pillar of fire by night and a cloud by day to show you the way. When the Lord heard your complaints, He was angry and swore that none of the evil generation would see the promised land, except Caleb, who followed the Lord completely. The Lord was also angry with me because of you and said I would not enter the land either. Instead, Joshua, who stands before you, will lead you into the land. Encourage him, for he will help Israel inherit it. Your children, whom you thought would be prey, will enter and possess the land. But as for you, turn back and journey into the wilderness by the way of the Red Sea.

You then admitted your sin against the Lord and prepared to fight as He commanded. But the Lord warned me to tell you not to go up and fight because He was not with you, and you would be defeated. You ignored this and went up the hill anyway, where the Amorites attacked and chased you like bees, defeating you at Seir and Hormah. You returned and wept before the Lord, but He did not listen. So, you stayed in Kadesh for many days.

We then turned and journeyed into the wilderness by the way of the Red Sea, as the Lord instructed, and circled Mount Seir for many days. The Lord told me it was time to turn northward and pass through the territory of our relatives, the descendants of Esau in Seir. They would be afraid of us, but we were not to provoke them because their land was not ours to take. We were to buy food and water from them, for the Lord had blessed us in all our work and had been with us for forty years, ensuring we lacked nothing.

We passed by our relatives, the descendants of Esau in Seir, and continued through the wilderness of Moab. The Lord instructed us not to harass the Moabites or engage them in battle, as their land was given to the descendants of Lot. The Emims, a great and tall people like the Anakims, once lived there, but the Moabites called them Emims. The Horims also lived in Seir before the descendants of Esau took over. The Lord told us to cross the brook Zered, and we did. It took thirty-eight years from Kadeshbarnea until the entire generation of fighting men perished, as the Lord had sworn.

When all the fighting men had died, the Lord told me to pass through Ar, the territory of Moab, and not to harass the Ammonites, as their land was given to the descendants of Lot. The land of the Ammonites was also considered a land of giants, called Zamzummims, who were great and tall like the Anakims. The Lord destroyed them before the Ammonites, who took over their land. The same happened with the descendants of Esau in Seir and the Avims in Hazerim, who were replaced by the Caphtorims.

The Lord then instructed us to cross the river Arnon and take possession of the land of Sihon, king of Heshbon. He promised to instill fear and dread of us in all nations under heaven. I sent messengers to Sihon with words of peace, asking to pass through his land, buying food and water as needed. But Sihon refused because the Lord had hardened his spirit to deliver him into our hands. We fought Sihon and his people at Jahaz, and the Lord delivered them to us. We captured all their cities and destroyed everyone, taking only the cattle and spoils for ourselves.

We did not take the land of the Ammonites or any place forbidden by the Lord. We then turned and went up to Bashan, where Og, king of Bashan, came out to fight us at Edrei. The Lord told us not to fear him, for He would deliver Og and his land into our hands. We defeated Og and his people, capturing all his cities, which were fortified with high walls, gates, and bars. We destroyed everyone in the cities but took the cattle and spoils. We took the land from the two Amorite kings, from the river Arnon to Mount Hermon. The Sidonians called Hermon Sirion, and the Amorites called it Shenir. We gave the land to the Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh.The Lord your God has given you this land to possess. All your warriors must cross over armed, ahead of your fellow Israelites. But your wives, children, and livestock (since you have many) will stay in the cities I have given you until the Lord gives rest to your fellow Israelites as He has to you, and they too possess the land the Lord your God is giving them across the Jordan. Then you may return to your own land.

I instructed Joshua at that time, saying, "You have seen all that the Lord your God has done to these two kings. The Lord will do the same to all the kingdoms you are going to. Do not be afraid of them, for the Lord your God will fight for you."

I pleaded with the Lord at that time, saying, "O Lord God, you have begun to show your servant your greatness and your mighty hand. What god in heaven or on earth can do the deeds and mighty works you do? Please let me cross over and see the good land beyond the Jordan, that fine hill country and Lebanon." But the Lord was angry with me because of you and would not listen. The Lord said to me, "That is enough. Do not speak to me anymore about this matter. Go up to the top of Pisgah and look west, north, south, and east. Look at the land with your own eyes, since you are not going to cross this Jordan. But commission Joshua, and encourage and strengthen him, for he will lead this people across and will cause them to inherit the land you will see." So we stayed in the valley near Beth Peor.

Now, Israel, listen to the statutes and laws I am teaching you to follow, so that you may live and go in and take possession of the land the Lord, the God of your ancestors, is giving you. Do not add to what I command you and do not subtract from it, but keep the commands of the Lord your God that I give you. You saw with your own eyes what the Lord did at Baal Peor. The Lord your God destroyed from among you everyone who followed the Baal of Peor, but all of you who held fast to the Lord your God are still alive today.

See, I have taught you decrees and laws as the Lord my God commanded me, so that you may follow them in the land you are entering to take possession of it. Observe them carefully, for this will show your wisdom and understanding to the nations, who will hear about all these decrees and say, "Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people." What other nation is so great as to have their gods near them the way the Lord our God is near us whenever we pray to him? And what other nation is so great as to have such righteous decrees and laws as this body of laws I am setting before you today?

Only be careful and watch yourselves closely so that you do not forget the things your eyes have seen or let them fade from your heart as long as you live. Teach them to your children and to their children after them. Remember the day you stood before the Lord your God at Horeb, when he said to me, "Assemble the people before me to hear my words so that they may learn to revere me as long as they live in the land and may teach them to their children." You came near and stood at the foot of the mountain while it blazed with fire to the very heavens, with black clouds and deep darkness. Then the Lord spoke to you out of the fire. You heard the sound of words but saw no form; there was only a voice. He declared to you his covenant, the Ten Commandments, which he commanded you to follow and then wrote them on two stone tablets. At that time the Lord directed me to teach you the decrees and laws you are to follow in the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess.

Be very careful, since you saw no form when the Lord spoke to you at Horeb out of the fire. Do not become corrupt and make for yourselves an idol, an image of any shape, whether formed like a man or a woman, or like any animal on earth or any bird that flies in the air, or like any creature that moves along the ground or any fish in the waters below. And when you look up to the sky and see the sun, the moon, and the stars—all the heavenly array—do not be enticed into bowing down to them and worshiping things the Lord your God has apportioned to all the nations under heaven. But as for you, the Lord took you and brought you out of the iron-smelting furnace, out of Egypt, to be the people of his inheritance, as you now are.

The Lord was angry with me because of you, and he solemnly swore that I would not cross the Jordan and enter the good land the Lord your God is giving you as your inheritance. I will die in this land; I will not cross the Jordan. But you are about to cross over and take possession of that good land. Be careful not to forget the covenant of the Lord your God that he made with you; do not make for yourselves an idol in the form of anything the Lord your God has forbidden. For the Lord your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.

After you have had children and grandchildren and have lived in the land a long time—if you then become corrupt and make any kind of idol, doing evil in the eyes of the Lord your God and arousing his anger—I call the heavens and the earth as witnesses against you this day that you will quickly perish from the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess. You will not live there long but will certainly be destroyed. The Lord will scatter you among the peoples, and only a few of you will survive among the nations to which the Lord will drive you. There you will worship man-made gods of wood and stone, which cannot see or hear or eat or smell. But if from there you seek the Lord your God, you will find him if you seek him with all your heart and with all your soul. When you are in distress and all these things have happened to you, then in later days you will return to the Lord your God and obey him. For the Lord your God is a merciful God; he will not abandon or destroy you or forget the covenant with your ancestors, which he confirmed to them by oath.

Ask now about the former days, long before your time, from the day God created human beings on the earth; ask from one end of the heavens to the other. Has anything so great as this ever happened, or has anything like it ever been heard of? Has any other people heard the voice of God speaking out of fire, as you have, and lived? Has any god ever tried to take for himself one nation out of another nation, by testings, by signs and wonders, by war, by a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, or by great and awesome deeds, like all the things the Lord your God did for you in Egypt before your very eyes?

You were shown these things so that you might know that the Lord is God; besides him, there is no other. From heaven, he made you hear his voice to discipline you. On earth, he showed you his great fire, and you heard his words from out of the fire. Because he loved your ancestors and chose their descendants after them, he brought you out of Egypt by his Presence and his great strength, to drive out before you nations greater and stronger than you and to bring you into their land to give it to you for your inheritance, as it is today.

Acknowledge and take to heart this day that the Lord is God in heaven above and on the earth below. There is no other. Keep his decrees and commands, which I am giving you today, so that it may go well with you and your children after you and that you may live long in the land the Lord your God gives you for all time.

Then Moses set aside three cities east of the Jordan, to which anyone who had killed a person could flee if they had unintentionally killed a neighbor without malice aforethought. They could flee into one of these cities and save their life. The cities were Bezer in the wilderness on the plateau, for the Reubenites; Ramoth in Gilead, for the Gadites; and Golan in Bashan, for the Manassites.

This is the law Moses set before the Israelites. These are the stipulations, decrees, and laws Moses gave them when they came out of Egypt and were in the valley near Beth Peor east of the Jordan, in the land of Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon and was defeated by Moses and the Israelites as they came out of Egypt. They took possession of his land and the land of Og king of Bashan, the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan. This land extended from Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge to Mount Sirion (that is, Hermon), and included all the Arabah east of the Jordan, as far as the Dead Sea, below the slopes of Pisgah.

Moses summoned all Israel and said: "Hear, Israel, the decrees and laws I declare in your hearing today. Learn them and be sure to follow them."The Lord our God made a covenant with us at Horeb. This covenant wasn't just with our ancestors but with all of us who are alive today. The Lord spoke to you face to face from the fire on the mountain. I stood between the Lord and you at that time to relay His words because you were afraid of the fire and didn't go up the mountain. He said:

"I am the Lord your God who brought you out of Egypt, out of slavery. You shall have no other gods before me. Do not make any idols or images of anything in heaven, on earth, or in the waters. Do not bow down to them or worship them, for I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God. I will punish the children for the sins of the parents to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me, but I will show love to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.

Do not misuse the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not hold anyone guiltless who misuses His name. Observe the Sabbath day by keeping it holy, as the Lord your God has commanded you. Six days you shall labor and do all your work, but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the Lord your God. On it, you shall not do any work, neither you, nor your son or daughter, nor your male or female servant, nor your ox, donkey, or any of your animals, nor any foreigner residing in your towns, so that your male and female servants may rest as you do. Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and that the Lord your God brought you out of there with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm. Therefore, the Lord your God has commanded you to observe the Sabbath day.

Honor your father and your mother, as the Lord your God has commanded you, so that you may live long and that it may go well with you in the land the Lord your God is giving you. You shall not murder. You shall not commit adultery. You shall not steal. You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor. You shall not covet your neighbor's wife. You shall not set your desire on your neighbor's house or land, his male or female servant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor."

These are the commandments the Lord proclaimed in a loud voice to your whole assembly on the mountain from out of the fire, the cloud, and the deep darkness; and He added nothing more. Then He wrote them on two stone tablets and gave them to me.

When you heard the voice out of the darkness while the mountain was ablaze with fire, all the leaders of your tribes and your elders came to me. You said, "The Lord our God has shown us His glory and His majesty, and we have heard His voice from the fire. Today we have seen that a person can live even if God speaks with them. But now, why should we die? This great fire will consume us, and we will die if we hear the voice of the Lord our God any longer. For what mortal has ever heard the voice of the living God speaking out of fire, as we have, and survived? Go near and listen to all that the Lord our God says. Then tell us whatever the Lord our God tells you. We will listen and obey."

The Lord heard you when you spoke to me, and He said, "I have heard what this people said to you. Everything they said was good. Oh, that their hearts would be inclined to fear me and keep all my commands always, so that it might go well with them and their children forever! Go, tell them to return to their tents. But you stay here with me so that I may give you all the commands, decrees, and laws you are to teach them to follow in the land I am giving them to possess."

So be careful to do what the Lord your God has commanded you; do not turn aside to the right or to the left. Walk in obedience to all that the Lord your God has commanded you, so that you may live and prosper and prolong your days in the land that you will possess.

These are the commands, decrees, and laws the Lord your God directed me to teach you to observe in the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess, so that you, your children, and their children after them may fear the Lord your God as long as you live by keeping all His decrees and commands that I give you, and so that you may enjoy long life. Hear, Israel, and be careful to obey so that it may go well with you and that you may increase greatly in a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your ancestors, promised you.

Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one. Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength. These commandments that I give you today are to be on your hearts. Impress them on your children. Talk about them when you sit at home and when you walk along the road, when you lie down and when you get up. Tie them as symbols on your hands and bind them on your foreheads. Write them on the doorframes of your houses and on your gates.

When the Lord your God brings you into the land He swore to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, to give you—a land with large, flourishing cities you did not build, houses filled with all kinds of good things you did not provide, wells you did not dig, and vineyards and olive groves you did not plant—then when you eat and are satisfied, be careful that you do not forget the Lord, who brought you out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery. Fear the Lord your God, serve Him only, and take your oaths in His name. Do not follow other gods, the gods of the peoples around you; for the Lord your God, who is among you, is a jealous God and His anger will burn against you, and He will destroy you from the face of the land. Do not put the Lord your God to the test as you did at Massah. Be sure to keep the commands of the Lord your God and the stipulations and decrees He has given you. Do what is right and good in the Lord's sight, so that it may go well with you and you may go in and take over the good land the Lord promised on oath to your ancestors, thrusting out all your enemies before you, as the Lord said.

In the future, when your son asks you, "What is the meaning of the stipulations, decrees, and laws the Lord our God has commanded you?" tell him: "We were slaves of Pharaoh in Egypt, but the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand. Before our eyes, the Lord sent signs and wonders—great and terrible—on Egypt and Pharaoh and his whole household. But He brought us out from there to bring us in and give us the land He promised on oath to our ancestors. The Lord commanded us to obey all these decrees and to fear the Lord our God, so that we might always prosper and be kept alive, as is the case today. And if we are careful to obey all this law before the Lord our God, as He has commanded us, that will be our righteousness."

When the Lord your God brings you into the land you are entering to possess and drives out many nations before you—the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, seven nations larger and stronger than you—and when the Lord your God has delivered them over to you and you have defeated them, then you must destroy them totally. Make no treaty with them and show them no mercy. Do not intermarry with them. Do not give your daughters to their sons or take their daughters for your sons, for they will turn your children away from following me to serve other gods, and the Lord's anger will burn against you and will quickly destroy you. This is what you are to do to them: Break down their altars, smash their sacred stones, cut down their Asherah poles, and burn their idols in the fire. For you are a people holy to the Lord your God. The Lord your God has chosen you out of all the peoples on the face of the earth to be His people, His treasured possession.

The Lord did not set His affection on you and choose you because you were more numerous than other peoples, for you were the fewest of all peoples. But it was because the Lord loved you and kept the oath He swore to your ancestors that He brought you out with a mighty hand and redeemed you from the land of slavery, from the power of Pharaoh king of Egypt. Know therefore that the Lord your God is God; He is the faithful God, keeping His covenant of love to a thousand generations of those who love Him and keep His commandments. But those who hate Him, He will repay to their face by destruction; He will not be slow to repay to their face those who hate Him. Therefore, take care to follow the commands, decrees, and laws I give you today."Follow these rules and laws carefully, as the Lord your God has commanded. If you do, He will keep His promise to your ancestors, showing you love, blessing you, and making you prosper. He will bless your children, your crops, your livestock, and everything you own. You will be more blessed than any other people, with no one among you or your animals being barren. The Lord will protect you from sickness and will place the diseases of Egypt on your enemies instead.

Destroy all the people the Lord delivers to you without pity, and do not worship their gods, as that will trap you. If you think these nations are too strong to defeat, remember what the Lord did to Pharaoh and Egypt. He will do the same to these nations, sending hornets to drive them out. Do not fear them, for the Lord your God is with you, a powerful and awesome God. He will gradually drive out these nations to prevent wild animals from becoming too numerous. The Lord will deliver their kings into your hands, and you will destroy their names from under heaven. No one will be able to stand against you.

Burn the images of their gods and do not desire the silver or gold on them, as it is detestable to the Lord. Do not bring any detestable thing into your house, or you will be cursed like it. Detest and abhor it, for it is cursed.

Follow all the commandments I give you today so that you may live, multiply, and possess the land the Lord promised to your ancestors. Remember how the Lord led you through the wilderness for forty years to humble and test you, to know what was in your heart. He humbled you by letting you hunger and then feeding you with manna, teaching you that man does not live by bread alone but by every word from the Lord. Your clothes did not wear out, and your feet did not swell during those forty years. Know in your heart that the Lord disciplines you as a father disciplines his son. Keep His commandments, walk in His ways, and fear Him.

The Lord is bringing you into a good land with streams, springs, and fertile valleys. It is a land of wheat, barley, vines, fig trees, pomegranates, olive oil, and honey. You will lack nothing and have abundant resources. When you have eaten and are satisfied, praise the Lord for the good land He has given you. Be careful not to forget the Lord by failing to keep His commandments, judgments, and statutes. When you are prosperous, do not let your heart become proud and forget the Lord who brought you out of Egypt, through the wilderness, and provided for you. Remember that it is the Lord who gives you the ability to produce wealth, confirming His covenant with your ancestors.

If you forget the Lord and follow other gods, you will surely perish like the nations the Lord is destroying before you. Listen, Israel: You are crossing the Jordan to possess nations greater and stronger than you, with large fortified cities. The Lord will go before you as a consuming fire, destroying them quickly. Do not think it is because of your righteousness that the Lord is giving you this land; it is because of the wickedness of these nations. The Lord is fulfilling His promise to your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Understand that it is not because of your righteousness, for you are a stubborn people.

Remember how you provoked the Lord to anger in the wilderness, from the day you left Egypt until you reached this place. At Horeb, you made the Lord so angry that He wanted to destroy you. When I went up the mountain to receive the stone tablets of the covenant, I stayed there forty days and nights without eating or drinking. The Lord gave me the two stone tablets inscribed by His finger, containing all the words He spoke to you from the fire on the mountain. After forty days and nights, the Lord gave me the tablets and told me to go down quickly because the people had corrupted themselves by making an idol. The Lord called them a stiff-necked people and wanted to destroy them, but I prayed for them, and the Lord listened.

I came down from the mountain with the two tablets, saw the sin you committed, and broke the tablets before your eyes. I then lay prostrate before the Lord for another forty days and nights, without eating or drinking, because of your sin. I prayed for Aaron, whom the Lord was also angry with, and took the calf you made, burned it, ground it to dust, and threw the dust into the brook. You provoked the Lord at Taberah, Massah, and Kibroth Hattaavah. When the Lord sent you from Kadesh Barnea to possess the land, you rebelled and did not trust or obey Him. You have been rebellious against the Lord from the day I knew you."I prayed to the Lord for forty days and nights, asking Him not to destroy His people, whom He had saved from Egypt with His great power. I reminded Him of His promises to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and asked Him not to look at the stubbornness and sins of the people. I feared that other nations would think the Lord couldn't bring us into the promised land and had brought us out to kill us in the wilderness. 

The Lord then told me to carve two stone tablets like the first ones and come up the mountain. He would write the same words on these tablets, and I was to place them in a wooden ark. I did as He commanded, and He wrote the Ten Commandments on the new tablets. I came down the mountain and placed the tablets in the ark.

The Israelites traveled from Beeroth to Mosera, where Aaron died and was buried, and his son Eleazar took over as priest. They continued their journey to Gudgodah and then to Jotbath, a land with streams of water. At that time, the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the ark of the covenant, to serve Him, and to bless in His name. The Levites have no inheritance among their brothers; the Lord is their inheritance.

I stayed on the mountain for another forty days and nights, and the Lord listened to me again and did not destroy the people. He told me to lead the people to possess the land He promised to their ancestors.

Now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you? To fear Him, walk in His ways, love Him, and serve Him with all your heart and soul. Keep His commandments for your own good. The heavens and the earth belong to the Lord, yet He chose your ancestors and their descendants above all people. Therefore, do not be stubborn. The Lord your God is the greatest, showing no partiality and accepting no bribes. He defends the cause of the fatherless and the widow and loves the foreigner, providing them with food and clothing. So, love the foreigner, for you were foreigners in Egypt. Fear the Lord your God, serve Him, hold fast to Him, and take your oaths in His name. He is your praise and your God, who has done great and awesome things for you. Your ancestors went down to Egypt with seventy people, and now the Lord has made you as numerous as the stars in the sky.

Love the Lord your God and keep His commandments always. Remember the great things He has done, including the miracles in Egypt and the wilderness. Keep His commandments so you may be strong and possess the land He promised to your ancestors, a land flowing with milk and honey. The land you are entering is not like Egypt, where you had to irrigate your fields. It is a land of hills and valleys that drinks rain from heaven, a land the Lord cares for. If you obey His commands, He will send rain in its season, and you will gather your grain, wine, and oil. He will provide grass for your cattle, and you will have plenty to eat. Be careful not to be deceived and turn to other gods, or the Lord's anger will burn against you, and He will shut up the heavens so that it will not rain, and the ground will yield no produce.

Fix these words in your hearts and minds, tie them as symbols on your hands, and bind them on your foreheads. Teach them to your children, talking about them at home and on the road, when you lie down and get up. Write them on the doorframes of your houses and on your gates, so that your days and the days of your children may be many in the land the Lord swore to give your ancestors.

If you carefully observe all these commands, love the Lord your God, walk in His ways, and hold fast to Him, He will drive out all these nations before you, and you will dispossess nations larger and stronger than you. Every place where you set your foot will be yours. No one will be able to stand against you, for the Lord your God will put the fear and dread of you on all the land you set foot on.

Today, I set before you a blessing and a curse: a blessing if you obey the commands of the Lord your God, and a curse if you disobey and turn to other gods. When the Lord brings you into the land, proclaim the blessing on Mount Gerizim and the curse on Mount Ebal. These mountains are across the Jordan, westward, near the Canaanites. You are about to cross the Jordan to possess the land the Lord your God is giving you. Be sure to obey all the decrees and laws I am setting before you today.

These are the decrees and laws you must follow in the land the Lord your God is giving you. Destroy all the places where the nations you are dispossessing worship their gods, whether on high mountains, hills, or under spreading trees. Break down their altars, smash their sacred stones, burn their Asherah poles, and cut down the idols of their gods, wiping out their names from those places. Do not worship the Lord your God in the same way. Seek the place the Lord your God will choose from among all your tribes to put His name there for His dwelling.Bring your offerings, vows, and freewill gifts, along with the firstborn of your herds and flocks, to the place the Lord chooses. There, you and your households will eat and rejoice in all the blessings the Lord has given you. Don't do as we do here today, where everyone does as they see fit. You haven't yet reached the resting place and inheritance the Lord is giving you. 

When you cross the Jordan and settle in the land the Lord is giving you, and He grants you rest from your enemies, then bring all your offerings to the place He chooses for His name to dwell. Rejoice there with your families and the Levites, who have no inheritance of their own. Be careful not to offer your burnt offerings anywhere you like, but only at the place the Lord chooses. 

You may slaughter and eat meat within your towns whenever you desire, as the Lord has blessed you. Both the ceremonially clean and unclean may eat it, just as you would eat gazelle or deer. However, do not consume the blood; pour it out on the ground like water. 

You must not eat the tithe of your grain, new wine, or oil, or the firstborn of your herds and flocks, or any of your vowed offerings, or freewill offerings, or special gifts within your towns. Instead, eat them in the presence of the Lord at the place He chooses, along with your family and the Levites. Rejoice in all you do, and do not neglect the Levites as long as you live in your land.

When the Lord enlarges your territory, and you desire to eat meat, you may do so as you wish. If the place the Lord chooses is too far, you may slaughter animals from your herds and flocks as He has commanded and eat them in your towns. Both the clean and unclean may eat it, just as you would eat gazelle or deer. But be sure not to consume the blood, for the blood is the life, and you must not eat the life with the meat. Pour it out on the ground like water. Do not eat it, so that it may go well with you and your children after you, for doing what is right in the Lord's eyes.

Take your holy offerings and vows to the place the Lord chooses. Offer your burnt offerings on the altar of the Lord, and pour out the blood beside the altar. Eat the meat. Be careful to obey all these commands so that it may go well with you and your children forever, for doing what is good and right in the Lord's eyes.

When the Lord cuts off the nations before you and you take their land, be careful not to be ensnared by their ways. Do not inquire about their gods, asking how they worship, and do not imitate them. The Lord detests their practices, including burning their sons and daughters in the fire. Follow only what the Lord commands you; do not add or take away from it.
