If a prophet or dreamer arises and performs a sign or wonder, and then says, "Let's follow other gods," do not listen. The Lord is testing you to see if you love Him with all your heart and soul. Follow the Lord, fear Him, keep His commands, obey His voice, serve Him, and hold fast to Him. That prophet or dreamer must be put to death for inciting rebellion against the Lord, who brought you out of Egypt. Purge the evil from among you.

If your brother, son, daughter, wife, or closest friend secretly entices you to worship other gods, do not yield or listen. Show no pity or concealment; you must kill them. Your hand must be the first to put them to death, followed by the hands of all the people. Stone them to death for trying to turn you away from the Lord. All Israel will hear and be afraid, and no one will do such wickedness again.

If you hear that wicked men have led a city astray to worship other gods, investigate thoroughly. If it is true, destroy the city and all its inhabitants and livestock with the sword. Gather all the plunder in the public square and burn the city and everything in it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. It must remain a ruin forever, never to be rebuilt. Keep none of the plunder, so the Lord may turn from His fierce anger and show you mercy, compassion, and increase your numbers, as He promised your ancestors. Obey the Lord's commands, doing what is right in His eyes.

You are the children of the Lord. Do not cut yourselves or shave your foreheads for the dead, for you are a holy people chosen by the Lord to be His treasured possession. Do not eat anything detestable. You may eat ox, sheep, goat, deer, gazelle, roe deer, wild goat, ibex, antelope, and mountain sheep. You may eat any animal that has a split hoof and chews the cud. However, do not eat camels, rabbits, or coneys, as they chew the cud but do not have a split hoof; they are unclean. Do not eat pigs, as they have a split hoof but do not chew the cud; they are unclean. Do not eat their meat or touch their carcasses. 

You may eat any fish with fins and scales, but do not eat those without fins and scales; they are unclean. You may eat any clean bird, but do not eat eagles, vultures, kites, ravens, owls, hawks, and other unclean birds. Do not eat any flying insects that are unclean. You may eat any clean bird.You must not eat anything that dies naturally. Instead, give it to a foreigner living in your town, or sell it to a foreigner. Remember, you are a holy people to the Lord your God. Do not cook a young goat in its mother's milk.

Set aside a tenth of all your produce each year. Eat it in the presence of the Lord at the place He chooses, so you may learn to revere Him always. If the place is too far and you can't carry your tithe, convert it to money and take it to the place the Lord chooses. Use the money to buy whatever you desire—cattle, sheep, wine, or other drinks—and enjoy it there with your household. Don't forget the Levites in your town, as they have no inheritance of their own.

Every three years, bring all the tithes of that year's produce and store them in your towns. This will provide for the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows, so they may eat and be satisfied. Then the Lord your God will bless you in all the work of your hands.

At the end of every seven years, cancel debts. This is how it is to be done: every creditor shall cancel any loan they have made to a fellow Israelite. They must not demand payment from anyone among their own people, because the Lord's time for canceling debts has been proclaimed. You may require payment from a foreigner, but you must cancel any debt your fellow Israelite owes you. There should be no poor among you, for the Lord will bless you in the land He is giving you to possess as your inheritance, if only you fully obey Him and carefully follow all His commands.

The Lord will bless you as He promised, and you will lend to many nations but borrow from none. You will rule over many nations, but none will rule over you. If anyone is poor among your fellow Israelites in any of the towns of the land the Lord is giving you, do not be hardhearted or tightfisted toward them. Rather, be openhanded and freely lend them whatever they need. Be careful not to harbor this wicked thought: "The seventh year, the year for canceling debts, is near," so that you do not show ill will toward the needy among your fellow Israelites and give them nothing. They may then appeal to the Lord against you, and you will be found guilty of sin. Give generously to them and do so without a grudging heart; then because of this, the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and in everything you put your hand to. There will always be poor people in the land. Therefore, I command you to be openhanded toward your fellow Israelites who are poor and needy in your land.

If any of your people—Hebrew men or women—sell themselves to you and serve you for six years, in the seventh year you must let them go free. And when you release them, do not send them away empty-handed. Supply them liberally from your flock, your threshing floor, and your winepress. Give to them as the Lord your God has blessed you. Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and the Lord your God redeemed you. That is why I give you this command today. But if your servant says to you, "I do not want to leave you," because they love you and your family and are well off with you, then take an awl and push it through their earlobe into the door, and they will become your servant for life. Do the same for your female servant.

Do not consider it a hardship to set your servant free, because their service to you these six years has been worth twice as much as that of a hired hand. And the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.

Set apart for the Lord your God every firstborn male of your herds and flocks. Do not put the firstborn of your cows to work, and do not shear the firstborn of your sheep. Each year you and your family are to eat them in the presence of the Lord your God at the place He will choose. If an animal has a defect, is lame or blind, or has any serious flaw, you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God. You are to eat it in your own towns. Both the ceremonially unclean and the clean may eat it, as if it were gazelle or deer. But you must not eat the blood; pour it out on the ground like water.

Observe the month of Abib and celebrate the Passover to the Lord your God, because in the month of Abib He brought you out of Egypt by night. Sacrifice as the Passover to the Lord your God an animal from your flock or herd at the place the Lord will choose as a dwelling for His Name. Do not eat it with bread made with yeast, but for seven days eat unleavened bread, the bread of affliction, because you left Egypt in haste—so that all the days of your life you may remember the time of your departure from Egypt. Let no yeast be found in your possession in all your land for seven days. Do not let any of the meat you sacrifice on the evening of the first day remain until morning.

You must not sacrifice the Passover in any town the Lord your God gives you except in the place He will choose as a dwelling for His Name. There you must sacrifice the Passover in the evening, when the sun goes down, on the anniversary of your departure from Egypt. Roast it and eat it at the place the Lord your God will choose. Then in the morning return to your tents. For six days eat unleavened bread and on the seventh day hold an assembly to the Lord your God and do no work.

Count off seven weeks from the time you begin to put the sickle to the standing grain. Then celebrate the Festival of Weeks to the Lord your God by giving a freewill offering in proportion to the blessings the Lord your God has given you. Rejoice before the Lord your God at the place He will choose as a dwelling for His Name—you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, the Levites in your towns, and the foreigners, the fatherless, and the widows living among you. Remember that you were slaves in Egypt, and follow carefully these decrees.

Celebrate the Festival of Tabernacles for seven days after you have gathered the produce of your threshing floor and your winepress. Be joyful at your festival—you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the Levites, the foreigners, the fatherless, and the widows who live in your towns. For seven days celebrate the festival to the Lord your God at the place the Lord will choose. For the Lord your God will bless you in all your harvest and in all the work of your hands, and your joy will be complete.

Three times a year all your men must appear before the Lord your God at the place He will choose: at the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Tabernacles. No one should appear before the Lord empty-handed: each of you must bring a gift in proportion to the way the Lord your God has blessed you.

Appoint judges and officials for each of your tribes in every town the Lord your God is giving you, and they shall judge the people fairly. Do not pervert justice or show partiality. Do not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds the eyes of the wise and twists the words of the innocent. Follow justice and justice alone, so that you may live and possess the land the Lord your God is giving you.

Do not set up any wooden Asherah pole beside the altar you build to the Lord your God, and do not erect a sacred stone, for these the Lord your God hates.

Do not sacrifice to the Lord your God an ox or a sheep that has any defect or flaw in it, for that would be detestable to Him. If a man or woman living among you in one of the towns the Lord gives you is found doing evil in the eyes of the Lord your God in violation of His covenant, and contrary to My command has worshiped other gods, bowing down to them or to the sun or the moon or the stars in the sky, and this has been brought to your attention, then you must investigate it thoroughly. If it is true and it has been proved that this detestable thing has been done in Israel...If you hear about someone committing a terrible act in Israel, investigate it thoroughly. If it's true, bring the guilty man or woman to the city gates and stone them to death. A person can only be sentenced to death if there are two or three witnesses; one witness is not enough. The witnesses must be the first to throw stones, followed by the rest of the people, to remove the evil from among you.

If a legal case is too difficult to decide, go to the place the Lord chooses and consult the priests and judges. Follow their decision exactly. Anyone who disobeys the priest or judge must be put to death to eliminate the evil from Israel. This will make the people hear and fear, preventing further disobedience.

When you enter the land God gives you and decide to appoint a king, choose one God selects from among your fellow Israelites. The king must not acquire many horses, return the people to Egypt, or accumulate excessive wealth. He must write a copy of the law, read it daily, and follow it to remain humble and obedient, ensuring a long reign for him and his descendants.

The Levite priests will have no inheritance in Israel; they will live off the offerings made to God. They are entitled to a portion of the sacrifices and the firstfruits of grain, wine, oil, and wool. If a Levite moves to the place God chooses, he can serve there like other Levites and share in the offerings.

When you enter the land God gives you, do not adopt the detestable practices of the nations there. Do not sacrifice your children, practice divination, sorcery, witchcraft, or consult the dead. These practices are detestable to God and the reason He drives out those nations. Be blameless before God.

God will raise a prophet from among you, like Moses, to whom you must listen. This prophet will speak God's words, and anyone who does not listen will be held accountable. A false prophet who speaks without God's command or in the name of other gods must be put to death. You can identify a false prophet if their predictions do not come true.

When God gives you the land and you settle in it, designate three cities as places of refuge for anyone who accidentally kills someone. This will protect them from revenge until they can stand trial. If God expands your territory, add three more cities to prevent innocent bloodshed. However, if someone kills out of hatred and flees to a refuge city, the elders must hand them over to the avenger of blood.

Do not move your neighbor's boundary markers set by previous generations. A single witness is not enough to convict someone of a crime; there must be two or three witnesses. If a false witness accuses someone, both parties must stand before the priests and judges. If the witness is proven false, they will receive the punishment they intended for the accused. This will deter others from committing such evil.

When you go to war and see a larger enemy force, do not be afraid because God is with you.When you are about to go into battle, the priest will address the people, saying, "Listen, Israel, today you are going into battle against your enemies. Do not lose heart or be afraid; do not panic or be terrified by them. For the Lord your God is with you to fight for you and save you."

The officers will then speak to the people, asking if anyone has built a new house but not yet dedicated it, planted a vineyard but not yet enjoyed its fruit, or become engaged but not yet married. These individuals should return home to avoid dying in battle and having someone else take their place. Additionally, anyone who is afraid or fainthearted should also return home to prevent demoralizing others.

Once the officers have finished speaking, they will appoint commanders to lead the troops.

When you approach a city to attack it, first offer peace. If the city accepts and opens its gates, its people will become your subjects and serve you. If they refuse and choose to fight, lay siege to the city. When the Lord your God delivers it into your hands, kill all the men, but take the women, children, livestock, and everything else as plunder. This is how you should treat cities far from you that do not belong to nearby nations.

For the cities of the nations the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, do not leave anything alive. Completely destroy the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, as the Lord has commanded, to prevent them from teaching you their detestable practices and leading you to sin against the Lord.

When you lay siege to a city for a long time, do not destroy its trees by cutting them down with an axe, as you can eat their fruit. Only cut down trees that you know are not fruit trees to build siege works until the city falls.

If someone is found murdered in the land the Lord your God is giving you, and the killer is unknown, the elders and judges must measure the distance to the surrounding cities. The elders of the nearest city will take a heifer that has never been worked or yoked, bring it to a valley with running water, and break its neck there. The priests, the sons of Levi, will come forward, as they are chosen by the Lord to minister and pronounce blessings. The elders will wash their hands over the heifer and declare their innocence, asking the Lord to forgive His people and not hold them accountable for the innocent blood. This will absolve the community of guilt.

When you go to war and take captives, if you see a beautiful woman among them and want her as your wife, bring her to your home. She must shave her head, trim her nails, and change her clothes. She will mourn her parents for a month, after which you may marry her. If you are not pleased with her, let her go free; do not sell her or treat her as a slave.

If a man has two wives, one loved and the other unloved, and both bear him sons, he must acknowledge the firstborn son of the unloved wife by giving him a double portion of his inheritance. The firstborn has the right of the firstborn, regardless of the father's feelings.

If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not obey his parents even after discipline, the parents must bring him to the city elders and declare his disobedience. The men of the city will stone him to death to remove the evil from among you, and all Israel will hear and be afraid.

If someone is guilty of a capital offense and is executed by hanging on a tree, do not leave the body hanging overnight. Bury it the same day, as anyone hung on a tree is under God's curse. This will prevent defiling the land the Lord your God is giving you.

If you see your brother's ox or sheep straying, do not ignore it. Return it to your brother. If your brother is not nearby or you do not know who owns it, take it home and keep it until your brother comes looking for it. Do the same with any lost item you find. Do not ignore it.

If you see your brother's donkey or ox fallen on the road, do not ignore it. Help him get it back on its feet.

A woman must not wear men's clothing, and a man must not wear women's clothing, for this is detestable to the Lord your God.

If you find a bird's nest with chicks or eggs, do not take the mother with the young. Let the mother go and take only the young, so that it may go well with you and you may have a long life.

When you build a new house, make a parapet for your roof to prevent anyone from falling off and bringing bloodshed on your house.

Do not plant two kinds of seeds in your vineyard, or the entire crop will be defiled. Do not plow with an ox and a donkey yoked together. Do not wear clothes of wool and linen woven together. Make tassels on the four corners of the cloak you wear.

If a man marries a woman, has relations with her, and then dislikes her, falsely accusing her of not being a virgin, the woman's parents must bring proof of her virginity to the city elders. The elders will punish the man, fine him a hundred shekels of silver, and give the money to the woman's father. The woman will remain his wife, and he cannot divorce her as long as he lives. If the accusation is true and no proof of the woman's virginity is found, she will be brought to the door of her father's house and stoned to death by the men of her city for dishonoring her father's house. This will remove the evil from among you.If a woman cannot prove her virginity, she will be taken to her father's house and stoned to death by the men of the city for bringing disgrace to her family. This will remove the evil from among you.

If a man is caught sleeping with another man's wife, both the man and the woman must be put to death to eliminate the evil from Israel.

If a virgin who is engaged is found sleeping with another man in the city, both must be taken to the city gate and stoned to death. The woman is punished for not crying out for help, and the man for violating another man's wife. This will remove the evil from among you.

If a man rapes an engaged woman in the countryside, only the man must die. The woman is not guilty because she cried for help, but no one was there to save her.

If a man rapes a virgin who is not engaged, he must pay her father fifty shekels of silver and marry her. He cannot divorce her for as long as he lives.

A man must not marry his father's wife or dishonor his father's bed.

A man with damaged genitals or a severed penis cannot enter the assembly of the Lord.

A child born out of wedlock cannot enter the assembly of the Lord, even to the tenth generation.

An Ammonite or Moabite cannot enter the assembly of the Lord, even to the tenth generation, because they did not help you with food and water when you came out of Egypt and hired Balaam to curse you. However, the Lord turned the curse into a blessing because He loves you. Do not seek peace or prosperity for them as long as you live.

Do not despise an Edomite, for he is your brother. Do not despise an Egyptian, for you were a stranger in his land. The children born to them may enter the assembly of the Lord in the third generation.

When you go to war, avoid anything impure. If a man becomes unclean due to a nocturnal emission, he must go outside the camp and stay there until evening. He must wash himself with water, and at sunset, he may return to the camp.

Designate a place outside the camp where you can relieve yourself. Carry a tool to dig a hole and cover your excrement. The Lord your God moves within your camp to protect you and deliver your enemies to you. Therefore, keep your camp holy and free from anything indecent.

Do not return a runaway slave to his master. Let him live among you wherever he chooses and do not oppress him.

There must be no prostitutes among the daughters of Israel or male prostitutes among the sons of Israel. Do not bring the earnings of a prostitute or the price of a dog into the house of the Lord your God to fulfill any vow, for both are detestable to the Lord.

Do not charge interest on loans to your fellow Israelites, whether money, food, or anything else. You may charge interest to foreigners, but not to your fellow Israelites, so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything you do in the land you are entering to possess.

If you make a vow to the Lord your God, do not delay in fulfilling it, for the Lord your God will demand it from you, and you will be guilty of sin. If you refrain from making a vow, you will not be guilty. Whatever your lips utter, you must be sure to do, because you made your vow freely to the Lord your God with your own mouth.

When you enter your neighbor's vineyard, you may eat all the grapes you want, but do not put any in your basket. When you enter your neighbor's grainfield, you may pick kernels with your hands, but do not use a sickle to harvest your neighbor's grain.

If a man marries a woman and later finds something indecent about her, he can write her a certificate of divorce, give it to her, and send her away. If she leaves his house and becomes another man's wife, and the second husband dislikes her and writes her a certificate of divorce, or if he dies, her first husband cannot marry her again after she has been defiled. This would be detestable in the eyes of the Lord. Do not bring sin upon the land the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.

If a man has recently married, he must not be sent to war or have any other duty laid on him. For one year, he is to be free to stay at home and bring happiness to the wife he has married.

Do not take a pair of millstones—not even the upper one—as security for a debt, because that would be taking a person's livelihood as security.

If someone is caught kidnapping a fellow Israelite and treating or selling them as a slave, the kidnapper must die. You must purge the evil from among you.

Be careful to follow all the instructions the Levitical priests give you regarding infectious skin diseases. Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam along the way after you came out of Egypt.

When you make a loan to your neighbor, do not go into their house to get what is offered to you as a pledge. Stay outside and let the neighbor bring the pledge out to you. If the neighbor is poor, do not go to sleep with their pledge in your possession. Return their cloak by sunset so that your neighbor may sleep in it and bless you. This will be regarded as a righteous act in the sight of the Lord your God.

Do not take advantage of a hired worker who is poor and needy, whether that worker is a fellow Israelite or a foreigner residing in one of your towns. Pay them their wages each day before sunset because they are poor and counting on it. Otherwise, they may cry to the Lord against you, and you will be guilty of sin.

Parents are not to be put to death for their children, nor children put to death for their parents; each will die for their own sin.

Do not deprive the foreigner or the fatherless of justice, or take the cloak of the widow as a pledge. Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and the Lord your God redeemed you from there. That is why I command you to do this.

When you are harvesting in your field and you overlook a sheaf, do not go back to get it. Leave it for the foreigner, the fatherless, and the widow, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work of your hands. When you beat the olives from your trees, do not go over the branches a second time. Leave what remains for the foreigner, the fatherless, and the widow. When you harvest the grapes in your vineyard, do not go over the vines again. Leave what remains for the foreigner, the fatherless, and the widow. Remember that you were slaves in Egypt. That is why I command you to do this.

If people have a dispute, they are to take it to court, and the judges will decide the case, acquitting the innocent and condemning the guilty. If the guilty person deserves to be beaten, the judge shall make them lie down and have them flogged in his presence with the number of lashes the crime deserves, but no more than forty lashes. If the guilty party is flogged more than that, your fellow Israelite will be degraded in your eyes.

Do not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain.

If brothers are living together and one of them dies without a son, his widow must not marry outside the family. Her husband's brother shall take her and marry her and fulfill the duty of a brother-in-law to her. The first son she bears shall carry on the name of the dead brother so that his name will not be blotted out from Israel.If a man refuses to marry his brother's widow, she should go to the city elders and declare his refusal. The elders will then speak to him. If he still refuses, the widow will remove his shoe and spit in his face, declaring that this is what happens to a man who won't uphold his family duty. His family will be known as "The house of the unsandaled."

If two men are fighting and the wife of one intervenes by grabbing the other man's private parts, her hand must be cut off without pity.

Do not use dishonest weights and measures. Always use accurate and fair weights and measures so that you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you. Dishonest practices are detestable to the Lord.

Remember what the Amalekites did to you on your journey out of Egypt. They attacked those who were lagging behind when you were tired and weary. When the Lord gives you rest from your enemies, you must erase the memory of Amalek from under heaven. Do not forget this.

When you enter the land the Lord your God is giving you, take the first fruits of your harvest, put them in a basket, and go to the place the Lord chooses for His name. Present the basket to the priest and declare that you have come to the land the Lord promised to your ancestors. The priest will place the basket before the altar, and you will recount how your ancestors were oppressed in Egypt and how the Lord delivered them with great signs and wonders. You will then rejoice in all the good things the Lord has given you and your household, along with the Levites and foreigners among you.

In the third year, the year of tithing, give a tenth of your produce to the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows so they may eat and be satisfied. Then declare before the Lord that you have followed His commands and not used the tithe for unclean purposes. Ask the Lord to bless His people and the land He has given you.

The Lord commands you to follow these statutes and judgments with all your heart and soul. You have declared that the Lord is your God and that you will walk in His ways and keep His commands. The Lord has declared that you are His treasured people, and He will set you high above all nations in praise, fame, and honor, making you a holy people to the Lord your God.

Moses and the elders of Israel instructed the people to keep all these commands. When you cross the Jordan River into the land the Lord is giving you, set up large stones and coat them with plaster. Write all the words of this law on them. Build an altar to the Lord your God with uncut stones and offer burnt and peace offerings on it. Rejoice before the Lord your God and write the words of this law clearly on the stones.

Moses and the Levitical priests told all Israel to listen and obey the Lord's commands. When you cross the Jordan, some tribes will stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people, and others will stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses. The Levites will declare curses on those who make idols, dishonor their parents, move boundary stones, mislead the blind, deny justice to foreigners, orphans, and widows, commit sexual immorality, or harm their neighbors. The people will affirm each curse by saying "Amen."

If you diligently obey the Lord's commands, He will set you high above all nations and bless you in the city and the field, in your offspring, crops, and livestock. Your basket and kneading trough will be blessed. You will be blessed when you come in and go out. The Lord will defeat your enemies and bless your storehouses and all your undertakings.If you follow the Lord's commandments, He will establish you as His holy people, as He promised. All the nations will see that you are called by the Lord's name and will respect you. The Lord will bless you with prosperity, including abundant offspring, livestock, and crops. He will provide rain in its season and bless all your work. You will lend to many nations but borrow from none. You will be the leader, not the follower, if you obey the Lord's commands and do not turn aside to follow other gods.

However, if you do not obey the Lord's commands, you will face many curses. You will be cursed in the city and the field, and your basket and store will be cursed. Your offspring, crops, and livestock will be cursed. You will be cursed when you come in and when you go out. The Lord will send curses, confusion, and rebuke in everything you do until you are destroyed because of your wickedness. He will bring diseases, fever, inflammation, and drought. The sky above will be like bronze, and the ground below like iron. The Lord will turn the rain into dust and powder until you are destroyed.

You will be defeated by your enemies and scattered among all nations. Your carcasses will be food for birds and wild animals. The Lord will afflict you with boils, tumors, scabs, and itching that cannot be cured. You will be driven mad by what you see. You will be oppressed and robbed continually, with no one to save you. You will build a house but not live in it, plant a vineyard but not enjoy its fruit. Your livestock will be taken away, and your children will be given to another people. Foreigners will consume your crops and oppress you.

If you do not serve the Lord with joy and gladness, you will serve your enemies in hunger, thirst, and nakedness. The Lord will bring a distant nation against you, a fierce nation that shows no respect for the old or young. They will consume your livestock and crops until you are destroyed. You will be besieged in your cities, leading to such desperation that you will eat your own children. The most delicate among you will turn against their own family members.

If you do not follow the words of this law, the Lord will bring extraordinary plagues and prolonged diseases upon you. All the diseases of Egypt and other unknown illnesses will afflict you until you are destroyed. You will be left few in number, though you were once as numerous as the stars. The Lord will scatter you among all peoples, and you will serve other gods. You will find no peace or rest, living in constant fear and uncertainty. You will long for morning in the evening and evening in the morning because of the terror in your heart. The Lord will bring you back to Egypt in ships, and there you will try to sell yourselves as slaves, but no one will buy you.You will be taken back to Egypt in ships, a journey I said you would never make again. There, you will try to sell yourselves as slaves to your enemies, but no one will buy you.

These are the terms of the covenant the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Israelites in Moab, in addition to the covenant made at Horeb. Moses summoned all Israel and said, "You have seen all that the Lord did in Egypt to Pharaoh, his officials, and his land. You witnessed the great trials, signs, and wonders. Yet, to this day, the Lord has not given you a mind that understands, eyes that see, or ears that hear. For forty years, I led you through the wilderness; your clothes and sandals did not wear out. You ate no bread and drank no wine or other fermented drink, so you would know that I am the Lord your God.

When you reached this place, Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan came out to fight us, but we defeated them. We took their land and gave it as an inheritance to the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. Therefore, keep the words of this covenant and follow them, so you may prosper in everything you do.

Today, all of you stand before the Lord your God—your leaders, elders, officials, all the men of Israel, your children, wives, and the foreigners in your camps who chop your wood and draw your water. You are here to enter into a covenant with the Lord your God, a covenant the Lord is making with you today. He wants to establish you as His people and be your God, as He promised your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. This covenant is not only with you who are here today but also with those who are not here.

You know how we lived in Egypt and passed through other nations. You saw their detestable images and idols of wood, stone, silver, and gold. Make sure there is no man, woman, family, or tribe among you whose heart turns away from the Lord to worship other gods. Such a person would be like a root producing bitter poison. When they hear the words of this curse, they may bless themselves and think they will be safe, even though they persist in their own way. This will bring disaster on the well-watered land as well as the dry.

The Lord will not be willing to forgive them; His anger and jealousy will burn against them. All the curses written in this book will fall on them, and the Lord will blot out their names from under heaven. He will single them out for disaster according to all the curses of the covenant written in this book of the law.

Future generations and foreigners from distant lands will see the plagues and diseases the Lord has inflicted on the land. The whole land will be a burning waste of salt and sulfur, unfit for planting, like the destruction of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboim, which the Lord overthrew in fierce anger. All nations will ask, 'Why has the Lord done this to this land? Why this fierce, burning anger?' The answer will be: 'It is because they abandoned the covenant of the Lord, the God of their ancestors, which He made with them when He brought them out of Egypt. They went off and worshiped other gods and bowed down to them, gods they did not know, gods He had not given them. Therefore, the Lord's anger burned against this land, bringing on it all the curses written in this book. In His furious anger and great wrath, the Lord uprooted them from their land and thrust them into another land, as it is now.'

The secret things belong to the Lord our God, but the revealed things belong to us and our children forever, so we may follow all the words of this law.

When all these blessings and curses I have set before you come upon you and you take them to heart wherever the Lord your God disperses you among the nations, and when you and your children return to the Lord your God and obey Him with all your heart and soul according to everything I command you today, then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you. He will gather you again from all the nations where He scattered you. Even if you have been banished to the most distant land under the heavens, from there the Lord your God will gather you and bring you back. He will bring you to the land that belonged to your ancestors, and you will take possession of it. He will make you more prosperous and numerous than your ancestors. The Lord your God will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, so you may love Him with all your heart and soul and live.

The Lord your God will put all these curses on your enemies who hate and persecute you. You will again obey the Lord and follow all His commands I am giving you today. Then the Lord your God will make you most prosperous in all the work of your hands and in the fruit of your womb, the young of your livestock, and the crops of your land. The Lord will again delight in you and make you prosperous, just as He delighted in your ancestors, if you obey the Lord your God and keep His commands and decrees that are written in this Book of the Law and turn to the Lord your God with all your heart and soul.

Now, what I am commanding you today is not too difficult for you or beyond your reach. It is not up in heaven, so you have to ask, 'Who will ascend into heaven to get it and proclaim it to us so we may obey it?' Nor is it beyond the sea, so you have to ask, 'Who will cross the sea to get it and proclaim it to us so we may obey it?' No, the word is very near you; it is in your mouth and in your heart so you may obey it.

See, I set before you today life and prosperity, death and destruction. For I command you today to love the Lord your God, to walk in obedience to Him, and to keep His commands, decrees, and laws; then you will live and increase, and the Lord your God will bless you in the land you are entering to possess. But if your heart turns away and you are not obedient, and if you are drawn away to bow down to other gods and worship them, I declare to you this day that you will certainly be destroyed. You will not live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to enter and possess.

This day I call the heavens and the earth as witnesses against you that I have set before you life and death, blessings and curses. Now choose life, so that you and your children may live and that you may love the Lord your God, listen to His voice, and hold fast to Him. For the Lord is your life, and He will give you many years in the land He swore to give to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob."

Moses went and spoke these words to all Israel: "I am now 120 years old and am no longer able to lead you. The Lord has told me, 'You shall not cross the Jordan.' The Lord your God Himself will cross over ahead of you. He will destroy these nations before you, and you will take possession of their land. Joshua also will cross over ahead of you, as the Lord said. And the Lord will do to them what He did to Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, whom He destroyed along with their land. The Lord will deliver them to you, and you must do to them all that I have commanded you. Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or terrified because of them, for the Lord your God goes with you; He will never leave you nor forsake you."

Then Moses summoned Joshua and said to him in the presence of all Israel, "Be strong and courageous, for you must go with this people into the land that the Lord swore to their ancestors to give them, and you must divide it among them as their inheritance. The Lord Himself goes before you and will be with you; He will never leave you nor forsake you. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged."

So Moses wrote down this law and gave it to the Levitical priests, who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord, and to all the elders of Israel. Then Moses commanded them: "At the end of every seven years, in the year for canceling debts, during the Festival of Tabernacles, when all Israel comes to appear before the Lord your God at the place He will choose, you shall read this law before them in their hearing. Assemble the people—men, women, and children, and the foreigners residing in your towns—so they can listen and learn to fear the Lord your God and follow carefully all the words of this law.""Gather everyone—men, women, children, and foreigners living in your towns—so they can listen, learn, and respect the Lord your God, and follow all the words of this law. This way, even the children who don't know anything yet will hear and learn to respect the Lord your God for as long as you live in the land you're about to enter and possess.

The Lord told Moses, 'Your time to die is near. Call Joshua and present yourselves at the tent of meeting so I can give him his instructions.' Moses and Joshua went to the tent of meeting, and the Lord appeared in a pillar of cloud, which stood at the entrance of the tent. The Lord said to Moses, 'You are about to rest with your ancestors, and these people will soon turn to other gods and break the covenant I made with them. My anger will burn against them, and I will abandon them, hiding my face from them. They will be destroyed, and many disasters will come upon them. Then they will say, "These disasters have come because our God is not with us." I will hide my face because of all the evil they have done by turning to other gods.

Now, write down this song and teach it to the Israelites. Have them sing it so it will be a witness for me against them. When I bring them into the land flowing with milk and honey, which I promised to their ancestors, and they eat their fill and prosper, they will turn to other gods and reject me, breaking my covenant. When many disasters and troubles come upon them, this song will testify against them, for it will not be forgotten by their descendants. I know what they are inclined to do, even before I bring them into the land I promised them.' So Moses wrote down the song that day and taught it to the Israelites.

Then Moses gave Joshua son of Nun this charge: 'Be strong and courageous, for you will bring the Israelites into the land I promised them, and I will be with you.' When Moses finished writing the words of this law in a book, he gave this command to the Levites who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord: 'Take this Book of the Law and place it beside the ark of the covenant of the Lord your God. It will remain there as a witness against you. For I know how rebellious and stiff-necked you are. If you have been rebellious against the Lord while I am still alive, how much more will you rebel after I die! Assemble all the elders of your tribes and your officials so I can speak these words in their hearing and call heaven and earth to witness against them. For I know that after my death you will become utterly corrupt and turn from the way I have commanded you. In the days to come, disaster will fall upon you because you will do evil in the sight of the Lord and provoke him to anger with the work of your hands.'

Moses recited the words of this song from beginning to end in the hearing of the whole assembly of Israel:

'Listen, heavens, and I will speak; hear, earth, the words of my mouth. My teaching will fall like rain, my words will descend like dew, like showers on new grass, like abundant rain on tender plants. I will proclaim the name of the Lord. Oh, praise the greatness of our God! He is the Rock, his works are perfect, and all his ways are just. A faithful God who does no wrong, upright and just is he. They are corrupt and not his children; to their shame they are a warped and crooked generation. Is this the way you repay the Lord, you foolish and unwise people? Is he not your Father, your Creator, who made you and formed you? Remember the days of old; consider the generations long past. Ask your father and he will tell you, your elders, and they will explain to you. When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, when he divided all mankind, he set up boundaries for the peoples according to the number of the sons of Israel. For the Lord's portion is his people, Jacob his allotted inheritance. In a desert land he found him, in a barren and howling waste. He shielded him and cared for him; he guarded him as the apple of his eye, like an eagle that stirs up its nest and hovers over its young, that spreads its wings to catch them and carries them aloft. The Lord alone led him; no foreign god was with him. He made him ride on the heights of the land and fed him with the fruit of the fields. He nourished him with honey from the rock, and with oil from the flinty crag, with curds and milk from herd and flock and with fattened lambs and goats, with choice rams of Bashan and the finest kernels of wheat. You drank the foaming blood of the grape.

Jeshurun grew fat and kicked; filled with food, they became heavy and sleek. They abandoned the God who made them and rejected the Rock their Savior. They made him jealous with their foreign gods and angered him with their detestable idols. They sacrificed to false gods, which are not God—gods they had not known, gods that recently appeared, gods your ancestors did not fear. You deserted the Rock, who fathered you; you forgot the God who gave you birth. The Lord saw this and rejected them because he was angered by his sons and daughters. "I will hide my face from them," he said, "and see what their end will be; for they are a perverse generation, children who are unfaithful. They made me jealous by what is no god and angered me with their worthless idols. I will make them envious by those who are not a people; I will make them angry by a nation that has no understanding. For a fire will be kindled by my wrath, one that burns down to the realm of the dead below. It will devour the earth and its harvests and set afire the foundations of the mountains. I will heap calamities on them and spend my arrows against them. I will send wasting famine against them, consuming pestilence and deadly plague; I will send against them the fangs of wild beasts, the venom of vipers that glide in the dust. In the street the sword will make them childless; in their homes terror will reign. The young men and young women will perish, the infants and those with gray hair. I said I would scatter them and erase their name from human memory, but I dreaded the taunt of the enemy, lest the adversary misunderstand and say, 'Our hand has triumphed; the Lord has not done all this.' They are a nation without sense, there is no discernment in them. If only they were wise and would understand this and discern what their end will be! How could one man chase a thousand, or two put ten thousand to flight, unless their Rock had sold them, unless the Lord had given them up? For their rock is not like our Rock, as even our enemies concede. Their vine comes from the vine of Sodom and from the fields of Gomorrah. Their grapes are filled with poison, and their clusters with bitterness. Their wine is the venom of serpents, the deadly poison of cobras. Have I not kept this in reserve and sealed it in my vaults? It is mine to avenge; I will repay. In due time their foot will slip; their day of disaster is near and their doom rushes upon them." The Lord will vindicate his people and relent concerning his servants when he sees their strength is gone and no one is left, slave or free. He will say: "Now where are their gods, the rock they took refuge in, the gods who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their drink offerings? Let them rise up to help you! Let them give you shelter! See now that I myself am he! There is no god besides me. I put to death and I bring to life, I have wounded and I will heal, and no one can deliver out of my hand. I lift my hand to heaven and solemnly swear: As surely as I live forever, when I sharpen my flashing sword and my hand grasps it in judgment, I will take vengeance on my adversaries and repay those who hate me. I will make my arrows drunk with blood, while my sword devours flesh: the blood of the slain and the captives, the heads of the enemy leaders." Rejoice, you nations, with his people, for he will avenge the blood of his servants; he will take vengeance on his enemies and make atonement for his land and people.'

Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people. When Moses finished reciting all these words to all Israel, he said to them, 'Take to heart all the words I have solemnly declared to you this day, so that you may command your children to obey carefully all the words of this law. They are not just idle words for you—they are your life. By them you will live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess.'"Moses went up to Mount Nebo, in the land of Moab, across from Jericho. There, God showed him the land of Canaan, which He promised to the Israelites. God told Moses that he would die on the mountain and join his ancestors, just as Aaron did on Mount Hor, because Moses had disobeyed God at the waters of Meribah. Although Moses could see the Promised Land, he would not enter it.

Before his death, Moses blessed the Israelites. He spoke of God's appearance from Sinai and His love for the people. Moses reminded them of the laws and blessings given to them. He blessed each tribe individually, wishing them prosperity, safety, and strength.

Moses then climbed Mount Nebo, saw the Promised Land, and died there at 120 years old. The Israelites mourned him for 30 days. Joshua, filled with wisdom from Moses, took over leadership. There was no prophet like Moses, who knew God face to face and performed great wonders in Egypt.

After Moses' death, God spoke to Joshua, instructing him to lead the people across the Jordan River into the Promised Land. God promised to be with Joshua as He was with Moses, urging him to be strong and courageous. Joshua commanded the people to prepare to cross the Jordan in three days. He reminded the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh of their commitment to help their fellow Israelites until everyone had rest and possession of the land. The people pledged their obedience to Joshua, just as they had to Moses, and prepared to follow his lead.Joshua sent two spies to secretly scout the land, especially Jericho. They stayed at the house of a woman named Rahab. The king of Jericho heard about the spies and sent a message to Rahab, demanding she hand them over. Rahab hid the men and told the king's messengers that the spies had already left. She then helped the spies escape by letting them down through a window with a rope, as her house was part of the city wall.

Rahab told the spies that everyone in Jericho was terrified because they had heard about the miracles God performed for the Israelites, like parting the Red Sea and defeating the Amorite kings. She asked the spies to promise to spare her and her family when they conquered the city. The spies agreed, instructing her to tie a scarlet cord in her window as a sign and to gather her family inside her house for safety.

The spies hid in the mountains for three days until it was safe to return to Joshua. They reported that the people of the land were indeed afraid, confirming that God had given them the land.

Early the next morning, Joshua and the Israelites moved from Shittim to the Jordan River, where they camped before crossing. After three days, the officers instructed the people to follow the Ark of the Covenant, carried by the Levite priests, but to keep a distance of about 2,000 cubits. Joshua told the people to sanctify themselves because God would perform wonders among them the next day.

Joshua commanded the priests to carry the Ark and stand in the Jordan River. As soon as the priests' feet touched the water, the river stopped flowing, allowing the Israelites to cross on dry ground. Joshua then instructed twelve men, one from each tribe, to take twelve stones from the riverbed and set them up as a memorial. This was to remind future generations of how God stopped the Jordan River for them to cross.

The priests stood in the middle of the river until everyone had crossed. Once they were on the other side, the priests carrying the Ark also crossed, and the river returned to its normal flow. The Israelites set up camp at Gilgal, where Joshua placed the twelve stones as a lasting memorial.Joshua set up the twelve stones taken from the Jordan River at Gilgal. He told the Israelites that when their children asked about the stones in the future, they should explain that Israel crossed the Jordan on dry land because God stopped the river's flow, just as He did with the Red Sea. This was to show God's power and to ensure that people would always respect Him.

When the Amorite and Canaanite kings heard that God had dried up the Jordan River for the Israelites, they were terrified and lost their courage. At that time, God instructed Joshua to circumcise the Israelites again because the men who had left Egypt had died in the wilderness, and those born during the journey had not been circumcised. Joshua obeyed, and the people stayed in the camp until they healed. God then told Joshua that He had removed the disgrace of Egypt from them, and the place was named Gilgal.

The Israelites celebrated Passover at Gilgal and ate the produce of the land. The manna, which had sustained them in the wilderness, stopped the day after they ate the local food. 

Near Jericho, Joshua encountered a man with a drawn sword who identified himself as the commander of the Lord's army. Joshua bowed and asked for instructions. The commander told him to remove his sandals because he was standing on holy ground, and Joshua complied.

Jericho was tightly shut because of the Israelites. God told Joshua that He had given Jericho, its king, and its warriors into his hands. Joshua was instructed to have his army march around the city once a day for six days, with seven priests carrying trumpets in front of the Ark of the Covenant. On the seventh day, they were to march around the city seven times, and the priests would blow the trumpets. When they heard a long blast, the people were to shout, and the city walls would collapse, allowing them to take the city.

Joshua followed these instructions, and on the seventh day, the walls of Jericho fell after the people shouted. They captured the city and destroyed everything in it, except for Rahab and her family, who were spared because she had hidden the spies. The valuable metals were placed in the treasury of the Lord's house. Joshua declared a curse on anyone who would rebuild Jericho, and the Lord was with Joshua, making him famous throughout the land.

However, the Israelites sinned by taking some of the items that were supposed to be destroyed. A man named Achan took some of these items, causing God's anger to burn against Israel. Joshua sent men to scout the city of Ai, and they advised sending only a small force. But the Israelites were defeated, and thirty-six men were killed. Joshua and the elders mourned and questioned why God had brought them across the Jordan only to be defeated.When the Amorite and Canaanite kings heard that God had dried up the Jordan River for the Israelites, they were terrified and lost their courage. At that time, God instructed Joshua to circumcise the Israelites again because the men who had left Egypt had died in the wilderness, and those born during the journey had not been circumcised. Joshua obeyed, and the people stayed in the camp until they healed. God then told Joshua that He had removed the disgrace of Egypt from them, and the place was named Gilgal.

The Israelites celebrated Passover at Gilgal and ate the produce of the land. The manna, which had sustained them in the wilderness, stopped the day after they ate the local food.

On the seventh day, they were to march around the city seven times, and the priests would blow the trumpets. When they heard a long blast, the people were to shout, and the city walls would collapse, allowing them to take the city.

Joshua followed these instructions, and on the seventh day, the walls of Jericho fell after the people shouted. However, the Israelites sinned by taking some of the items that were supposed to be destroyed. A man named Achan took some of these items, causing God's anger to burn against Israel. Joshua sent men to scout the city of Ai, and they advised sending only a small force. But the Israelites were defeated, and thirty-six men were killed. Joshua and the elders mourned and questioned why God had brought them across the Jordan only to be defeated.

God responded to Joshua, telling him to get up and stop lying on his face. He explained that Israel had sinned by taking some of the forbidden items, breaking His covenant. Because of this, they could not stand against their enemies. God instructed Joshua to sanctify the people and remove the forbidden items. The next morning, the tribes, families, and households were brought forward, and Achan was identified as the culprit. Achan confessed to taking a beautiful Babylonian garment, two hundred shekels of silver, and a fifty-shekel gold bar, which he had hidden in his tent.

Joshua sent messengers to retrieve the items, and they were laid out before the Lord. Achan, along with his family and possessions, was taken to the Valley of Achor, where they were stoned and burned. This act turned away God's anger, and the place was named the Valley of Achor.

God then told Joshua not to be afraid and to take the entire army to attack Ai. This time, they were allowed to keep the spoils and livestock. Joshua set an ambush behind the city. When the men of Ai came out to fight, Joshua and his troops pretended to retreat, drawing the men of Ai away from the city. The ambush force then entered the city, set it on fire, and the Israelites turned back to defeat the men of Ai. The city was completely destroyed, and its king was captured and hanged. Joshua built an altar to the Lord on Mount Ebal, as Moses had commanded, and wrote a copy of the law on stones. The Israelites, along with their leaders and priests, stood on either side of the Ark of the Covenant, and Joshua read all the words of the law to them.When the kings of the Amorites and Canaanites heard that God had dried up the Jordan River for the Israelites, they were terrified and lost their courage. At that time, God instructed Joshua to circumcise the Israelites again because the men who had left Egypt had died in the wilderness, and those born during the journey had not been circumcised. Joshua obeyed, and the people stayed in the camp until they healed. God then told Joshua that He had removed the disgrace of Egypt from them, and the place was named Gilgal.

The Israelites celebrated Passover at Gilgal and ate the produce of the land. The manna, which had sustained them in the wilderness, stopped the day after they ate the local food.

Joshua followed these instructions, and on the seventh day, the walls of Jericho fell after the people shouted. Joshua and the elders mourned and questioned why God had brought them across the Jordan only to be defeated.

Because of this, they could not stand against their enemies. God instructed Joshua to sanctify the people and remove the forbidden items. The next morning, the tribes, families, and households were brought forward, and Achan was identified as the culprit. Achan confessed to taking a beautiful Babylonian garment, two hundred shekels of silver, and a fifty-shekel gold bar, which he had hidden in his tent.

Joshua sent messengers to retrieve the items, and they were laid out before the Lord. Achan, along with his family and possessions, was taken to the Valley of Achor, where they were stoned and burned. This act turned away God's anger, and the place was named the Valley of Achor.

God then told Joshua not to be afraid and to take the entire army to attack Ai. This time, they were allowed to keep the spoils and livestock. Joshua set an ambush behind the city. When the men of Ai came out to fight, Joshua and his troops pretended to retreat, drawing the men of Ai away from the city. The ambush force then entered the city, set it on fire, and the Israelites turned back to defeat the men of Ai. The city was completely destroyed, and its king was captured and hanged. Joshua built an altar to the Lord on Mount Ebal, as Moses had commanded, and wrote a copy of the law on stones. The Israelites, along with their leaders and priests, stood on either side of the Ark of the Covenant, and Joshua read all the words of the law to them.

When the kings of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites heard about these events, they united to fight against Joshua and Israel. The people of Gibeon, however, resorted to deception. They pretended to be ambassadors from a distant land, wearing old clothes and carrying moldy bread to make it seem like they had traveled far. They asked Joshua to make a peace treaty with them. The Israelites were suspicious but eventually agreed without consulting God. Three days later, they discovered that the Gibeonites were actually their neighbors. Despite the deception, the Israelites honored the treaty because they had sworn an oath to God. The Gibeonites were spared but were made servants, tasked with cutting wood and drawing water for the Israelites.

When Adonizedek, king of Jerusalem, heard about Joshua's victories and the peace treaty with Gibeon, he feared greatly. Gibeon was a significant city with mighty warriors. Adonizedek called on four other Amorite kings to join him in attacking Gibeon. The Gibeonites sent word to Joshua for help. God assured Joshua not to fear, as He had delivered the enemies into his hands. Joshua and his army marched all night from Gilgal and launched a surprise attack. God caused confusion among the Amorite armies, and they were defeated. As they fled, God sent hailstones that killed more of them than the Israelites did with the sword. Joshua prayed for the sun and moon to stand still, and they did, allowing the Israelites to complete their victory. This event was unique, as God listened to a man's request and fought for Israel.

The five Amorite kings hid in a cave at Makkedah. Joshua ordered the cave's entrance to be sealed with large stones and guarded. The Israelites continued to pursue and defeat their enemies. After the battle, Joshua had the kings brought out, and he instructed his commanders to place their feet on the kings' necks as a sign of victory. The kings were then executed and hung on trees until evening. They were later buried in the cave, which was sealed with stones.

Joshua continued his campaign, capturing and destroying several cities, including Makkedah, Libnah, Lachish, and Eglon, following the same pattern of total destruction as with Jericho.Joshua and the Israelites continued their conquests, capturing and destroying cities like Hebron, Debir, and others, leaving no survivors as commanded by God. They defeated all the kings and their lands because God fought for Israel. Joshua then returned to the camp at Gilgal.

When Jabin, king of Hazor, heard about these victories, he allied with other kings to fight Israel. They gathered a massive army, but God assured Joshua of victory. Joshua launched a surprise attack, and God delivered the enemies into Israel's hands. They defeated them completely, burning their chariots and hamstringing their horses.

Joshua then turned back and captured Hazor, killing its king and destroying the city. He continued to conquer other cities, following God's commands given through Moses. Joshua took all the land, including the hills, valleys, and plains, and distributed it among the tribes of Israel. The land finally rested from war.

Joshua's victories included defeating 31 kings and their territories. Despite his old age, God reminded Joshua that there was still land to be possessed. Joshua was instructed to divide the remaining land among the tribes of Israel.Moses defeated the remaining giants in Edrei. However, the Israelites did not expel the Geshurites and Maachathites, who still live among them. The tribe of Levi received no land inheritance; their inheritance was the offerings made to God. Moses allocated land to the tribe of Reuben, including cities like Heshbon and Dibon. The tribe of Gad received land including Jazer and Gilead. Half the tribe of Manasseh received land in Bashan. The Levites received no land but were given cities to live in. The land was divided among the tribes as God commanded through Moses. Caleb, from the tribe of Judah, reminded Joshua of God's promise to him. Despite being 85 years old, Caleb claimed the land of Hebron as his inheritance. The tribe of Judah received their land, with specific borders and cities listed. Caleb drove out the Anakim from Hebron and offered his daughter Achsah in marriage to whoever captured Kirjathsepher. Othniel, Caleb's brother, captured it and married Achsah. She asked Caleb for additional land with springs, which he granted. The inheritance of the tribe of Judah included various cities and their villages.The land was divided among the tribes as God commanded through Moses. Caleb, from the tribe of Judah, reminded Joshua of God's promise to him. Despite being 85 years old, Caleb claimed the land of Hebron as his inheritance. The tribe of Judah received their land, with specific borders and cities listed. Caleb drove out the Anakim from Hebron and offered his daughter Achsah in marriage to whoever captured Kirjathsepher. Othniel, Caleb's brother, captured it and married Achsah. She asked Caleb for additional land with springs, which he granted. The inheritance of the tribe of Judah included various cities and their villages.

The cities and their villages included: Zenan, Hadashah, Migdalgad, Dilean, Mizpeh, Joktheel, Lachish, Bozkath, Eglon, Cabbon, Lahmam, Kithlish, Gederoth, Bethdagon, Naamah, Makkedah, Libnah, Ether, Ashan, Jiphtah, Ashnah, Nezib, Keilah, Achzib, Mareshah, Ekron, Ashdod, Gaza, Shamir, Jattir, Socoh, Dannah, Kirjathsannah (Debir), Anab, Eshtemoh, Anim, Goshen, Holon, Giloh, Arab, Dumah, Eshean, Janum, Bethtappuah, Aphekah, Humtah, Kirjatharba (Hebron), Zior, Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah, Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah, Cain, Gibeah, Timnah, Halhul, Bethzur, Gedor, Maarath, Bethanoth, Eltekon, Kirjathbaal (Kirjathjearim), Rabbah, Betharabah, Middin, Secacah, Nibshan, the city of Salt, and Engedi.

The Jebusites, inhabitants of Jerusalem, could not be driven out by the children of Judah and lived among them in Jerusalem to this day.

The lot for the children of Joseph extended from the Jordan by Jericho to the wilderness up to Bethel, then to Luz, and along the borders of Archi to Ataroth. It went westward to the coast of Japhleti, Bethhoron, and Gezer, ending at the sea. The children of Joseph, Manasseh, and Ephraim received their inheritance. The border of Ephraim's inheritance included Atarothaddar, Bethhoron, Michmethah, Taanathshiloh, Janohah, Ataroth, Naarath, Jericho, and the Jordan. The border extended from Tappuah westward to the river Kanah, ending at the sea. Ephraim's separate cities were among the inheritance of Manasseh. The Canaanites in Gezer were not driven out and lived among the Ephraimites, serving under tribute.

Manasseh, the firstborn of Joseph, received land for Machir, the father of Gilead, because he was a warrior. The rest of Manasseh's children received land by their families. Zelophehad, a descendant of Manasseh, had no sons but daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They asked for an inheritance among their father's brothers, and it was granted. Manasseh received ten portions of land, including Gilead and Bashan. The border of Manasseh extended from Asher to Michmethah, Shechem, Entappuah, the river Kanah, and the sea. Manasseh's land included cities in Issachar and Asher: Bethshean, Ibleam, Dor, Endor, Taanach, and Megiddo. The Canaanites in these cities were not driven out but lived among the Israelites, serving under tribute.

The children of Joseph asked Joshua for more land, as they were a great people. Joshua told them to clear the forested land of the Perizzites and giants if Mount Ephraim was too small. They expressed concern about the Canaanites with iron chariots. Joshua assured them they were strong and would drive out the Canaanites.

The whole congregation of Israel assembled at Shiloh and set up the tabernacle. Seven tribes had not yet received their inheritance. Joshua urged them to take possession of the land. He instructed them to send three men from each tribe to survey and describe the land, which would be divided into seven parts. Judah would remain in the south, and Joseph in the north. The Levites had no land inheritance, as their inheritance was the priesthood. Gad, Reuben, and half the tribe of Manasseh had received their inheritance east of the Jordan. The men surveyed the land and returned to Joshua, who cast lots for them at Shiloh, dividing the land according to their divisions.

The lot for the tribe of Benjamin was between Judah and Joseph. Their northern border started at the Jordan, went up to Jericho, through the mountains westward, and ended at the wilderness of Bethaven. The border continued to Luz (Bethel), Atarothadar, and the hill south of Bethhoron, ending at Kirjathbaal (Kirjathjearim). The southern border started at Kirjathjearim, went to the well of waters of Nephtoah, and descended to the end of the mountain before the valley of the son of Hinnom, in the valley of the giants on the north.The southern border of Benjamin's territory started at the Valley of Hinnom, near the Jebusite city (Jerusalem), and extended to Enrogel. From there, it went north to Enshemesh, then to Geliloth, near the ascent of Adummim, and descended to the stone of Bohan, son of Reuben. The border continued north of Arabah and down to the plains. It passed along the northern side of Bethhoglah and ended at the northern bay of the Dead Sea, at the mouth of the Jordan River. This was the southern boundary. The Jordan River marked the eastern boundary. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Benjamin, defined by its borders.

The cities of Benjamin included Jericho, Bethhoglah, the Valley of Keziz, Betharabah, Zemaraim, Bethel, Avim, Parah, Ophrah, Chepharhaammonai, Ophni, and Gaba—twelve cities with their villages. Additionally, Gibeon, Ramah, Beeroth, Mizpeh, Chephirah, Mozah, Rekem, Irpeel, Taralah, Zelah, Eleph, Jebus (Jerusalem), Gibeath, and Kirjath—fourteen cities with their villages. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Benjamin according to their families.

The second lot fell to the tribe of Simeon. Their inheritance was within the territory of Judah because Judah's portion was too large. Simeon's inheritance included Beersheba, Sheba, Moladah, Hazarshual, Balah, Azem, Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah, Ziklag, Bethmarcaboth, Hazarsusah, Bethlebaoth, and Sharuhen—thirteen cities with their villages. Also, Ain, Remmon, Ether, and Ashan—four cities with their villages, and all the surrounding villages as far as Baalathbeer (Ramah of the south). This was the inheritance of the tribe of Simeon according to their families.

The third lot fell to the tribe of Zebulun. Their territory extended to Sarid. Their border went west to Maralah, touched Dabbasheth, and reached the brook near Jokneam. From Sarid, it turned eastward toward the sunrise to the border of Chisloth Tabor, then went to Daberath and up to Japhia. From there, it continued east to Gittahhepher, Ittahkazin, and extended to Remmonmethoar and Neah. The border circled north to Hannathon and ended in the Valley of Jiphthahel. Included were Kattath, Nahallal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem—twelve cities with their villages. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Zebulun according to their families.

The fourth lot fell to the tribe of Issachar. Their territory included Jezreel, Chesulloth, Shunem, Haphraim, Shihon, Anaharath, Rabbith, Kishion, Abez, Remeth, Engannim, Enhaddah, and Bethpazzez. The border reached Tabor, Shahazimah, and Bethshemesh, ending at the Jordan River—sixteen cities with their villages. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Issachar according to their families.

The fifth lot fell to the tribe of Asher. Their territory included Helkath, Hali, Beten, Achshaph, Alammelech, Amad, Misheal, and extended west to Carmel and Shihorlibnath. It turned east to Bethdagon, reached Zebulun and the Valley of Jiphthahel, then north to Bethemek and Neiel, and continued to Cabul on the left. It included Hebron, Rehob, Hammon, Kanah, and extended to Greater Sidon. The border turned to Ramah and the fortified city of Tyre, then to Hosah, ending at the sea. Included were Ummah, Aphek, and Rehob—twenty-two cities with their villages. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Asher according to their families.

The sixth lot fell to the tribe of Naphtali. Their territory extended from Heleph, from the oak in Zaanannim, Adami Nekeb, and Jabneel, to Lakum, ending at the Jordan River. The border turned west to Aznothtabor, continued to Hukkok, and reached Zebulun on the south, Asher on the west, and Judah at the Jordan River on the east. The fortified cities included Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Chinnereth, Adamah, Ramah, Hazor, Kedesh, Edrei, Enhazor, Iron, Migdalel, Horem, Bethanath, and Bethshemesh—nineteen cities with their villages. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Naphtali according to their families.

The seventh lot fell to the tribe of Dan. Their territory included Zorah, Eshtaol, Irshemesh, Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Jethlah, Elon, Thimnathah, Ekron, Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Baalath, Jehud, Beneberak, Gathrimmon, Mejarkon, and Rakkon, with the area near Joppa. The territory of Dan was too small, so they fought against Leshem, captured it, and settled there, renaming it Dan after their ancestor. This was the inheritance of the tribe of Dan according to their families.

After dividing the land, the Israelites gave Joshua, son of Nun, the city he requested, Timnathserah in the hill country of Ephraim. He built and settled in the city. These were the inheritances distributed by Eleazar the priest, Joshua, and the leaders of the tribes at Shiloh before the Lord, at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting. This completed the division of the land.

The Lord instructed Joshua to designate cities of refuge, as commanded through Moses. These cities were for anyone who killed someone unintentionally to flee and find protection from the avenger of blood. The person would present their case to the city elders, who would provide a place to live. They would remain there until they stood trial or until the high priest died. The cities of refuge were Kedesh in Galilee, Shechem in Ephraim, and Hebron in Judah. East of the Jordan, they were Bezer in Reuben, Ramoth in Gad, and Golan in Manasseh. These cities were for all Israelites and foreigners living among them, providing refuge for anyone who killed someone unintentionally.

The heads of the Levite families approached Eleazar, Joshua, and the leaders of Israel at Shiloh, requesting cities to live in, as commanded by the Lord through Moses. The Israelites gave the Levites cities and surrounding pasturelands from their own inheritances. The Kohathite clans, including the descendants of Aaron, received thirteen cities from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin. The rest of the Kohathites received ten cities from the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and half of Manasseh. The Gershonites received thirteen cities from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the other half of Manasseh.The descendants of Merari received twelve cities from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun. The Israelites allocated these cities to the Levites as the Lord commanded through Moses. From the tribes of Judah and Simeon, they gave the following cities to the descendants of Aaron, who were part of the Kohathite families: Hebron (a city of refuge), Libnah, Jattir, Eshtemoa, Holon, Debir, Ain, Juttah, and Bethshemesh—nine cities in total. From the tribe of Benjamin, they received Gibeon, Geba, Anathoth, and Almon—four cities. In total, the descendants of Aaron received thirteen cities.

The remaining Kohathite families received cities from the tribe of Ephraim: Shechem (a city of refuge), Gezer, Kibzaim, and Bethhoron—four cities. From the tribe of Dan, they received Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Aijalon, and Gathrimmon—four cities. From the half-tribe of Manasseh, they received Tanach and Gathrimmon—two cities. In total, the remaining Kohathite families received ten cities.

The Gershonite families received cities from the other half-tribe of Manasseh: Golan in Bashan (a city of refuge) and Beeshterah—two cities. From the tribe of Issachar, they received Kishon, Dabareh, Jarmuth, and Engannim—four cities. From the tribe of Asher, they received Mishal, Abdon, Helkath, and Rehob—four cities. From the tribe of Naphtali, they received Kedesh in Galilee (a city of refuge), Hammothdor, and Kartan—three cities. In total, the Gershonites received thirteen cities.

The Merarite families received cities from the tribe of Zebulun: Jokneam, Kartah, Dimnah, and Nahalal—four cities. From the tribe of Reuben, they received Bezer, Jahazah, Kedemoth, and Mephaath—four cities. From the tribe of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead (a city of refuge), Mahanaim, Heshbon, and Jazer—four cities. In total, the Merarites received twelve cities.

In total, the Levites received forty-eight cities with their surrounding pasturelands. The Lord fulfilled His promise to give Israel the land, and they settled in it. He gave them peace and delivered their enemies into their hands. Every promise the Lord made to Israel came true.

Joshua then called the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, commending them for obeying Moses and his commands. He blessed them and sent them back to their land with riches and spoils from their enemies. They returned to their land in Gilead, but built a large altar by the Jordan River, which alarmed the rest of Israel. They feared it was an act of rebellion against the Lord. The Israelites sent Phinehas and ten leaders to confront them. The Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh explained that the altar was not for sacrifices, but as a witness between them and future generations that they still worship the Lord. This explanation satisfied the Israelites, and they praised God, avoiding conflict.The Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh explained that the altar they built was not for sacrifices but as a symbol to remind future generations that they still worship the Lord. This explanation pleased Phinehas and the leaders of Israel, and they praised God, avoiding conflict.

Joshua, now old, gathered all the leaders of Israel and reminded them of everything the Lord had done for them. He urged them to remain faithful to God's laws and not to associate with the remaining nations or their gods. He warned that if they turned away from God, they would face severe consequences.

Joshua recounted how God had fulfilled all His promises, driving out their enemies and giving them the land. He emphasized the importance of loving and obeying God, warning that if they served other gods, they would be destroyed.

Joshua then gathered all the tribes at Shechem and reminded them of their history, from Abraham to their current state. He urged them to choose whom they would serve, declaring that he and his household would serve the Lord. The people reaffirmed their commitment to serve the Lord, and Joshua made a covenant with them, setting up a stone as a witness to their promise.

After these events, Joshua died at the age of 110 and was buried in his inheritance. Israel continued to serve the Lord throughout Joshua's lifetime and the lifetimes of the elders who outlived him.After Joshua's death, the Israelites asked God who should lead the fight against the Canaanites.
