God chose the tribe of Judah. Judah invited the tribe of Simeon to join them, and together they defeated the Canaanites and Perizzites, killing 10,000 men in Bezek. They captured and punished Adonibezek, who acknowledged that God repaid him for his own cruelty. Judah also conquered Jerusalem, setting it on fire, and continued to fight and defeat the Canaanites in various regions.

Caleb offered his daughter Achsah in marriage to whoever captured Kirjathsepher. Othniel, Caleb's younger brother, succeeded and married Achsah. She requested and received additional land with springs of water from her father.

The Kenites, descendants of Moses' father-in-law, settled with the tribe of Judah. Judah and Simeon continued to conquer Canaanite cities, including Gaza, Askelon, and Ekron. However, they couldn't drive out the inhabitants of the valley due to their iron chariots.

The tribe of Benjamin failed to drive out the Jebusites from Jerusalem, and they lived together. The house of Joseph successfully spied on and captured Bethel, previously known as Luz, with the help of a local man who showed them the city's entrance.

Several tribes, including Manasseh, Ephraim, Zebulun, Asher, and Naphtali, failed to completely drive out the Canaanites from their territories, allowing them to live among them and sometimes making them pay tribute.

The Amorites forced the tribe of Dan into the mountains, but the house of Joseph eventually subdued them, making them pay tribute. The boundaries of the Amorites extended from Akrabbim to the rock and beyond.

An angel of the Lord rebuked the Israelites for not obeying God's command to destroy the altars of the land's inhabitants, leading to their future suffering. The people wept and sacrificed to the Lord at Bochim.

After Joshua's death, the Israelites served the Lord during the lifetimes of Joshua and the elders who outlived him. However, a new generation arose that did not know the Lord or His works, leading them to worship other gods and angering the Lord. God allowed their enemies to oppress them, but He raised judges to deliver them. Despite this, the Israelites repeatedly turned away from God after each judge's death, worsening their behavior and provoking God's anger. God decided not to drive out the remaining nations to test Israel's faithfulness.The Israelites lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites. They intermarried with them and began worshiping their gods, forgetting the Lord. This angered God, and He allowed them to be conquered by King Chushanrishathaim of Mesopotamia, whom they served for eight years. When the Israelites cried out to God, He sent Othniel, Caleb's younger brother, to deliver them. Othniel led them to victory, and the land had peace for forty years until his death.

After Othniel's death, the Israelites again did evil, and God allowed King Eglon of Moab to conquer them. They served Eglon for eighteen years until they cried out to God, who sent Ehud, a left-handed man from the tribe of Benjamin, to deliver them. Ehud made a double-edged dagger, hid it under his clothes, and presented a tribute to Eglon. After sending away the tribute bearers, Ehud told Eglon he had a secret message from God. When Eglon stood up, Ehud stabbed him with the dagger, killing him. Ehud escaped, rallied the Israelites, and they defeated the Moabites, bringing peace for eighty years.

After Ehud, Shamgar son of Anath killed six hundred Philistines with an ox goad and delivered Israel.

When Ehud died, the Israelites again did evil, and God allowed them to be oppressed by King Jabin of Canaan, whose army was led by Sisera. The Israelites cried out to God, and He raised Deborah, a prophetess, to lead them. Deborah called Barak to gather ten thousand men to fight Sisera. Barak agreed only if Deborah would go with him. Deborah warned that the honor of victory would go to a woman. Barak and his men defeated Sisera's army, but Sisera fled to the tent of Jael, wife of Heber the Kenite. Jael gave him milk, covered him, and then killed him by driving a tent peg through his head while he slept. Israel continued to grow stronger until they destroyed Jabin.

Deborah and Barak sang a song of praise to God for avenging Israel and for the people's willingness to fight. They recounted God's mighty acts and the victory over Sisera, celebrating the peace that followed.From the tribe of Ephraim, leaders rose to fight against Amalek. Benjamin also joined the battle, and from Machir came rulers, while Zebulun provided skilled writers. The leaders of Issachar supported Deborah and Barak, who led the troops into the valley. The tribe of Reuben had deep internal conflicts, questioning their role. Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan, and Dan remained with their ships. Asher stayed by the seashore, but Zebulun and Naphtali risked their lives on the battlefield.

The kings of Canaan fought at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo but gained no wealth. The stars fought from the heavens against Sisera, and the Kishon River swept them away. The horses' hooves were shattered in the chaos. The angel of the Lord cursed Meroz for not helping in the battle, while Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, was blessed for her bravery. She gave Sisera milk instead of water, then killed him with a tent peg.

Sisera's mother anxiously awaited his return, imagining he was dividing the spoils of war. But all of God's enemies perished, and those who loved Him shone like the sun. The land had peace for forty years.

After this period, the Israelites again did evil, and God allowed them to be oppressed by the Midianites for seven years. The Midianites were so oppressive that the Israelites hid in caves and strongholds. Whenever the Israelites planted crops, the Midianites, Amalekites, and other eastern peoples invaded, destroying the land and leaving no food or livestock.

The Israelites were impoverished and cried out to God for help. God sent a prophet to remind them of their deliverance from Egypt and their disobedience. An angel of the Lord appeared to Gideon, who was hiding from the Midianites, and called him a mighty warrior. Gideon questioned why they were suffering if God was with them. The Lord told Gideon to use his strength to save Israel and assured him of His presence.

Gideon asked for a sign and prepared an offering. The angel instructed him to place the offering on a rock, and fire consumed it. Realizing he had seen an angel, Gideon feared for his life, but the Lord assured him of peace. Gideon built an altar named "The Lord is Peace."

That night, God instructed Gideon to destroy his father's altar to Baal and build an altar to the Lord. Gideon obeyed but did it at night out of fear. The townspeople discovered the destroyed altar and demanded Gideon's death. Joash, Gideon's father, defended him, saying Baal should defend himself if he was a god. Gideon was then called Jerubbaal, meaning "Let Baal contend."

The Midianites, Amalekites, and other eastern peoples gathered in the Jezreel Valley. The Spirit of the Lord came upon Gideon, and he called for support from the tribes of Manasseh, Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali. Gideon asked God for a sign with a fleece to confirm his mission. God granted the sign, making the fleece wet with dew while the ground remained dry, and then reversing it the next night.

Gideon and his men camped near the Midianites. God told Gideon he had too many men and instructed him to send home those who were afraid. Twenty-two thousand left, leaving ten thousand.Gideon had too many men, so God told him to take them to the water for a test. Those who lapped the water with their tongues like dogs were separated from those who knelt to drink. Only 300 men lapped the water, and God said He would use these 300 to save Israel and defeat the Midianites. The rest were sent home.

That night, God told Gideon to go down to the Midianite camp. If he was afraid, he could take his servant Phurah. Gideon and Phurah went and overheard a man telling a dream about a barley loaf tumbling into the Midianite camp and overturning a tent. The dream was interpreted as Gideon's victory over Midian. Encouraged, Gideon returned to his camp, divided his 300 men into three groups, and gave each man a trumpet and an empty jar with a torch inside.

Gideon instructed his men to follow his lead. When they reached the edge of the Midianite camp, they blew their trumpets, broke the jars, and shouted, "A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!" The Midianites panicked, turned on each other, and fled. Gideon called for reinforcements from the tribes of Naphtali, Asher, and Manasseh to pursue the Midianites.

The men of Ephraim captured and killed the Midianite princes Oreb and Zeeb. They brought their heads to Gideon. The Ephraimites were upset that they hadn't been called earlier to fight, but Gideon calmed them by praising their achievements.

Gideon and his 300 men, exhausted but still in pursuit, asked the men of Succoth and Penuel for food but were refused. Gideon promised to punish them after defeating Zebah and Zalmunna, the Midianite kings. Gideon captured the kings and punished the men of Succoth and Penuel as promised. He then killed Zebah and Zalmunna for killing his brothers.

The Israelites asked Gideon to rule over them, but he refused, saying the Lord would rule over them. He requested gold earrings from the plunder, which he used to make an ephod. Unfortunately, the ephod became a snare, leading the Israelites into idolatry.

Midian was subdued, and the land had peace for 40 years during Gideon's lifetime. Gideon had many wives and 70 sons. After his death, the Israelites again turned away from God and worshiped Baal. They forgot the Lord and showed no kindness to Gideon's family.Abimelech, one of Gideon's sons, convinced the people of Shechem to support him as their leader by reminding them that he was their relative. They gave him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baalberith, which he used to hire reckless men to follow him. Abimelech then went to his father's house in Ophrah and killed his seventy brothers, except for the youngest, Jotham, who escaped by hiding.

The people of Shechem and the house of Millo gathered and made Abimelech king. When Jotham heard about this, he climbed Mount Gerizim and shouted a parable to the people of Shechem, comparing them to trees seeking a king. The olive tree, fig tree, and vine all refused, but the bramble accepted, warning that if they were sincere in making Abimelech king, they should trust in his protection; otherwise, fire would come from the bramble and consume them.

Jotham reminded them of how Gideon (Jerubbaal) had risked his life to save them from the Midianites, and how they had repaid him by killing his sons and making Abimelech, the son of a servant, their king. He warned that if they had acted in good faith, they should rejoice in Abimelech, but if not, fire would come from Abimelech and the people of Shechem to destroy each other. Jotham then fled to Beer to escape Abimelech.

Abimelech ruled Israel for three years before God sent a spirit of discord between him and the people of Shechem. The people of Shechem began to act treacherously against Abimelech to avenge the murder of Gideon's sons. They set ambushes in the mountains to rob travelers, and Abimelech was informed of their actions.

Gaal, son of Ebed, moved to Shechem and gained the trust of the people. During a festival, Gaal questioned why they should serve Abimelech and suggested they serve the descendants of Hamor, the founder of Shechem, instead. He challenged Abimelech to gather his army and fight.

When Zebul, the city's ruler, heard Gaal's words, he secretly informed Abimelech and advised him to set an ambush. Abimelech and his men laid in wait, and when Gaal went out to the city gate, Abimelech attacked. Gaal and his followers were defeated and driven out of Shechem.

The next day, Abimelech divided his forces into three groups and ambushed the people of Shechem as they went into the fields. He captured the city, killed its inhabitants, and destroyed it, sowing it with salt. The remaining people took refuge in the tower of Shechem, but Abimelech and his men set it on fire, killing about a thousand men and women.

Abimelech then attacked the city of Thebez, where the people also took refuge in a strong tower. As Abimelech approached to set it on fire, a woman dropped a millstone on his head, fatally injuring him. To avoid the disgrace of being killed by a woman, he asked his armor-bearer to kill him, and the young man did so.

With Abimelech dead, the Israelites returned home. Thus, God repaid Abimelech for his wickedness in killing his brothers and brought the curse of Jotham upon the people of Shechem.

After Abimelech, Tola, son of Puah, from the tribe of Issachar, judged Israel for twenty-three years. He was followed by Jair, a Gileadite, who judged Israel for twenty-two years. Jair had thirty sons who rode thirty donkeys and controlled thirty towns in Gilead, known as Havoth Jair. After Jair's death, the Israelites again turned to idolatry, worshiping the gods of various neighboring nations, and abandoned the Lord. This angered God, and He allowed the Philistines and Ammonites to oppress them for eighteen years. The Ammonites even crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin, and Ephraim, causing great distress in Israel.The Israelites cried out to the Lord, admitting they had sinned by abandoning Him and worshiping Baal. The Lord reminded them of how He had saved them from various oppressors in the past, but they had turned away from Him. He told them to seek help from the gods they had chosen. The Israelites confessed their sins and pleaded for deliverance, putting away their foreign gods and serving the Lord again. Moved by their misery, the Lord began to help them.

The Ammonites gathered for battle in Gilead, and the Israelites assembled at Mizpeh. The leaders of Gilead asked who would lead them against the Ammonites, promising that person would become their leader.

Jephthah, a mighty warrior from Gilead, was the son of a prostitute. His half-brothers drove him away, denying him any inheritance. Jephthah fled to Tob, where he gathered a group of outcasts. When the Ammonites waged war against Israel, the elders of Gilead sought Jephthah's help, asking him to lead them. Jephthah reminded them of their past mistreatment but agreed to help if they made him their leader. The elders swore an oath before the Lord, and Jephthah became their leader.

Jephthah sent messengers to the king of Ammon, asking why he was attacking Israel. The king claimed Israel had taken his land when they came out of Egypt. Jephthah responded, explaining that Israel had not taken Ammonite land but had been refused passage through Edom and Moab, leading them to fight the Amorites instead. He argued that the Lord had given Israel the land and questioned why the Ammonites had not reclaimed it in the past 300 years. The king of Ammon ignored Jephthah's message.

Empowered by the Spirit of the Lord, Jephthah led Israel to victory over the Ammonites. He had made a vow to the Lord, promising to sacrifice whatever came out of his house to greet him if he returned victorious. Tragically, his only daughter came out to meet him. Jephthah was devastated but felt bound by his vow. His daughter accepted her fate, asking for two months to mourn her virginity with her friends. After two months, she returned, and Jephthah fulfilled his vow. This event led to an annual tradition where Israelite women would lament Jephthah's daughter for four days each year.

The men of Ephraim confronted Jephthah for not involving them in the battle against Ammon. Jephthah explained that he had called for their help, but they did not respond. A conflict ensued, and Jephthah's forces defeated the Ephraimites. Jephthah judged Israel for six years before his death.

After Jephthah, Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel for seven years, followed by Elon the Zebulonite, who judged for ten years.Abdon, the son of Hillel, a Pirathonite, judged Israel for eight years. He had forty sons and thirty grandsons who rode on seventy donkeys. When Abdon died, he was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.

Once again, the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, and He handed them over to the Philistines for forty years. There was a man named Manoah from Zorah, of the Danite tribe, whose wife was unable to have children. An angel of the Lord appeared to her and said, "You are barren, but you will conceive and bear a son. Be careful not to drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean. Your son will be a Nazirite dedicated to God from birth, and he will begin to deliver Israel from the Philistines."

The woman told her husband about the angel's visit. Manoah prayed to the Lord, asking for the man of God to return and teach them how to raise the child. God listened, and the angel appeared again to Manoah's wife while she was in the field. She quickly fetched her husband, and Manoah asked the angel how they should raise the child. The angel repeated the instructions: the woman must avoid wine, strong drink, and unclean food.

Manoah offered to prepare a meal for the angel, but the angel said he would not eat and instructed Manoah to offer a burnt offering to the Lord. Manoah did not realize he was speaking to an angel. When Manoah asked for the angel's name, the angel replied that it was beyond understanding. Manoah then offered a young goat on a rock to the Lord, and as the flame rose from the altar, the angel ascended in the flame. Manoah and his wife fell to the ground in awe, realizing they had seen an angel of the Lord. Manoah feared they would die, but his wife reassured him that the Lord would not have accepted their offering or revealed these things if He intended to kill them.

The woman gave birth to a son and named him Samson. The Lord blessed him, and the Spirit of the Lord began to stir him while he was in the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol.

Samson went to Timnah and saw a Philistine woman he wanted to marry. Despite his parents' objections, he insisted on marrying her because she pleased him. They did not realize this was part of the Lord's plan to confront the Philistines, who were ruling over Israel at the time.

On his way to Timnah, Samson encountered a young lion. The Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him, and he tore the lion apart with his bare hands but did not tell his parents. Later, he found a swarm of bees and honey in the lion's carcass, which he ate and shared with his parents without revealing its source.

Samson held a feast in Timnah, as was customary for young men. He proposed a riddle to his thirty companions, promising them thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes if they could solve it within seven days. If they failed, they would owe him the same. The riddle was: "Out of the eater came something to eat, and out of the strong came something sweet." After three days, they could not solve it.

On the seventh day, they pressured Samson's wife to coax the answer from him, threatening to burn her and her father's house. She wept and pleaded with Samson until he finally revealed the answer, which she then told her people. Before sunset on the seventh day, the men of the city answered Samson's riddle. Enraged, Samson went to Ashkelon, killed thirty men, and took their clothes to pay his debt. In his anger, he returned to his father's house, and his wife was given to his companion.

Later, during the wheat harvest, Samson visited his wife with a young goat, intending to go to her room. Her father refused, thinking Samson hated her and had given her to his companion. He offered Samson her younger sister instead. Furious, Samson caught three hundred foxes, tied their tails together in pairs with torches, and set them loose in the Philistines' grain fields, burning the grain, vineyards, and olive groves.

When the Philistines learned that Samson was responsible, they burned his wife and her father to death. Samson vowed revenge and attacked them viciously. He then retreated to a cave in the rock of Etam. The Philistines camped in Judah, prompting the men of Judah to confront Samson. They reminded him that the Philistines ruled over them and asked why he had caused trouble. Samson replied that he had only done to them what they had done to him. The men of Judah agreed to bind Samson and hand him over to the Philistines, but Samson made them swear not to kill him themselves.The men of Judah promised Samson they wouldn't kill him but would hand him over to the Philistines. They tied him up with new ropes and brought him to Lehi. When the Philistines saw him, they shouted in triumph, but the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon Samson. The ropes on his arms became like charred flax and fell off. He found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, picked it up, and killed a thousand men with it. Afterward, he threw away the jawbone and named the place Ramath Lehi.

Samson was very thirsty and called out to the Lord, saying, "You have given your servant this great victory. Must I now die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?" God opened up a hollow place in Lehi, and water came out. Samson drank, his strength returned, and he revived. He named the place En Hakkore, and it is still called that today. Samson led Israel for twenty years during the time of the Philistines.

One day, Samson went to Gaza and saw a prostitute. He spent the night with her. The people of Gaza were told, "Samson is here!" They surrounded the place and lay in wait for him all night at the city gate. They kept quiet, thinking, "At dawn, we'll kill him." But Samson stayed in bed only until midnight. Then he got up, took hold of the doors of the city gate, along with the two posts, and tore them loose, bar and all. He lifted them to his shoulders and carried them to the top of the hill that faces Hebron.

Some time later, Samson fell in love with a woman in the Valley of Sorek named Delilah. The rulers of the Philistines went to her and said, "See if you can lure him into showing you the secret of his great strength and how we can overpower him so we may tie him up and subdue him. Each one of us will give you eleven hundred shekels of silver."

So Delilah said to Samson, "Tell me the secret of your great strength and how you can be tied up and subdued." Samson answered her, "If anyone ties me with seven fresh bowstrings that have not been dried, I'll become as weak as any other man." Then the rulers of the Philistines brought her seven fresh bowstrings that had not been dried, and she tied him with them. With men hidden in the room, she called to him, "Samson, the Philistines are upon you!" But he snapped the bowstrings as easily as a piece of string snaps when it comes close to a flame. So the secret of his strength was not discovered.

Then Delilah said to Samson, "You have made a fool of me; you lied to me. Come now, tell me how you can be tied." He said, "If anyone ties me securely with new ropes that have never been used, I'll become as weak as any other man." So Delilah took new ropes and tied him with them. Then, with men hidden in the room, she called to him, "Samson, the Philistines are upon you!" But he snapped the ropes off his arms as if they were threads.

Delilah then said to Samson, "All this time you have been making a fool of me and lying to me. Tell me how you can be tied." He replied, "If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom and tighten it with the pin, I'll become as weak as any other man." So while he was sleeping, Delilah took the seven braids of his head, wove them into the fabric, and tightened it with the pin. Again she called to him, "Samson, the Philistines are upon you!" He awoke from his sleep and pulled up the pin and the loom, with the fabric.

Then she said to him, "How can you say, 'I love you,' when you won't confide in me? This is the third time you have made a fool of me and haven't told me the secret of your great strength." With such nagging, she prodded him day after day until he was sick to death of it. So he told her everything. "No razor has ever been used on my head," he said, "because I have been a Nazirite dedicated to God from my mother's womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would leave me, and I would become as weak as any other man."

When Delilah saw that he had told her everything, she sent word to the rulers of the Philistines, "Come back once more; he has told me everything." So the rulers of the Philistines returned with the silver in their hands. After putting him to sleep on her lap, she called for someone to shave off the seven braids of his hair, and so began to subdue him. And his strength left him.

Then she called, "Samson, the Philistines are upon you!" He awoke from his sleep and thought, "I'll go out as before and shake myself free." But he did not know that the Lord had left him. The Philistines seized him, gouged out his eyes, and took him down to Gaza. Binding him with bronze shackles, they set him to grinding grain in the prison. But the hair on his head began to grow again after it had been shaved.

The rulers of the Philistines assembled to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to celebrate, saying, "Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands." When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying, "Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, the one who laid waste our land and multiplied our slain." While they were in high spirits, they shouted, "Bring out Samson to entertain us." So they called Samson out of the prison, and he performed for them. When they stood him among the pillars, Samson said to the servant who held his hand, "Put me where I can feel the pillars that support the temple, so that I may lean against them." Now the temple was crowded with men and women; all the rulers of the Philistines were there, and on the roof were about three thousand men and women watching Samson perform.

Then Samson prayed to the Lord, "Sovereign Lord, remember me. Please, God, strengthen me just once more, and let me with one blow get revenge on the Philistines for my two eyes." Then Samson reached toward the two central pillars on which the temple stood. Bracing himself against them, his right hand on one and his left hand on the other, Samson said, "Let me die with the Philistines!" Then he pushed with all his might, and down came the temple on the rulers and all the people in it. Thus he killed many more when he died than while he lived.

Then his brothers and his father's whole family went down to get him. They brought him back and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah his father. He had led Israel for twenty years.

There was a man named Micah from the hill country of Ephraim. He said to his mother, "The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from you and about which you cursed—I have it. I took it." Then his mother said, "The Lord bless you, my son!" When he returned the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother, she said, "I solemnly consecrate my silver to the Lord for my son to make an image overlaid with silver. I will give it back to you." So after he returned the silver to his mother, she took two hundred shekels of silver and gave them to a silversmith, who used them to make the idol. And it was put in Micah's house.

Now this man Micah had a shrine, and he made an ephod and some household gods and installed one of his sons as his priest. In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit. A young Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, who had been living within the clan of Judah, left that town in search of some other place to stay. On his way, he came to Micah's house in the hill country of Ephraim. Micah asked him, "Where are you from?" "I'm a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah," he said, "and I'm looking for a place to stay."

Then Micah said to him, "Live with me and be my father and priest, and I'll give you ten shekels of silver a year, your clothes, and your food." So the Levite agreed to live with him, and the young man became like one of his sons to him. Then Micah installed the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in his house. And Micah said, "Now I know that the Lord will be good to me, since this Levite has become my priest."

In those days Israel had no king. And in those days the tribe of the Danites was seeking a place of their own where they might settle, because they had not yet come into an inheritance among the tribes of Israel. So the Danites sent five of their leading men from Zorah and Eshtaol to spy out the land and explore it. These men represented all the Danites. They told them, "Go, explore the land." So they entered the hill country of Ephraim and came to the house of Micah, where they spent the night. When they were near Micah's house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite; so they turned in there and asked him, "Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? Why are you here?" He told them what Micah had done for him, and said, "He has hired me, and I am his priest." They said to him, "Please inquire of God to learn whether our journey will be successful."The five men asked the priest to pray to God to see if their journey would be successful. The priest told them to go in peace, as the Lord was with them. The men then traveled to Laish and saw that the people there lived carefree, like the Sidonians, without any rulers to shame them. They returned to their brothers in Zorah and Eshtaol and reported that the land was good and urged them to take it. Six hundred armed men from the Danite tribe set out and camped near Kirjathjearim in Judah, naming the place Mahaneh Dan. They then moved to the hill country of Ephraim and reached Micah's house.

The five spies informed their brothers about the religious items in Micah's house, including an ephod and household gods. They decided to take these items. The six hundred armed men stood at the gate while the five spies entered Micah's house and took the religious items. The priest questioned their actions, but they convinced him to join them, offering him a better position as a priest for their tribe. The priest agreed and left with them, taking the religious items.

As they departed, they placed their children, livestock, and possessions in front of them. When they were a distance from Micah's house, Micah and his neighbors caught up with them and demanded to know why they had taken his gods and priest. The Danites warned Micah to stay quiet to avoid violence. Realizing he couldn't overpower them, Micah returned home.

The Danites then attacked the peaceful and secure city of Laish, killing its inhabitants and burning it down. They rebuilt the city and named it Dan, after their ancestor. They set up the religious items they had taken from Micah, and Jonathan, the son of Gershom, and his descendants served as priests for the tribe of Dan until the land's captivity. The religious items remained in use as long as the house of God was in Shiloh.

During this time, there was no king in Israel. A Levite living in the hill country of Ephraim took a concubine from Bethlehem in Judah. She was unfaithful and returned to her father's house in Bethlehem. After four months, the Levite went to persuade her to return, bringing his servant and two donkeys. Her father welcomed him and insisted he stay for several days. On the fifth day, the Levite decided to leave despite his father-in-law's urging to stay longer.

As they traveled, they reached Jebus (Jerusalem) near evening. The Levite's servant suggested they stay in the city, but the Levite preferred to continue to Gibeah or Ramah, towns of the Israelites. They arrived in Gibeah, but no one offered them lodging. An old man from Ephraim, living in Gibeah, invited them to stay at his house, providing for their needs.

While they were enjoying themselves, some wicked men from the city surrounded the house, demanding to have sex with the Levite. The old man pleaded with them not to commit such an evil act and offered his daughter and the Levite's concubine instead. The men refused, so the Levite sent his concubine outside. They abused her all night, and she collapsed at the door in the morning. The Levite found her there, unresponsive, and took her home. He then cut her body into twelve pieces and sent them throughout Israel to rally the tribes against the atrocity.The Levite sent pieces of his concubine's body throughout Israel, shocking everyone who saw it. They said nothing like this had ever happened since Israel left Egypt. They urged everyone to consider the matter and speak up.

All the Israelites, from Dan to Beersheba and the land of Gilead, gathered as one before the Lord at Mizpeh. Four hundred thousand armed men presented themselves. The tribe of Benjamin heard about this gathering. The Israelites asked, "How did this wickedness happen?"

The Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, explained that he and his concubine had stayed in Gibeah, a town of Benjamin. The men of Gibeah attacked them, intending to kill him and abusing his concubine to death. He then cut her body into pieces and sent them throughout Israel because of the vile act committed.

The Israelites, united, decided not to return home until they had dealt with Gibeah. They planned to draw lots to decide who would attack. They would gather provisions and go to Gibeah to punish the wickedness.

The tribes of Israel sent messengers to Benjamin, demanding they hand over the guilty men of Gibeah for execution to purge the evil. But the Benjamites refused and prepared for battle. They gathered 26,000 men, plus 700 elite left-handed soldiers who could sling stones with great accuracy.

The Israelites, excluding Benjamin, numbered 400,000 warriors. They sought God's guidance on who should lead the attack, and God chose Judah. The Israelites set up camp near Gibeah and prepared for battle.

On the first day, the Benjamites killed 22,000 Israelites. The Israelites encouraged themselves and regrouped. They wept before the Lord and asked if they should continue fighting. God told them to go up against Benjamin again.

On the second day, the Benjamites killed another 18,000 Israelites. The Israelites wept, fasted, and offered sacrifices, seeking God's counsel again. God assured them that He would deliver Benjamin into their hands the next day.

The Israelites set an ambush around Gibeah. On the third day, they drew the Benjamites out of the city and began to retreat, luring them away. The ambush then attacked Gibeah, setting it on fire. Seeing the smoke, the Israelites turned and fought the Benjamites, who realized they were trapped.

The Benjamites tried to flee but were overtaken. The Israelites killed 25,100 Benjamite soldiers. The remaining Benjamites fled to the wilderness but were pursued and killed. Only 600 men escaped to the rock of Rimmon, where they stayed for four months.

The Israelites then destroyed the remaining Benjamite cities, killing everyone and burning everything. They had sworn not to give their daughters to the Benjamites as wives. They wept before God, lamenting the loss of a tribe.

The next day, they built an altar and offered sacrifices. They realized no one from Jabesh Gilead had joined the assembly, so they sent 12,000 warriors to kill the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead, sparing only the virgin women.The Israelites gathered 400 young virgins from Jabesh Gilead and brought them to the camp at Shiloh in Canaan. The entire congregation sent messengers to the Benjamites at the rock of Rimmon, offering peace. The Benjamites returned, and the Israelites gave them the women from Jabesh Gilead, but there weren't enough.

The people felt remorse for Benjamin, as the Lord had caused a division among the tribes of Israel. The elders asked how they could provide wives for the remaining Benjamites since the women of Benjamin had been destroyed. They decided that the surviving Benjamites must have an inheritance to prevent the tribe from disappearing.

However, they couldn't give their own daughters as wives because they had sworn not to. They noted that there was an annual festival of the Lord in Shiloh, located north of Bethel, east of the highway to Shechem, and south of Lebonah. They instructed the Benjamites to hide in the vineyards and, when the daughters of Shiloh came out to dance, to seize a wife from among them and return to Benjamin.

When the fathers or brothers of the women complained, the Israelites would tell them to be kind for their sake, as they hadn't provided wives during the war and thus weren't guilty. The Benjamites did as instructed, taking wives from the dancers, and returned to rebuild their cities.

The Israelites then returned to their own tribes and families. In those days, Israel had no king, and everyone did what they thought was right.

In the time of the judges, there was a famine in the land. A man from Bethlehem in Judah, named Elimelech, went to live in Moab with his wife Naomi and their two sons, Mahlon and Chilion. Elimelech died, leaving Naomi with her two sons, who married Moabite women named Orpah and Ruth. After about ten years, both sons died, leaving Naomi without her husband and sons.

Naomi decided to return to Judah after hearing that the Lord had provided food for His people. She set out with her daughters-in-law but urged them to return to their mothers' homes, wishing them kindness and new husbands. They wept, and Orpah returned, but Ruth clung to Naomi, insisting on staying with her.

Ruth declared her loyalty to Naomi, saying she would go where Naomi went, live where she lived, and worship Naomi's God. Naomi saw Ruth's determination and stopped urging her to leave. They traveled to Bethlehem, where the whole town was stirred by their arrival. Naomi, feeling bitter, asked to be called Mara, as she felt the Almighty had afflicted her.

Naomi and Ruth arrived in Bethlehem at the beginning of the barley harvest. Naomi had a wealthy relative named Boaz. Ruth asked Naomi's permission to glean in the fields, and she happened to work in Boaz's field. Boaz noticed her and learned about her loyalty to Naomi. He instructed his workers to protect her and let her gather grain.

Ruth was grateful for Boaz's kindness, and he invited her to eat with his workers. She continued to glean in his field, gathering a substantial amount of barley. Naomi was pleased and blessed Boaz, recognizing him as a close relative. Ruth continued to work in Boaz's fields throughout the harvests, living with Naomi.

Naomi then advised Ruth to seek security with Boaz, who was winnowing barley at the threshing floor. She instructed Ruth to wash, anoint herself, and go to Boaz, uncovering his feet and lying down. Ruth followed Naomi's instructions.Naomi advised Ruth to dress nicely and go to the threshing floor where Boaz was working. She told Ruth to wait until Boaz had finished eating and drinking, then to note where he lay down. Ruth was to uncover his feet and lie down, and Boaz would tell her what to do next. Ruth agreed to follow Naomi's instructions.

Ruth went to the threshing floor and did as Naomi had told her. After Boaz had eaten and was in good spirits, he lay down at the end of a pile of grain. Ruth approached quietly, uncovered his feet, and lay down. Around midnight, Boaz woke up and was startled to find a woman lying at his feet. He asked who she was, and Ruth replied, "I am your servant Ruth. Spread your garment over me, for you are a guardian-redeemer of our family."

Boaz blessed Ruth for her kindness and assured her that he would do everything she asked, as everyone in town knew she was a virtuous woman. However, he mentioned that there was another guardian-redeemer closer in line than he was. Boaz asked Ruth to stay the night and promised to resolve the matter in the morning. If the other guardian-redeemer was willing to redeem her, fine; if not, Boaz would do it.

Ruth stayed at Boaz's feet until morning but left before anyone could recognize her. Boaz gave her six measures of barley to take back to Naomi, saying she shouldn't return empty-handed. When Ruth returned to Naomi, she recounted everything that had happened. Naomi advised Ruth to wait, as Boaz would not rest until he had settled the matter that day.

Boaz went to the town gate and waited for the other guardian-redeemer to pass by. He called him over and gathered ten elders of the town as witnesses. Boaz explained that Naomi was selling a piece of land that belonged to their relative Elimelech. The other guardian-redeemer initially agreed to redeem it, but Boaz added that he would also have to marry Ruth to maintain the family line. The guardian-redeemer declined, fearing it would jeopardize his own estate, and told Boaz to redeem it himself.

To confirm the transaction, the guardian-redeemer removed his sandal and gave it to Boaz, a customary act in Israel. Boaz then declared to the elders and all the people that he had bought all of Elimelech's property and taken Ruth as his wife to preserve the family name. The elders and people blessed Boaz and Ruth, wishing them a prosperous future.

Boaz married Ruth, and the Lord blessed them with a son. The women of the town congratulated Naomi, saying the child would renew her life and sustain her in old age, as Ruth, who loved her, had given birth to him. Naomi took care of the child, and the women named him Obed. Obed became the father of Jesse, who was the father of David.

The genealogy from Perez to David is as follows: Perez fathered Hezron, Hezron fathered Ram, Ram fathered Amminadab, Amminadab fathered Nahshon, Nahshon fathered Salmon, Salmon fathered Boaz, Boaz fathered Obed, Obed fathered Jesse, and Jesse fathered David.

In the time of the judges, there was a man named Elkanah from Ramathaim in the hill country of Ephraim. He had two wives, Hannah and Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had none. Every year, Elkanah went to Shiloh to worship and sacrifice to the Lord. He gave portions of the sacrifice to Peninnah and her children, but he gave a double portion to Hannah because he loved her, even though the Lord had closed her womb.

Peninnah would provoke Hannah to irritate her, causing Hannah to weep and not eat. Elkanah tried to comfort her, asking why she was sad and if he wasn't better to her than ten sons. After eating and drinking in Shiloh, Hannah prayed to the Lord in deep anguish, vowing that if He gave her a son, she would dedicate him to the Lord for his entire life.

Eli the priest saw Hannah praying silently and thought she was drunk. He rebuked her, but Hannah explained that she was deeply troubled and was pouring out her soul to the Lord. Eli blessed her, asking God to grant her request. Hannah left, feeling uplifted, and ate something.

The next morning, Elkanah and his family worshipped before the Lord and returned home. The Lord remembered Hannah, and she conceived and gave birth to a son, naming him Samuel, saying, "Because I asked the Lord for him."

When it was time for the annual sacrifice, Hannah did not go, telling Elkanah she would wait until Samuel was weaned. Elkanah agreed, and when Samuel was weaned, Hannah took him to the house of the Lord in Shiloh, along with a sacrifice. She presented Samuel to Eli, reminding him that she was the woman who had prayed for this child. She dedicated Samuel to the Lord, and he worshipped there.

Hannah prayed a prayer of thanksgiving, rejoicing in the Lord's deliverance and exalting His power.Hannah prayed, "My heart rejoices in the Lord; my strength is lifted up by Him. There is no one holy like the Lord, no one besides Him, no rock like our God. Stop boasting so proudly, for the Lord is a God who knows, and He judges actions. The mighty warriors' bows are broken, but those who stumbled are now strong. Those who were full now work for food, while the hungry are satisfied. The barren woman has seven children, but the one with many sons is weak. The Lord brings death and gives life; He brings down to the grave and raises up. He makes some poor and others rich; He humbles and exalts. He lifts the poor from the dust and the needy from the ash heap, seating them with princes and giving them a place of honor. The foundations of the earth belong to the Lord; He has set the world upon them. He guards the steps of His faithful ones, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. It is not by strength that one prevails; those who oppose the Lord will be shattered. He will thunder against them from heaven; the Lord will judge the ends of the earth. He will give strength to His king and exalt the horn of His anointed."

Elkanah went home to Ramah, but the boy Samuel served the Lord under Eli the priest. Eli's sons were wicked; they did not know the Lord. The custom for the priests with the people was that when anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come with a three-pronged fork while the meat was boiling and would plunge it into the pan, kettle, or pot. Whatever the fork brought up, the priest would take for himself. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came to Shiloh. Even before the fat was burned, the priest's servant would come and say to the person sacrificing, "Give the priest some meat to roast; he won't accept boiled meat from you, only raw." If the person said, "Let the fat be burned first, and then take whatever you want," the servant would answer, "No, hand it over now; if you don't, I'll take it by force." This sin of the young men was very great in the Lord's sight, for they were treating the Lord's offering with contempt.

But Samuel was ministering before the Lord—a boy wearing a linen ephod. Each year his mother made him a little robe and took it to him when she went up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice. Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, saying, "May the Lord give you children by this woman to take the place of the one she prayed for and gave to the Lord." Then they would go home. The Lord was gracious to Hannah; she gave birth to three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Samuel grew up in the presence of the Lord.

Eli was very old, and he heard about everything his sons were doing to all Israel and how they slept with the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting. So he said to them, "Why do you do such things? I hear from all the people about these wicked deeds of yours. No, my sons; the report I hear spreading among the Lord's people is not good. If one person sins against another, God may mediate for the offender; but if anyone sins against the Lord, who will intercede for them?" His sons, however, did not listen to their father's rebuke, for it was the Lord's will to put them to death.

And the boy Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with the Lord and with people. Now a man of God came to Eli and said to him, "This is what the Lord says: 'Did I not clearly reveal myself to your ancestor's family when they were in Egypt under Pharaoh? I chose your ancestor out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, and to wear an ephod in my presence. I also gave your ancestor's family all the food offerings presented by the Israelites. Why do you scorn my sacrifice and offering that I prescribed for my dwelling? Why do you honor your sons more than me by fattening yourselves on the choice parts of every offering made by my people Israel?' Therefore the Lord, the God of Israel, declares: 'I promised that members of your family would minister before me forever.' But now the Lord declares: 'Far be it from me! Those who honor me I will honor, but those who despise me will be disdained. The time is coming when I will cut short your strength and the strength of your priestly house so that no one in it will reach old age, and you will see distress in my dwelling. Although good will be done to Israel, no one in your family line will ever reach old age. Every one of you that I do not cut off from serving at my altar I will spare only to destroy your sight and sap your strength, and all your descendants will die in the prime of life. And what happens to your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will be a sign to you—they will both die on the same day. I will raise up for myself a faithful priest, who will do according to what is in my heart and mind. I will firmly establish his priestly house, and they will minister before my anointed one always. Then everyone left in your family line will come and bow down before him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread and plead, "Appoint me to some priestly office so I can have food to eat."'"

The boy Samuel ministered before the Lord under Eli. In those days the word of the Lord was rare; there were not many visions. One night Eli, whose eyes were becoming so weak that he could barely see, was lying down in his usual place. The lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was lying down in the house of the Lord, where the ark of God was. Then the Lord called Samuel. Samuel answered, "Here I am." And he ran to Eli and said, "Here I am; you called me." But Eli said, "I did not call; go back and lie down." So he went and lay down. Again the Lord called, "Samuel!" And Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, "Here I am; you called me." "My son," Eli said, "I did not call; go back and lie down." Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord: The word of the Lord had not yet been revealed to him. A third time the Lord called, "Samuel!" And Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, "Here I am; you called me." Then Eli realized that the Lord was calling the boy. So Eli told Samuel, "Go and lie down, and if he calls you, say, 'Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.'" So Samuel went and lay down in his place. The Lord came and stood there, calling as at the other times, "Samuel! Samuel!" Then Samuel said, "Speak, for your servant is listening." And the Lord said to Samuel: "See, I am about to do something in Israel that will make the ears of everyone who hears about it tingle. At that time I will carry out against Eli everything I spoke against his family—from beginning to end. For I told him that I would judge his family forever because of the sin he knew about; his sons blasphemed God, and he did not restrain them. Therefore I swore to the house of Eli, 'The guilt of Eli's house will never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering.'"

Samuel lay down until morning and then opened the doors of the house of the Lord. He was afraid to tell Eli the vision, but Eli called him and said, "Samuel, my son." Samuel answered, "Here I am." "What was it he said to you?" Eli asked. "Do not hide it from me. May God deal with you, be it ever so severely, if you hide from me anything he told you." So Samuel told him everything, hiding nothing from him. Then Eli said, "He is the Lord; let him do what is good in his eyes."

The Lord was with Samuel as he grew up, and he let none of Samuel's words fall to the ground. And all Israel from Dan to Beersheba recognized that Samuel was attested as a prophet of the Lord. The Lord continued to appear at Shiloh, and there he revealed himself to Samuel through his word. And Samuel's word came to all Israel.

Now the Israelites went out to fight against the Philistines. The Israelites camped at Ebenezer, and the Philistines at Aphek. The Philistines deployed their forces to meet Israel, and as the battle spread, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand of them on the battlefield. When the soldiers returned to camp, the elders of Israel asked, "Why did the Lord bring defeat on us today before the Philistines? Let us bring the ark of the Lord's covenant from Shiloh, so that he may go with us and save us from the hand of our enemies." So the people sent men to Shiloh, and they brought back the ark of the covenant of the Lord Almighty, who is enthroned between the cherubim. And Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God. When the ark of the Lord's covenant came into the camp, all Israel raised such a great shout that the ground shook. Hearing the uproar, the Philistines asked, "What's all this shouting in the Hebrew camp?" When they learned that the ark of the Lord had come into the camp, the Philistines were afraid. "A god has come into the camp," they said. "Oh no! Nothing like this has happened before. Woe to us! Who will deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all kinds of plagues in the wilderness."The Philistines, recalling the plagues that struck Egypt, urged each other to be brave and fight like men to avoid becoming slaves to the Hebrews. They fought fiercely, and Israel was defeated, losing thirty thousand soldiers. The Ark of God was captured, and Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were killed.

A man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battlefield to Shiloh with torn clothes and dirt on his head, a sign of mourning. Eli, who was 98 years old and nearly blind, was anxiously waiting for news about the Ark. When the man arrived and reported the defeat, the deaths of Eli's sons, and the capture of the Ark, Eli fell backward from his seat, broke his neck, and died. He had judged Israel for forty years.

Phinehas' wife, who was pregnant and near delivery, went into labor upon hearing the news of the Ark's capture and the deaths of her husband and father-in-law. She gave birth to a son and named him Ichabod, meaning "The glory has departed from Israel," because the Ark of God was taken.

The Philistines took the Ark to Ashdod and placed it in the temple of their god Dagon. The next morning, they found Dagon fallen face down before the Ark. They set Dagon back up, but the following morning, Dagon had fallen again, this time with his head and hands broken off. The people of Ashdod were struck with tumors, and they decided to send the Ark to Gath. The same afflictions struck Gath, so they sent the Ark to Ekron. The Ekronites, fearing for their lives, demanded the Ark be sent back to Israel.

The Philistine leaders decided to return the Ark with a guilt offering of five gold tumors and five gold rats, representing the plagues that had struck them. They placed the Ark on a new cart pulled by two cows and sent it towards Beth Shemesh. The cows went straight to Beth Shemesh, where the people rejoiced to see the Ark. They offered sacrifices to the Lord, but some men of Beth Shemesh looked into the Ark and were struck down by God.

The people of Beth Shemesh sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kiriath Jearim, asking them to take the Ark. The men of Kiriath Jearim brought the Ark to the house of Abinadab and consecrated his son Eleazar to guard it. The Ark remained there for twenty years, and the Israelites mourned and sought the Lord.

Samuel told the Israelites to return to the Lord with all their hearts, put away foreign gods, and serve Him only. They gathered at Mizpah, fasted, and confessed their sins. When the Philistines heard of the gathering, they prepared to attack. The Israelites, fearing the Philistines, asked Samuel to pray for their deliverance.Samuel offered a young lamb as a burnt offering to the Lord and prayed for Israel. As he did, the Philistines approached for battle, but the Lord thundered loudly, causing confusion among them, and they were defeated by the Israelites. The Israelites chased the Philistines and struck them down until they reached Bethcar. Samuel set up a stone between Mizpeh and Shen, naming it Ebenezer, meaning "Thus far the Lord has helped us." The Philistines were subdued and did not invade Israel again during Samuel's lifetime. The cities taken by the Philistines were returned to Israel, and there was peace between Israel and the Amorites.

Samuel judged Israel throughout his life, traveling annually to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpeh to judge the people. He lived in Ramah, where he also judged Israel and built an altar to the Lord.

When Samuel grew old, he appointed his sons, Joel and Abiah, as judges over Israel in Beersheba. However, his sons were corrupt, taking bribes and perverting justice. The elders of Israel came to Samuel at Ramah, asking for a king to judge them like other nations. Samuel was displeased and prayed to the Lord, who told him to listen to the people, as they were rejecting God, not Samuel. God instructed Samuel to warn them about the consequences of having a king.

Samuel conveyed God's message to the people, explaining that a king would take their sons for his army and labor, their daughters for his service, and a portion of their fields, vineyards, and produce for his officials and servants. Despite the warning, the people insisted on having a king to lead and fight for them. Samuel reported their request to the Lord, who told him to grant their wish. Samuel then told the people to return to their cities.

A man named Kish from the tribe of Benjamin had a son named Saul, who was tall and handsome. Kish's donkeys went missing, so he sent Saul and a servant to find them. They searched various regions without success. In the land of Zuph, Saul suggested returning home, but the servant proposed consulting a man of God in a nearby city. They decided to visit the seer, bringing a small silver coin as a gift.

As they approached the city, they met young women drawing water, who directed them to the seer, Samuel. Samuel had been informed by the Lord the previous day that Saul would come and be anointed as the leader of Israel. When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord confirmed that Saul was the chosen one. Saul asked Samuel for directions to the seer's house, and Samuel revealed his identity, inviting Saul to dine with him and promising to disclose God's message the next day.

Samuel reassured Saul about the lost donkeys, which had been found, and hinted at Saul's future importance. Saul, surprised, mentioned his humble background. Samuel then brought Saul and his servant to a banquet, giving Saul a special portion of food. After the meal, Samuel spoke privately with Saul on the rooftop. The next morning, Samuel prepared to send Saul on his way, but first, he anointed Saul with oil, declaring him the chosen leader of Israel. Samuel gave Saul specific signs to confirm his anointment, including meeting men near Rachel's tomb who would inform him that the donkeys were found and that his father was now worried about him.Samuel told Saul that he would meet three men near the oak of Tabor. They would be carrying three young goats, three loaves of bread, and a bottle of wine. They would greet Saul and give him two loaves of bread. After that, Saul would go to the hill of God, where the Philistine garrison was. There, he would meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place with musical instruments, and they would be prophesying. The Spirit of the Lord would come upon Saul, and he would prophesy with them, becoming a different person. Samuel instructed Saul to do whatever the situation required because God would be with him. Saul was to go to Gilgal and wait seven days for Samuel to come and offer sacrifices and tell him what to do next.

As Saul turned to leave Samuel, God changed Saul's heart, and all the signs Samuel had mentioned came to pass that day. When Saul and his servant arrived at the hill, they met the group of prophets, and the Spirit of God came upon Saul, and he prophesied with them. People who knew Saul were surprised and asked if Saul was also among the prophets. This became a saying, "Is Saul also among the prophets?" After prophesying, Saul went to the high place.

Saul's uncle asked him and his servant where they had been. Saul replied that they had been looking for the donkeys and went to Samuel when they couldn't find them. Saul's uncle asked what Samuel had told them, and Saul said that Samuel had told them the donkeys were found but did not mention anything about the kingdom.

Samuel gathered the people at Mizpeh and reminded them that the Lord had brought them out of Egypt and saved them from their enemies. However, they had rejected God by asking for a king. Samuel then had all the tribes of Israel come forward, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen. From the tribe of Benjamin, the family of Matri was chosen, and Saul, the son of Kish, was selected. But Saul was hiding among the supplies. When they found him and brought him out, he stood taller than anyone else. Samuel told the people that Saul was the one the Lord had chosen, and the people shouted, "Long live the king!"

Samuel explained the rights and duties of kingship and wrote them down on a scroll, which he placed before the Lord. Then he sent everyone home, including Saul, who went to Gibeah with a group of men whose hearts God had touched. However, some troublemakers doubted Saul's ability to lead and did not bring him gifts, but Saul kept silent.

Nahash the Ammonite besieged Jabesh Gilead, and the people of Jabesh asked for a treaty, offering to serve Nahash. Nahash agreed on the condition that he could gouge out the right eye of every man in Jabesh to disgrace Israel. The elders of Jabesh asked for seven days to seek help from Israel. When the messengers reached Gibeah and told the people, they wept. Saul, returning from the fields, asked why they were crying, and they told him about the situation in Jabesh. The Spirit of God came upon Saul, and he became very angry. He took a pair of oxen, cut them into pieces, and sent the pieces throughout Israel, warning that anyone who did not follow him and Samuel would have their oxen treated the same way. The fear of the Lord fell on the people, and they united to follow Saul.

Saul mustered the troops at Bezek, counting 300,000 from Israel and 30,000 from Judah. He sent a message to the people of Jabesh Gilead, promising rescue by the next day. The people of Jabesh were overjoyed and told Nahash they would surrender the next day. Saul divided his men into three groups and attacked the Ammonite camp during the morning watch, defeating them and scattering the survivors.

The people then asked Samuel who had doubted Saul's kingship, wanting to put them to death. But Saul declared that no one would be executed that day because the Lord had rescued Israel. Samuel then invited the people to go to Gilgal to renew the kingship. They went to Gilgal, made Saul king before the Lord, and offered sacrifices, rejoicing greatly.

Samuel addressed all Israel, reminding them that he had listened to their request for a king and had appointed one. He asked if he had wronged anyone or taken anything unjustly, and the people confirmed that he had not. Samuel reminded them of the Lord's righteous acts, from bringing their ancestors out of Egypt to delivering them from their enemies. He warned them to follow the Lord and obey His commands, or they would face consequences. To demonstrate their wrongdoing in asking for a king, Samuel called upon the Lord to send thunder and rain during the wheat harvest, which the Lord did, causing the people to fear greatly. They asked Samuel to pray for them, acknowledging their sin in asking for a king. Samuel reassured them not to fear but to serve the Lord faithfully."Don't turn away to follow useless things that can't help or save you. The Lord won't abandon His people because of His great name and because He chose you. As for me, I will continue to pray for you and teach you the right way. Serve the Lord faithfully with all your heart and remember the great things He has done for you. But if you continue to do evil, both you and your king will be destroyed.

Saul reigned for one year, and in his second year, he chose 3,000 men from Israel. He kept 2,000 with him at Michmash and Bethel, and 1,000 with Jonathan in Gibeah. The rest were sent home. Jonathan attacked the Philistine garrison at Geba, and the Philistines heard about it. Saul blew the trumpet throughout the land, calling the Hebrews to hear. All Israel heard that Saul had attacked the Philistine garrison, making Israel detestable to the Philistines. The people gathered to Saul at Gilgal.

The Philistines assembled to fight Israel with 30,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen, and troops as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They camped at Michmash, east of Beth Aven. When the Israelites saw they were in trouble, they hid in caves, thickets, rocks, high places, and pits. Some crossed the Jordan to Gad and Gilead. Saul remained at Gilgal, and the people with him were trembling.

Saul waited seven days, the time set by Samuel, but Samuel did not come to Gilgal, and the people began to scatter. Saul then offered the burnt offering himself. Just as he finished, Samuel arrived, and Saul went out to greet him. Samuel asked what Saul had done. Saul explained that he saw the people scattering, Samuel had not arrived on time, and the Philistines were gathering at Michmash. Saul felt compelled to offer the burnt offering to seek the Lord's favor.

Samuel told Saul he had acted foolishly and not kept the Lord's command. If he had, the Lord would have established his kingdom over Israel forever. But now, Saul's kingdom would not endure. The Lord had sought a man after His own heart and appointed him leader because Saul did not keep the Lord's command. Samuel then left Gilgal and went to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul counted about 600 men with him.

Saul, Jonathan, and their men stayed in Gibeah, while the Philistines camped at Michmash. Raiding parties came from the Philistine camp in three groups, heading toward Ophrah, Beth Horon, and the valley of Zeboim. There were no blacksmiths in Israel because the Philistines had banned them to prevent the Hebrews from making swords or spears. The Israelites had to go to the Philistines to sharpen their tools. On the day of battle, only Saul and Jonathan had swords or spears.

One day, Jonathan told his armor-bearer to go with him to the Philistine outpost on the other side, but he did not tell his father. Saul was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah under a pomegranate tree in Migron with about 600 men, including Ahijah, the priest. Jonathan and his armor-bearer crossed a pass with sharp rocks on either side, named Bozez and Seneh. Jonathan suggested they go to the Philistine outpost, believing the Lord could save them regardless of their numbers. His armor-bearer agreed to follow him.

Jonathan proposed they reveal themselves to the Philistines. If the Philistines told them to wait, they would stay put. But if the Philistines invited them up, it would be a sign that the Lord had given them into their hands. When they showed themselves, the Philistines mocked them, saying the Hebrews were coming out of their hiding places. They invited Jonathan and his armor-bearer to come up, and Jonathan took it as a sign. They climbed up, and Jonathan struck down about twenty men in a small area. Panic struck the Philistine camp, and the ground shook, causing great confusion.

Saul's lookouts in Gibeah saw the Philistine army melting away. Saul ordered a count and found Jonathan and his armor-bearer missing. Saul then called for the ark of God. While he was talking to the priest, the commotion in the Philistine camp increased, and Saul told the priest to stop. Saul and his men joined the battle, finding the Philistines in chaos, fighting each other. Hebrews who had previously joined the Philistines switched sides to fight with Israel. Israelites who had hidden in the hills of Ephraim also joined the battle. The Lord saved Israel that day, and the battle moved beyond Beth Aven.

The Israelites were in distress because Saul had bound them with an oath, cursing anyone who ate food before evening. The troops were exhausted. They came to a forest with honey on the ground, but no one ate because of the oath. Jonathan, unaware of the oath, dipped his staff in the honeycomb and ate, feeling refreshed. When told about the oath, Jonathan criticized his father for troubling the land, noting how much better the victory would have been if the troops had eaten. The Israelites struck down the Philistines from Michmash to Aijalon, but they were exhausted and pounced on the plunder, eating meat with blood, which was against the law. Saul was informed and ordered a large stone to be rolled over. He instructed the people to slaughter their animals properly and eat without sinning against the Lord. That night, Saul built an altar to the Lord, the first he had built.

Saul then proposed to pursue the Philistines by night and plunder them until dawn. The troops agreed, but the priest suggested seeking God's will first. Saul asked God if he should pursue the Philistines, but received no answer. Saul then gathered the leaders and declared that someone had sinned, vowing that even if it was his son Jonathan, they would die. The people remained silent. Saul and Jonathan were chosen by lot, and Jonathan was identified as the sinner. Jonathan admitted to eating a little honey and was ready to die. But the people defended Jonathan, saying he had brought about the great victory and should not die. They rescued Jonathan, and he was not put to death. Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines, and they withdrew to their own land."Saul was informed that the people were sinning against the Lord by eating meat with blood. He ordered a large stone to be rolled over and instructed everyone to bring their oxen and sheep to be slaughtered properly, so they wouldn't sin against the Lord. That night, everyone brought their animals and slaughtered them there. Saul built an altar to the Lord, the first one he had built.

Saul then suggested attacking the Philistines by night and plundering them until morning. The troops agreed, but the priest advised seeking God's guidance first. Saul asked God if they should pursue the Philistines, but received no answer. Saul then gathered the leaders to find out who had sinned, vowing that even if it was his son Jonathan, they would die. The people remained silent.

Saul and Jonathan were chosen by lot, and Jonathan was identified as the sinner. Jonathan admitted to eating a little honey and was ready to die. However, the people defended Jonathan, saying he had brought about the great victory and should not die. They rescued Jonathan, and he was not put to death. Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines, and they withdrew to their own land.

Saul took control of the kingdom of Israel and fought against all his enemies on every side: Moab, Ammon, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. He gathered an army and defeated the Amalekites, delivering Israel from those who plundered them. Saul's sons were Jonathan, Ishui, and Melchishua, and his daughters were Merab and Michal. His wife was Ahinoam, and the captain of his army was Abner, Saul's uncle's son. There was constant war with the Philistines during Saul's reign, and he recruited any strong or valiant man he saw.

Samuel told Saul that the Lord had sent him to anoint Saul as king over Israel and now commanded him to destroy the Amalekites completely. Saul gathered his troops and attacked the Amalekites, but he spared their king, Agag, and the best of their livestock. The Lord told Samuel that He regretted making Saul king because he had not followed His commands. Samuel confronted Saul, who claimed he had obeyed the Lord but blamed the people for sparing the best livestock to sacrifice to God. Samuel rebuked Saul, saying obedience is better than sacrifice and that rebellion is like witchcraft. Because Saul rejected the Lord's command, the Lord rejected him as king.

Saul admitted his sin and asked Samuel to pardon him and return with him to worship the Lord. Samuel refused, saying the Lord had rejected Saul as king. As Samuel turned to leave, Saul tore his robe, and Samuel declared that the Lord had torn the kingdom from Saul and given it to someone better. Saul pleaded for honor before the elders and Israel, and Samuel reluctantly agreed. Samuel then executed Agag, the Amalekite king, and returned to Ramah, while Saul went to his home in Gibeah. Samuel mourned for Saul, and the Lord regretted making Saul king over Israel.

The Lord instructed Samuel to stop mourning for Saul and go to Jesse of Bethlehem, for He had chosen one of Jesse's sons as king. Samuel feared Saul would kill him if he found out, but the Lord told him to take a heifer and say he was going to sacrifice to the Lord. Samuel did as the Lord commanded and went to Bethlehem. The town's elders trembled at his arrival, but Samuel assured them he came in peace to sacrifice to the Lord. He invited Jesse and his sons to the sacrifice. When Samuel saw Jesse's son Eliab, he thought he was the Lord's anointed, but the Lord told Samuel not to consider his appearance or height, for the Lord looks at the heart, not the outward appearance. Jesse then called his son Abinadab to pass before Samuel.Samuel then asked Jesse if he had any more sons. Jesse mentioned his youngest son, who was tending the sheep. Samuel insisted they bring him, saying they wouldn't sit down until he arrived. When David came, he was handsome and healthy-looking. The Lord told Samuel to anoint him, as he was the chosen one. Samuel anointed David, and the Spirit of the Lord came upon him from that day forward. Samuel then returned to Ramah.

Meanwhile, the Spirit of the Lord had left Saul, and he was tormented by an evil spirit. Saul's servants suggested finding someone who could play the harp to soothe him. One servant mentioned David, the son of Jesse, who was skilled at playing the harp and was also a brave warrior. Saul sent for David, and Jesse sent David to Saul with gifts. David entered Saul's service and became his armor-bearer. Whenever the evil spirit troubled Saul, David would play the harp, and Saul would feel better.

The Philistines gathered their armies for battle at a place called Shochoh in Judah. Saul and the Israelites set up camp in the Valley of Elah to face them. The Philistines had a champion named Goliath, who was over nine feet tall and wore heavy armor. Goliath challenged the Israelites to send a man to fight him, saying the losing side would become the servants of the winners. Saul and the Israelites were terrified.

David, the youngest son of Jesse, was tending his father's sheep. Jesse sent David to the battlefield with food for his brothers and to check on them. When David arrived, he heard Goliath's challenge and saw the fear in the Israelite camp. David asked what would be done for the man who defeated Goliath. His brothers scolded him, but David persisted.

David was brought to Saul and offered to fight Goliath. Saul doubted David's ability, but David recounted how he had killed lions and bears while protecting his sheep. He believed the Lord would deliver him from Goliath as well. Saul agreed and gave David his armor, but David found it cumbersome and took it off. Instead, he took his staff, five smooth stones, and his sling.

As David approached Goliath, the giant mocked him. David responded that he came in the name of the Lord and that the Lord would deliver Goliath into his hands. David ran towards Goliath, slung a stone, and struck Goliath on the forehead, killing him. David then used Goliath's sword to cut off his head. The Philistines fled, and the Israelites pursued them, winning a great victory.David's stone hit Goliath in the forehead, sinking in and causing him to fall face down on the ground. David defeated Goliath with just a sling and a stone, without a sword. He then ran over, took Goliath's sword, and used it to cut off his head. Seeing their champion dead, the Philistines fled. The Israelites and men of Judah chased them down, killing many along the way and plundering their camp. David took Goliath's head to Jerusalem but kept his armor in his tent.

When Saul saw David going out to fight Goliath, he asked his commander, Abner, about David's family. Abner didn't know, so Saul asked David directly. David replied that he was the son of Jesse from Bethlehem. After David finished speaking with Saul, Jonathan, Saul's son, formed a deep bond with David and loved him as himself. Saul kept David with him and didn't let him return home. Jonathan and David made a covenant because of their strong friendship. Jonathan gave David his robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt.

David succeeded in everything Saul sent him to do, and Saul made him a high-ranking officer. This pleased all the people and Saul's servants. When David returned from killing Goliath, women from all over Israel came out singing and dancing to celebrate, praising David for killing tens of thousands compared to Saul's thousands. This made Saul very angry and jealous, fearing that David might take over the kingdom.

The next day, an evil spirit from God tormented Saul, and he tried to kill David with a javelin while David was playing the harp. David escaped twice. Saul was afraid of David because the Lord was with David but had left Saul. Saul then made David a commander over a thousand men, and David continued to succeed in everything he did because the Lord was with him. This made Saul even more afraid, but all of Israel and Judah loved David.

Saul offered his older daughter, Merab, to David in marriage, hoping the Philistines would kill David in battle. David humbly questioned his worthiness to be the king's son-in-law. However, Merab was given to another man. Saul's other daughter, Michal, loved David, and Saul saw this as another opportunity to trap David. Saul told David he could marry Michal if he brought back 100 Philistine foreskins, hoping David would be killed in the process. David succeeded, bringing back 200 foreskins, and married Michal. Saul realized the Lord was with David and that Michal loved him, making Saul even more fearful and hostile towards David.

David continued to succeed in battles, gaining more respect than all of Saul's other officers. Saul then ordered his son Jonathan and all his servants to kill David. Jonathan, who loved David, warned him to hide and spoke well of him to Saul. Saul swore not to kill David, and Jonathan brought David back to Saul's service. However, another war broke out, and David again defeated the Philistines. Saul, tormented by an evil spirit, tried to kill David with a javelin again, but David escaped.

Saul sent men to David's house to kill him, but Michal helped David escape through a window. She then deceived Saul's men by placing an idol in David's bed. When Saul confronted Michal, she claimed David had threatened her. David fled to Samuel in Ramah, and they stayed in Naioth. Saul sent men to capture David, but they ended up prophesying under the influence of the Spirit of God. This happened three times. Finally, Saul went himself, but he too was overcome by the Spirit and prophesied, lying naked all day and night.

David fled from Naioth in Ramah and asked Jonathan why Saul wanted to kill him, questioning what he had done wrong.Jonathan reassured David, saying, "Don't worry, you won't die. My father tells me everything, big or small. Why would he hide this from me? It can't be true." But David insisted, "Your father knows we're close friends, so he won't tell you. But as surely as the Lord lives, I'm just a step away from death." Jonathan then asked, "What do you want me to do?" David replied, "Tomorrow is the new moon festival, and I should be dining with the king. Let me hide in the field until the evening of the third day. If your father notices I'm missing, tell him I asked to go to Bethlehem for a family sacrifice. If he says it's okay, then I'm safe. But if he gets angry, you'll know he intends to harm me.
