Please be kind to me, as we've made a covenant before the Lord. If I'm guilty, kill me yourself rather than bringing me to your father." Jonathan responded, "Never! If I knew my father planned to harm you, I'd tell you."

David then asked, "How will you let me know if your father answers harshly?" Jonathan suggested they go out to the field. There, Jonathan said, "By tomorrow or the next day, I'll find out my father's intentions. If he's favorable towards you, I'll send word. But if he plans to harm you, I'll let you know so you can escape safely. May the Lord be with you as He was with my father. Show me the Lord's kindness while I'm alive, and don't ever cut off your kindness from my family, even when the Lord has eliminated all your enemies." Jonathan made a covenant with David's house, and they reaffirmed their bond because Jonathan loved David as himself.

Jonathan then instructed David, "Tomorrow is the new moon festival, and you'll be missed because your seat will be empty. After three days, go to the place where you hid before and stay by the stone Ezel. I'll shoot three arrows as if aiming at a target. If I tell the boy fetching the arrows, 'Look, the arrows are on this side of you,' then you can come back safely. But if I say, 'The arrows are beyond you,' then you must leave, for the Lord is sending you away. Remember, the Lord is witness between us forever."

David hid in the field, and when the new moon festival came, the king sat down to eat. Saul noticed David's absence but thought he might be ceremonially unclean. On the second day, Saul asked Jonathan why David wasn't at the meal. Jonathan explained that David had asked to go to Bethlehem for a family sacrifice. Saul became furious with Jonathan, accusing him of siding with David to his own shame. He declared that as long as David lived, Jonathan's kingdom would not be established and ordered Jonathan to bring David to him to be killed. Jonathan questioned why David should be killed, and Saul threw a javelin at him. Jonathan realized his father was determined to kill David.

The next morning, Jonathan went to the field with a boy and shot an arrow beyond him, signaling David to flee. Jonathan sent the boy back to the city with his gear. David then came out from hiding, bowed to Jonathan, and they wept together. Jonathan told David to go in peace, reaffirming their covenant in the Lord's name. David then left, and Jonathan returned to the city.

David went to Nob to see Ahimelech the priest, who was alarmed to see him alone. David explained that he was on a secret mission from the king and asked for food. Ahimelech gave him consecrated bread, as there was no other bread available. David also asked for a weapon, and Ahimelech gave him the sword of Goliath. David then fled to Achish, the king of Gath. When Achish's servants recognized him, David pretended to be insane to avoid harm. Achish dismissed him, saying he had enough madmen already.

David escaped to the cave of Adullam, where his family and others in distress joined him, forming a group of about 400 men. David then went to Mizpeh in Moab, asking the king to shelter his parents until he knew God's plan for him. The prophet Gad later advised David to leave the stronghold and go to the land of Judah.David left and went to the forest of Hareth. When Saul heard that David and his men had been found, he was in Gibeah, sitting under a tree with his spear in hand, surrounded by his servants. Saul addressed his servants, accusing them of conspiring with David and not informing him about Jonathan's alliance with David. Doeg the Edomite, one of Saul's servants, reported seeing David with Ahimelech the priest, who had provided David with food and the sword of Goliath.

Saul summoned Ahimelech and all the priests from Nob. When they arrived, Saul accused Ahimelech of conspiring with David. Ahimelech defended himself, stating that David was a loyal servant and son-in-law to the king. He claimed ignorance of any conspiracy. Despite this, Saul ordered the death of Ahimelech and his family. Saul's servants refused to kill the priests, so Doeg carried out the order, killing 85 priests and destroying the city of Nob, including its inhabitants and livestock.

One of Ahimelech's sons, Abiathar, escaped and joined David, informing him of the massacre. David acknowledged his role in the tragedy and assured Abiathar of his protection.

David then learned that the Philistines were attacking Keilah and sought God's guidance on whether to intervene. God instructed David to save Keilah. Despite his men's fear, David obeyed and defeated the Philistines, saving the town. Abiathar brought an ephod to David, which he used to seek further guidance from God.

Saul heard of David's presence in Keilah and planned to besiege the town. David, aware of Saul's intentions, asked God if the people of Keilah would betray him. God confirmed they would, so David and his 600 men left Keilah and wandered in the wilderness. Saul continued to pursue David, but God protected him.

Jonathan visited David in the wilderness, encouraging him and reaffirming their covenant. The Ziphites informed Saul of David's location, prompting Saul to pursue him again. David narrowly escaped when Saul was called away to deal with a Philistine invasion. David then moved to the strongholds of Engedi.

Saul, upon returning from the Philistine battle, resumed his search for David with 3,000 men. Saul entered a cave to rest, unaware that David and his men were hiding inside. David's men urged him to kill Saul, but David only cut off a piece of Saul's robe, later feeling guilty for even that. David revealed himself to Saul, showing the piece of the robe as proof of his loyalty and lack of ill intent. Saul, moved by David's gesture, acknowledged David's righteousness and predicted his future as king.David said to Saul, "Why are you chasing me? I'm like a dead dog or a flea. Let the Lord judge between us and save me from your hand." When David finished speaking, Saul recognized his voice and wept, admitting that David was more righteous for repaying good for evil. Saul acknowledged that David would be king and asked him to swear not to destroy his descendants. David agreed, and Saul went home while David and his men returned to their stronghold.

After Samuel died, David moved to the wilderness of Paran. There was a wealthy man named Nabal in Maon, who was harsh and evil, but his wife Abigail was intelligent and beautiful. David sent men to ask Nabal for provisions, reminding him of the protection they had provided his shepherds. Nabal insulted David's men, refusing to help. David, angered, prepared to attack Nabal.

One of Nabal's servants informed Abigail of the situation. She quickly gathered supplies and went to meet David, pleading for mercy and taking the blame for her husband's actions. She reminded David that God had kept him from bloodshed and asked him to accept her gift. David praised her wisdom and accepted the provisions, promising not to harm Nabal's household.

When Abigail told Nabal what had happened, he had a heart attack and died ten days later. David praised God for avenging him and sent for Abigail to become his wife. She agreed and joined David, along with her maidservants. David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel, while Saul gave David's first wife, Michal, to another man.

The Ziphites informed Saul of David's location, prompting Saul to pursue him with 3,000 men. David, aware of Saul's approach, sent spies and confirmed Saul's presence. David and Abishai snuck into Saul's camp at night, finding Saul asleep with his spear stuck in the ground beside him.David and Abishai found Saul asleep with his spear stuck in the ground beside him, surrounded by his men. Abishai suggested killing Saul, but David refused, saying it was wrong to harm the Lord's anointed. Instead, David took Saul's spear and water jug and left. 

From a safe distance, David called out to Abner, Saul's commander, questioning why he hadn't protected the king. Saul recognized David's voice and admitted his wrongdoing, asking David to return. David showed the spear as proof of his mercy and reiterated his trust in God's justice. Saul blessed David, acknowledging his future success, and they parted ways.

David, fearing for his life, decided to escape to the land of the Philistines. He and his men, along with their families, settled in Gath under King Achish. Saul stopped pursuing David upon hearing this. David requested a place in the countryside, and Achish gave him Ziklag, where David lived for a year and four months.

During this time, David and his men raided various groups, leaving no survivors to report back to Gath. Achish trusted David, believing he had turned against Israel. 

The Philistines prepared for war against Israel, and Achish expected David to join them. David agreed, and Achish promised to make him his personal bodyguard.

Meanwhile, Saul, desperate for guidance as the Philistines gathered for battle, sought out a medium in Endor. Disguised, he asked her to summon Samuel. When Samuel appeared, he rebuked Saul for disturbing him and foretold Saul's defeat and death in the upcoming battle. Saul, terrified and weak from fasting, was persuaded by the medium and his servants to eat before returning to his camp.The Philistines gathered their armies at Aphek, while the Israelites camped by a spring in Jezreel. The Philistine leaders marched in units of hundreds and thousands, with David and his men at the rear with Achish. The Philistine commanders questioned Achish about David's presence, reminding him that David was once Saul's servant and had been with them for a long time without causing trouble. However, the commanders were angry and insisted that David should not join them in battle, fearing he might turn against them to regain favor with Saul.

Achish called David and told him that although he trusted him, the other leaders did not. He asked David to return to the place he had been given and not join the battle. David questioned what he had done wrong, but Achish reassured him that he was trusted like an angel of God. Despite this, the commanders' decision stood, and David was to leave early the next morning.

David and his men left early and returned to the land of the Philistines, while the Philistines advanced to Jezreel. When David and his men reached Ziklag on the third day, they found it had been attacked and burned by the Amalekites, who had taken their families captive. David and his men were devastated and wept until they had no strength left. David's two wives were also taken captive.

David was deeply distressed as his men spoke of stoning him out of grief for their families. However, David found strength in the Lord. He asked Abiathar the priest to bring him the ephod and inquired of the Lord whether he should pursue the raiders. The Lord told him to pursue, promising that he would overtake them and recover everything.

David set out with his 600 men, but 200 were too exhausted to cross the brook Besor, so they stayed behind. David and the remaining 400 men continued the pursuit. They found an Egyptian in the field, gave him food and water, and revived him. The Egyptian revealed he was a servant of an Amalekite and had been left behind when he fell ill. He confirmed that the Amalekites had raided the south and burned Ziklag.

David asked the Egyptian to lead him to the raiders, and the man agreed on the condition that David would not kill him or return him to his master. The Egyptian led David to the Amalekites, who were spread out, celebrating their plunder. David attacked them from twilight until the evening of the next day, recovering everything the Amalekites had taken, including his two wives. Nothing was missing, and David took all the flocks and herds, declaring them his spoil.

When David returned to the 200 men who had stayed behind, some of the men who had fought with him did not want to share the plunder with them. David insisted that everyone should share equally, as the Lord had preserved them and delivered their enemies into their hands. This became a lasting ordinance in Israel.

David also sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah and his friends, sharing the spoils with those in various towns where he and his men had roamed.

Meanwhile, the Philistines fought against Israel, and the Israelites fled, with many falling on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines killed Saul's sons, Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua. Saul was critically wounded by archers and asked his armor-bearer to kill him to avoid capture. When the armor-bearer refused, Saul fell on his own sword. Seeing Saul dead, the armor-bearer also killed himself. Thus, Saul, his three sons, his armor-bearer, and all his men died together that day.

The Israelites on the other side of the valley and the Jordan saw the defeat and fled, allowing the Philistines to occupy their towns. The next day, the Philistines found Saul and his sons' bodies on Mount Gilboa. They beheaded Saul, stripped his armor, and sent it throughout their land to proclaim their victory. They placed his armor in the temple of Ashtaroth and fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan.

When the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done, their valiant men retrieved the bodies of Saul and his sons, burned them, and buried their bones under a tree in Jabesh, fasting for seven days.

After Saul's death, David returned to Ziklag from defeating the Amalekites. On the third day, a man arrived from Saul's camp with torn clothes and dirt on his head, showing respect to David. David asked him where he came from, and the man replied that he had escaped from the Israelite camp. David inquired about the battle, and the man reported that the people had fled, many were dead, and Saul and his son Jonathan were also dead.David asked the young man how he knew Saul and Jonathan were dead. The young man, an Amalekite, explained that he found Saul on Mount Gilboa, leaning on his spear with chariots and horsemen closing in. Saul saw him and asked who he was. When the young man replied he was an Amalekite, Saul asked him to kill him to end his suffering. The young man did so, took Saul's crown and bracelet, and brought them to David.

David and his men mourned, wept, and fasted until evening for Saul, Jonathan, and the fallen people of Israel. David then questioned the young man about his background and why he wasn't afraid to kill the Lord's anointed. David ordered one of his men to kill the young Amalekite for his actions.

David lamented over Saul and Jonathan, expressing his grief and honoring their bravery and unity in life and death. He instructed the people of Judah to learn the use of the bow, as recorded in the Book of Jasher. David's lament highlighted the loss of Israel's beauty and strength, urging that the news not be spread to avoid the Philistines' rejoicing.

David then asked the Lord if he should go to any city in Judah, and the Lord directed him to Hebron. David, his two wives, and his men moved to Hebron, where the men of Judah anointed him king over the house of Judah. David sent a message to the men of Jabesh-gilead, thanking them for burying Saul and encouraging them to be strong and valiant.

Meanwhile, Abner, the commander of Saul's army, made Saul's son Ishbosheth king over Israel, except for Judah, which followed David. Ishbosheth reigned for two years, while David was king in Hebron for seven and a half years. A battle ensued between Abner's and David's forces, resulting in heavy losses for Abner's men.

During the battle, Asahel, one of David's men, pursued Abner but was killed. Joab and Abishai continued the pursuit until Abner called for a truce, which Joab accepted. Both sides retreated, and David's forces returned to Hebron.

The conflict between the houses of Saul and David continued, with David growing stronger. David had several sons born in Hebron. Abner, strengthening his position in Saul's house, had a falling out with Ishbosheth over a concubine. Angered, Abner decided to support David, offering to bring all Israel under David's rule. David agreed, on the condition that Abner bring Saul's daughter Michal to him.David told Abner that he wouldn't see him unless he brought Michal, Saul's daughter. David then sent messengers to Ishbosheth, Saul's son, demanding Michal, his wife, whom he had married for a bride price of 100 Philistine foreskins. Ishbosheth took Michal from her husband, Phaltiel, who followed her weeping until Abner told him to go back.

Abner spoke to the elders of Israel, reminding them that they had wanted David as king and that God had promised David would save Israel from their enemies. Abner also spoke to the tribe of Benjamin and then went to Hebron to meet David with 20 men. David hosted a feast for them. Abner promised to gather all Israel to support David as king, and David sent him away in peace.

When Joab returned from a raid and learned that David had let Abner go, he confronted David, accusing Abner of deceit. Joab then secretly sent for Abner and killed him to avenge his brother Asahel's death. David declared his innocence in Abner's death and cursed Joab's family. David mourned Abner, and all the people wept with him, understanding that David had not ordered Abner's death.

When Ishbosheth heard of Abner's death, he lost courage, and all Israel was troubled. Ishbosheth had two captains, Baanah and Rechab, who killed him while he was resting at noon. They brought his head to David, expecting a reward. Instead, David condemned them for killing an innocent man and had them executed. Ishbosheth's head was buried in Abner's tomb.

All the tribes of Israel then came to David at Hebron, acknowledging him as their leader. They anointed David king over Israel. David was 30 years old when he began to reign, ruling Judah for seven and a half years and all Israel and Judah for 33 years. David captured Jerusalem from the Jebusites and made it his city, growing stronger with God's support.

King Hiram of Tyre sent materials and workers to build David a palace. David realized that God had established his kingdom for the sake of Israel. He took more wives and concubines in Jerusalem, and many children were born to him.

When the Philistines heard that David was king over Israel, they attacked. David sought God's guidance and defeated them at Baal-perazim. The Philistines attacked again, and God instructed David to circle behind them and wait for the sound of marching in the mulberry trees. David followed God's command and defeated the Philistines from Geba to Gezer.David gathered 30,000 chosen men of Israel and went with them to bring the Ark of God from Baale of Judah. They placed the Ark on a new cart, driven by Uzzah and Ahio, sons of Abinadab. As they transported the Ark, David and the Israelites celebrated with various musical instruments. When they reached Nachon's threshing floor, Uzzah touched the Ark to steady it, and God struck him down for his error. David was upset and named the place Perezuzzah. Fearing the Lord, David decided not to bring the Ark into the City of David but instead took it to the house of Obededom the Gittite, where it stayed for three months, blessing Obededom's household.

Hearing of these blessings, David brought the Ark to the City of David with great joy. After every six steps, he sacrificed oxen and fatlings. David danced with all his might, wearing a linen ephod, and the Israelites celebrated with shouts and trumpet sounds. Michal, Saul's daughter, saw David dancing and despised him. The Ark was placed in a tent David had set up, and he offered burnt and peace offerings. David then blessed the people and distributed food to everyone before they returned home.

When David returned to bless his household, Michal criticized him for dancing shamelessly. David responded that he danced before the Lord, who chose him over her father Saul, and would continue to do so. Michal remained childless until her death.

Later, as David rested from his enemies, he expressed to the prophet Nathan his desire to build a house for the Ark of God. Nathan initially encouraged him, but that night, God told Nathan to inform David that He had never asked for a house of cedar. God reminded David of his humble beginnings as a shepherd and His support in making David a great leader. God promised to establish a place for Israel and to build a house for David's lineage, ensuring his kingdom's eternal legacy. David's son would build a house for God's name, and his throne would be established forever. God assured David of His unwavering mercy, unlike with Saul.

David humbly thanked God for His promises and prayed for their fulfillment, praising God's greatness and His unique relationship with Israel. David then defeated the Philistines, Moabites, and Hadadezer, king of Zobah, taking many captives and spoils. He also subdued the Syrians of Damascus, who became his servants and brought gifts. David dedicated the silver and gold from these conquests to the Lord, further establishing his reign and God's favor.David gained fame after defeating the Syrians in the Valley of Salt, killing 18,000 men. He established military outposts throughout Edom, and the Edomites became his servants. The Lord protected David wherever he went. David ruled over all Israel, ensuring justice and fairness for everyone. Joab, son of Zeruiah, led the army; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the recorder; Zadok, son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, son of Abiathar, were priests; Seraiah was the scribe; Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, commanded the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David's sons were chief officials.

David asked if anyone from Saul's family was still alive so he could show kindness for Jonathan's sake. A servant named Ziba informed him that Jonathan's son, Mephibosheth, who was lame in both feet, was living in Lodebar. David brought Mephibosheth to Jerusalem, assured him not to fear, and promised to restore Saul's land to him and have him eat at the king's table always. Mephibosheth humbly accepted, and David instructed Ziba and his family to farm the land for Mephibosheth. Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem and ate at the king's table, despite his disability.

After the king of the Ammonites died, David sent messengers to console his son Hanun. However, Hanun's advisors suspected David's intentions and humiliated the messengers. David, hearing of this, instructed the messengers to stay in Jericho until their beards grew back. The Ammonites, realizing they had angered David, hired Syrian mercenaries. David sent Joab and his army to confront them. Joab divided his forces, and they successfully defeated the Syrians and Ammonites. The Syrians regrouped but were again defeated by David, who killed many of their soldiers and their commander, Shobach. The remaining Syrian kings made peace with Israel and served them, fearing to help the Ammonites again.

In the spring, when kings typically go to war, David sent Joab and the army to besiege Rabbah, but he stayed in Jerusalem. One evening, David saw a beautiful woman, Bathsheba, bathing. He learned she was the wife of Uriah the Hittite. David summoned her, slept with her, and she became pregnant. David called Uriah back from the battlefield, hoping he would sleep with his wife and cover up the pregnancy. Uriah, however, refused to go home while his comrades were in battle. David then made Uriah drunk, but he still didn't go home. David sent Uriah back to the front lines with a letter instructing Joab to place him in a dangerous position where he would be killed. Uriah died in battle, and Joab reported back to David.David received news that Uriah the Hittite had died in battle. He told the messenger to encourage Joab, saying that the sword takes one person as well as another, and to strengthen their attack on the city. When Uriah's wife, Bathsheba, heard of his death, she mourned. After her mourning period, David brought her to his house, made her his wife, and she bore him a son. However, the Lord was displeased with David's actions.

The Lord sent the prophet Nathan to David. Nathan told David a parable about a rich man with many flocks and a poor man with only one beloved lamb. When a traveler came to the rich man, he took the poor man's lamb to prepare a meal instead of using one of his own. David was furious and declared that the man deserved to die and must repay fourfold for his lack of pity. Nathan then revealed that David was the man in the parable, condemning him for taking Uriah's wife and having Uriah killed.

Nathan conveyed God's message: God had given David everything, yet David despised His command by committing this evil. As a consequence, violence would plague David's family, and his wives would be given to someone close to him in broad daylight. David confessed his sin, and Nathan assured him that God had forgiven him, but the child born to Bathsheba would die. The child became very ill, and David fasted and prayed for its recovery. Despite his efforts, the child died on the seventh day. David's servants hesitated to inform him, fearing his reaction, but David realized the child had died and accepted it. He then washed, changed clothes, worshipped in the house of the Lord, and ate.

David explained to his servants that while the child was alive, he hoped for God's grace, but now that the child was dead, fasting was futile. He comforted Bathsheba, and they had another son named Solomon, whom the Lord loved. Nathan the prophet named him Jedidiah, meaning "loved by the Lord."

Meanwhile, Joab continued to fight against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal city. He urged David to gather the rest of the troops to take the city, ensuring it would be named after David. David led the final assault, took the city, and claimed the king's crown, which was very heavy and adorned with precious stones. He also took a great amount of spoil from the city and subjected its people to forced labor. David and his army then returned to Jerusalem.

After these events, David's son Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar, whom their half-brother Amnon loved. Amnon became obsessed with Tamar and, with the help of his cunning friend Jonadab, devised a plan to be alone with her. Pretending to be ill, Amnon requested Tamar to prepare food for him. When she brought the food to his room, he forced himself on her despite her pleas. Afterward, Amnon's love turned to intense hatred, and he cruelly sent her away. Tamar, devastated, went to her brother Absalom's house, who advised her to stay quiet about the incident. King David was furious when he heard about it, but Absalom said nothing to Amnon, though he hated him for what he had done to Tamar.

Two years later, Absalom invited all the king's sons to a sheep-shearing event. He insisted that Amnon join them, despite David's initial reluctance.Absalom invited all the king's sons to a sheep-shearing event and insisted that Amnon join them. When Amnon was drunk, Absalom ordered his servants to kill him. The other sons fled on their mules. News reached David that all his sons were dead, but Jonadab clarified that only Amnon was killed, as Absalom had planned since Amnon assaulted Tamar. Absalom fled to Geshur and stayed there for three years. David longed to see Absalom, as he had come to terms with Amnon's death.

Joab noticed David's longing for Absalom and devised a plan. He sent a wise woman from Tekoa to pretend to be in mourning and tell David a story about her two sons, one of whom killed the other. She pleaded for the king's protection for her remaining son. David promised her safety, and she revealed that her story was a metaphor for Absalom's situation. David realized Joab's involvement and agreed to bring Absalom back to Jerusalem but did not allow him to see the king.

Absalom returned to Jerusalem and lived there for two years without seeing David. Frustrated, he set Joab's field on fire to get his attention. Joab arranged a meeting with the king, and Absalom bowed before David, who kissed him, signifying reconciliation.

Absalom then began to build his support by presenting himself as a just and approachable leader. He gained the favor of many Israelites. After four years, he asked David for permission to go to Hebron to fulfill a vow. David agreed, but Absalom used the opportunity to declare himself king. He gathered followers, including David's advisor Ahithophel, and the conspiracy grew stronger. A messenger informed David that Absalom had won the hearts of the Israelites, prompting David to flee Jerusalem with his servants to avoid a violent confrontation."Your servants are ready to do whatever you command, my lord the king," they said. So the king and his entire household set out, leaving behind ten concubines to take care of the palace. As they departed, they stopped at a distant place. All of David's servants, including the Cherethites, Pelethites, and six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath, passed before him.

David then spoke to Ittai the Gittite, "Why are you coming with us? Go back and stay with the new king, for you are a foreigner and an exile. You only arrived yesterday, so why should you wander with us? Go back and take your people with you. May the Lord show you kindness and faithfulness."

But Ittai replied, "As surely as the Lord lives and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether in life or death, there will your servant be."

David said to Ittai, "Go ahead, march on." So Ittai the Gittite and all his men and their families went on. The whole countryside wept aloud as all the people passed by. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people moved on toward the wilderness.

Zadok and all the Levites with him were carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had left the city. Then the king instructed Zadok, "Take the Ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the Lord's eyes, He will bring me back and let me see it and His dwelling place again. But if He says, 'I am not pleased with you,' then I am ready; let Him do to me whatever seems good to Him."

The king also said to Zadok the priest, "Aren't you a seer? Go back to the city in peace with your son Ahimaaz and Jonathan, the son of Abiathar. I will wait at the fords in the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me." So Zadok and Abiathar took the Ark of God back to Jerusalem and stayed there.

David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered, and he was barefoot. All the people with him also covered their heads and wept as they went up. Someone told David, "Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom." So David prayed, "Lord, turn Ahithophel's counsel into foolishness."

When David reached the summit where people used to worship God, Hushai the Arkite was there to meet him, his robe torn and dust on his head. David said to him, "If you go with me, you will be a burden to me. But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, 'Your Majesty, I will be your servant; I was your father's servant in the past, but now I will be your servant,' then you can help me by frustrating Ahithophel's advice. Won't the priests Zadok and Abiathar be there with you? Tell them anything you hear in the king's palace. Their two sons, Ahimaaz and Jonathan, are there with them. Send them to me with anything you hear."

So Hushai, David's friend, arrived in Jerusalem as Absalom was entering the city.

When David had gone a short distance beyond the summit, Ziba, the steward of Mephibosheth, met him with a string of donkeys saddled and loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred cakes of raisins, a hundred cakes of figs, and a skin of wine. The king asked Ziba, "Why have you brought these?"

Ziba answered, "The donkeys are for the king's household to ride on, the bread and fruit are for the men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness."

The king then asked, "Where is your master's grandson?"

Ziba said to him, "He is staying in Jerusalem because he thinks, 'Today the Israelites will restore to me my grandfather's kingdom.'"

Then the king said to Ziba, "All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours."

"I humbly bow," Ziba said. "May I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king."

As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the same clan as Saul's family came out from there. His name was Shimei, son of Gera, and he cursed as he came out. He pelted David and all the king's officials with stones, though all the troops and the special guard were on David's right and left. As he cursed, Shimei said, "Get out, get out, you murderer, you scoundrel! The Lord has repaid you for all the blood you shed in the household of Saul, in whose place you have reigned. The Lord has given the kingdom into the hands of your son Absalom. You have come to ruin because you are a murderer!"

Then Abishai, son of Zeruiah, said to the king, "Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head."

But the king said, "What does this have to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the Lord said to him, 'Curse David,' who can ask, 'Why do you do this?'"

David then said to Abishai and all his officials, "My son, my own flesh and blood, is trying to kill me. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone; let him curse, for the Lord has told him to. It may be that the Lord will look upon my misery and restore to me His covenant blessing instead of His curse today."

So David and his men continued along the road while Shimei was going along the hillside opposite him, cursing as he went and throwing stones at him and showering him with dirt. The king and all the people with him arrived at their destination exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.

Meanwhile, Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him. Then Hushai the Arkite, David's confidant, went to Absalom and said to him, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"

Absalom said to Hushai, "So this is the love you show your friend? If he's your friend, why didn't you go with him?"

Hushai said to Absalom, "No, the one chosen by the Lord, by these people, and by all the men of Israel—his I will be, and I will remain with him. Furthermore, whom should I serve? Should I not serve the son? Just as I served your father, so I will serve you."

Absalom then said to Ahithophel, "Give us your advice. What should we do?"

Ahithophel answered, "Sleep with your father's concubines, whom he left to take care of the palace. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself obnoxious to your father, and the hands of everyone with you will be more resolute." So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.

Now in those days, the advice Ahithophel gave was like that of one who inquires of God. That was how both David and Absalom regarded all of Ahithophel's advice.

Ahithophel said to Absalom, "Let me choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David. I would attack him while he is weary and weak. I would strike him with terror, and then all the people with him will flee. I would strike down only the king and bring all the people back to you. The death of the man you seek will mean the return of all; all the people will be unharmed."

This plan seemed good to Absalom and to all the elders of Israel. But Absalom said, "Summon also Hushai the Arkite, so we can hear what he has to say as well."

When Hushai came to him, Absalom said, "Ahithophel has given this advice. Should we do what he says? If not, give us your opinion."

Hushai replied to Absalom, "The advice Ahithophel has given is not good this time. You know your father and his men; they are fighters, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Besides, your father is an experienced warrior; he will not spend the night with the troops. Even now, he is hidden in a cave or some other place. If he should attack your troops first, whoever hears about it will say, 'There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.' Then even the bravest soldier, whose heart is like the heart of a lion, will melt with fear, for all Israel knows that your father is a fighter and that those with him are brave.

"So I advise you: Let all Israel, from Dan to Beersheba—as numerous as the sand on the seashore—be gathered to you, with you yourself leading them into battle. Then we will attack him wherever he may be found, and we will fall on him as dew settles on the ground. Neither he nor any of his men will be left alive. If he withdraws into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not so much as a pebble is left."

Absalom and all the men of Israel said, "The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than that of Ahithophel." For the Lord had determined to frustrate the good advice of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.Hushai informed the priests Zadok and Abiathar about Ahithophel's advice to Absalom and the elders of Israel, as well as his own counsel. He urged them to quickly send a message to David, warning him not to stay in the wilderness but to cross over immediately to avoid being trapped. Jonathan and Ahimaaz, who were staying at Enrogel, received the message from a servant girl and relayed it to David. However, a boy saw them and reported it to Absalom, prompting them to hide in a well at a man's house in Bahurim. The man's wife covered the well and spread grain over it to conceal them. When Absalom's servants came looking for Jonathan and Ahimaaz, she misled them, saying they had crossed the brook. After the servants left, Jonathan and Ahimaaz emerged from the well and informed David, urging him to cross the river quickly. David and his people crossed the Jordan River by morning.

When Ahithophel realized his advice was not followed, he went home, set his affairs in order, and hanged himself. He was buried in his father's tomb. David reached Mahanaim, while Absalom and the Israelites crossed the Jordan. Absalom appointed Amasa as the new commander of the army, replacing Joab. David received supplies and support from Shobi, Machir, and Barzillai, who brought food and provisions for him and his people.

David organized his troops, appointing commanders over thousands and hundreds. He divided his forces into three groups, led by Joab, Abishai, and Ittai. Although David wanted to join the battle, his people insisted he stay behind for their safety. David agreed and instructed his commanders to deal gently with Absalom. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim, where David's forces defeated the Israelites, resulting in a heavy loss of 20,000 men. The forest claimed more lives than the sword.

During the battle, Absalom got caught in the branches of a large oak tree while riding a mule. A man saw him and reported it to Joab, who questioned why he didn't kill Absalom. The man refused, citing David's command to protect Absalom. Joab then took three spears and thrust them into Absalom's heart, and his armor-bearers finished him off. Joab blew the trumpet to halt the pursuit, and Absalom's body was thrown into a pit and covered with stones. The Israelites fled to their homes.

Ahimaaz, eager to deliver the news to David, was initially denied by Joab but eventually allowed to run. He outran another messenger, Cushi, and reached David first. When David asked about Absalom, Ahimaaz evaded the question. Cushi arrived and informed David that the Lord had avenged him, but David was more concerned about Absalom's fate. Upon hearing of Absalom's death, David was deeply grieved and mourned for his son.

Joab confronted David, accusing him of shaming his loyal servants by mourning for Absalom instead of celebrating their victory. He urged David to encourage his troops, warning that failure to do so would result in their desertion. David heeded Joab's advice, sat at the gate, and the people came before him.The tribes of Israel were in conflict, saying, "The king saved us from our enemies and the Philistines, but now he has fled because of Absalom. Absalom, whom we anointed, is dead. Why aren't we bringing the king back?" King David sent a message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar, asking them to speak to the elders of Judah, questioning why they were the last to bring him back. He reminded them that they were his kin and urged them to bring him back. He also told them to inform Amasa that he would be the new commander of the army, replacing Joab.

David's message won over the hearts of the men of Judah, who then invited him to return with all his servants. David returned and crossed the Jordan River, where the people of Judah met him at Gilgal to escort him. Shimei, a Benjamite, hurried to meet David with a thousand men from Benjamin, along with Ziba, Saul's servant, and his family. Shimei begged David for forgiveness for his past wrongdoings. Abishai, son of Zeruiah, suggested that Shimei be put to death for cursing David, but David refused, declaring that no one would be executed that day.

Mephibosheth, Saul's grandson, also came to meet David. He had not taken care of himself since David left. When David asked why he didn't join him, Mephibosheth explained that his servant deceived him because he was lame. David decided that Mephibosheth and Ziba would divide the land. Mephibosheth expressed his contentment with David's safe return.

Barzillai the Gileadite, an elderly man who had supported David, also came to escort him. David invited Barzillai to stay with him in Jerusalem, but Barzillai declined, preferring to return home to die near his parents' graves. He suggested that Chimham go with David instead, and David agreed.

As David crossed the Jordan, the people of Judah and half of Israel accompanied him. The men of Israel questioned why the men of Judah had taken David without consulting them, leading to a heated argument. A man named Sheba, son of Bichri, incited a rebellion against David, causing the Israelites to abandon David and follow Sheba. However, the men of Judah remained loyal to David.

David returned to his house in Jerusalem and confined the ten concubines he had left to take care of the house, providing for them but not visiting them. David then ordered Amasa to assemble the men of Judah within three days, but Amasa took longer than expected. David instructed Abishai to pursue Sheba before he could fortify himself in a city. Joab's men, along with the Cherethites, Pelethites, and other warriors, set out to pursue Sheba.

At Gibeon, Joab met Amasa and, under the pretense of greeting him, killed him. Joab and Abishai continued their pursuit of Sheba. They besieged Sheba in the city of Abel Beth Maacah. A wise woman from the city negotiated with Joab, agreeing to deliver Sheba's head to him to save the city. The woman convinced the people, and they executed Sheba, throwing his head over the wall to Joab. Joab then called off the siege and returned to Jerusalem.In her wisdom, the woman convinced the people to cut off Sheba's head and throw it to Joab. Joab then blew a trumpet, signaling his men to retreat from the city and return to their tents. Joab went back to Jerusalem to report to King David.

Joab was in charge of Israel's army, Benaiah son of Jehoiada led the Cherethites and Pelethites, Adoram managed the tribute, Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder, Sheva was the scribe, and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests. Ira the Jairite was also a chief official under David.

During David's reign, there was a three-year famine. David sought the Lord, who revealed that it was due to Saul's actions against the Gibeonites. David asked the Gibeonites how he could make amends. They requested the execution of seven of Saul's male descendants. David agreed but spared Mephibosheth, Jonathan's son, due to his oath with Jonathan. He handed over two sons of Rizpah and five sons of Michal, who were then executed by the Gibeonites.

Rizpah mourned and protected the bodies until rain fell. David, hearing of her actions, retrieved the bones of Saul and Jonathan from Jabesh Gilead and buried them in Saul's family tomb. After this, God ended the famine.

The Philistines waged war again, and David, along with his men, fought them. David grew tired, and Ishbibenob, a giant's descendant, tried to kill him. Abishai saved David and killed the Philistine. David's men insisted he no longer join battles to preserve his life.

In subsequent battles, Sibbechai killed Saph, another giant's descendant, and Elhanan killed Goliath's brother. Jonathan, David's nephew, killed a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot. These giants were defeated by David and his men.

David sang a song of praise to the Lord for delivering him from his enemies and from Saul. He described the Lord as his rock, fortress, deliverer, shield, and savior. David recounted how the Lord responded to his cries for help, shaking the earth and scattering his enemies with lightning. He praised the Lord for rewarding his righteousness and for being his strength and protection. David vowed to continue trusting in the Lord, who had always been his refuge and salvation.David, the son of Jesse, spoke these words: "The Spirit of the Lord spoke through me, and His words were on my tongue. The God of Israel said, 'The Rock of Israel spoke to me: The one who rules over people must be just, ruling in the fear of God. He will be like the light of the morning at sunrise, a morning without clouds, like the tender grass springing out of the earth by clear shining after rain.' Even though my house is not perfect with God, He has made an everlasting covenant with me, ordered and secure in every way. This is all my salvation and all my desire, even though He does not make it grow. But the wicked are like thorns that are thrown away, for they cannot be handled. Whoever touches them must be armed with iron and the shaft of a spear; they will be completely burned up where they lie."

These are the names of David's mighty warriors: Josheb-Basshebeth, a Tahkemonite, was chief of the Three; he raised his spear against eight hundred men, whom he killed in one encounter. Next to him was Eleazar son of Dodai the Ahohite. As one of the three mighty warriors, he was with David when they taunted the Philistines gathered at Pas Dammim for battle. Then the Israelites retreated, but Eleazar stood his ground and struck down the Philistines till his hand grew tired and froze to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day; the troops returned to Eleazar, but only to strip the dead.

Next to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a place where there was a field full of lentils, Israel’s troops fled from them. But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field. He defended it and struck the Philistines down, and the Lord brought about a great victory.

During harvest time, three of the thirty chief warriors came down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim. At that time, David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem. David longed for water and said, "Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!" So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem, and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out before the Lord. "Far be it from me, Lord, to do this!" he said. "Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?" And David would not drink it.

Abishai, the brother of Joab and son of Zeruiah, was chief of the Three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the Three. Was he not held in greater honor than the Three? He became their commander, even though he was not included among them.

Benaiah son of Jehoiada, a valiant fighter from Kabzeel, performed great exploits. He struck down Moab’s two mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion. And he struck down a huge Egyptian. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club. He snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear. Such were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada; he too was as famous as the three mighty warriors. He was held in greater honor than any of the Thirty, but he was not included among the Three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.

Among the Thirty were: Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem, Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite, Helez the Paltite, Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa, Abiezer from Anathoth, Mebunnai the Hushathite, Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite, Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin, Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash, Abi-Albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite, Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan son of Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite, Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maacathite, Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite, Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite, Igal son of Nathan from Zobah, the son of Hagri, Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah, Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite, and Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.

Once again, the anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and He incited David against them, saying, "Go and take a census of Israel and Judah." So the king said to Joab and the army commanders with him, "Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and enroll the fighting men, so that I may know how many there are." But Joab replied to the king, "May the Lord your God multiply the troops a hundred times over, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it. But why does my lord the king want to do such a thing?" The king’s word, however, overruled Joab and the army commanders; so they left the presence of the king to enroll the fighting men of Israel.

After crossing the Jordan, they camped near Aroer, south of the town in the gorge, and then went through Gad and on to Jazer. They went to Gilead and the region of Tahtim Hodshi, and on to Dan Jaan and around toward Sidon. Then they went toward the fortress of Tyre and all the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went on to Beersheba in the Negev of Judah. After they had gone through the entire land, they came back to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days. Joab reported the number of the fighting men to the king: In Israel, there were eight hundred thousand able-bodied men who could handle a sword, and in Judah, five hundred thousand.

David was conscience-stricken after he had counted the fighting men, and he said to the Lord, "I have sinned greatly in what I have done. Now, Lord, I beg you, take away the guilt of your servant. I have done a very foolish thing." Before David got up the next morning, the word of the Lord had come to Gad the prophet, David’s seer: "Go and tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says: I am giving you three options. Choose one of them for me to carry out against you.’" So Gad went to David and said to him, "Shall there come on you three years of famine in your land? Or three months of fleeing from your enemies while they pursue you? Or three days of plague in your land? Now then, think it over and decide how I should answer the one who sent me."

David said to Gad, "I am in deep distress. Let us fall into the hands of the Lord, for His mercy is great; but do not let me fall into human hands." So the Lord sent a plague on Israel from that morning until the end of the time designated, and seventy thousand of the people from Dan to Beersheba died. When the angel stretched out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, the Lord relented concerning the disaster and said to the angel who was afflicting the people, "Enough! Withdraw your hand." The angel of the Lord was then at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

When David saw the angel who was striking down the people, he said to the Lord, "I have sinned; I, the shepherd, have done wrong. These are but sheep. What have they done? Let your hand fall on me and my family." On that day Gad went to David and said to him, "Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite." So David went up, as the Lord had commanded through Gad. When Araunah looked and saw the king and his officials coming toward him, he went out and bowed down before the king with his face to the ground.

Araunah said, "Why has my lord the king come to his servant?" "To buy your threshing floor," David answered, "so I can build an altar to the Lord, that the plague on the people may be stopped." Araunah said to David, "Let my lord the king take whatever he wishes and offer it up. Here are oxen for the burnt offering, and here are threshing sledges and ox yokes for the wood. Your Majesty, Araunah gives all this to the king." Araunah also said to him, "May the Lord your God accept you."

But the king replied to Araunah, "No, I insist on paying you for it. I will not sacrifice to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing." So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen and paid fifty shekels of silver for them. David built an altar to the Lord there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then the Lord answered his prayer in behalf of the land, and the plague on Israel was stopped.

As King David grew old and advanced in years, his servants covered him with blankets, but he could not keep warm. So they said to him, "Let us find a young virgin to attend the king and take care of him. She can lie beside him so that our lord the king may keep warm." Then they searched throughout Israel for a beautiful young woman and found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king. The woman was very beautiful; she took care of the king and waited on him, but the king had no sexual relations with her.Adonijah, son of Haggith, declared himself king and gathered chariots, horsemen, and fifty men to run ahead of him. His father, King David, never questioned his actions. Adonijah was handsome and born after Absalom. He conferred with Joab, son of Zeruiah, and Abiathar the priest, who supported him. However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's mighty men did not support Adonijah.

Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fattened cattle by the stone of Zoheleth near Enrogel and invited all his brothers, the king's sons, and the men of Judah, but not Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, or his brother Solomon. Nathan spoke to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, advising her to inform King David about Adonijah's actions and remind him of his promise that Solomon would succeed him as king. Bathsheba approached the aging King David, who was being cared for by Abishag the Shunammite, and informed him of Adonijah's actions.

While Bathsheba was speaking, Nathan the prophet arrived and confirmed her words. King David then called Bathsheba back and reaffirmed his oath that Solomon would be king. He instructed Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada to anoint Solomon as king at Gihon. They followed David's orders, and Solomon was anointed king, causing great rejoicing among the people.

Adonijah and his guests heard the commotion and learned that Solomon had been made king. Fearing for his life, Adonijah sought refuge at the altar. Solomon promised not to harm him if he proved to be a worthy man. Adonijah bowed to Solomon, who then sent him home.

As David's death approached, he instructed Solomon to be strong, follow God's commands, and deal wisely with Joab and Shimei. David died after reigning for forty years, and Solomon's kingdom was firmly established. Adonijah approached Bathsheba with a request, acknowledging that the kingdom had been his but was now Solomon's.Adonijah, son of Haggith, declared himself king and gathered chariots, horsemen, and fifty men to run ahead of him. His father, King David, never questioned his actions. Adonijah was handsome and born after Absalom. He conferred with Joab, son of Zeruiah, and Abiathar the priest, who supported him. However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's mighty men did not support Adonijah.

Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fattened cattle by the stone of Zoheleth near Enrogel and invited all his brothers, the king's sons, and the men of Judah, but not Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, or his brother Solomon. Nathan spoke to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, advising her to inform King David about Adonijah's actions and remind him of his promise that Solomon would succeed him as king. Bathsheba approached the aging King David, who was being cared for by Abishag the Shunammite, and informed him of Adonijah's actions.

While Bathsheba was speaking, Nathan the prophet arrived and confirmed her words. King David then called Bathsheba back and reaffirmed his oath that Solomon would be king. He instructed Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada to anoint Solomon as king at Gihon. They followed David's orders, and Solomon was anointed king, causing great rejoicing among the people.

Adonijah and his guests heard the commotion and learned that Solomon had been made king. Fearing for his life, Adonijah sought refuge at the altar. Solomon promised not to harm him if he proved to be a worthy man. Adonijah bowed to Solomon, who then sent him home.

As David's death approached, he instructed Solomon to be strong, follow God's commands, and deal wisely with Joab and Shimei. David died after reigning for forty years, and Solomon's kingdom was firmly established. Adonijah approached Bathsheba with a request, acknowledging that the kingdom had been his but was now Solomon's.

Adonijah said to Bathsheba, "Please ask King Solomon to give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife." Bathsheba agreed to speak to Solomon on his behalf. When she approached Solomon, he welcomed her and listened to her request. However, Solomon saw this as a threat to his throne and ordered Adonijah's execution. Solomon also removed Abiathar from the priesthood and ordered Joab's execution for his past crimes. Solomon then dealt with Shimei, confining him to Jerusalem and warning him that leaving the city would result in his death. When Shimei later violated this order, Solomon had him executed as well.

Solomon's kingdom was now secure. He formed an alliance with Pharaoh, king of Egypt, by marrying Pharaoh's daughter. Solomon loved the Lord and followed his father David's statutes, although he still offered sacrifices at high places. One night, God appeared to Solomon in a dream and asked what he wanted. Solomon asked for wisdom to govern his people, and God granted him unparalleled wisdom, along with riches and honor. Solomon's wisdom was soon demonstrated when he resolved a dispute between two women claiming to be the mother of the same child. His judgment impressed all of Israel, and they recognized his wisdom from God.Solomon was recognized as the king over all of Israel. He had a team of key officials: Azariah, son of Zadok, was the priest; Elihoreph and Ahiah, sons of Shisha, were scribes; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the recorder. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, led the army, and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests. Azariah, son of Nathan, managed the officers, and Zabud, son of Nathan, was a principal officer and the king's friend. Ahishar managed the household, and Adoniram, son of Abda, oversaw the tribute.

Solomon appointed twelve officers over Israel to provide food for the king and his household, each responsible for one month of the year. Their names and regions were: the son of Hur in Mount Ephraim; the son of Dekar in Makaz, Shaalbim, Bethshemesh, and Elonbethhanan; the son of Hesed in Aruboth, Sochoh, and the land of Hepher; the son of Abinadab in the region of Dor, who was married to Solomon's daughter Taphath; Baana, son of Ahilud, in Taanach, Megiddo, and Bethshean; the son of Geber in Ramothgilead, including the towns of Jair and the region of Argob in Bashan; Ahinadab, son of Iddo, in Mahanaim; Ahimaaz in Naphtali, who married Solomon's daughter Basmath; Baanah, son of Hushai, in Asher and Aloth; Jehoshaphat, son of Paruah, in Issachar; Shimei, son of Elah, in Benjamin; and Geber, son of Uri, in Gilead, the land of Sihon and Og.

Judah and Israel were numerous, living in peace and prosperity. Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and the border of Egypt. These kingdoms brought him gifts and served him throughout his life. Solomon's daily provisions included thirty measures of fine flour, sixty measures of meal, ten fat oxen, twenty pasture-fed oxen, a hundred sheep, and various game animals. He had dominion over the region west of the Euphrates, from Tiphsah to Gaza, and enjoyed peace on all sides. The people of Judah and Israel lived safely, each under their own vine and fig tree, from Dan to Beersheba.

Solomon had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots and twelve thousand horsemen. His officers ensured that the king and his household were well-provisioned, each in their assigned month. They also provided barley and straw for the horses and camels. God granted Solomon exceptional wisdom and understanding, making him wiser than anyone else, including Ethan the Ezrahite, Heman, Chalcol, and Darda. His fame spread to all the surrounding nations. Solomon spoke three thousand proverbs and composed a thousand and five songs. He discussed various topics, including trees, animals, birds, reptiles, and fish. People from all nations, including kings, came to hear Solomon's wisdom.

Hiram, king of Tyre, sent his servants to Solomon upon hearing of his anointment as king, as Hiram had always been a friend of David. Solomon sent a message to Hiram, explaining that David could not build a temple for God due to the wars surrounding him. Now that Solomon had peace, he intended to build the temple as God had promised David. Solomon requested cedar trees from Lebanon, offering to pay Hiram's servants for their work. Hiram agreed, rejoicing that God had given David a wise son to rule over Israel. Hiram provided Solomon with cedar and fir trees, and Solomon supplied Hiram with wheat and oil annually. The two kings made a peace treaty.

Solomon conscripted thirty thousand men from Israel for labor, sending ten thousand to Lebanon each month in shifts. He also had seventy thousand burden-bearers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the mountains, supervised by three thousand three hundred chief officers. Solomon commanded the preparation of large, costly stones for the temple's foundation. Solomon's and Hiram's builders, along with the stonecutters, prepared the materials for the temple.

In the fourth year of Solomon's reign, during the month of Ziv, he began building the temple of the Lord. The temple was sixty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high. The porch in front of the temple was twenty cubits long and ten cubits wide. Solomon made narrow windows for the temple and built chambers around the walls of the temple. The lowest chamber was five cubits wide, the middle six cubits, and the third seven cubits, with ledges around the outside to support the beams. The temple was constructed with prepared stones, so no hammer or iron tool was heard during its building. The entrance to the middle chamber was on the right side, with winding stairs leading to the upper chambers. Solomon finished the temple, covering it with cedar beams and boards. He built chambers around the temple, five cubits high, resting on the cedar beams.

God spoke to Solomon, promising to fulfill His word to David if Solomon followed His statutes and commandments. Solomon completed the temple, lining the interior with cedar boards and covering the floor with fir planks. He built a twenty-cubit section at the rear of the temple, lined with cedar, for the Most Holy Place. The main hall of the temple was forty cubits long. The interior cedar was carved with gourds and open flowers, with no stone visible. Solomon prepared the inner sanctuary to house the Ark of the Covenant.Solomon covered the entire interior of the temple with pure gold, including the cedar altar. He partitioned the inner sanctuary with gold chains and overlaid everything with gold. He also made two cherubim from olive wood, each ten cubits high, with wings spanning ten cubits. These cherubim were placed in the inner sanctuary, their wings touching the walls and each other, and they were overlaid with gold.

Solomon carved the walls with images of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, and covered the floors with gold. The entrance to the inner sanctuary had doors made of olive wood, with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and flowers, all overlaid with gold. The main doors of the temple were made of fir wood, with similar carvings and gold overlay.

The inner courtyard was built with three rows of hewn stone and a row of cedar beams. The foundation of the temple was laid in the fourth year of Solomon's reign, and it was completed in the eleventh year, taking seven years to build.

Solomon also built his own palace, which took thirteen years to complete. He constructed the House of the Forest of Lebanon, which was 100 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high, with cedar pillars and beams. It had three rows of windows and a porch with pillars. He also built a porch for his throne, where he would judge, covered with cedar from floor to ceiling. Solomon's own residence had a similar courtyard, and he built a house for Pharaoh's daughter, whom he had married.

All these buildings were made with costly stones, cut to size and sawed on all sides, from the foundation to the coping. The great courtyard had three rows of hewn stones and a row of cedar beams, similar to the inner courtyard of the temple and its porch.

King Solomon brought Hiram from Tyre, a skilled craftsman in brass, to work on the temple. Hiram cast two large brass pillars, each 18 cubits high, with capitals of five cubits each. He decorated the capitals with networks of chains and rows of pomegranates. The pillars were set up at the temple's porch, named Jachin and Boaz.

Hiram also made a large brass basin, called the "Sea," which was ten cubits in diameter and five cubits high, standing on twelve oxen. He crafted ten brass bases, each four cubits square and three cubits high, with intricate designs of lions, oxen, and cherubim. Each base had four brass wheels and supports.

Hiram completed all the work for Solomon, including the pillars, the Sea, the bases, and various utensils like pots, shovels, and basins, all made of bright brass. These items were cast in the plain of Jordan, between Succoth and Zarethan. Solomon did not weigh the brass items because they were too numerous.

Solomon also made all the gold vessels for the temple, including the altar, the table for the showbread, and ten gold lampstands, five on each side of the inner sanctuary.Solomon finished all the work for the temple of the Lord. He brought in the items his father David had dedicated, including silver, gold, and vessels, and placed them in the temple's treasury.

Solomon then gathered the elders of Israel, the tribal leaders, and the heads of families in Jerusalem to bring the Ark of the Covenant from the City of David (Zion). During the feast in the seventh month, all the men of Israel assembled. The priests carried the Ark, the tabernacle, and all the holy vessels. Solomon and the entire congregation offered countless sacrifices of sheep and oxen.

The priests placed the Ark in the inner sanctuary, under the wings of the cherubim, whose wings spread over the Ark. The staves of the Ark were visible from the holy place but not from outside. Inside the Ark were the two stone tablets Moses had placed there at Horeb, where the Lord made a covenant with the Israelites after they left Egypt.

When the priests exited the holy place, a cloud filled the temple, signifying the Lord's glory, making it impossible for the priests to continue their service. Solomon then spoke, acknowledging that the Lord had chosen to dwell in thick darkness and that he had built a permanent house for the Lord.

Solomon blessed the congregation of Israel, praising the Lord for fulfilling His promise to David. He recounted how the Lord chose David to lead Israel and how David had desired to build a temple for the Lord. However, the Lord told David that his son would build the temple. Solomon declared that he had fulfilled this promise by building the temple and placing the Ark of the Covenant there.

Solomon then prayed, acknowledging the uniqueness of the Lord and His faithfulness to His covenant. He asked the Lord to keep His promise to David, ensuring that his descendants would continue to rule Israel if they remained faithful. Solomon also prayed for the Lord to hear the prayers of the people when they faced various troubles, such as sin, defeat, drought, famine, or captivity, and to forgive and restore them.

He asked the Lord to hear the prayers of foreigners who came to the temple, so that all people would know and fear the Lord. Solomon concluded by asking the Lord to maintain the cause of His people when they went to battle and to forgive them if they sinned and repented, even in captivity. He reminded the Lord that the Israelites were His chosen people, brought out of Egypt, and asked for His continued attention to their prayers.Solomon finished praying on his knees with his hands raised to heaven. He then stood up and blessed the entire congregation of Israel with a loud voice, saying, "Praise the LORD, who has given rest to His people Israel, just as He promised. Not one word has failed of all the good promises He made through His servant Moses. May the LORD our God be with us as He was with our ancestors; may He never leave us or forsake us. May He turn our hearts to Him, to walk in all His ways and keep His commandments, statutes, and judgments, which He commanded our ancestors. May these words of mine, which I have prayed before the LORD, be near to the LORD our God day and night, so that He may uphold the cause of His servant and His people Israel as each day requires. May all the peoples of the earth know that the LORD is God; there is no other. Therefore, let your hearts be fully committed to the LORD our God, to live by His decrees and obey His commands, as at this time."

Then Solomon and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the LORD. Solomon offered a sacrifice of fellowship offerings to the LORD: twenty-two thousand cattle and a hundred and twenty thousand sheep and goats. So the king and all the Israelites dedicated the temple of the LORD. On that same day, the king consecrated the middle part of the courtyard in front of the temple of the LORD, and there he offered burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of the fellowship offerings, because the bronze altar before the LORD was too small to hold all the burnt offerings, the grain offerings, and the fat of the fellowship offerings.

So Solomon observed the festival at that time, and all Israel with him—a vast assembly, people from Lebo Hamath to the Wadi of Egypt. They celebrated it before the LORD our God for seven days and seven days more, fourteen days in all. On the eighth day, he sent the people away. They blessed the king and went home, joyful and glad in heart for all the good things the LORD had done for His servant David and His people Israel.

When Solomon had finished building the temple of the LORD and the royal palace, and had achieved all he had desired to do, the LORD appeared to him a second time, as He had appeared to him at Gibeon. The LORD said to him, "I have heard the prayer and plea you have made before me; I have consecrated this temple, which you have built, by putting my Name there forever. My eyes and my heart will always be there. As for you, if you walk before me faithfully with integrity of heart and uprightness, as David your father did, and do all I command and observe my decrees and laws, I will establish your royal throne over Israel forever, as I promised David your father when I said, 'You shall never fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.' But if you or your descendants turn away from me and do not observe the commands and decrees I have given you and go off to serve other gods and worship them, then I will cut off Israel from the land I have given them and will reject this temple I have consecrated for my Name. Israel will then become a byword and an object of ridicule among all peoples. This temple will become a heap of rubble. All who pass by will be appalled and will scoff and say, 'Why has the LORD done such a thing to this land and to this temple?' People will answer, 'Because they have forsaken the LORD their God, who brought their ancestors out of Egypt, and have embraced other gods, worshiping and serving them—that is why the LORD brought all this disaster on them.'"

At the end of twenty years, during which Solomon built these two buildings—the temple of the LORD and the royal palace—King Solomon gave twenty towns in Galilee to Hiram king of Tyre, because Hiram had supplied him with all the cedar and juniper and gold he wanted. But when Hiram went from Tyre to see the towns that Solomon had given him, he was not pleased with them. "What kind of towns are these you have given me, my brother?" he asked. And he called them the Land of Kabul, a name they have to this day. Now Hiram had sent to the king 120 talents of gold.

Here is the account of the forced labor King Solomon conscripted to build the LORD's temple, his own palace, the terraces, the wall of Jerusalem, and Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer. (Pharaoh king of Egypt had attacked and captured Gezer. He had set it on fire. He killed its Canaanite inhabitants and then gave it as a wedding gift to his daughter, Solomon's wife. And Solomon rebuilt Gezer.) He built up Lower Beth Horon, Baalath, and Tadmor in the desert, within his land, as well as all his store cities and the towns for his chariots and for his horses—whatever he desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout all the territory he ruled.

All the people left from the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—these peoples were not Israelites—Solomon conscripted the descendants of all these people remaining in the land, whom the Israelites could not exterminate, to serve as slave labor, as it is to this day. But Solomon did not make slaves of any of the Israelites; they were his fighting men, his government officials, his officers, his captains, and the commanders of his chariots and charioteers. They were also the chief officials in charge of Solomon's projects—550 officials supervising those who did the work.

After Pharaoh's daughter had come up from the City of David to the palace Solomon had built for her, he constructed the terraces. Three times a year Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar he had built for the LORD, burning incense before the LORD along with them, and so fulfilled the temple obligations.

King Solomon also built ships at Ezion Geber, which is near Elath in Edom, on the shore of the Red Sea. And Hiram sent his men—sailors who knew the sea—to serve in the fleet with Solomon's men. They sailed to Ophir and brought back 420 talents of gold, which they delivered to King Solomon.

When the queen of Sheba heard about the fame of Solomon and his relationship to the LORD, she came to test Solomon with hard questions. Arriving at Jerusalem with a very great caravan—with camels carrying spices, large quantities of gold, and precious stones—she came to Solomon and talked with him about all that she had on her mind. Solomon answered all her questions; nothing was too hard for the king to explain to her. When the queen of Sheba saw all the wisdom of Solomon and the palace he had built, the food on his table, the seating of his officials, the attending servants in their robes, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings he made at the temple of the LORD, she was overwhelmed.

She said to the king, "The report I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom is true. But I did not believe these things until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half was told me; in wisdom and wealth you have far exceeded the report I heard. How happy your people must be! How happy your officials, who continually stand before you and hear your wisdom! Praise be to the LORD your God, who has delighted in you and placed you on the throne of Israel. Because of the LORD's eternal love for Israel, He has made you king to maintain justice and righteousness."

And she gave the king 120 talents of gold, large quantities of spices, and precious stones. Never again were so many spices brought in as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.

(Hiram's ships brought gold from Ophir; and from there they brought great cargoes of almugwood and precious stones. The king used the almugwood to make supports for the temple of the LORD and for the royal palace, and to make harps and lyres for the musicians. So much almugwood has never been imported or seen since that day.)

King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba all she desired and asked for, besides what he had given her out of his royal bounty. Then she left and returned with her retinue to her own country.

The weight of the gold that Solomon received yearly was 666 talents, not including the revenues from merchants and traders and from all the Arabian kings and the governors of the territories. King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold; 600 shekels of gold went into each shield. He also made 300 small shields of hammered gold, with three minas of gold in each shield. The king put them in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon.King Solomon's fleet, in partnership with Hiram's navy, sailed to Tarshish every three years, bringing back gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks. Solomon's wealth and wisdom surpassed all other kings on earth. People from all over came to hear his wisdom, bringing gifts of silver, gold, garments, armor, spices, horses, and mules annually.

Solomon amassed 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horsemen, stationed in chariot cities and with him in Jerusalem. He made silver as common as stones in Jerusalem and cedar as plentiful as sycamore trees. Solomon imported horses from Egypt and linen yarn, with chariots costing 600 shekels of silver and horses 150 shekels. These were also supplied to the Hittite and Syrian kings.

However, Solomon loved many foreign women, including the daughter of Pharaoh, Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites, despite God's warning that these nations would lead the Israelites astray. Solomon had 700 wives and 300 concubines, who turned his heart away from God in his old age. He worshipped Ashtoreth, Milcom, Chemosh, and Molech, building high places for these gods, which angered the Lord.

God appeared to Solomon twice, commanding him not to follow other gods, but Solomon disobeyed. As a result, God decided to tear the kingdom from Solomon and give it to his servant, but not during Solomon's lifetime, for the sake of David.
