Instead, the kingdom would be taken from Solomon's son, leaving him with only one tribe for David's sake and for Jerusalem.

God raised adversaries against Solomon, including Hadad the Edomite, who fled to Egypt as a child and found favor with Pharaoh. Hadad returned to Edom after David and Joab's deaths. Another adversary was Rezon, who fled from Hadadezer, king of Zobah, and became king in Damascus, opposing Israel all Solomon's days.

Jeroboam, an industrious servant of Solomon, also rebelled. The prophet Ahijah told Jeroboam that God would give him ten tribes of Israel, leaving one tribe for Solomon's son for David's sake. God promised Jeroboam a lasting dynasty if he followed His commands. Solomon sought to kill Jeroboam, who fled to Egypt until Solomon's death.

Solomon reigned in Jerusalem for 40 years. After his death, his son Rehoboam became king. Rehoboam went to Shechem, where all Israel gathered to make him king. Jeroboam, still in Egypt, was called back by the Israelites. They asked Rehoboam to lighten the harsh labor and heavy yoke imposed by Solomon. Rehoboam consulted the elders, who advised him to serve the people kindly, but he rejected their counsel and sought advice from the young men he grew up with. They advised him to increase the burden, leading to further conflict.On the third day, as the king had instructed, the people returned. King Rehoboam responded harshly, ignoring the advice of the elders and following the counsel of the young men. He told the people, "My father made your burden heavy, but I will make it even heavier. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will use scorpions."

The king's refusal to listen to the people was part of God's plan, fulfilling the prophecy given by Ahijah to Jeroboam. When the Israelites saw that the king wouldn't listen, they declared, "We have no share in David, no inheritance in the son of Jesse. To your tents, Israel! Look after your own house, David!" So, the Israelites went home.

Rehoboam continued to rule over the Israelites living in the cities of Judah. When he sent Adoram, who was in charge of forced labor, the Israelites stoned him to death. Rehoboam quickly fled to Jerusalem. Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David ever since.

When the Israelites heard that Jeroboam had returned, they called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the house of David. Rehoboam gathered 180,000 warriors from Judah and Benjamin to fight against Israel and restore the kingdom to him. But God spoke to Shemaiah, a man of God, instructing him to tell Rehoboam and the people of Judah and Benjamin not to fight their fellow Israelites. They obeyed God's word and went home.

Jeroboam fortified Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and lived there. He also built up Penuel. Worried that the people might return to Rehoboam if they continued to worship in Jerusalem, Jeroboam made two golden calves and told the people, "It's too much for you to go to Jerusalem. Here are your gods, Israel, who brought you out of Egypt." He placed one calf in Bethel and the other in Dan, leading the people into sin as they worshipped these idols.

Jeroboam built shrines on high places and appointed priests from all sorts of people, not just the Levites. He instituted a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, similar to the festival in Judah, and offered sacrifices on the altar in Bethel. He also installed priests at the high places he had made.

One day, a man of God from Judah came to Bethel by God's command. As Jeroboam stood by the altar to make an offering, the man of God cried out against the altar, prophesying that a future king named Josiah would sacrifice the priests of the high places on it and burn human bones on it. He gave a sign that the altar would split apart and its ashes would be poured out.

When King Jeroboam heard this, he stretched out his hand from the altar and ordered the man to be seized. But his hand shriveled up, and he couldn't pull it back. The altar split apart, and its ashes poured out, just as the man of God had said. Jeroboam pleaded with the man of God to pray for his hand to be restored. The man of God prayed, and the king's hand was healed.

Jeroboam invited the man of God to his home for a meal and a reward, but the man of God refused, saying he was commanded by God not to eat or drink there or return by the same way he came. So, he left by a different route.

An old prophet living in Bethel heard about the man of God's actions and went after him. He found him sitting under an oak tree and invited him to his home. The man of God initially refused, citing God's command, but the old prophet lied, claiming an angel had told him to bring the man of God back. The man of God returned with him and ate and drank at his house.

While they were eating, the word of God came to the old prophet, who then told the man of God that because he had disobeyed God's command, he would not be buried in his family's tomb. After the meal, the man of God left, but a lion met him on the road and killed him. His body lay on the road with the lion and his donkey standing beside it.

People passing by saw the body and reported it in the city where the old prophet lived. The old prophet retrieved the body, mourned for him, and buried him in his own tomb. He instructed his sons to bury him in the same tomb when he died, recognizing that the prophecy against the altar in Bethel and the high places in Samaria would come true.

Despite these events, Jeroboam did not turn from his evil ways. He continued to appoint priests for the high places from all sorts of people, leading to sin that eventually brought about the downfall of his house.Ahijah, who was now old and blind, received a message from God about Jeroboam's wife coming to ask for help for her sick son. God told Ahijah what to say to her. When she arrived, pretending to be someone else, Ahijah recognized her and delivered God's message: Jeroboam had failed to follow God's ways and had angered Him by worshipping other gods. As a result, God would bring disaster upon Jeroboam's family, leaving none of his descendants alive. The child would die as soon as she returned home, and all of Israel would mourn for him because he was the only one in Jeroboam's family who had anything good in him. God would also raise a new king to destroy Jeroboam's house and scatter Israel because of their sins.

Jeroboam's wife returned home, and as she entered the city, her child died, fulfilling Ahijah's prophecy. Jeroboam reigned for 22 years before dying, and his son Nadab succeeded him. Meanwhile, Rehoboam, Solomon's son, ruled Judah for 17 years, but the people of Judah also sinned greatly, provoking God's anger. They built high places and idols, and there were even male shrine prostitutes in the land.

In Rehoboam's fifth year, Shishak, the king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the temple and the royal palace. Rehoboam replaced the stolen gold shields with bronze ones. Rehoboam's reign was marked by constant conflict with Jeroboam. After Rehoboam died, his son Abijam became king of Judah.

Abijam ruled for three years and continued in the sins of his father. However, for David's sake, God allowed Abijam's lineage to continue. Abijam's son Asa succeeded him and ruled Judah for 41 years. Asa did what was right in God's eyes, removing idols and shrine prostitutes from the land. He even deposed his grandmother Maachah from her position as queen mother because she had made an idol. Asa brought dedicated items into the temple and maintained a heart loyal to God throughout his life.

Asa faced ongoing conflict with Baasha, the king of Israel. Baasha fortified Ramah to prevent anyone from leaving or entering Asa's territory. Asa responded by sending silver and gold to Ben-Hadad, the king of Aram, to break his alliance with Baasha. Ben-Hadad attacked Israel, forcing Baasha to abandon Ramah. Asa then used the materials from Ramah to build Geba and Mizpah.

Asa's reign was recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. In his old age, Asa suffered from a foot disease. After his death, his son Jehoshaphat succeeded him. Nadab, Jeroboam's son, ruled Israel for two years but continued in his father's sinful ways. Baasha conspired against Nadab, killed him, and took the throne, fulfilling Ahijah's prophecy by destroying Jeroboam's entire family. Baasha ruled Israel for 24 years but also did evil in God's sight, leading Israel into sin.God made you a leader over Israel, but you followed Jeroboam's sinful ways, leading Israel into sin and provoking God's anger. Therefore, God will destroy Baasha's family just like Jeroboam's. Those who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the fields will be eaten by birds. Baasha's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. Baasha died and was buried in Tirzah, and his son Elah became king.

The prophet Jehu delivered God's message against Baasha for his evil deeds and for killing Jeroboam. Elah, Baasha's son, ruled Israel for two years in Tirzah. Zimri, one of Elah's officers, conspired against him and killed him while he was drunk. Zimri then became king and killed all of Baasha's family, fulfilling God's prophecy.

Zimri ruled for seven days before the people of Israel, who were besieging Gibbethon, made Omri their king. Omri besieged Tirzah, and Zimri, seeing the city was taken, set the palace on fire and died. Omri became king and ruled for twelve years, six of which were in Tirzah. He bought the hill of Samaria and built a city there, naming it Samaria. Omri did more evil than all the kings before him, following Jeroboam's sinful ways.

Omri's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. He died and was succeeded by his son Ahab, who ruled Israel for 22 years. Ahab did more evil than any king before him, marrying Jezebel and worshipping Baal. He built an altar and a temple for Baal in Samaria and angered God more than any previous king.

During Ahab's reign, Hiel of Bethel rebuilt Jericho, fulfilling Joshua's prophecy by losing his firstborn and youngest sons. Elijah the Tishbite told Ahab that there would be no rain except by his word. God then instructed Elijah to hide by the brook Cherith, where ravens fed him. When the brook dried up, God sent Elijah to a widow in Zarephath, who provided for him despite her own scarcity. Elijah promised that her supplies would not run out until it rained again.

The widow's son later fell ill and died. Elijah prayed to God, and the boy was revived. The widow then recognized Elijah as a true man of God. After many days, God told Elijah to present himself to Ahab, promising to send rain. There was a severe famine in Samaria, and Ahab instructed Obadiah, his palace administrator who feared God, to search for grass to save their animals. Obadiah had previously hidden and fed 100 prophets from Jezebel. While searching, Obadiah met Elijah, who instructed him to tell Ahab that Elijah was there.Obadiah expressed his fear to Elijah, saying, "If I tell Ahab you're here and the Spirit of the Lord takes you away, Ahab will kill me because he won't find you. I've been faithful to the Lord since my youth. Didn't you hear how I hid 100 of the Lord's prophets from Jezebel and fed them? Now you want me to tell Ahab you're here? He'll kill me!" Elijah reassured him, "As the Lord lives, I will show myself to Ahab today."

Obadiah went to Ahab and told him, and Ahab went to meet Elijah. When Ahab saw Elijah, he said, "Is it you, the one who troubles Israel?" Elijah replied, "I haven't troubled Israel; you and your father's house have, by abandoning the Lord's commandments and following Baal. Gather all Israel and the 450 prophets of Baal and the 400 prophets of Asherah who eat at Jezebel's table, and meet me at Mount Carmel."

Ahab gathered the people and the prophets at Mount Carmel. Elijah addressed the people, "How long will you waver between two opinions? If the Lord is God, follow Him; if Baal, follow him." The people were silent. Elijah continued, "I am the only prophet of the Lord left, but Baal has 450 prophets. Let's each prepare a bull for sacrifice without setting fire to it. Call on your god, and I'll call on the Lord. The god who answers by fire is the true God." The people agreed.

The prophets of Baal prepared their bull and called on Baal from morning until noon, but there was no response. They danced around the altar they had made. At noon, Elijah mocked them, saying, "Shout louder! Maybe he's deep in thought, busy, traveling, or sleeping and needs to be awakened." They shouted louder and cut themselves with knives until they bled, but there was still no response.

Elijah then called the people to him and repaired the Lord's altar with twelve stones representing the tribes of Israel. He built an altar in the Lord's name, dug a trench around it, arranged the wood, cut the bull into pieces, and laid it on the wood. He instructed them to pour water over the offering and the wood three times until the trench was filled with water.

At the time of the evening sacrifice, Elijah prayed, "Lord, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, let it be known today that You are God in Israel and I am Your servant. Answer me, Lord, so these people will know that You are God and that You are turning their hearts back again." The fire of the Lord fell and consumed the offering, the wood, the stones, the soil, and the water in the trench. The people fell on their faces, declaring, "The Lord, He is God!"

Elijah commanded, "Seize the prophets of Baal; don't let any escape." They captured them, and Elijah took them to the Kishon Valley and killed them. Elijah then told Ahab, "Go eat and drink, for there is the sound of heavy rain." Ahab went to eat and drink, while Elijah climbed to the top of Carmel, bent down to the ground, and put his face between his knees. He told his servant to look toward the sea. The servant went and saw nothing. Elijah told him to go back seven times. On the seventh time, the servant saw a small cloud rising from the sea. Elijah told him to inform Ahab to prepare his chariot and go before the rain stops him. The sky grew black with clouds, the wind rose, and heavy rain fell. Ahab rode to Jezreel, and the power of the Lord came upon Elijah, who tucked his cloak into his belt and ran ahead of Ahab all the way to Jezreel.

Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, including killing the prophets. Jezebel sent a message to Elijah, threatening to kill him by the next day. Elijah fled for his life to Beersheba in Judah, leaving his servant there. He went a day's journey into the wilderness, sat under a juniper tree, and prayed to die, saying, "I've had enough, Lord. Take my life; I'm no better than my ancestors." He lay down and slept under the tree. An angel touched him and said, "Get up and eat." He saw a cake of bread baked over hot coals and a jar of water. He ate and drank and lay down again. The angel returned, touched him, and said, "Get up and eat, for the journey is too much for you." He ate and drank, and strengthened by that food, he traveled forty days and nights to Horeb, the mountain of God.

Elijah went into a cave and spent the night. The word of the Lord came to him, asking, "What are you doing here, Elijah?" He replied, "I've been very zealous for the Lord God Almighty. The Israelites have rejected Your covenant, torn down Your altars, and killed Your prophets. I'm the only one left, and they're trying to kill me too." The Lord said, "Go out and stand on the mountain in the presence of the Lord, for the Lord is about to pass by." A great and powerful wind tore the mountains apart, but the Lord was not in the wind. After the wind, there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. After the fire, there was a gentle whisper. When Elijah heard it, he pulled his cloak over his face and stood at the mouth of the cave. A voice asked, "What are you doing here, Elijah?" He repeated his earlier statement about being zealous for the Lord and the Israelites' actions.

The Lord told him to go back the way he came and go to the Desert of Damascus. There, he was to anoint Hazael king over Aram, Jehu son of Nimshi king over Israel, and Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah to succeed him as prophet. The Lord said, "Jehu will put to death any who escape the sword of Hazael, and Elisha will put to death any who escape the sword of Jehu. Yet I reserve seven thousand in Israel—all whose knees have not bowed to Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him."

Elijah left and found Elisha son of Shaphat plowing with twelve yoke of oxen. Elijah went up to him and threw his cloak around him. Elisha left the oxen and ran after Elijah, asking to kiss his father and mother goodbye before following him. Elijah told him to go back. Elisha returned, took his yoke of oxen, slaughtered them, burned the plowing equipment to cook the meat, and gave it to the people to eat. Then he set out to follow Elijah and became his servant.

Meanwhile, Ben-Hadad king of Aram mustered his entire army, accompanied by thirty-two kings with their horses and chariots. He went up and besieged Samaria, attacking it.Ben-Hadad, the king of Aram, sent messengers to Ahab, the king of Israel, demanding his silver, gold, wives, and children. Ahab agreed to the demands, but Ben-Hadad's messengers returned with an additional demand: they would search Ahab's palace and the houses of his officials, taking anything they found valuable. Ahab consulted with the elders of Israel, who advised him not to agree to these terms. Ahab then told Ben-Hadad's messengers that he would comply with the initial demands but not the additional ones.

Ben-Hadad, angered by Ahab's refusal, threatened to destroy Samaria. Ahab responded confidently, warning Ben-Hadad not to boast before the battle was over. Ben-Hadad, drinking with his allies, ordered his troops to prepare for battle. Meanwhile, a prophet approached Ahab, assuring him that the Lord would deliver the vast Aramean army into his hands to prove that He is the Lord. Ahab asked how this would happen, and the prophet explained that the young officers of the provincial commanders would lead the battle, with Ahab organizing the troops.

Ahab mustered 232 young officers and 7,000 Israelites. They launched a surprise attack at noon while Ben-Hadad and his allies were drunk. The young officers led the charge, and the Arameans fled. Ben-Hadad escaped on horseback, and the Israelites pursued and defeated the Aramean army. A prophet warned Ahab to prepare for another attack the following year.

The Aramean officials believed that Israel's gods were gods of the hills and suggested fighting on the plains, where they thought they would have the advantage. They replaced their kings with military commanders and rebuilt their army. The following year, they fought Israel at Aphek. Despite being vastly outnumbered, the Israelites, with God's help, defeated the Arameans, killing 100,000 soldiers in one day. The remaining Arameans fled to Aphek, where a wall collapsed, killing 27,000 more. Ben-Hadad sought mercy from Ahab, who spared his life and made a treaty with him.

A prophet, disguised with ashes, confronted Ahab, telling a parable about a man who let a prisoner escape, resulting in his own life being forfeited. The prophet revealed his identity and declared that because Ahab had spared Ben-Hadad, Ahab's life would be taken in place of Ben-Hadad's, and his people would suffer. Ahab returned to Samaria, troubled.

Later, Ahab desired Naboth's vineyard, which was near his palace. Naboth refused to sell it, as it was his ancestral inheritance. Ahab became sullen and refused to eat. Jezebel, his wife, took matters into her own hands, writing letters in Ahab's name to the elders and nobles of Naboth's city, instructing them to falsely accuse Naboth of blasphemy and stone him to death. The elders and nobles followed Jezebel's instructions, and Naboth was killed.They took Naboth outside the city and stoned him to death. Then they informed Jezebel that Naboth was dead. Jezebel told Ahab to take possession of Naboth's vineyard since Naboth was no longer alive. Ahab went to the vineyard to claim it. 

The Lord spoke to Elijah, telling him to confront Ahab in Naboth's vineyard. Elijah told Ahab that because he had killed Naboth and taken his land, dogs would lick Ahab's blood in the same place. Ahab called Elijah his enemy, and Elijah replied that Ahab had sold himself to do evil. Elijah prophesied that disaster would come upon Ahab and his descendants, and that Jezebel would be eaten by dogs by the wall of Jezreel. 

Ahab humbled himself before the Lord, so the Lord decided not to bring disaster during Ahab's lifetime but in his son's days. 

Three years passed without war between Syria and Israel. In the third year, Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, visited Ahab, king of Israel. Ahab asked Jehoshaphat to join him in reclaiming Ramoth in Gilead from the king of Syria. Jehoshaphat agreed but asked to seek the Lord's guidance first. Ahab gathered about 400 prophets who encouraged him to go to battle, but Jehoshaphat asked if there was another prophet of the Lord. Ahab mentioned Micaiah, whom he disliked because Micaiah never prophesied anything good for him. 

Micaiah was summoned and initially told Ahab to go to battle and succeed. However, Ahab insisted on the truth, and Micaiah revealed a vision of Israel scattered like sheep without a shepherd. Micaiah explained that a lying spirit had been sent to deceive Ahab's prophets. Ahab ordered Micaiah to be imprisoned until he returned safely. Micaiah declared that if Ahab returned safely, the Lord had not spoken through him.

Ahab and Jehoshaphat went to battle. Ahab disguised himself, but a random arrow struck him, and he was mortally wounded. He died that evening, and his blood was washed from his chariot, fulfilling Elijah's prophecy. 

Ahab's son Ahaziah succeeded him. Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah, following the ways of his father Asa and doing what was right in the Lord's eyes. He made peace with the king of Israel and removed the remaining male shrine prostitutes from the land. Jehoshaphat attempted to build ships for gold, but they were wrecked. Ahaziah, Ahab's son, proposed a joint venture, but Jehoshaphat refused.Jehoshaphat refused to let his servants join Ahaziah's in the ships. Jehoshaphat died and was buried in the city of David, and his son Jehoram took over as king. Ahaziah, son of Ahab, became king of Israel in Samaria during Jehoshaphat's seventeenth year as king of Judah and ruled for two years. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, following the ways of his parents and Jeroboam, who led Israel into sin. He worshipped Baal, angering the Lord.

After Ahab's death, Moab rebelled against Israel. Ahaziah fell through a lattice in his upper room in Samaria and was injured. He sent messengers to ask Baalzebub, the god of Ekron, if he would recover. The angel of the Lord told Elijah to meet the messengers and ask why they were consulting Baalzebub instead of the God of Israel. Elijah told them Ahaziah would not recover and would die.

The messengers returned to Ahaziah, who asked why they came back so soon. They explained that a man had told them to return and deliver the message from the Lord. Ahaziah asked what the man looked like, and they described him as a hairy man with a leather belt. Ahaziah recognized him as Elijah.

Ahaziah sent a captain with fifty men to bring Elijah down from a hill. Elijah called down fire from heaven, which consumed the captain and his men. Ahaziah sent another captain with fifty men, and the same thing happened. The third captain begged Elijah for mercy, and the angel of the Lord told Elijah to go with him. Elijah delivered the same message to Ahaziah, who then died, fulfilling the prophecy. Jehoram succeeded him as king because Ahaziah had no son.

Elijah was taken up to heaven in a whirlwind, and Elisha succeeded him. Elisha performed miracles, including parting the Jordan River and healing the waters of Jericho. He also cursed mocking children, resulting in two bears mauling forty-two of them. Jehoram, son of Ahab, became king of Israel and did evil in the Lord's sight, though not as severely as his parents. He removed Baal's image but continued the sins of Jeroboam.

Mesha, king of Moab, rebelled against Israel after Ahab's death. Jehoram mustered Israel and sought help from Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, to fight Moab. They agreed to go through the wilderness of Edom.Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there a prophet of the Lord here so we can ask for guidance?" One of the king of Israel's servants replied, "Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who served Elijah, is here." Jehoshaphat said, "The word of the Lord is with him." So the kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom went to Elisha.

Elisha said to the king of Israel, "Why come to me? Go to the prophets of your parents." The king of Israel replied, "No, the Lord has called us three kings together to deliver us into the hands of Moab." Elisha responded, "As surely as the Lord lives, if it weren't for my respect for Jehoshaphat, I wouldn't even look at you. But now, bring me a musician." As the musician played, the hand of the Lord came upon Elisha, and he said, "This is what the Lord says: Make this valley full of ditches. You won't see wind or rain, but the valley will be filled with water for you, your cattle, and your animals. This is an easy thing for the Lord; He will also deliver the Moabites into your hands. You will destroy every fortified city, cut down every good tree, stop up all the wells, and ruin every good piece of land with stones."

The next morning, water flowed from Edom, filling the land. When the Moabites heard the kings were coming to fight, they gathered everyone who could wear armor and stood at the border. Early in the morning, the sun shone on the water, making it look red like blood. The Moabites thought, "The kings have fought and killed each other. Let's go take the spoils!" But when they reached the Israelite camp, the Israelites attacked and defeated them, pursuing them into their own land. They destroyed the cities, filled the fields with stones, stopped up the wells, and cut down the trees. Only Kirharaseth was left with its stones, but the slingers surrounded and attacked it.

When the king of Moab saw the battle was too fierce, he took 700 swordsmen to break through to the king of Edom but failed. In desperation, he sacrificed his eldest son on the city wall, causing great anger against Israel, and they withdrew and returned to their land.

A widow of a prophet cried out to Elisha, saying her husband was dead and a creditor was coming to take her two sons as slaves. Elisha asked what she had in her house, and she replied, "Only a pot of oil." Elisha told her to borrow many empty vessels from her neighbors, shut the door, and pour oil into all the vessels. She did so, and the oil kept flowing until all the vessels were full. Elisha then told her to sell the oil, pay her debt, and live on the rest.

Elisha often passed through Shunem, where a wealthy woman urged him to eat at her house. She told her husband, "I know this is a holy man of God. Let's make a small room for him with a bed, table, chair, and lamp so he can stay whenever he comes." One day, Elisha stayed there and asked his servant Gehazi to call the woman. Elisha asked how he could repay her kindness. She said she was content among her people. Gehazi mentioned she had no son, and her husband was old. Elisha told her she would have a son by the same time next year. She doubted but conceived and bore a son as Elisha had said.

When the child grew, he went to his father in the fields, complaining of a headache. A servant carried him to his mother, where he sat on her lap until noon and then died. She laid him on Elisha's bed, shut the door, and went to find Elisha. Her husband asked why she was going, as it wasn't a special day. She assured him it would be well. She rode quickly to Elisha at Mount Carmel. When Elisha saw her, he sent Gehazi to ask if everything was well. She said it was, but when she reached Elisha, she grabbed his feet in distress. Gehazi tried to push her away, but Elisha said to leave her alone as the Lord had hidden her trouble from him.

She asked Elisha why he had given her a son only for him to die. Elisha sent Gehazi with his staff to lay on the child's face, instructing him not to greet anyone on the way. The child's mother insisted Elisha come too. Gehazi went ahead and laid the staff on the child, but there was no response. Elisha arrived, shut the door, and prayed. He lay on the child, mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, hands to hands, and the child's body warmed. Elisha walked around, then repeated the process. The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes. Elisha called Gehazi to bring the mother, who fell at Elisha's feet in gratitude and took her son.

Elisha returned to Gilgal during a famine. He told his servant to make a large pot of stew for the prophets. One man gathered wild gourds, not knowing they were poisonous. As they ate, they cried out, "There is death in the pot!" Elisha added some flour, and the stew became safe to eat.

A man from Baalshalisha brought Elisha twenty loaves of barley bread and fresh grain. Elisha told his servant to give it to the people to eat. The servant doubted it would be enough for a hundred men, but Elisha insisted, saying the Lord had promised they would eat and have leftovers. The servant distributed the food, and there was plenty left over, just as the Lord had said.Naaman, a respected commander of the Syrian army, was a valiant warrior but suffered from leprosy. During a raid, the Syrians captured a young girl from Israel who became a servant to Naaman's wife. The girl suggested that Naaman visit the prophet in Samaria to be healed. Naaman informed the king of Syria, who sent a letter to the king of Israel, along with gifts of silver, gold, and clothing, requesting Naaman's healing.

The king of Israel was distressed, thinking the request was a ploy to provoke conflict. When Elisha, the prophet, heard about the king's distress, he asked for Naaman to be sent to him. Naaman arrived at Elisha's house with his entourage. Elisha sent a messenger instructing Naaman to wash in the Jordan River seven times to be healed. Naaman was initially angry, expecting a more dramatic healing process, but his servants convinced him to follow Elisha's simple instructions. Naaman did as told and was miraculously healed, his skin becoming as healthy as a child's.

Grateful, Naaman returned to Elisha, offering gifts, but Elisha refused to accept them. Naaman then asked for permission to take some earth from Israel to build an altar to the Lord, vowing to worship only the God of Israel. Elisha granted his request and sent him away in peace.

However, Gehazi, Elisha's servant, saw an opportunity for personal gain. He chased after Naaman and falsely claimed that Elisha had sent him to request silver and clothing for two visiting prophets. Naaman generously gave Gehazi more than he asked for. Gehazi hid the gifts and returned to Elisha, who confronted him. Elisha knew of Gehazi's deceit and declared that Naaman's leprosy would now cling to Gehazi and his descendants forever. Gehazi left Elisha's presence, afflicted with leprosy.

Later, the sons of the prophets told Elisha that their living quarters were too small. They proposed to build a new place by the Jordan River, and Elisha agreed to join them. While cutting wood, one of the men lost a borrowed axe head in the river. Elisha miraculously made the iron float, allowing the man to retrieve it.

Meanwhile, the king of Syria planned to attack Israel. Elisha warned the king of Israel about the Syrian ambushes, saving the Israelites multiple times. The Syrian king suspected a traitor among his ranks, but his servants revealed that Elisha, the prophet, was informing the king of Israel about their plans. The Syrian king sent a large force to capture Elisha in Dothan. Elisha's servant panicked upon seeing the enemy, but Elisha prayed for his eyes to be opened. The servant then saw the mountain full of horses and chariots of fire protecting them.

Elisha prayed for the Syrian army to be struck with blindness and led them to Samaria. Once there, Elisha prayed for their sight to be restored. The king of Israel wanted to kill the captured Syrians, but Elisha instructed him to feed them and send them back to their master. This act of kindness led the Syrian raiders to stop attacking Israel.

Later, Benhadad, the king of Syria, besieged Samaria, causing a severe famine. The situation became so dire that people resorted to cannibalism. The king of Israel, in despair, blamed Elisha and sought to kill him. Elisha, aware of the king's intentions, instructed the elders to hold the door against the king's messenger.While Elisha was still speaking, the messenger arrived and said, "This disaster is from the LORD. Why should I wait for the LORD any longer?" Elisha responded, "Listen to the word of the LORD: By this time tomorrow, a measure of fine flour will sell for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel at the gate of Samaria." A royal officer, on whom the king leaned, doubted and said, "Even if the LORD opened the windows of heaven, could this happen?" Elisha replied, "You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it."

At the city gate, four men with leprosy discussed their dire situation. They decided to surrender to the Syrian camp, hoping for mercy. When they arrived, they found the camp deserted because the LORD had caused the Syrians to hear the sound of a great army, making them flee in panic, leaving everything behind. The lepers ate, drank, and took silver, gold, and clothes, hiding them. Realizing they should share the good news, they informed the city gatekeepers, who relayed the message to the king's household.

The king suspected a trap but sent scouts to investigate. They found the road littered with abandoned goods, confirming the Syrians' hasty retreat. The people plundered the Syrian camp, and as Elisha had prophesied, a measure of fine flour sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel. The doubting officer was trampled at the gate and died, fulfilling Elisha's prophecy.

Elisha then warned a woman, whose son he had revived, to leave because of an impending seven-year famine. She and her household stayed in Philistine territory for seven years. Upon returning, she appealed to the king for her property. Gehazi, Elisha's servant, was recounting Elisha's miracles to the king when the woman arrived. The king restored her property and the produce of her fields.

Elisha visited Damascus, where the Syrian king Benhadad was ill. Benhadad sent Hazael with gifts to ask Elisha if he would recover. Elisha told Hazael that the king would recover but would surely die. Elisha wept, foreseeing the harm Hazael would bring to Israel. Hazael denied he would do such things, but Elisha revealed he would become king of Syria. Hazael returned and reported to Benhadad, who later died under suspicious circumstances, and Hazael became king.

Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat, began his reign over Judah, following the ways of Ahab's house and doing evil in the LORD's sight. Despite this, the LORD did not destroy Judah for David's sake. During his reign, Edom and Libnah revolted. Jehoram's acts are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. He was succeeded by his son Ahaziah, who also did evil, influenced by his mother Athaliah, Ahab's daughter. Ahaziah joined Joram, Ahab's son, in battle against Hazael of Syria, where Joram was wounded. Ahaziah visited the injured Joram in Jezreel.

Elisha then instructed a young prophet to anoint Jehu, son of Jehoshaphat, as king over Israel. The young prophet did as told, anointing Jehu and then fleeing.Jehu approached the captains of the army and said, "I have a message for you, Captain." Jehu asked, "Which one of us?" The messenger replied, "For you, Captain." Jehu got up, went inside, and the messenger anointed him with oil, saying, "The LORD God of Israel has anointed you king over His people, Israel. You are to destroy the house of Ahab to avenge the blood of the LORD's prophets and servants shed by Jezebel. The entire house of Ahab will perish, and Jezebel will be eaten by dogs in Jezreel."

Jehu returned to his fellow officers, who asked, "Is everything alright? Why did that madman come to you?" Jehu replied, "You know the man and his talk." They insisted, "That's not true; tell us." Jehu then revealed, "He said, 'The LORD has anointed you king over Israel.'" Immediately, they laid their garments under him on the steps, blew trumpets, and proclaimed, "Jehu is king!"

Jehu conspired against Joram, who was recovering in Jezreel from wounds inflicted by the Syrians. Jehu instructed his men to ensure no one escaped to inform Jezreel. Jehu then rode to Jezreel, where Joram and Ahaziah, king of Judah, were present. A watchman saw Jehu's company approaching and reported it. Joram sent a horseman to ask, "Do you come in peace?" Jehu responded, "What do you know about peace? Fall in behind me." The watchman reported that the messenger did not return. Joram sent another horseman, who received the same response from Jehu.

Recognizing Jehu's furious driving, Joram and Ahaziah went out to meet him. Joram asked, "Do you come in peace, Jehu?" Jehu replied, "How can there be peace as long as your mother Jezebel's idolatry and witchcraft continue?" Joram turned to flee, shouting, "Treachery, Ahaziah!" Jehu shot Joram with an arrow, killing him. Jehu ordered his captain, Bidkar, to throw Joram's body into Naboth's field, fulfilling the LORD's prophecy.

Ahaziah fled but was pursued and killed by Jehu's men. His body was taken to Jerusalem and buried. Jehu then entered Jezreel, where Jezebel, having heard of his arrival, painted her face and looked out a window. She taunted Jehu, but he called out, "Who is on my side?" Two or three eunuchs looked out, and Jehu commanded, "Throw her down." They threw Jezebel out the window, and she died. Jehu ordered her burial, but only her skull, feet, and hands were found, fulfilling Elijah's prophecy that dogs would eat Jezebel's flesh.

Jehu then wrote letters to the rulers of Samaria, instructing them to behead Ahab's seventy sons and bring the heads to Jezreel. They complied, and Jehu displayed the heads at the city gate. He declared that the LORD's word against Ahab's house had been fulfilled. Jehu continued to eliminate Ahab's remaining family and supporters in Jezreel and Samaria.

Jehu then deceived the worshippers of Baal by proclaiming a grand sacrifice. He gathered all Baal's priests and followers into the temple, ensuring no servants of the LORD were present. Once inside, Jehu ordered his men to kill them all, destroying the temple and eradicating Baal worship from Israel.Jehu warned his men that if anyone let an enemy escape, they would pay with their own life. After offering a burnt sacrifice, Jehu commanded his guards and captains to kill everyone inside the temple of Baal. They did so, and then destroyed the temple and its idols, turning the site into a latrine. This marked the end of Baal worship in Israel.

However, Jehu did not completely turn away from the sins of Jeroboam, who had led Israel into idolatry with golden calves in Bethel and Dan. Despite this, the LORD commended Jehu for his actions against Ahab's house and promised that his descendants would rule Israel for four generations. But Jehu did not fully follow the LORD's laws, continuing in Jeroboam's sins.

During Jehu's reign, the LORD began to reduce Israel's territory, and Hazael of Syria attacked and conquered parts of Israel. Jehu's deeds and reign are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. He ruled for 28 years and was succeeded by his son Jehoahaz.

When Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, saw her son was dead, she killed all the royal heirs. However, Jehosheba, Ahaziah's sister, hid Joash, Ahaziah's son, in the temple for six years while Athaliah ruled. In the seventh year, Jehoiada the priest organized a coup, bringing the rulers, captains, and guards to the temple. He made a covenant with them and revealed Joash, the rightful king.

Jehoiada instructed them to guard Joash and the temple. They armed themselves with King David's weapons and surrounded Joash. They crowned and anointed him king, and the people rejoiced. Athaliah, hearing the commotion, came to the temple and saw Joash. She cried out "Treason!" but Jehoiada ordered her to be taken outside and killed.

Jehoiada then renewed the covenant between the LORD, the king, and the people. They destroyed the temple of Baal and killed its priest. Jehoiada appointed officers over the LORD's temple, and Joash was brought to the king's house and placed on the throne. The people rejoiced, and the city was peaceful. Joash was seven years old when he began to reign.

In the seventh year of Jehu's reign, Joash began his 40-year rule in Jerusalem. He did what was right in the LORD's eyes as long as Jehoiada the priest guided him. However, the high places were not removed, and people continued to offer sacrifices there.

Joash instructed the priests to use the dedicated money to repair the temple. But by the 23rd year of his reign, the repairs were not done. Joash then ordered the priests to stop collecting money and instead use it for the temple repairs. The priests agreed, and Jehoiada placed a chest in the temple to collect the money. The funds were used to pay workers who faithfully repaired the temple.

However, no silver bowls, snuffers, basins, trumpets, or other gold or silver vessels were made from the money collected. Instead, it was all used for the temple repairs. The money for trespass and sin offerings remained with the priests.

Hazael, king of Syria, attacked and captured Gath, then set his sights on Jerusalem. Joash took all the sacred items and gold from the temple and his palace and sent them to Hazael, who then withdrew from Jerusalem.

The rest of Joash's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. His servants conspired against him and killed him in the house of Millo. He was buried in the city of David, and his son Amaziah succeeded him.

In the 23rd year of Joash's reign in Judah, Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, began his 17-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He did evil in the LORD's sight, continuing in the sins of Jeroboam, which led Israel into sin. The LORD's anger was kindled against Israel, and He delivered them into the hands of Hazael and Benhadad, Hazael's son.Jehoahaz sought the LORD's help, and the LORD listened because He saw how the king of Syria was oppressing Israel. The LORD provided a savior for Israel, allowing them to escape Syrian control and live in peace again. However, the people continued to follow the sinful ways of Jeroboam, and the sacred grove remained in Samaria. Jehoahaz was left with only fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand foot soldiers because the king of Syria had decimated his forces.

The rest of Jehoahaz's deeds and his might are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. When he died, he was buried in Samaria, and his son Joash succeeded him. In the thirty-seventh year of Joash, king of Judah, Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz, began his sixteen-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He did evil in the LORD's sight, continuing the sins of Jeroboam.

The rest of Joash's acts, including his battles against Amaziah, king of Judah, are also recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. Joash died and was buried in Samaria, and his son Jeroboam took the throne.

Elisha fell ill and was on his deathbed when Joash, king of Israel, visited him and wept, calling him the chariot and horsemen of Israel. Elisha instructed Joash to take a bow and arrows, place his hand on the bow, and then Elisha placed his hands on Joash's hands. Elisha told him to open the east window and shoot an arrow, declaring it the arrow of the LORD's deliverance from Syria. He then told Joash to strike the ground with the arrows. Joash struck the ground three times and stopped, which angered Elisha. He said Joash should have struck the ground five or six times to completely defeat Syria, but now he would only defeat them three times.

Elisha died and was buried. During a Moabite invasion, a man was hastily buried in Elisha's tomb, and upon touching Elisha's bones, the man revived and stood up. Hazael, king of Syria, oppressed Israel throughout Jehoahaz's reign, but the LORD was gracious and compassionate because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He did not destroy Israel or cast them from His presence.

Hazael died, and his son Benhadad succeeded him. Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz, recaptured the cities taken by Benhadad from his father through three victories.

In the second year of Joash, son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel, Amaziah, son of Joash, king of Judah, began his twenty-nine-year reign in Jerusalem. He did what was right in the LORD's eyes, like his father Joash, but did not remove the high places where people continued to offer sacrifices. Once his rule was secure, he executed the servants who had killed his father but spared their children, following the law of Moses.

Amaziah defeated ten thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt and captured Selah, renaming it Joktheel. He then challenged Jehoash, king of Israel, to face him. Jehoash warned Amaziah to stay home and not seek trouble, but Amaziah insisted. They met in battle at Bethshemesh, where Judah was defeated, and Jehoash captured Amaziah. Jehoash broke down Jerusalem's wall and took all the gold, silver, and treasures from the temple and the king's house, along with hostages, and returned to Samaria.

The rest of Jehoash's acts, including his battles with Amaziah, are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. Jehoash died and was buried in Samaria, and his son Jeroboam succeeded him. Amaziah lived fifteen years after Jehoash's death. His deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. A conspiracy against him in Jerusalem forced him to flee to Lachish, where he was killed. He was buried in Jerusalem, and his son Azariah, at sixteen years old, was made king. Azariah rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah.

In the fifteenth year of Amaziah, Jeroboam, son of Joash, began his forty-one-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He did evil in the LORD's sight, continuing the sins of Jeroboam, son of Nebat. He restored Israel's borders from Hamath to the Dead Sea, fulfilling the word of the LORD spoken through Jonah, son of Amittai. The LORD saw Israel's suffering and saved them through Jeroboam, not wanting to erase their name from under heaven.

The rest of Jeroboam's acts, including his wars and the recovery of Damascus and Hamath for Israel, are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. Jeroboam died and was succeeded by his son Zachariah.

In the twenty-seventh year of Jeroboam, Azariah, son of Amaziah, began his fifty-two-year reign in Jerusalem. He did what was right in the LORD's eyes, like his father Amaziah, but did not remove the high places. The LORD struck him with leprosy, and he lived in isolation while his son Jotham governed the land. Azariah's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. He died and was buried in the city of David, and his son Jotham succeeded him.

In the thirty-eighth year of Azariah, Zachariah, son of Jeroboam, began his six-month reign over Israel in Samaria. He did evil in the LORD's sight, continuing the sins of Jeroboam. Shallum, son of Jabesh, conspired against and killed him, taking the throne. Zachariah's acts are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel, fulfilling the LORD's word that Jeroboam's descendants would rule for four generations.In the thirty-ninth year of Uzziah, king of Judah, Shallum, son of Jabesh, began his reign over Israel in Samaria, but it lasted only a month. Menahem, son of Gadi, came from Tirzah to Samaria, killed Shallum, and took over the throne. The rest of Shallum's deeds and his conspiracy are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

Menahem attacked Tiphsah and its surrounding areas because they did not open their gates to him. He brutally killed all the inhabitants, including pregnant women. Menahem ruled Israel for ten years, starting in the thirty-ninth year of Azariah, king of Judah. He continued the sinful practices of Jeroboam, son of Nebat.

When Pul, king of Assyria, invaded the land, Menahem paid him a thousand talents of silver to secure his support and maintain his rule. Menahem collected this money from the wealthy men of Israel, each contributing fifty shekels of silver. Pul then withdrew from the land. The rest of Menahem's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel. After his death, his son Pekahiah succeeded him.

In the fiftieth year of Azariah, king of Judah, Pekahiah, son of Menahem, began his two-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He continued the sinful ways of Jeroboam. Pekah, son of Remaliah, one of his captains, conspired against him and killed him in the palace, along with Argob and Arieh, and fifty men from Gilead. Pekah then took over the throne. The rest of Pekahiah's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

In the fifty-second year of Azariah, king of Judah, Pekah, son of Remaliah, began his twenty-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He continued the sinful practices of Jeroboam. During his reign, Tiglath-Pileser, king of Assyria, captured several cities and regions, including Ijon, Abel Beth Maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, and all of Naphtali, and took the inhabitants to Assyria. Hoshea, son of Elah, conspired against Pekah, killed him, and took over the throne in the twentieth year of Jotham, son of Uzziah. The rest of Pekah's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Israel.

In the second year of Pekah, son of Remaliah, Jotham, son of Uzziah, began his sixteen-year reign over Judah in Jerusalem. He was twenty-five years old when he became king. His mother was Jerusha, daughter of Zadok. Jotham did what was right in the LORD's eyes, following the example of his father Uzziah, but he did not remove the high places where people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense. He built the upper gate of the LORD's temple. The rest of Jotham's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. During his reign, the LORD began to send Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, against Judah. Jotham died and was buried in the city of David, and his son Ahaz succeeded him.

In the seventeenth year of Pekah, son of Remaliah, Ahaz, son of Jotham, began his sixteen-year reign over Judah in Jerusalem. He was twenty years old when he became king. Unlike his ancestor David, Ahaz did not do what was right in the LORD's eyes. He followed the practices of the kings of Israel, even sacrificing his son in the fire, imitating the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites. He offered sacrifices and burned incense at the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.

Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel, attacked Jerusalem but could not conquer it. Rezin recovered Elath for Syria, driving out the Jews, and the Syrians settled there. Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglath-Pileser, king of Assyria, asking for help against the kings of Syria and Israel. Ahaz took silver and gold from the LORD's temple and the royal treasury and sent it as a gift to the king of Assyria, who responded by attacking Damascus, capturing it, and killing Rezin. Ahaz then went to Damascus to meet Tiglath-Pileser and saw an altar there. He sent a model and detailed plans of the altar to Uriah the priest, who built it before Ahaz returned. When Ahaz came back, he offered sacrifices on the new altar and moved the bronze altar from its place in front of the LORD's temple to the north side of the new altar. He commanded Uriah to use the new altar for all the regular offerings and sacrifices, while the bronze altar would be for his personal inquiries. Uriah followed the king's orders.

Ahaz also removed the side panels and basins from the movable stands and took down the bronze sea from the bronze oxen it stood on, placing it on a stone base. He made these changes to appease the king of Assyria. The rest of Ahaz's deeds are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Ahaz died and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David, and his son Hezekiah succeeded him.

In the twelfth year of Ahaz, king of Judah, Hoshea, son of Elah, began his nine-year reign over Israel in Samaria. He did evil in the LORD's eyes, but not like the kings of Israel before him. Shalmaneser, king of Assyria, attacked Hoshea, who became his vassal and paid him tribute. However, the king of Assyria discovered that Hoshea was conspiring with So, king of Egypt, and had stopped paying tribute. Shalmaneser imprisoned Hoshea and besieged Samaria for three years. In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria captured Samaria and deported the Israelites to Assyria, settling them in Halah, Habor, and the cities of the Medes.The Israelites turned away from the LORD, ignoring His laws and covenant. They followed worthless idols and adopted the practices of the surrounding nations, which the LORD had forbidden. They abandoned all the commandments of the LORD, made idols, and worshipped celestial bodies and Baal. They even sacrificed their children in fire, practiced divination, and engaged in sorcery, provoking the LORD's anger. As a result, the LORD removed Israel from His presence, leaving only the tribe of Judah.

Judah also failed to keep the LORD's commandments, following the sinful practices of Israel. Consequently, the LORD rejected all of Israel's descendants, allowing them to be plundered and exiled. This happened because they had made Jeroboam king, who led Israel into great sin. The Israelites continued in Jeroboam's sins until the LORD removed them from His sight, as foretold by His prophets. The Israelites were taken to Assyria, where they remain to this day.

The king of Assyria brought people from various regions to settle in Samaria, replacing the Israelites. These new inhabitants did not fear the LORD, so He sent lions among them, killing some. They informed the king of Assyria, who sent one of the exiled priests back to teach them how to worship the LORD. However, each group continued to make their own gods and worship them in high places.

Despite learning about the LORD, these people continued to worship their own gods, following the customs of the nations from which they came. They did not follow the LORD's statutes, ordinances, or commandments given to the children of Jacob, whom He named Israel. The LORD had made a covenant with them, instructing them not to fear or worship other gods, but to worship Him alone, who brought them out of Egypt. They were to observe His laws and commandments forever. However, they did not listen and continued their previous practices, fearing the LORD but also serving their own idols. This behavior persisted through generations.

In the third year of Hoshea, king of Israel, Hezekiah, son of Ahaz, began his reign over Judah. He was twenty-five years old and reigned for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother was Abi, daughter of Zechariah. Hezekiah did what was right in the LORD's eyes, following the example of his ancestor David. He removed the high places, smashed the sacred stones, cut down the Asherah poles, and broke into pieces the bronze serpent Moses had made, which the Israelites had been burning incense to, calling it Nehushtan. Hezekiah trusted in the LORD, and there was no king like him among all the kings of Judah, either before or after him. He remained faithful to the LORD, keeping His commandments, and the LORD was with him, making him successful in everything he did. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him. He defeated the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory.

In Hezekiah's fourth year, which was the seventh year of Hoshea, king of Israel, Shalmaneser, king of Assyria, attacked Samaria and besieged it. After three years, Samaria was captured in Hezekiah's sixth year, which was Hoshea's ninth year. The king of Assyria deported the Israelites to Assyria because they had not obeyed the LORD's commands and had violated His covenant.

In Hezekiah's fourteenth year, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, attacked and captured all the fortified cities of Judah. Hezekiah sent a message to the king of Assyria at Lachish, admitting his wrongdoing and agreeing to pay whatever was demanded. The king of Assyria imposed a tribute of three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold. Hezekiah gave him all the silver found in the LORD's temple and the royal treasury. He even stripped the gold from the doors and pillars of the temple to pay the king of Assyria.

The king of Assyria then sent his officials with a large army to Jerusalem. They stood by the aqueduct of the upper pool and called for the king. Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah went out to meet them. The Assyrian official, Rabshakeh, questioned their confidence and mocked their reliance on Egypt and the LORD. He claimed that the LORD had sent him to destroy the land. Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah asked him to speak in Aramaic, not Hebrew, so the people on the wall would not understand. But Rabshakeh insisted on speaking in Hebrew, loudly proclaiming that the king of Assyria would not save them and urging them not to trust Hezekiah's promises of deliverance by the LORD."Make a deal with me and come out, and you will each eat from your own vine and fig tree, and drink water from your own cistern. Until I come and take you to a land like your own, a land of grain and wine, bread and vineyards, olive oil, and honey, so you may live and not die. Don't listen to Hezekiah when he says, 'The LORD will deliver us.' Have any of the gods of the nations saved their lands from the king of Assyria? Where are the gods of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivah? Did they save Samaria from my hand? Who among all the gods of these countries has saved their land from me, that the LORD should save Jerusalem?"

But the people remained silent and did not answer, as the king had commanded. Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah went to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and reported Rabshakeh's words.

When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and went to the temple of the LORD. He sent Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests, all in sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah. They told him, "This is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace. It may be that the LORD your God will hear the words of Rabshakeh, whom his master, the king of Assyria, has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke him. Therefore, pray for the remnant that still survives."

Isaiah replied, "Tell your master, 'This is what the LORD says: Do not be afraid of what you have heard, those words with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me. I will put a spirit in him so that he will hear a rumor and return to his own country, and I will have him cut down with the sword there.'"

Rabshakeh returned to find the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, having heard that he had left Lachish. When he heard that Tirhakah, king of Ethiopia, was coming to fight against him, he sent messengers to Hezekiah with this message: "Do not let the God you depend on deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria. You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other countries, destroying them completely. Will you be delivered? Did the gods of the nations that were destroyed by my predecessors deliver them? Where are the kings of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivah?"

Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers, read it, and went up to the temple of the LORD. He spread it out before the LORD and prayed, "LORD, the God of Israel, enthroned between the cherubim, you alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made heaven and earth. Give ear, LORD, and hear; open your eyes, LORD, and see; listen to the words Sennacherib has sent to ridicule the living God. It is true, LORD, that the Assyrian kings have laid waste these nations and their lands. They have thrown their gods into the fire and destroyed them, for they were not gods but only wood and stone, fashioned by human hands. Now, LORD our God, deliver us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone, LORD, are God."

Then Isaiah sent a message to Hezekiah: "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I have heard your prayer concerning Sennacherib king of Assyria. This is the word the LORD has spoken against him: 'The Virgin Daughter Zion despises you and mocks you. Daughter Jerusalem tosses her head as you flee. Who is it you have ridiculed and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes in pride? Against the Holy One of Israel! By your messengers you have ridiculed the Lord. And you have said, "With my many chariots I have ascended the heights of the mountains, the utmost heights of Lebanon. I have cut down its tallest cedars, the choicest of its junipers. I have reached its remotest parts, the finest of its forests. I have dug wells in foreign lands and drunk the water there. With the soles of my feet, I have dried up all the streams of Egypt."

Have you not heard? Long ago I ordained it. In days of old, I planned it; now I have brought it to pass, that you have turned fortified cities into piles of stone. Their people, drained of power, are dismayed and put to shame. They are like plants in the field, like tender green shoots, like grass sprouting on the roof, scorched before it grows up. But I know where you are and when you come and go and how you rage against me. Because you rage against me and because your insolence has reached my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, and I will make you return by the way you came.'

This will be the sign for you, Hezekiah: This year you will eat what grows by itself, and the second year what springs from that. But in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit. Once more a remnant of the kingdom of Judah will take root below and bear fruit above. For out of Jerusalem will come a remnant, and out of Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the LORD Almighty will accomplish this.

Therefore, this is what the LORD says concerning the king of Assyria: 'He will not enter this city or shoot an arrow here. He will not come before it with a shield or build a siege ramp against it. By the way that he came, he will return; he will not enter this city,' declares the LORD. 'I will defend this city and save it, for my sake and for the sake of David my servant.'"

That night, the angel of the LORD went out and put to death 185,000 in the Assyrian camp. When the people got up the next morning, there were all the dead bodies! So Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and withdrew. He returned to Nineveh and stayed there.

One day, while he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped to the land of Ararat. And Esarhaddon his son succeeded him as king.

In those days, Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz went to him and said, "This is what the LORD says: Put your house in order, because you are going to die; you will not recover." Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD, "Remember, LORD, how I have walked before you faithfully and with wholehearted devotion and have done what is good in your eyes." And Hezekiah wept bitterly.

Before Isaiah had left the middle court, the word of the LORD came to him: "Go back and tell Hezekiah, the ruler of my people, 'This is what the LORD, the God of your father David, says: I have heard your prayer and seen your tears; I will heal you. On the third day from now, you will go up to the temple of the LORD. I will add fifteen years to your life. And I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria. I will defend this city for my sake and for the sake of my servant David.'"

Then Isaiah said, "Prepare a poultice of figs." They did so and applied it to the boil, and he recovered.

Hezekiah had asked Isaiah, "What will be the sign that the LORD will heal me and that I will go up to the temple of the LORD on the third day from now?"

Isaiah answered, "This is the LORD's sign to you that the LORD will do what he has promised: Shall the shadow go forward ten steps, or shall it go back ten steps?"

"It is a simple matter for the shadow to go forward ten steps," said Hezekiah. "Rather, have it go back ten steps."

Then the prophet Isaiah called on the LORD, and the LORD made the shadow go back the ten steps it had gone down on the stairway of Ahaz.

At that time, Marduk-Baladan son of Baladan king of Babylon sent Hezekiah letters and a gift because he had heard of Hezekiah's illness. Hezekiah received the envoys and showed them all that was in his storehouses—the silver, the gold, the spices, and the fine olive oil—his armory and everything found among his treasures. There was nothing in his palace or in all his kingdom that Hezekiah did not show them.

Then Isaiah the prophet went to King Hezekiah and asked, "What did those men say, and where did they come from?"

"From a distant land," Hezekiah replied. "They came from Babylon."

The prophet asked, "What did they see in your palace?"

"They saw everything in my palace," Hezekiah said. "There is nothing among my treasures that I did not show them."Isaiah told Hezekiah, "Listen to what the LORD says: 'The time is coming when everything in your palace, all the treasures stored up by your ancestors, will be taken to Babylon. Nothing will be left. Some of your descendants will be taken away and made eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.'"

Hezekiah responded, "The word of the LORD you have spoken is good." He thought, "At least there will be peace and security during my lifetime."

The rest of Hezekiah's deeds, his achievements, and how he built a pool and a tunnel to bring water into the city, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Hezekiah died, and his son Manasseh succeeded him as king.

Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he ruled for fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother was Hephzibah. He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, following the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites. He rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had destroyed, set up altars for Baal, made an Asherah pole, and worshiped all the starry hosts. He built altars in the temple of the LORD, where the LORD had said, "In Jerusalem I will put my Name." In both courts of the temple, he built altars to the starry hosts. He sacrificed his own son in the fire, practiced divination, sought omens, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the eyes of the LORD, provoking Him to anger.

Manasseh also placed a carved Asherah pole in the temple, of which the LORD had said to David and Solomon, "In this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my Name forever. I will not again make the feet of the Israelites wander from the land I gave their ancestors, if they will only be careful to do everything I commanded them and keep the whole Law that my servant Moses gave them." But the people did not listen. Manasseh led them astray, so they did more evil than the nations the LORD had destroyed before the Israelites.

The LORD spoke through His servants the prophets, saying, "Because Manasseh king of Judah has committed these detestable sins, doing more evil than the Amorites who preceded him, and has led Judah into sin with his idols, I am going to bring such disaster on Jerusalem and Judah that the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle. I will stretch out over Jerusalem the measuring line used against Samaria and the plumb line used against the house of Ahab. I will wipe out Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down. I will forsake the remnant of my inheritance and give them into the hands of their enemies. They will be looted and plundered by all their foes because they have done evil in my eyes and have aroused my anger from the day their ancestors came out of Egypt until now."

Manasseh also shed so much innocent blood that he filled Jerusalem from end to end—besides the sin he had caused Judah to commit, so they did evil in the eyes of the LORD. The rest of Manasseh's deeds, including his sins, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. Manasseh died and was buried in the garden of his own house, in the garden of Uzza. His son Amon succeeded him as king.

Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he ruled for two years in Jerusalem. His mother was Meshullemeth, daughter of Haruz from Jotbah. He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, as his father Manasseh had done. He followed the ways of his father, worshiping the idols his father had worshiped and forsaking the LORD, the God of his ancestors. Amon's officials conspired against him and assassinated him in his palace. But the people of the land killed all who had plotted against King Amon, and they made his son Josiah king in his place. The rest of Amon's deeds are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah. He was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza, and his son Josiah succeeded him as king.

Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he ruled for thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jedidah, daughter of Adaiah from Boscath. He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD and followed completely the ways of his ancestor David, not turning aside to the right or to the left.

In the eighteenth year of his reign, King Josiah sent Shaphan son of Azaliah, the son of Meshullam, the secretary, to the temple of the LORD. He said, "Go up to Hilkiah the high priest and have him get ready the money that has been brought into the temple of the LORD, which the doorkeepers have collected from the people. Have them entrust it to the men appointed to supervise the work on the temple. And have these men pay the workers who repair the temple of the LORD—the carpenters, the builders, and the masons. Also have them purchase timber and dressed stone to repair the temple. But they need not account for the money entrusted to them, because they are honest in their dealings."

Hilkiah the high priest said to Shaphan the secretary, "I have found the Book of the Law in the temple of the LORD." He gave it to Shaphan, who read it. Then Shaphan the secretary went to the king and reported to him: "Your officials have paid out the money that was in the temple of the LORD and have entrusted it to the workers and supervisors at the temple." Then Shaphan the secretary informed the king, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book." And Shaphan read from it in the presence of the king.

When the king heard the words of the Book of the Law, he tore his robes. He gave these orders to Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Akbor son of Micaiah, Shaphan the secretary, and Asaiah the king's attendant: "Go and inquire of the LORD for me and for the people and for all Judah about what is written in this book that has been found. Great is the LORD's anger that burns against us because those who have gone before us have not obeyed the words of this book; they have not acted in accordance with all that is written there concerning us."

Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Akbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to speak to the prophet Huldah, who was the wife of Shallum son of Tikvah, the son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe. She lived in Jerusalem, in the New Quarter. She said to them, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Tell the man who sent you to me, 'This is what the LORD says: I am going to bring disaster on this place and its people, according to everything written in the book the king of Judah has read. Because they have forsaken me and burned incense to other gods and aroused my anger by all the idols their hands have made, my anger will burn against this place and will not be quenched.' Tell the king of Judah, who sent you to inquire of the LORD, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says concerning the words you heard: Because your heart was responsive and you humbled yourself before the LORD when you heard what I have spoken against this place and its people—that they would become a curse and be laid waste—and because you tore your robes and wept in my presence, I have also heard you, declares the LORD. Therefore, I will gather you to your ancestors, and you will be buried in peace. Your eyes will not see all the disaster I am going to bring on this place.'"

So they took her answer back to the king. Then the king called together all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem. He went up to the temple of the LORD with the people of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests, and the prophets—all the people from the least to the greatest. He read in their hearing all the words of the Book of the Covenant, which had been found in the temple of the LORD. The king stood by the pillar and renewed the covenant in the presence of the LORD—to follow the LORD and keep his commands, statutes, and decrees with all his heart and all his soul, thus confirming the words of the covenant written in this book. Then all the people pledged themselves to the covenant.

The king ordered Hilkiah the high priest, the priests next in rank, and the doorkeepers to remove from the temple of the LORD all the articles made for Baal and Asherah and all the starry hosts. He burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of the Kidron Valley and took the ashes to Bethel. He did away with the idolatrous priests appointed by the kings of Judah to burn incense on the high places of the towns of Judah and those around Jerusalem—those who burned incense to Baal, to the sun and moon, to the constellations, and to all the starry hosts.Josiah removed all the priests from the cities of Judah and desecrated the high places where they had burned incense, from Geba to Beersheba. He destroyed the high places at the gates of the city, including those at the entrance of the gate of Joshua, the governor of the city. Although the priests of these high places did not serve at the altar of the LORD in Jerusalem, they still ate unleavened bread with their fellow priests.

Josiah defiled Topheth in the Valley of Hinnom to prevent anyone from sacrificing their children to Molech. He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun and burned the chariots of the sun. He demolished the altars on the roof of Ahaz's upper chamber and the altars Manasseh had made in the temple courts, throwing their debris into the Kidron Valley.

He also desecrated the high places east of Jerusalem, which Solomon had built for Ashtoreth, Chemosh, and Milcom. Josiah smashed the sacred stones, cut down the Asherah poles, and filled their sites with human bones. He destroyed the altar at Bethel and the high place built by Jeroboam, burning the high place and grinding it to powder.

As Josiah looked around, he noticed tombs on the hillside. He had the bones removed and burned on the altar to defile it, fulfilling the prophecy of the man of God. When he asked about a particular tomb, he was told it belonged to the prophet who had foretold these events. Josiah ordered that the prophet's bones be left undisturbed.

Josiah also removed all the shrines in the towns of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had built to provoke the LORD. He executed the priests of these high places and burned human bones on their altars before returning to Jerusalem.

Josiah then commanded the people to celebrate the Passover as written in the Book of the Covenant. This Passover was unlike any observed since the days of the judges or the kings of Israel and Judah. In his eighteenth year, Josiah celebrated this Passover in Jerusalem.

Josiah also eradicated mediums, wizards, idols, and all other abominations in Judah and Jerusalem to fulfill the words of the law found by Hilkiah the priest. No king before or after Josiah turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and strength, as he did, following the law of Moses.

Despite Josiah's reforms, the LORD's fierce anger against Judah remained due to the provocations of Manasseh. The LORD declared that He would remove Judah from His sight, just as He had removed Israel, and reject Jerusalem and the temple.

The rest of Josiah's acts are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. During his reign, Pharaoh Necho of Egypt went to assist the king of Assyria at the Euphrates River. Josiah confronted him at Megiddo, where he was killed. His servants brought his body back to Jerusalem for burial. The people then anointed Josiah's son Jehoahaz as king.

Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, but he reigned only three months in Jerusalem. He did evil in the sight of the LORD, following the ways of his ancestors. Pharaoh Necho imprisoned him at Riblah in the land of Hamath and imposed a tribute on the land. Necho then made Eliakim, Josiah's son, king and changed his name to Jehoiakim, taking Jehoahaz to Egypt, where he died.

Jehoiakim taxed the land to pay the tribute to Pharaoh. He was twenty-five years old when he became king and reigned eleven years in Jerusalem, doing evil in the sight of the LORD. During his reign, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, invaded, and Jehoiakim became his vassal for three years before rebelling.

The LORD sent raiders from various nations to destroy Judah, fulfilling His word through the prophets. This was due to the sins of Manasseh and the innocent blood he shed, which the LORD would not forgive. The rest of Jehoiakim's acts are recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Judah. He died, and his son Jehoiachin succeeded him.

During Jehoiachin's reign, Nebuchadnezzar besieged Jerusalem. Jehoiachin, his family, and his officials surrendered, and Nebuchadnezzar took them captive. He also took all the treasures from the temple and the royal palace, as well as the skilled workers and soldiers, leaving only the poorest people behind. Nebuchadnezzar made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, king and changed his name to Zedekiah.In the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his army besieged Jerusalem. The siege lasted until the eleventh year of Zedekiah's reign. By the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine in the city was severe, and there was no food for the people. The city walls were breached, and the soldiers fled at night through the gate between the two walls near the king's garden, even though the Chaldeans surrounded the city. The Chaldean army pursued King Zedekiah and captured him in the plains of Jericho, scattering his troops.

They brought Zedekiah to King Nebuchadnezzar at Riblah, where he was judged. Zedekiah's sons were killed before his eyes, and then his eyes were put out. He was bound in bronze chains and taken to Babylon.
