On the seventh day of the fifth month, in the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar's reign, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, arrived in Jerusalem. He burned down the temple of the LORD, the royal palace, and all the houses in Jerusalem. The Chaldean army, under his command, tore down the city walls. Nebuzaradan took the remaining people in the city, including those who had defected to the Babylonians, and the rest of the population, into exile. However, he left some of the poorest people behind to tend the vineyards and fields.

The Chaldeans broke apart the bronze pillars, the bronze sea, and the stands in the temple of the LORD and took the bronze to Babylon. They also took the pots, shovels, wick trimmers, dishes, and all the bronze articles used in temple service. The captain of the guard took away the firepans and bowls, which were made of gold and silver. The bronze from the two pillars, the sea, and the stands, which Solomon had made for the temple, was too heavy to be weighed. Each pillar was eighteen cubits high, with a bronze capital three cubits high, decorated with a network and pomegranates.

Nebuzaradan also took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three doorkeepers. From the city, he took an officer in charge of the fighting men, five royal advisors, the army commander’s secretary who conscripted the people, and sixty other men found in the city. Nebuzaradan brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah, where they were executed. Thus, Judah was taken into exile.

Nebuchadnezzar appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam as governor over the remaining people in Judah. When the army officers and their men heard about this, they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah. Gedaliah assured them and their men not to be afraid of serving the Babylonians and to settle in the land and serve the king of Babylon, promising that it would go well for them. However, in the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, along with ten men, assassinated Gedaliah and the Jews and Babylonians with him at Mizpah. Fearing the Babylonians, all the people, from the least to the greatest, fled to Egypt.

In the thirty-seventh year of Jehoiachin's exile, on the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month, Evil-Merodach, king of Babylon, released Jehoiachin from prison. He spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat of honor higher than those of the other kings in Babylon. Jehoiachin changed out of his prison clothes and dined regularly at the king's table for the rest of his life. The king provided Jehoiachin with a daily allowance for the rest of his life.

The First Book of Chronicles begins with a genealogy from Adam to Abraham, listing the descendants of Adam, Noah, and the sons of Noah: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. It continues with the descendants of Japheth, Ham, and Shem, including notable figures like Nimrod, who was a mighty warrior on earth. The genealogy also covers the descendants of Abraham through his sons Isaac and Ishmael, and the sons of Keturah, Abraham's concubine. The lineage of Esau and the kings of Edom is also detailed, concluding with the sons of Israel: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.Achar, known as the troublemaker of Israel, violated the ban on taking accursed things. Ethan's son was Azariah. Hezron's sons were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai. Ram fathered Amminadab, who fathered Nahshon, a leader of Judah. Nahshon fathered Salma, who fathered Boaz. Boaz fathered Obed, who fathered Jesse. Jesse's firstborn was Eliab, followed by Abinadab, Shimma, Nethaneel, Raddai, Ozem, and David. David's sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah's sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel. Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.

Caleb, son of Hezron, had children with his wife Azubah and Jerioth. Their sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon. After Azubah's death, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur. Hur fathered Uri, who fathered Bezalel. Hezron married the daughter of Machir, father of Gilead, at sixty years old, and they had Segub. Segub fathered Jair, who controlled twenty-three cities in Gilead. He also took Geshur and Aram, including the towns of Jair and Kenath, totaling sixty cities. These belonged to the sons of Machir, father of Gilead. After Hezron's death in Caleb Ephrathah, his wife Abiah bore him Ashur, father of Tekoa.

Jerahmeel, Hezron's firstborn, had sons: Ram, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah. Jerahmeel also had another wife, Atarah, mother of Onam. Ram's sons were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker. Onam's sons were Shammai and Jada. Shammai's sons were Nadab and Abishur. Abishur's wife was Abihail, who bore him Ahban and Molid. Nadab's sons were Seled and Appaim, but Seled died childless. Appaim's son was Ishi, whose son was Sheshan. Sheshan's child was Ahlai. Jada's sons were Jether and Jonathan, but Jether died childless. Jonathan's sons were Peleth and Zaza. These were Jerahmeel's descendants.

Sheshan had no sons, only daughters. He gave his daughter to his Egyptian servant Jarha, who fathered Attai. Attai fathered Nathan, who fathered Zabad. Zabad fathered Ephlal, who fathered Obed. Obed fathered Jehu, who fathered Azariah. Azariah fathered Helez, who fathered Eleasah. Eleasah fathered Sisamai, who fathered Shallum. Shallum fathered Jekamiah, who fathered Elishama.

Caleb's brother Jerahmeel's sons were Mesha, father of Ziph, and Mareshah, father of Hebron. Hebron's sons were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema. Shema fathered Raham, father of Jorkoam. Rekem fathered Shammai. Shammai's son was Maon, father of Bethzur. Caleb's concubine Ephah bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran fathered Gazez. Jahdai's sons were Regem, Jotham, Gesham, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph. Caleb's concubine Maachah bore Sheber and Tirhanah. She also bore Shaaph, father of Madmannah, Sheva, father of Machbenah and Gibea. Caleb's daughter was Achsa.

These were Caleb's descendants: Shobal, father of Kirjathjearim; Salma, father of Bethlehem; and Hareph, father of Bethgader. Shobal's sons were Haroeh and half of the Manahethites. The families of Kirjathjearim were the Ithrites, Puhites, Shumathites, and Mishraites, from whom came the Zareathites and Eshtaulites. Salma's descendants were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Ataroth, the house of Joab, and half of the Manahethites, the Zorites. The families of scribes living at Jabez were the Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Suchathites. These were the Kenites from Hemath, father of the house of Rechab.

David's sons born in Hebron were Amnon (by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess), Daniel (by Abigail the Carmelitess), Absalom (by Maachah, daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur), Adonijah (by Haggith), Shephatiah (by Abital), and Ithream (by Eglah). David reigned in Hebron for seven years and six months, and in Jerusalem for thirty-three years. His sons born in Jerusalem were Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon (by Bathshua, daughter of Ammiel), Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet. These were David's sons, along with the sons of his concubines, and their sister Tamar.

Solomon's son was Rehoboam, whose descendants were Abia, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Joram, Ahaziah, Joash, Amaziah, Azariah, Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, and Josiah. Josiah's sons were Johanan, Jehoiakim, Zedekiah, and Shallum. Jehoiakim's sons were Jeconiah and Zedekiah. Jeconiah's sons were Assir and Salathiel. Other descendants included Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazar, Jecamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah. Pedaiah's sons were Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel's children were Meshullam, Hananiah, and their sister Shelomith, along with Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushabhesed. Hananiah's sons were Pelatiah and Jesaiah, and their descendants included Rephaiah, Arnan, Obadiah, and Shechaniah. Shechaniah's son was Shemaiah, whose sons were Hattush, Igeal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat. Neariah's sons were Elioenai, Hezekiah, and Azrikam. Elioenai's sons were Hodaiah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Dalaiah, and Anani.

Judah's descendants were Pharez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal. Shobal's son Reaiah fathered Jahath, who fathered Ahumai and Lahad. These were the Zorathite families. The descendants of Etam were Jezreel, Ishma, Idbash, and their sister Hazelelponi. Penuel fathered Gedor, and Ezer fathered Hushah. These were Hur's descendants, the firstborn of Ephratah and father of Bethlehem. Ashur, father of Tekoa, had two wives, Helah and Naarah. Naarah bore him Ahuzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari. Helah's sons were Zereth, Jezoar, and Ethnan. Coz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Aharhel, son of Harum.

Jabez was more honorable than his brothers. His mother named him Jabez, saying, "I bore him in pain." Jabez prayed to the God of Israel, asking for blessings, expanded territory, God's hand to be with him, and protection from harm. God granted his request. Chelub, Shuah's brother, fathered Mehir, who fathered Eshton. Eshton fathered Bethrapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah, father of Irnahash. These were the men of Rechah. Kenaz's sons were Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel's sons were Hathath and Meonothai, who fathered Ophrah. Seraiah fathered Joab, the father of the valley of craftsmen. Caleb, son of Jephunneh, had sons Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah's son was Kenaz. Jehaleleel's sons were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asareel. Ezra's sons were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered's wife bore Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah, father of Eshtemoa. His wife from Judah bore Jered, father of Gedor, Heber, father of Socho, and Jekuthiel, father of Zanoah. These were the sons of Bithiah, Pharaoh's daughter, whom Mered married. His wife Hodiah's sister bore Keilah the Garmite and Eshtemoa the Maachathite. Shimon's sons were Amnon, Rinnah, Benhanan, and Tilon. Ishi's sons were Zoheth and Benzoheth. Shelah, son of Judah, had sons Er, father of Lecah, Laadah, father of Mareshah, and the families of the house of Ashbea, who worked fine linen. Jokim, the men of Chozeba, Joash, and Saraph ruled in Moab and Jashubilehem. These are ancient records. These were the potters and those who lived among plants and hedges, dwelling there for the king's work. Simeon's sons were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul. Shaul's descendants were Shallum, Mibsam, and Mishma. Mishma's descendants were Hamuel, Zacchur, and Shimei. Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters, but his brothers did not have many children, and their families did not multiply like Judah's. They lived in Beersheba, Moladah, Hazarshual, Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad, Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag, Bethmarcaboth, and Hazarsusim.The descendants of Simeon lived in the cities of Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan, along with their surrounding villages, until the reign of David. Their genealogy included Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah (son of Amaziah), Joel, Jehu (son of Josibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, and Benaiah. Ziza, son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah, was also mentioned. These individuals were leaders in their families, and their households grew significantly.

They traveled to the entrance of Gedor, on the east side of the valley, to find pasture for their flocks. They discovered rich and peaceful land, previously inhabited by the descendants of Ham. During the reign of Hezekiah, king of Judah, they attacked and destroyed the tents and settlements they found there, taking over the land because it had good pasture for their flocks. Five hundred men from the sons of Simeon, led by Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel (sons of Ishi), went to Mount Seir and defeated the remaining Amalekites, settling there permanently.

Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, lost his birthright due to defiling his father's bed, and it was given to the sons of Joseph. However, Judah became the leading tribe, and the birthright belonged to Joseph. Reuben's sons were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. Joel's descendants included Shemaiah, Gog, Shimei, Micah, Reaia, Baal, and Beerah, who was taken captive by Tilgathpilneser, king of Assyria. Other notable descendants were Jeiel, Zechariah, and Bela (son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel), who lived in Aroer, Nebo, and Baalmeon, extending eastward to the Euphrates River due to their growing cattle population.

During Saul's reign, they fought the Hagarites and settled in their tents throughout the eastern land of Gilead. The descendants of Gad lived in Bashan, with Joel as the chief, followed by Shapham, Jaanai, and Shaphat. Their notable family members included Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jachan, Zia, and Heber. These were the descendants of Abihail, son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz. Ahi, son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was the chief of their family. They lived in Gilead, Bashan, and its towns, and in the suburbs of Sharon.

These genealogies were recorded during the reigns of Jotham, king of Judah, and Jeroboam, king of Israel. The sons of Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh were valiant warriors, skilled in using shields, swords, and bows, totaling 44,760 men ready for battle. They fought the Hagarites, Jetur, Nephish, and Nodab, and were victorious because they trusted in God. They captured their livestock, including 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep, 2,000 donkeys, and 100,000 people. Many enemies were killed because the battle was God's will, and they settled in the land until the captivity.

The half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land from Bashan to Baalhermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. Their leaders included Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel, who were renowned warriors and heads of their families. However, they sinned against God by worshiping the gods of the people in the land, whom God had destroyed before them. Consequently, God stirred up the spirit of Pul, king of Assyria, and Tilgathpilneser, king of Assyria, who took the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh into captivity, bringing them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the river Gozan, where they remain to this day.

The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Kohath's sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Amram's children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron's sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. Eleazar's lineage included Phinehas, Abishua, Bukki, Uzzi, Zerahiah, Meraioth, Amariah, Ahitub, Zadok, Ahimaaz, Azariah, Johanan, and another Azariah, who served as a priest in Solomon's temple in Jerusalem. This Azariah's descendants included Amariah, Ahitub, Zadok, Shallum, Hilkiah, another Azariah, Seraiah, and Jehozadak, who went into captivity when the Lord exiled Judah and Jerusalem by Nebuchadnezzar.

The sons of Levi were Gershom, Kohath, and Merari. Gershom's sons were Libni and Shimei. Kohath's sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Merari's sons were Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their fathers. Gershom's descendants included Libni, Jahath, Zimmah, Joah, Iddo, Zerah, and Jeaterai. Kohath's descendants included Amminadab, Korah, Assir, Elkanah, Ebiasaph, another Assir, Tahath, Uriel, Uzziah, and Shaul. Elkanah's descendants included Amasai and Ahimoth. Elkanah's lineage continued with Zophai, Nahath, Eliab, Jeroham, and another Elkanah. Samuel's sons were Vashni and Abiah. Merari's descendants included Mahli, Libni, Shimei, Uzza, Shimea, Haggiah, and Asaiah.

These were the individuals David appointed to oversee the music in the house of the Lord after the ark was placed there. They served with singing before the tabernacle until Solomon built the temple in Jerusalem, and they continued their duties according to their order. The Kohathites included Heman, a singer, son of Joel, son of Shemuel, son of Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Toah, son of Zuph, son of Elkanah, son of Mahath, son of Amasai, son of Elkanah, son of Joel, son of Azariah, son of Zephaniah, son of Tahath, son of Assir, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah, son of Izhar, son of Kohath, son of Levi, son of Israel. Heman's brother Asaph stood on his right hand, and his lineage included Berachiah, Shimea, Michael, Baaseiah, Malchiah, Ethni, Zerah, Adaiah, Ethan, Zimmah, Shimei, Jahath, Gershom, and Levi. The sons of Merari stood on the left hand, including Ethan, son of Kishi, son of Abdi, son of Malluch, son of Hashabiah, son of Amaziah, son of Hilkiah, son of Amzi, son of Bani, son of Shamer, son of Mahli, son of Mushi, son of Merari, son of Levi. Their fellow Levites were appointed to various services in the tabernacle of the house of God.

Aaron and his sons were responsible for offering sacrifices on the altar of burnt offering and the altar of incense, performing all the work of the most holy place, and making atonement for Israel according to Moses' commands. Aaron's descendants included Eleazar, Phinehas, Abishua, Bukki, Uzzi, Zerahiah, Meraioth, Amariah, Ahitub, Zadok, and Ahimaaz. These were their dwelling places within their territories, assigned to the families of the Kohathites. They were given Hebron in the land of Judah and its surrounding suburbs, but the fields and villages of the city were given to Caleb, son of Jephunneh. The sons of Aaron received the cities of Judah, including Hebron.The Levites were given cities and their surrounding lands as their inheritance. The descendants of Kohath received cities from the tribe of Manasseh, totaling ten cities. The descendants of Gershom were given thirteen cities from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Manasseh in Bashan. The descendants of Merari received twelve cities from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun. The Israelites provided these cities and their surrounding lands to the Levites.

The remaining families of the Kohathites received cities from the tribe of Ephraim, including Shechem, a city of refuge, and other cities like Gezer, Jokmeam, Bethhoron, Aijalon, and Gathrimmon. The descendants of Gershom received cities from the half-tribe of Manasseh, including Golan in Bashan and Ashtaroth. They also received cities from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, and Naphtali. The descendants of Merari received cities from the tribe of Zebulun, including Rimmon and Tabor, and from the tribe of Reuben, including Bezer and Jahzah. They also received cities from the tribe of Gad, including Ramoth in Gilead, Mahanaim, Heshbon, and Jazer.

The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron. Tola's descendants were valiant warriors, numbering 22,600 during David's time. Uzzi's descendants included Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Ishiah, all of whom were leaders. They had 36,000 soldiers due to their many wives and children. The total number of valiant men among the families of Issachar was 87,000.

The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, and Jediael. Bela's descendants included Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri, who were mighty warriors, totaling 22,034. Becher's descendants included Zemira, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jerimoth, Abiah, Anathoth, and Alameth, totaling 20,200. Jediael's descendants included Bilhan, Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tharshish, and Ahishahar, totaling 17,200 soldiers.

The sons of Naphtali were Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum. The sons of Manasseh included Ashriel and Machir, the father of Gilead. Machir's wife bore Peresh and Sheresh, whose sons were Ulam and Rakem. Ulam's descendants included Bedan. The sons of Ephraim included Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eladah, and Zabad. Ephraim mourned the loss of his sons Ezer and Elead, who were killed by the men of Gath. Ephraim's descendants included Beriah, who had a daughter named Sherah, who built Bethhoron and Uzzensherah. Other descendants included Rephah, Resheph, Telah, Tahan, Laadan, Ammihud, Elishama, Non, and Jehoshuah.

The sons of Asher were Imnah, Isuah, Ishuai, and Beriah, and their sister Serah. Beriah's descendants included Heber and Malchiel. Heber's descendants included Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their sister Shua. Japhlet's descendants included Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath. Shamer's descendants included Ahi, Rohgah, Jehubbah, and Aram. Helem's descendants included Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal. Zophah's descendants included Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah, Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, and Beera. Jether's descendants included Jephunneh, Pispah, and Ara. Ulla's descendants included Arah, Haniel, and Rezia. The total number of valiant men of Asher was 26,000.

The sons of Benjamin included Bela, Ashbel, Aharah, Nohah, and Rapha. Bela's descendants included Addar, Gera, Abihud, Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah, Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram. The sons of Ehud were heads of the families in Geba and were relocated to Manahath. Naaman, Ahiah, and Gera were also relocated and had descendants including Uzza and Ahihud. Shaharaim had children in Moab after sending away his wives Hushim and Baara. He had sons with his wife Hodesh, including Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcham, Jeuz, Shachia, and Mirma. Hushim's descendants included Abitub and Elpaal. Elpaal's descendants included Eber, Misham, Shamed, Beriah, and Shema, who were heads of the families in Aijalon and drove away the inhabitants of Gath. Other descendants included Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth, Zebadiah, Arad, Ader, Michael, Ispah, Joha, Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hezeki, Heber, Ishmerai, Jezliah, Jobab, Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi, Elienai, Zilthai, Eliel, Adaiah, Beraiah, Shimrath, Ishpan, Heber, Eliel, Abdon, Zichri, Hanan, Hananiah, Elam, Antothijah, Iphedeiah, Penuel, Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah, Jaresiah, Eliah, and Zichri. These were the heads of the families who lived in Jerusalem.

At Gibeon, the father of Gibeon lived with his wife Maachah. Their firstborn son was Abdon, followed by Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, and Zacher. Mikloth had a son named Shimeah. They also lived with their relatives in Jerusalem. Ner was the father of Kish, who was the father of Saul. Saul's sons were Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal. Jonathan's son was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal's son was Micah. Micah's sons were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz. Ahaz was the father of Jehoaddah, who was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri was the father of Moza, who was the father of Binea. Binea's descendants included Raphah, Eleasah, and Azel. Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the descendants of Azel.Jonathan's son was Meribbaal, who had a son named Micah. Micah's sons were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz. Ahaz fathered Jehoadah, who fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri fathered Moza, who fathered Binea. Binea's descendants included Rapha, Eleasah, and Azel. Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were all the sons of Azel. 

Eshek, Azel's brother, had three sons: Ulam, Jehush, and Eliphelet. Ulam's sons were known as brave warriors and skilled archers, having many descendants—150 in total. These were the descendants of Benjamin.

All of Israel was recorded in genealogies, which were documented in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah. These records included those who were exiled to Babylon due to their unfaithfulness. The first inhabitants to return to their cities were the Israelites, priests, Levites, and temple servants.

In Jerusalem, people from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh lived. Among them were Uthai, son of Ammihud, and Asaiah, the firstborn of the Shilonites. From the sons of Zerah, there were Jeuel and 690 of their relatives. From the sons of Benjamin, there were Sallu, Ibneiah, Elah, and Meshullam, along with 956 of their relatives, who were heads of their families.

The priests included Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin, and Azariah, who was the ruler of the house of God. Other priests were Adaiah and Maasiai, along with 1,760 of their relatives, who were capable men for the service of the house of God.

The Levites included Shemaiah, Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah, Obadiah, and Berechiah. The gatekeepers were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives, with Shallum as the chief. They were responsible for guarding the gates of the tabernacle, a duty passed down from their ancestors.

Phinehas, son of Eleazar, had been their leader in the past, and the Lord was with him. Zechariah, son of Meshelemiah, was the gatekeeper of the tabernacle's entrance. In total, 212 gatekeepers were chosen by genealogy and appointed by David and Samuel the seer. They and their descendants were responsible for guarding the gates of the house of the Lord.

The gatekeepers were stationed in four directions: east, west, north, and south. Their relatives from the villages would join them every seven days. The four chief gatekeepers were in charge of the chambers and treasuries of the house of God. They stayed around the house of God because they were responsible for opening it every morning.

Some Levites were in charge of the temple's utensils, ensuring they were brought in and out as needed. Others oversaw the sanctuary's instruments, fine flour, wine, oil, incense, and spices. Some of the priests' sons made the ointment for the spices. Mattithiah, a Levite and firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, was responsible for the items made in pans. Other Kohathites were in charge of preparing the showbread every Sabbath.

The singers, who were heads of the Levite families, stayed in the temple chambers and were exempt from other duties because they were employed in their work day and night. These heads of the Levite families lived in Jerusalem.

In Gibeon lived the father of Gibeon, Jehiel, and his wife Maachah. Their firstborn son was Abdon, followed by Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab, Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth. Mikloth fathered Shimeam. They also lived with their relatives in Jerusalem.

Ner fathered Kish, who fathered Saul. Saul's sons were Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal. Jonathan's son was Meribbaal, who fathered Micah. Micah's sons were Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz. Ahaz fathered Jarah, who fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri fathered Moza, who fathered Binea. Binea's descendants included Rephaiah, Eleasah, and Azel. Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the sons of Azel.

The Philistines fought against Israel, and the Israelites fled, falling slain on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons, killing Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua. The battle was intense, and Saul was critically wounded by archers. He asked his armor-bearer to kill him to avoid capture, but the armor-bearer refused. So, Saul took his own sword and fell on it. When the armor-bearer saw Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died. Thus, Saul, his three sons, and his entire household died together.

When the Israelites in the valley saw that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities, and the Philistines occupied them. The next day, the Philistines came to strip the dead and found Saul and his sons on Mount Gilboa. They took Saul's head and armor and sent them throughout Philistia to proclaim the news to their idols and people. They placed his armor in the temple of their gods and fastened his head in the temple of Dagon.

When the people of Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul, all their valiant men retrieved the bodies of Saul and his sons, brought them to Jabesh, buried their bones under an oak tree, and fasted for seven days. Saul died because he was unfaithful to the Lord, disobeyed His word, and consulted a medium for guidance instead of seeking the Lord. Therefore, the Lord put him to death and gave the kingdom to David, son of Jesse.

All Israel gathered to David at Hebron, acknowledging that he was their own flesh and blood. They recalled that even when Saul was king, David led Israel in battle, and the Lord had said David would shepherd His people and become their ruler. So, the elders of Israel came to David at Hebron, and he made a covenant with them before the Lord. They anointed David as king over Israel, as the Lord had promised through Samuel.

David and all Israel then went to Jerusalem, also known as Jebus, where the Jebusites lived. The Jebusites taunted David, saying he could not enter their city. However, David captured the fortress of Zion, which became the City of David. David declared that whoever led the attack on the Jebusites would become the chief and commander. Joab, son of Zeruiah, led the charge and became the chief. David took up residence in the fortress, and it was called the City of David. He built up the city around it, from the supporting terraces to the surrounding area, while Joab restored the rest of the city. David became more and more powerful because the Lord Almighty was with him.

These were the leaders of David's mighty warriors, who supported him in his kingdom and helped him become king, as the Lord had promised concerning Israel. The chief of David's mighty warriors was Jashobeam, a Hachmonite, who used his spear to kill 300 men in one encounter. Next was Eleazar, son of Dodo.Eleazar, the Ahohite, was one of David's three mighty warriors. He stood with David at Pasdammim when the Philistines gathered for battle. The field was full of barley, and the Israelites fled from the Philistines. But Eleazar and David took a stand in the middle of the field, defended it, and defeated the Philistines. The Lord granted them a great victory.

Three of the thirty chief warriors went down to David at the cave of Adullam while the Philistine army was camped in the Valley of Rephaim. At that time, David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem. David expressed a longing for water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem. The three warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well, and brought it back to David. However, David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord, saying, "God forbid that I should drink this water. It represents the blood of these men who risked their lives to bring it to me." So, he did not drink it. These were the exploits of the three mighty warriors.

Abishai, the brother of Joab, was the chief of the three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the three. He was doubly honored above the three and became their commander, even though he was not included among them.

Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was a valiant fighter from Kabzeel who performed great exploits. He struck down Moab's two mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion. Additionally, he struck down an Egyptian who was five cubits tall. Although the Egyptian had a spear like a weaver's rod, Benaiah went against him with a club, snatched the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear. These were the exploits of Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, who was as famous as the three mighty warriors. He was held in greater honor than any of the thirty, but he was not included among the three. David put him in charge of his bodyguard.

Other valiant warriors included Asahel, the brother of Joab; Elhanan, son of Dodo from Bethlehem; Shammoth the Harorite; Helez the Pelonite; Ira, son of Ikkesh from Tekoa; Abiezer from Anathoth; Sibbecai the Hushathite; Ilai the Ahohite; Maharai the Netophathite; Heled, son of Baanah the Netophathite; Ithai, son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin; Benaiah the Pirathonite; Hurai from the ravines of Gaash; Abiel the Arbathite; Azmaveth the Baharumite; Eliahba the Shaalbonite; the sons of Hashem the Gizonite; Jonathan, son of Shage the Hararite; Ahiam, son of Sacar the Hararite; Eliphal, son of Ur; Hepher the Mecherathite; Ahijah the Pelonite; Hezro the Carmelite; Naarai, son of Ezbai; Joel, the brother of Nathan; Mibhar, son of Hagri; Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai the Berothite, the armor-bearer of Joab, son of Zeruiah; Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite; Uriah the Hittite; Zabad, son of Ahlai; Adina, son of Shiza the Reubenite, a leader of the Reubenites, and thirty with him; Hanan, son of Maachah; Joshaphat the Mithnite; Uzzia the Ashterathite; Shama and Jehiel, the sons of Hothan the Aroerite; Jediael, son of Shimri, and his brother Joha the Tizite; Eliel the Mahavite; Jeribai and Joshaviah, the sons of Elnaam; Ithmah the Moabite; Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaite.

These are the men who came to David at Ziklag while he was hiding from Saul, son of Kish. They were among the warriors who helped him in battle. They were armed with bows and could use both their right and left hands to sling stones and shoot arrows. They were relatives of Saul from the tribe of Benjamin. The chief was Ahiezer, followed by Joash, the sons of Shemaah the Gibeathite; Jeziel and Pelet, the sons of Azmaveth; Beracah; Jehu the Anathothite; Ismaiah the Gibeonite, a mighty warrior among the thirty and a leader over the thirty; Jeremiah; Jahaziel; Johanan; Josabad the Gederathite; Eluzai; Jerimoth; Bealiah; Shemariah; Shephatiah the Haruphite; Elkanah; Jesiah; Azarel; Joezer; Jashobeam the Korahite; and Joelah and Zebadiah, the sons of Jeroham from Gedor.

From the tribe of Gad, some brave warriors joined David at his stronghold in the wilderness. They were experienced soldiers, skilled with shield and spear, whose faces were as fierce as lions and as swift as gazelles on the mountains. Ezer was the chief, followed by Obadiah, Eliab, Mishmannah, Jeremiah, Attai, Eliel, Johanan, Elzabad, Jeremiah, and Machbannai. These Gadites were army commanders; the least of them was a match for a hundred, and the greatest for a thousand. They crossed the Jordan in the first month when it was overflowing its banks and chased away all who lived in the valleys, both to the east and to the west.

Some men from Benjamin and Judah also came to David at his stronghold. David went out to meet them and said, "If you have come to me in peace to help me, I am ready to welcome you. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies, even though I have done no wrong, may the God of our ancestors see it and judge you." Then the Spirit came upon Amasai, chief of the Thirty, and he said, "We are yours, David! We are with you, son of Jesse! Peace, peace to you, and peace to those who help you, for your God helps you." So, David received them and made them leaders of his raiding bands.

Some men from the tribe of Manasseh defected to David when he went with the Philistines to fight against Saul. However, they did not help the Philistines because the Philistine rulers sent David away, fearing he would turn against them and rejoin Saul. When David went to Ziklag, these men of Manasseh joined him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zilthai, leaders of thousands in Manasseh. They helped David against raiding bands, for they were all brave warriors, and they became commanders in his army. Day after day, men came to help David until he had a great army, like the army of God.

These are the numbers of the men armed for battle who came to David at Hebron to turn Saul's kingdom over to him, as the Lord had said. From Judah, carrying shield and spear, there were 6,800 armed for battle. From Simeon, warriors ready for battle, 7,100. From Levi, 4,600, including Jehoiada, leader of the family of Aaron, with 3,700 men, and Zadok, a brave young warrior, with 22 officers from his family. From Benjamin, Saul's tribe, 3,000, most of whom had remained loyal to Saul's house until then. From Ephraim, brave warriors, famous in their own clans, 20,800. From half the tribe of Manasseh, designated by name to come and make David king, 18,000. From Issachar, men who understood the times and knew what Israel should do, 200 chiefs, with all their relatives under their command. From Zebulun, experienced soldiers prepared for battle with every type of weapon, 50,000, who were loyal to David. From Naphtali, 1,000 officers, together with 37,000 men carrying shields and spears. From Dan, ready for battle, 28,600. From Asher, experienced soldiers prepared for battle, 40,000. And from the east side of the Jordan, from Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, armed with every type of weapon, 120,000.

All these warriors, armed for battle, came to Hebron fully determined to make David king over all Israel. All the rest of the Israelites were also of one mind to make David king. They spent three days there with David, eating and drinking, for their families had supplied provisions for them. Also, their neighbors from as far as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali brought food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen. There were plentiful supplies of flour, fig cakes, raisin cakes, wine, olive oil, cattle, and sheep, for there was joy in Israel.

David consulted with the commanders of thousands and hundreds and with every leader. He then said to the whole assembly of Israel, "If it seems good to you and if it is the will of the Lord our God, let us send word far and wide to the rest of our people throughout the territories of Israel, and also to the priests and Levites who are with them in their towns and pasturelands, to come and join us. Let us bring the ark of our God back to us, for we did not inquire of it during the reign of Saul." The whole assembly agreed to do this because it seemed right to all the people. So, David assembled all Israel.David and all of Israel went to Baalah (Kirjathjearim) in Judah to bring the Ark of God, which is called by the name of the Lord who dwells between the cherubim. They transported the Ark on a new cart from Abinadab's house, with Uzza and Ahio guiding it. David and all of Israel celebrated with all their might before God, with songs, harps, lyres, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.

When they reached the threshing floor of Chidon, the oxen stumbled, and Uzza reached out to steady the Ark. The Lord's anger burned against Uzza for his irreverence, and he struck him down, and Uzza died there before God. David was upset because the Lord's wrath had broken out against Uzza, and he named that place Perez Uzza. David was also afraid of God that day and wondered how he could bring the Ark to himself. So, he did not take the Ark to the City of David but instead took it to the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite. The Ark stayed there for three months, and the Lord blessed Obed-Edom's household and everything he had.

King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar logs, carpenters, and stonemasons to build a palace for him. David realized that the Lord had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel. David took more wives in Jerusalem and had more sons and daughters. The names of his children born in Jerusalem were Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet, Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphelet.

When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over all Israel, they went up in full force to search for him. David heard about it and went out to meet them. The Philistines had come and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim. David inquired of God, asking if he should attack the Philistines and if God would deliver them into his hands. The Lord answered, "Go, I will deliver them into your hands." So, David and his men went to Baal Perazim, where he defeated them. David said, "God has broken through my enemies by my hand, like a breakthrough of water." So, they named that place Baal Perazim. The Philistines abandoned their gods there, and David gave orders to burn them in the fire.

Once again, the Philistines raided the valley. David inquired of God again, and God told him not to go straight up but to circle around and attack them in front of the balsam trees. God said, "When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, move out to battle, because that will mean God has gone out in front of you to strike the Philistine army." David did as God commanded, and they struck down the Philistine army all the way from Gibeon to Gezer. David's fame spread throughout every land, and the Lord made all the nations fear him.

David built houses for himself in the City of David and prepared a place for the Ark of God, pitching a tent for it. He said that only the Levites should carry the Ark of God because the Lord had chosen them to carry it and to minister before Him forever. David assembled all Israel in Jerusalem to bring up the Ark of the Lord to the place he had prepared for it. He gathered the descendants of Aaron and the Levites: from the Kohathites, Uriel the chief and 120 relatives; from the Merarites, Asaiah the chief and 220 relatives; from the Gershomites, Joel the chief and 130 relatives; from the Elizaphanites, Shemaiah the chief and 200 relatives; from the Hebronites, Eliel the chief and 80 relatives; and from the Uzzielites, Amminadab the chief and 112 relatives.

David summoned Zadok and Abiathar the priests and the Levites: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab. He said to them, "You are the heads of the Levitical families; you and your fellow Levites are to consecrate yourselves and bring up the Ark of the Lord, the God of Israel, to the place I have prepared for it. Because you did not carry it the first time, the Lord our God broke out in anger against us. We did not inquire of Him about how to do it in the prescribed way." So, the priests and Levites consecrated themselves to bring up the Ark of the Lord, the God of Israel. The Levites carried the Ark of God with poles on their shoulders, as Moses had commanded in accordance with the word of the Lord.

David told the leaders of the Levites to appoint their fellow Levites as musicians to make a joyful sound with musical instruments: lyres, harps, and cymbals. So, the Levites appointed Heman son of Joel; from his relatives, Asaph son of Berechiah; and from their relatives the Merarites, Ethan son of Kushaiah; and with them their relatives of the second rank: Zechariah, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Elipheleh, Mikneiah, Obed-Edom, and Jeiel, the gatekeepers.

The musicians Heman, Asaph, and Ethan were to sound the bronze cymbals; Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah were to play the lyres according to Alamoth; and Mattithiah, Elipheleh, Mikneiah, Obed-Edom, Jeiel, and Azaziah were to play the harps, directing according to Sheminith. Kenaniah, the head Levite, was in charge of the singing; that was his responsibility because he was skillful at it. Berechiah and Elkanah were to be doorkeepers for the Ark. Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer, the priests, were to blow trumpets before the Ark of God. Obed-Edom and Jehiah were also to be doorkeepers for the Ark.

So, David and the elders of Israel and the commanders of units of a thousand went to bring up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from the house of Obed-Edom, with rejoicing. Because God had helped the Levites who were carrying the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, seven bulls and seven rams were sacrificed. David was wearing a robe of fine linen, as were all the Levites who were carrying the Ark, and as were the musicians and Kenaniah, who was in charge of the singing of the choirs. David also wore a linen ephod. So, all Israel brought up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord with shouts, the sound of rams' horns, trumpets, and cymbals, and the playing of lyres and harps.

As the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord was entering the City of David, Michal daughter of Saul watched from a window. When she saw King David dancing and celebrating, she despised him in her heart. They brought the Ark of God and set it inside the tent that David had pitched for it, and they presented burnt offerings and fellowship offerings before God. After David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord. Then he gave a loaf of bread, a cake of dates, and a cake of raisins to each Israelite man and woman.

David appointed some of the Levites to minister before the Ark of the Lord, to extol, thank, and praise the Lord, the God of Israel. Asaph was the chief, and next to him in rank were Zechariah, then Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-Edom, and Jeiel. They were to play the lyres and harps, Asaph was to sound the cymbals, and Benaiah and Jahaziel the priests were to blow the trumpets regularly before the Ark of the Covenant of God. 

That day, David first appointed Asaph and his associates to give praise to the Lord in this manner:

"Give praise to the Lord, proclaim his name; make known among the nations what he has done. Sing to him, sing praise to him; tell of all his wonderful acts. Glory in his holy name; let the hearts of those who seek the Lord rejoice. Look to the Lord and his strength; seek his face always. Remember the wonders he has done, his miracles, and the judgments he pronounced, you his servants, the descendants of Israel, his chosen ones, the children of Jacob. He is the Lord our God; his judgments are in all the earth. He remembers his covenant forever, the promise he made, for a thousand generations, the covenant he made with Abraham, the oath he swore to Isaac. He confirmed it to Jacob as a decree, to Israel as an everlasting covenant: 'To you I will give the land of Canaan as the portion you will inherit.' When they were but few in number, few indeed, and strangers in it, they wandered from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another. He allowed no one to oppress them; for their sake, he rebuked kings: 'Do not touch my anointed ones; do my prophets no harm.' Sing to the Lord, all the earth; proclaim his salvation day after day. Declare his glory among the nations, his marvelous deeds among all peoples. For great is the Lord and most worthy of praise; he is to be feared above all gods."All the gods of other nations are just idols, but the LORD created the heavens. Glory and honor are in His presence; strength and joy are in His place. Give to the LORD, families of nations, give to the LORD glory and strength. Give to the LORD the glory due His name; bring an offering and come before Him. Worship the LORD in the splendor of His holiness. Tremble before Him, all the earth! The world is firmly established; it cannot be moved. Let the heavens rejoice, let the earth be glad; let them say among the nations, "The LORD reigns!" Let the sea resound, and everything in it; let the fields be jubilant, and everything in them. Then the trees of the forest will sing for joy before the LORD, for He comes to judge the earth. Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His love endures forever. Cry out, "Save us, God of our salvation; gather us and deliver us from the nations, that we may give thanks to Your holy name and glory in Your praise." Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting. And all the people said, "Amen," and praised the LORD.

David left Asaph and his associates before the Ark of the Covenant of the LORD to minister there regularly, according to each day's requirements. He also left Obed-Edom and his sixty-eight associates to serve there. Obed-Edom son of Jeduthun and Hosah were gatekeepers. David left Zadok the priest and his fellow priests before the tabernacle of the LORD at the high place in Gibeon to present burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar of burnt offering regularly, morning and evening, in accordance with everything written in the Law of the LORD, which He had given Israel. With them were Heman and Jeduthun and the rest of those chosen and designated by name to give thanks to the LORD, "for His love endures forever." Heman and Jeduthun were responsible for the sounding of the trumpets and cymbals and for the playing of the other instruments for sacred song. The sons of Jeduthun were stationed at the gate.

Then all the people left, each for their own home, and David returned home to bless his household.

After this, David settled in his palace and said to Nathan the prophet, "Here I am, living in a house of cedar, while the Ark of the Covenant of the LORD is under a tent." Nathan replied to David, "Whatever you have in mind, do it, for God is with you."

But that night the word of God came to Nathan, saying, "Go and tell my servant David, 'This is what the LORD says: You are not the one to build me a house to dwell in. I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought Israel up out of Egypt to this day. I have moved from one tent site to another, from one dwelling place to another. Wherever I have moved with all the Israelites, did I ever say to any of their leaders whom I commanded to shepherd my people, "Why have you not built me a house of cedar?"'

"Now then, tell my servant David, 'This is what the LORD Almighty says: I took you from the pasture, from tending the flock, and appointed you ruler over my people Israel. I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make your name like the names of the greatest men on earth. And I will provide a place for my people Israel and will plant them so that they can have a home of their own and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people will not oppress them anymore, as they did at the beginning and have done ever since the time I appointed leaders over my people Israel. I will also subdue all your enemies.

"'I declare to you that the LORD will build a house for you: When your days are over and you go to be with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring to succeed you, one of your own sons, and I will establish his kingdom. He is the one who will build a house for me, and I will establish his throne forever. I will be his father, and he will be my son. I will never take my love away from him, as I took it away from your predecessor. I will set him over my house and my kingdom forever; his throne will be established forever.'"

Nathan reported to David all the words of this entire revelation.

Then King David went in and sat before the LORD, and he said: "Who am I, LORD God, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far? And as if this were not enough in your sight, my God, you have spoken about the future of the house of your servant. You, LORD God, have looked on me as though I were the most exalted of men.

"What more can David say to you for honoring your servant? For you know your servant, LORD. For the sake of your servant and according to your will, you have done this great thing and made known all these great promises.

"There is no one like you, LORD, and there is no God but you, as we have heard with our own ears. And who is like your people Israel—the one nation on earth whose God went out to redeem a people for himself, and to make a name for yourself, and to perform great and awesome wonders by driving out nations from before your people, whom you redeemed from Egypt? You made your people Israel your very own forever, and you, LORD, have become their God.

"And now, LORD, let the promise you have made concerning your servant and his house be established forever. Do as you promised, so that it will be established and that your name will be great forever. Then people will say, 'The LORD Almighty, the God of Israel, is Israel's God!' And the house of your servant David will be established before you.

"You, my God, have revealed to your servant that you will build a house for him. So your servant has found courage to pray to you. You, LORD, are God! You have promised these good things to your servant. Now you have been pleased to bless the house of your servant, that it may continue forever in your sight; for you, LORD, have blessed it, and it will be blessed forever."

In the course of time, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and he took Gath and its surrounding villages from the control of the Philistines. David also defeated the Moabites, and they became subject to him and brought him tribute. Moreover, David defeated Hadadezer king of Zobah in the vicinity of Hamath, when he went to set up his monument at the Euphrates River. David captured a thousand of his chariots, seven thousand charioteers, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He hamstrung all but a hundred of the chariot horses.

When the Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand of them. He put garrisons in the Aramean kingdom of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to him and brought him tribute. The LORD gave David victory wherever he went.

David took the gold shields carried by the officers of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem. From Tebah and Kun, towns that belonged to Hadadezer, David took a great quantity of bronze, which Solomon used to make the bronze Sea, the pillars, and various bronze articles.

When Tou king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer king of Zobah, he sent his son Hadoram to King David to greet him and congratulate him on his victory in battle over Hadadezer, who had been at war with Tou. Hadoram brought all kinds of articles of gold, silver, and bronze. King David dedicated these articles to the LORD, as he had done with the silver and gold he had taken from all these nations: Edom and Moab, the Ammonites and the Philistines, and Amalek.

Abishai son of Zeruiah struck down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt. He put garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became subject to David. The LORD gave David victory wherever he went.

David reigned over all Israel, doing what was just and right for all his people. Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder; Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelek son of Abiathar were priests; Shavsha was secretary; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites; and David's sons were chief officials at the king's side.

In the course of time, Nahash king of the Ammonites died, and his son succeeded him as king. David thought, "I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, because his father showed kindness to me." So David sent a delegation to express his sympathy to Hanun concerning his father.

When David's envoys came to Hanun in the land of the Ammonites to express sympathy to him, the Ammonite commanders said to Hanun, "Do you think David is honoring your father by sending envoys to you to express sympathy? Haven't his envoys come to you to explore and spy out the country and overthrow it?" So Hanun seized David's envoys, shaved them, cut off their garments at the buttocks, and sent them away.

When someone came and told David about the men, he sent messengers to meet them, for they were greatly humiliated. The king said, "Stay at Jericho till your beards have grown, and then come back."

When the Ammonites realized that they had become obnoxious to David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent a thousand talents of silver to hire chariots and horsemen from Aram Naharaim, Aram Maakah, and Zobah.The Ammonites hired 32,000 chariots and the king of Maachah with his people. They camped near Medeba, and the Ammonites gathered from their cities to prepare for battle. When David heard about this, he sent Joab and his elite troops. The Ammonites positioned themselves at the city gate, while the allied kings were in the field.

Seeing the battle lines against him, Joab chose the best troops of Israel to face the Syrians, while the rest, led by his brother Abishai, faced the Ammonites. Joab told Abishai, "If the Syrians are too strong for me, help me; if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I'll help you. Be courageous and fight for our people and the cities of our God. Let the LORD do what is good in His sight."

Joab and his troops advanced against the Syrians, who fled. When the Ammonites saw the Syrians retreat, they also fled before Abishai and entered the city. Joab then returned to Jerusalem.

The Syrians regrouped and brought reinforcements from beyond the river, led by Shophach, the commander of Hadadezer's army. David was informed and gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and set up battle lines against the Syrians. The Syrians fought but fled before Israel. David killed 7,000 charioteers and 40,000 foot soldiers, including Shophach. The remaining servants of Hadadezer made peace with David and became his subjects, and the Syrians no longer helped the Ammonites.

The following spring, Joab led the army to ravage the Ammonite territory and besieged Rabbah, while David stayed in Jerusalem. Joab captured Rabbah and took the crown from their king, which weighed a talent of gold and was adorned with precious stones. David placed it on his head and took a large amount of plunder from the city. He also brought out the people and put them to work with saws, iron tools, and axes. David did this to all the Ammonite cities and then returned to Jerusalem with his people.

Later, there was another war with the Philistines at Gezer, where Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Sippai, a descendant of the giants, subduing them. Another battle with the Philistines saw Elhanan, son of Jair, kill Lahmi, the brother of Goliath, whose spear was as large as a weaver's beam. Yet another battle at Gath involved a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, who defied Israel but was killed by Jonathan, son of Shimea, David's brother. These giants were defeated by David and his servants.

Satan incited David to take a census of Israel. David instructed Joab and the leaders to count the people from Beersheba to Dan. Joab questioned the need, but David insisted. Joab reported the count: 1.1 million men in Israel and 470,000 in Judah, excluding Levi and Benjamin, as Joab found the king's command detestable. God was displeased and struck Israel. David confessed his sin and asked for forgiveness.

God sent the prophet Gad to offer David three choices: three years of famine, three months of defeat by enemies, or three days of plague. David chose to fall into God's hands, trusting His mercy. The LORD sent a plague, killing 70,000 Israelites. As an angel was about to destroy Jerusalem, God relented and stopped the angel at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite. David and the elders, in sackcloth, pleaded with God, asking for the punishment to fall on David and his family instead of the people.

God instructed Gad to tell David to build an altar on Ornan's threshing floor. David bought the site for 600 shekels of gold and built an altar, offering sacrifices. The LORD answered with fire from heaven, and the angel sheathed his sword. David continued to offer sacrifices there, as he was afraid to go to the tabernacle at Gibeon due to the angel's sword.

David declared the site as the house of the LORD and the altar for Israel. He gathered materials and workers to build the temple, preparing iron, bronze, and cedar in abundance. David charged his son Solomon to build the temple, explaining that he couldn't do it himself due to the bloodshed in his reign. He assured Solomon that God had chosen him to build the temple and that he would have peace and rest from his enemies.David continued, "My son Solomon will be a man of peace, and I will give him rest from all his enemies. His name will be Solomon, and I will grant peace and quiet to Israel during his reign. He will build a house for my name, and he will be my son, and I will be his father. I will establish his kingdom over Israel forever. Now, my son, may the LORD be with you and help you build the house of the LORD your God, as He has promised. May the LORD give you wisdom and understanding to lead Israel and to follow His laws. You will prosper if you carefully obey the statutes and judgments the LORD gave Moses for Israel. Be strong and courageous; do not be afraid or discouraged.

I have worked hard to prepare for the house of the LORD, gathering 100,000 talents of gold, 1,000,000 talents of silver, and an abundance of bronze and iron. I have also collected timber and stone, and you can add to these materials. You have many skilled workers, including stonecutters, carpenters, and craftsmen of all kinds. The gold, silver, bronze, and iron are beyond measure. Get to work, and may the LORD be with you."

David also instructed all the leaders of Israel to help Solomon, saying, "The LORD your God is with you and has given you peace on every side. He has handed the inhabitants of the land over to me, and the land is subdued before the LORD and His people. Now, dedicate yourselves to seeking the LORD your God. Get up and build the sanctuary of the LORD God, so that the ark of the covenant and the holy vessels of God can be brought into the house built for the name of the LORD."

When David was old and nearing the end of his life, he made Solomon king over Israel. He gathered all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and Levites. The Levites, aged thirty and above, were counted, totaling 38,000 men. Of these, 24,000 were assigned to oversee the work of the house of the LORD, 6,000 were officers and judges, 4,000 were gatekeepers, and 4,000 praised the LORD with musical instruments that David had made for worship.

David organized the Levites into divisions based on their family lines: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. The descendants of Gershon included Laadan and Shimei. Laadan's sons were Jehiel, Zetham, and Joel. Shimei's sons were Shelomith, Haziel, and Haran. The descendants of Kohath included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Amram's sons were Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his descendants were set apart to handle the most sacred duties, including offering incense and blessings in the name of the LORD forever. Moses' sons were Gershom and Eliezer. Gershom's son was Shebuel, and Eliezer's son was Rehabiah. Izhar's son was Shelomith. Hebron's sons were Jeriah, Amariah, Jahaziel, and Jekameam. Uzziel's sons were Micah and Jesiah. Merari's sons were Mahli and Mushi. Mahli's sons were Eleazar and Kish. Eleazar had no sons, only daughters, who married their cousins, the sons of Kish. Mushi's sons were Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth.

These were the descendants of Levi, listed by their families, who served in the house of the LORD from the age of twenty and above. David said, "The LORD God of Israel has given rest to His people, and they will dwell in Jerusalem forever. The Levites will no longer need to carry the tabernacle or its vessels for service." By David's last instructions, the Levites were counted from the age of twenty and above. Their duties included assisting the descendants of Aaron in the service of the house of the LORD, in the courts and rooms, and in the purification of all holy things. They were responsible for the bread of the Presence, the fine flour for grain offerings, the unleavened wafers, the baking, the mixing, and all measurements and sizes. They were to stand every morning to thank and praise the LORD, and likewise in the evening. They were to offer all burnt sacrifices to the LORD on the Sabbaths, new moons, and appointed festivals, according to the number required by the regulations. They were to serve continually before the LORD and take care of the tabernacle and the holy place, and assist their fellow descendants of Aaron in the service of the house of the LORD.

David also organized the descendants of Aaron into divisions. Aaron's sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar. Nadab and Abihu died before their father and had no children, so Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests. David, along with Zadok from Eleazar's descendants and Ahimelech from Ithamar's descendants, divided them according to their appointed duties. There were more leaders among Eleazar's descendants than Ithamar's, so they were divided accordingly: sixteen leaders from Eleazar's family and eight from Ithamar's family. They were assigned duties by lot, with both families having equal representation in the service of the sanctuary and the house of God. Shemaiah, a Levite scribe, recorded their names in the presence of the king, the leaders, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and the heads of the families of the priests and Levites. The first lot fell to Jehoiarib, the second to Jedaiah, the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim, the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin, the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah, the ninth to Jeshua, the tenth to Shecaniah, the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim, the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Jeshebeab, the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer, the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Happizzez, the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezkel, the twenty-first to Jachin, the twenty-second to Gamul, the twenty-third to Delaiah, and the twenty-fourth to Maaziah. These divisions served in the house of the LORD according to the regulations established by their ancestor Aaron, as commanded by the LORD God of Israel.

The remaining descendants of Levi were also organized: Shubael from Amram's descendants, Jehdeiah from Shubael's descendants, Isshiah from Rehabiah's descendants, Shelomith from Izhar's descendants, Jahath from Shelomith's descendants, Jeriah from Hebron's descendants, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth. Micah from Uzziel's descendants, Shamir from Micah's descendants, Zechariah from Isshiah's descendants, Mahli and Mushi from Merari's descendants, and Jaaziah's descendants: Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri. Eleazar, a descendant of Mahli, had no sons, only daughters, who married their cousins, the sons of Kish. Jerahmeel was the son of Kish. Mushi's descendants were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the Levites listed by their families, who served in the house of the LORD.

David and the leaders of the army set apart some of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun for the ministry of prophesying with harps, lyres, and cymbals. The list of those who performed this service included the sons of Asaph: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah, under the direction of Asaph, who prophesied under the king's supervision. The sons of Jeduthun: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, six in all, under the direction of their father Jeduthun, who prophesied with the harp, giving thanks and praise to the LORD. The sons of Heman: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-Ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth. All these were the sons of Heman, the king's seer, who were given to him through the promises of God to exalt him. God gave Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.All these musicians served under their fathers' direction for the music in the house of the LORD, using cymbals, harps, and lyres, as ordered by the king. There were 288 skilled musicians in total. They cast lots for their duties, regardless of age or skill level. The first lot fell to Joseph, the second to Gedaliah, the third to Zaccur, and so on, each group consisting of twelve members.

Regarding the gatekeepers: Meshelemiah, a Korhite, had seven sons: Zechariah, Jediael, Zebadiah, Jathniel, Elam, Jehohanan, and Elioenai. Obed-Edom had eight sons: Shemaiah, Jehozabad, Joah, Sacar, Nethaneel, Ammiel, Issachar, and Peulthai, all blessed by God. Shemaiah's sons were Othni, Rephael, Obed, Elzabad, Elihu, and Semachiah, all strong men. In total, Obed-Edom's family had 62 capable men. Meshelemiah's family had 18 strong men. Hosah, from the Merari clan, had four sons: Simri, Hilkiah, Tebaliah, and Zechariah, totaling 13 men.

These gatekeepers were assigned to their posts by lot, with equal representation for each family. The east gate was assigned to Shelemiah, the north gate to Zechariah, the south gate to Obed-Edom, and the west gate to Shuppim and Hosah. Each gate had a specific number of guards assigned daily.

Ahijah was in charge of the treasures of the house of God. The Gershonite clan, led by Jehieli, managed the treasures. Shebuel, a descendant of Moses, was the chief treasurer. Other treasurers included Rehabiah, Jeshaiah, Joram, Zichri, and Shelomith. They managed the dedicated treasures from battles and offerings made by Samuel, Saul, Abner, Joab, and others.

The Izharites, led by Chenaniah, were responsible for external affairs and served as officers and judges. The Hebronites, led by Hashabiah, managed the LORD's work and the king's service west of the Jordan. Jerijah led the Hebronites in Gilead, where they found 2,700 capable men who were appointed as leaders over the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh.

David organized the Israelites into divisions, each serving the king monthly. Each division had 24,000 men. The first division was led by Jashobeam, the second by Dodai, the third by Benaiah, the fourth by Asahel, the fifth by Shamhuth, the sixth by Ira, the seventh by Helez, the eighth by Sibbecai, the ninth by Abiezer, the tenth by Maharai, the eleventh by Benaiah, and the twelfth by Heldai.

David also appointed leaders over the tribes of Israel: Eliezer for Reuben, Shephatiah for Simeon, Hashabiah for Levi, Zadok for Aaron, Elihu for Judah, Omri for Issachar, Ishmaiah for Zebulun, Jerimoth for Naphtali, Hoshea for Ephraim, Joel for the half-tribe of Manasseh, Iddo for the other half-tribe in Gilead, Jaasiel for Benjamin, and Azareel for Dan.

David did not count those under twenty years old, as the LORD promised to increase Israel's population. Joab began a census but did not finish due to God's wrath, and the final count was not recorded in King David's chronicles. Azmaveth was in charge of the king's treasuries.Jehonathan, son of Uzziah, was in charge of the storehouses in the fields, cities, villages, and castles. Ezri, son of Chelub, oversaw the workers in the fields. Shimei the Ramathite managed the vineyards, and Zabdi the Shiphmite handled the wine cellars. Baalhanan the Gederite was responsible for the olive and sycamore trees in the lowlands, while Joash managed the oil cellars. Shitrai the Sharonite took care of the herds in Sharon, and Shaphat, son of Adlai, managed the herds in the valleys. Obil the Ishmaelite was in charge of the camels, Jehdeiah the Meronothite managed the donkeys, and Jaziz the Hagerite oversaw the flocks. These were the officials in charge of King David's property.

Jonathan, David's uncle, was a counselor, a wise man, and a scribe. Jehiel, son of Hachmoni, was with the king's sons. Ahithophel was the king's counselor, and Hushai the Archite was the king's companion. After Ahithophel, Jehoiada, son of Benaiah, and Abiathar took over. Joab was the general of the king's army.

David gathered all the leaders of Israel, including the tribal princes, captains of the divisions serving the king, captains over thousands and hundreds, stewards of the king's property, officers, mighty men, and valiant men, in Jerusalem. David stood up and addressed them, expressing his desire to build a resting place for the Ark of the Covenant and a footstool for God. However, God told him he could not build it because he was a man of war and had shed blood. Instead, God chose David's son Solomon to build the house and its courts, promising to establish Solomon's kingdom if he followed God's commandments.

David urged Solomon and the people to seek and keep God's commandments to inherit the land and pass it on to future generations. He advised Solomon to serve God with a perfect heart and willing mind, as God understands all thoughts and intentions. If Solomon sought God, he would find Him, but if he forsook God, he would be cast off forever. David encouraged Solomon to be strong and build the sanctuary, assuring him that God would be with him until the work was completed.

David provided Solomon with detailed plans for the temple, including the porch, houses, treasuries, upper chambers, inner parlors, and the mercy seat. He also gave instructions for the priests, Levites, and all the vessels of service. David provided gold and silver by weight for various items, including candlesticks, lamps, tables, flesh hooks, bowls, cups, basins, and the altar of incense. He explained that God had given him these plans in writing.

David encouraged Solomon to be strong and courageous, assuring him that God would not fail or forsake him until the work was finished. He reminded Solomon that the priests, Levites, skilled workers, and all the people would support him.

David then addressed the congregation, acknowledging that Solomon was young and the work was great because the palace was for God, not man. He had prepared materials for the temple, including gold, silver, brass, iron, wood, onyx stones, and other precious stones. David also gave from his own wealth, contributing gold and silver for the temple. He asked who else was willing to consecrate their service to God.

The leaders of Israel, including the tribal princes, captains, and rulers, willingly offered gold, silver, brass, iron, and precious stones for the temple. The people rejoiced because they offered willingly with perfect hearts, and David also rejoiced.

David blessed God before the congregation, praising His greatness, power, glory, victory, and majesty. He acknowledged that everything comes from God and that they were only giving back what was already His. David prayed for God to keep the people's hearts devoted to Him and to give Solomon a perfect heart to keep God's commandments and build the temple.

David instructed the congregation to bless God, and they did so, bowing their heads and worshipping the Lord and the king. The next day, they offered numerous sacrifices and burnt offerings to God, celebrating with great joy. They also confirmed Solomon as king.Solomon was anointed as king for the second time, and Zadok was appointed as the priest. Solomon then took his place on the throne of the Lord, succeeding his father David, and prospered as all of Israel obeyed him. All the princes, mighty men, and David's sons pledged their allegiance to Solomon. The Lord greatly exalted Solomon, giving him a royal majesty unmatched by any previous king in Israel.

David, son of Jesse, reigned over Israel for forty years—seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem. He died at an old age, full of days, riches, and honor, and Solomon succeeded him as king. The acts of King David, from beginning to end, are recorded in the books of Samuel the seer, Nathan the prophet, and Gad the seer, detailing his reign, his might, and the events that affected him and Israel.

Solomon, strengthened in his kingdom, was blessed by the Lord his God. He spoke to all of Israel's leaders, including captains, judges, and governors. Solomon and the congregation went to the high place at Gibeon, where the tabernacle of God, made by Moses, was located. David had brought the Ark of God to Jerusalem, where he had prepared a tent for it. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on the bronze altar before the tabernacle.

That night, God appeared to Solomon and asked what he desired. Solomon requested wisdom and knowledge to lead the vast people of Israel. God granted Solomon wisdom and knowledge, and also promised him riches, wealth, and honor greater than any king before or after him.

Solomon returned to Jerusalem and reigned over Israel. He amassed chariots and horsemen, making silver and gold as common as stones in Jerusalem, and cedar trees as plentiful as sycamore trees. Solomon imported horses and chariots from Egypt, trading them with the kings of the Hittites and Syria.

Solomon decided to build a temple for the Lord and a palace for his kingdom. He assigned 70,000 men to carry burdens, 80,000 to quarry stone, and 3,600 to oversee the work. Solomon requested cedar, fir, and algum trees from Huram, king of Tyre, who had previously supplied materials to David. Solomon promised to provide wheat, barley, wine, and oil for Huram's servants in return.

Huram praised the Lord for giving David a wise son to build the temple and the kingdom. He sent a skilled craftsman, Huram-Abi, to work with Solomon's craftsmen. Solomon provided the necessary materials and began building the temple on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to David. The construction started in the second month of the fourth year of Solomon's reign.

The temple's dimensions were sixty cubits long and twenty cubits wide. The porch in front of the temple was twenty cubits wide and 120 cubits high, overlaid with pure gold. The main hall was paneled with fir and overlaid with fine gold, decorated with palm trees and chains. Precious stones adorned the temple, and the gold used was from Parvaim. The beams, posts, walls, and doors were overlaid with gold, and cherubim were carved on the walls.

In the most holy place, Solomon made two cherubim of image work, overlaid with gold. Their wings spanned twenty cubits, touching the walls and each other. The veil of the temple was made of blue, purple, crimson, and fine linen, with cherubim embroidered on it. Solomon also made two pillars, each thirty-five cubits high, with five-cubit capitals on top, adorned with chains.Solomon decorated the temple pillars with red pomegranates on chains. He set up two pillars at the temple entrance, naming the one on the right Jachin and the one on the left Boaz. He made a bronze altar, 20 cubits long and wide, and 10 cubits high. He also created a large bronze basin, 10 cubits in diameter and 5 cubits high, decorated with oxen figures. This basin, supported by twelve oxen facing different directions, held 3,000 baths of water.

Solomon made ten smaller basins, placing five on each side of the temple for washing offerings, while the large basin was for the priests. He crafted ten gold lampstands, placing five on each side of the temple, and ten tables, also five on each side. He made 100 gold basins. The priests' courtyard and the great courtyard had doors overlaid with bronze, and the large basin was positioned on the southeast side.

Huram made various items for the temple, including pots, shovels, and basins, all from bright brass. These were cast in the Jordan plain between Succoth and Zeredathah. Solomon made many vessels, including a golden altar, tables for the showbread, gold lampstands, and various gold utensils. The temple doors, including those to the most holy place, were also covered in gold.

Once all the work was completed, Solomon brought in the items his father David had dedicated, placing the silver, gold, and other instruments in the temple treasury. Solomon then gathered Israel's elders and tribal leaders in Jerusalem to bring the Ark of the Covenant from the City of David. During the seventh month festival, the Levites carried the Ark, the tabernacle, and all holy vessels to the temple. Solomon and the congregation offered countless sacrifices.

The priests placed the Ark in the most holy place under the cherubim's wings. The cherubim's wings covered the Ark and its poles, which were visible from the holy place but not from outside. The Ark contained only the two tablets Moses had placed there at Horeb. When the priests left the holy place, they and the Levite singers, dressed in white linen and playing instruments, praised the Lord. As they sang, the temple filled with a cloud, symbolizing the Lord's glory, making it impossible for the priests to continue their service.

Solomon then addressed the congregation, blessing them and praising the Lord for fulfilling His promise to David. He recounted how God chose Jerusalem and David, and how David had desired to build a temple for the Lord. However, God had chosen Solomon to complete this task.
