Solomon declared that he had built the temple for the Lord and placed the Ark of the Covenant inside.

Solomon stood before the altar, spread his hands toward heaven, and prayed, acknowledging God's uniqueness and faithfulness. He asked God to keep His promise to David, ensuring that his descendants would continue to rule Israel if they followed God's laws. Solomon questioned whether God would truly dwell on earth, given that even the heavens couldn't contain Him, and asked God to listen to the prayers made in the temple and to forgive His people. He prayed for justice and mercy, asking God to hear and respond to the prayers of the people of Israel.When Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offerings and sacrifices, and the glory of the Lord filled the temple. The priests couldn't enter the temple because of the overwhelming presence of the Lord's glory. All the Israelites saw the fire and the glory of the Lord and bowed down, worshipping and praising Him, saying, "He is good; His mercy endures forever."

King Solomon and all the people offered sacrifices to the Lord. Solomon sacrificed 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep, dedicating the temple. The priests performed their duties, and the Levites, with musical instruments made by King David, praised the Lord, saying, "His mercy endures forever." The priests blew trumpets, and all Israel stood.

Solomon consecrated the middle of the courtyard in front of the temple because the bronze altar he had made couldn't hold all the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings. Solomon and all Israel celebrated the festival for seven days, from the entrance of Hamath to the Brook of Egypt. On the eighth day, they held a solemn assembly, having dedicated the altar for seven days and celebrated the festival for another seven days. On the 23rd day of the seventh month, Solomon sent the people home, joyful and glad for the goodness the Lord had shown to David, Solomon, and His people Israel.

Solomon completed the temple and his royal palace, successfully carrying out all he had planned to do in the temple and his own house. The Lord appeared to Solomon at night, saying, "I have heard your prayer and chosen this place for myself as a temple for sacrifices. If I shut up the heavens so there is no rain, or command locusts to devour the land, or send a plague among my people, if my people, who are called by my name, humble themselves, pray, seek my face, and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, forgive their sin, and heal their land. My eyes will be open and my ears attentive to the prayers offered in this place. I have chosen and consecrated this temple so that my name may be there forever. My eyes and my heart will always be there.

As for you, if you walk before me faithfully as David your father did, and do all I command, observing my decrees and laws, I will establish your royal throne, as I covenanted with David, saying, 'You shall never fail to have a successor to rule over Israel.' But if you turn away and forsake the decrees and commands I have given you and go off to serve other gods and worship them, then I will uproot Israel from my land, which I have given them, and will reject this temple I have consecrated for my name. I will make it a byword and an object of ridicule among all peoples. This temple will become a heap of rubble. All who pass by will be appalled and say, 'Why has the Lord done such a thing to this land and to this temple?' People will answer, 'Because they have forsaken the Lord, the God of their ancestors, who brought them out of Egypt, and have embraced other gods, worshipping and serving them—that is why he brought all this disaster on them.'"

After twenty years, during which Solomon built the temple of the Lord and his own palace, he rebuilt the cities Huram had given him and settled Israelites in them. Solomon went to Hamath Zobah and captured it. He built up Tadmor in the desert and all the store cities he had built in Hamath. He rebuilt Upper Beth Horon and Lower Beth Horon as fortified cities, with walls and gates and bars, as well as Baalath and all his store cities, and all the cities for his chariots and horses—whatever he desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout all the territory he ruled.

All the people left from the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not Israelites, Solomon conscripted for slave labor, as they are to this day. But Solomon did not make slaves of the Israelites; they were his fighting men, commanders of his captains, and commanders of his chariots and charioteers. They were also King Solomon's chief officials—250 officials supervising the men.

Solomon brought Pharaoh's daughter up from the City of David to the palace he had built for her, for he said, "My wife must not live in the palace of David king of Israel, because the places the ark of the Lord has entered are holy."

On the altar of the Lord that he had built in front of the portico, Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings to the Lord, according to the daily requirement for offerings commanded by Moses for the Sabbaths, the New Moons, and the three annual festivals—the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Tabernacles. Following the regulations of his father David, he appointed the divisions of the priests for their duties and the Levites to lead the praise and to assist the priests according to each day's requirement. He also appointed the gatekeepers by divisions for the various gates, because this was what David the man of God had ordered.The Levites and priests followed King David's instructions, performing their duties daily. They didn't deviate from the king's orders regarding the priests, Levites, or the temple treasures. Solomon's work on the Lord's temple was completed from its foundation to its finish, making it perfect.

Solomon then traveled to Ezion-Geber and Eloth by the sea in Edom. Huram sent ships and experienced sailors to help Solomon's servants travel to Ophir, where they obtained 450 talents of gold and brought it back to King Solomon.

When the Queen of Sheba heard of Solomon's fame, she visited him in Jerusalem with a large entourage, bringing spices, gold, and precious stones. She tested Solomon with difficult questions, and he answered them all. Impressed by his wisdom, the palace he built, the food at his table, the organization of his officials, and the way they served, she was left in awe.

The Queen of Sheba acknowledged that Solomon's wisdom and prosperity exceeded the reports she had heard. She praised the Lord for placing Solomon on the throne to rule with justice. She gave Solomon 120 talents of gold, a great quantity of spices, and precious stones, unmatched by any other.

Huram's and Solomon's servants also brought gold from Ophir, algum wood, and precious stones. Solomon used the algum wood to make terraces for the Lord's temple and the royal palace, as well as harps and lyres for musicians, which were unique in Judah.

Solomon gave the Queen of Sheba everything she desired, in addition to what she had brought him. She then returned to her land with her servants.

Each year, Solomon received 666 talents of gold, excluding what traders and merchants brought. Kings of Arabia and regional governors also brought gold and silver to Solomon. He made 200 large shields and 300 smaller shields of hammered gold, placing them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.

Solomon crafted a great ivory throne overlaid with pure gold, with six steps, a gold footstool, armrests, and two lions standing beside the armrests. Twelve lions stood on the six steps, unmatched by any other kingdom. All of Solomon's drinking vessels and the vessels in the House of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold, as silver was considered of little value during his reign.

Solomon's fleet, in partnership with Huram's servants, traveled to Tarshish every three years, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks. Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom. Kings from around the world sought his presence to hear the wisdom God had given him, bringing annual gifts of silver, gold, garments, armor, spices, horses, and mules.

Solomon had 4,000 stalls for horses and chariots and 12,000 horsemen, stationed in chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem. He ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and the border of Egypt. He made silver as common as stones in Jerusalem and cedar as plentiful as sycamore trees in the lowlands. Horses were imported for Solomon from Egypt and all other lands.

The rest of Solomon's acts, from beginning to end, are recorded in the writings of Nathan the prophet, Ahijah the Shilonite's prophecy, and the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam son of Nebat. Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel for 40 years. When he died, he was buried in the city of David, and his son Rehoboam succeeded him.

Rehoboam went to Shechem, where all Israel had gathered to make him king. Jeroboam son of Nebat, who had fled to Egypt to escape Solomon, returned when he heard the news. The people, led by Jeroboam, asked Rehoboam to lighten the harsh labor and heavy yoke imposed by his father, promising to serve him if he did.

Rehoboam asked for three days to consider their request. He consulted the elders who had served his father Solomon, who advised him to be kind and speak gently to the people, ensuring their loyalty. However, Rehoboam rejected their advice and consulted the young men he had grown up with, who advised him to increase the burden on the people, saying his little finger was thicker than his father's waist and that he would chastise them with scorpions instead of whips.

When Jeroboam and the people returned on the third day, Rehoboam harshly rejected their request, following the young men's advice. This decision, influenced by God to fulfill Ahijah's prophecy, led to Israel's rebellion against the house of David. The people declared they had no share in David's lineage and returned to their homes, leaving Rehoboam to rule only over the Israelites in Judah.

Rehoboam sent Hadoram, in charge of forced labor, but the Israelites stoned him to death. Rehoboam fled to Jerusalem, and Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David ever since. Rehoboam gathered 180,000 warriors from Judah and Benjamin to fight Israel and restore his rule, but God, through Shemaiah the man of God, commanded them not to fight their brothers, and they obeyed, returning home.

Rehoboam lived in Jerusalem and fortified cities in Judah, including Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa, Beth-Zur, Soco, Adullam, Gath, Mareshah, Ziph, Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah, Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. He strengthened these strongholds, placing captains and supplies of food, oil, and wine in each city, ensuring their security.The Levites left their towns and properties to move to Judah and Jerusalem because Jeroboam and his sons had stopped them from serving as priests for the Lord. Jeroboam appointed his own priests for the high places, idols, and golden calves he had made. People from all the tribes of Israel who were devoted to seeking the Lord God of Israel came to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices to the Lord, the God of their ancestors. This strengthened the kingdom of Judah and made Rehoboam, Solomon's son, strong for three years, as they followed the ways of David and Solomon.

Rehoboam married Mahalath, the daughter of David's son Jerimoth, and Abihail, the daughter of Eliab, Jesse's son. They had children: Jeush, Shamariah, and Zaham. Later, he married Maachah, the daughter of Absalom, who bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith. Rehoboam loved Maachah more than all his other wives and concubines, having eighteen wives and sixty concubines, fathering twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters. He appointed Maachah's son Abijah as the chief prince, intending to make him king. Rehoboam wisely distributed his sons throughout the fortified cities of Judah and Benjamin, providing them with ample provisions and seeking many wives for them.

When Rehoboam had established and strengthened his kingdom, he abandoned the law of the Lord, and all Israel followed his lead. In the fifth year of Rehoboam's reign, Shishak, the king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem because they had been unfaithful to the Lord. Shishak came with 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horsemen, and countless troops from Egypt, including Libyans, Sukkites, and Cushites. He captured the fortified cities of Judah and advanced to Jerusalem.

The prophet Shemaiah came to Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah, who had gathered in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and said, "This is what the Lord says: 'You have abandoned me; therefore, I now abandon you to Shishak.'" The leaders of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, "The Lord is just." When the Lord saw their humility, he spoke to Shemaiah, saying, "Since they have humbled themselves, I will not destroy them but will grant them some deliverance. My wrath will not be poured out on Jerusalem through Shishak. However, they will become his subjects, so they may learn the difference between serving me and serving the kings of other lands."

Shishak attacked Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the Lord's temple and the royal palace, including the gold shields Solomon had made. Rehoboam replaced them with bronze shields and assigned them to the commanders of the guard who protected the entrance to the royal palace. Whenever the king went to the Lord's temple, the guards would bring out the shields and then return them to the guardroom. Because Rehoboam humbled himself, the Lord's anger turned away from him, and he was not completely destroyed. Conditions in Judah improved.

Rehoboam strengthened his position in Jerusalem and ruled for seventeen years. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned in the city the Lord had chosen from all the tribes of Israel to put his name there. His mother was Naamah, an Ammonite. Rehoboam did evil because he did not set his heart on seeking the Lord. The events of Rehoboam's reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in the writings of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer concerning genealogies. There were continual wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam. Rehoboam died and was buried in the city of David, and his son Abijah succeeded him.

In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign, Abijah became king of Judah. He ruled in Jerusalem for three years. His mother was Michaiah, the daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam. Abijah went into battle with 400,000 valiant warriors, while Jeroboam confronted him with 800,000 able fighters. Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in the hill country of Ephraim and addressed Jeroboam and all Israel, reminding them that the Lord had given the kingdom of Israel to David and his descendants forever by a covenant of salt. He accused Jeroboam, the son of Nebat and a servant of Solomon, of rebelling against his master and gathering worthless scoundrels to oppose Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced.

Abijah warned that they were now challenging the kingdom of the Lord, led by David's descendants, and that they had brought golden calves as gods. He reminded them that they had expelled the Lord's priests, the descendants of Aaron and the Levites, and appointed their own priests like the pagan nations. In contrast, Abijah and his people had not forsaken the Lord. The priests of the Lord, descendants of Aaron, and the Levites continued their duties, offering burnt sacrifices and incense, arranging the showbread, and lighting the golden lampstand every evening. They kept the charge of the Lord, while Israel had abandoned him. Abijah declared that God was with them as their leader, and his priests were ready to sound the trumpets against Israel. He warned them not to fight against the Lord, the God of their ancestors, as they would not succeed.

Meanwhile, Jeroboam had sent troops to ambush Judah from behind, so the battle was in front and behind them. Judah cried out to the Lord, and the priests blew their trumpets. The men of Judah raised a battle cry, and as they shouted, God struck down Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah. The Israelites fled, and God delivered them into Judah's hands. Abijah and his army inflicted heavy casualties, killing 500,000 of Israel's chosen men. The Israelites were subdued, and Judah prevailed because they relied on the Lord, the God of their ancestors. Abijah pursued Jeroboam, capturing cities including Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephron, along with their surrounding villages. Jeroboam never regained power during Abijah's lifetime, and the Lord struck him down, and he died.

Abijah grew strong, married fourteen wives, and had twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters. The rest of Abijah's deeds, his ways, and his sayings are recorded in the story of the prophet Iddo. Abijah died and was buried in the city of David, and his son Asa succeeded him. During Asa's reign, the land experienced ten years of peace. Asa did what was right and good in the eyes of the Lord his God. He removed the foreign altars and high places, smashed the sacred stones, and cut down the Asherah poles. He commanded Judah to seek the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and to obey his laws and commands. He removed the high places and incense altars from all the towns of Judah, and the kingdom was at peace under him.

Asa built up the fortified cities of Judah during this time of peace, as no one was at war with him. The Lord had given him rest. He said to Judah, "Let us build these towns and put walls around them, with towers, gates, and bars. The land is still ours because we have sought the Lord our God; we sought him, and he has given us rest on every side." So they built and prospered. Asa had an army of 300,000 men from Judah, equipped with large shields and spears, and 280,000 men from Benjamin, armed with small shields and bows. All these were brave fighting men.

Zerah the Cushite marched out against them with a vast army and 300 chariots and came as far as Mareshah. Asa went out to meet him, and they took up battle positions in the Valley of Zephathah near Mareshah. Asa called to the Lord his God, saying, "Lord, there is no one like you to help the powerless against the mighty. Help us, Lord our God, for we rely on you, and in your name, we have come against this vast army. Lord, you are our God; do not let mere mortals prevail against you." The Lord struck down the Cushites before Asa and Judah. The Cushites fled, and Asa and his army pursued them as far as Gerar. The Cushites were crushed and could not recover; they were shattered before the Lord and his forces.Asa and his army carried away a lot of loot from the defeated cities around Gerar. They also took livestock, including sheep and camels, and returned to Jerusalem. 

The Spirit of God came upon Azariah, son of Oded, who went to meet Asa. He told Asa and all of Judah and Benjamin that the Lord would be with them as long as they sought Him, but if they abandoned Him, He would abandon them. For a long time, Israel had been without the true God, a teaching priest, or the law. But when they turned to the Lord in their distress, He was found by them. During those times, there was no peace for those who went out or came in, as there were great troubles on all the inhabitants of the lands. Nations and cities were destroyed because God troubled them with adversity. Azariah encouraged them to be strong and not to give up, for their work would be rewarded.

When Asa heard these words and the prophecy of Oded, he took courage. He removed the detestable idols from all the land of Judah and Benjamin and from the cities he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim. He repaired the altar of the Lord in front of the temple. Asa gathered all of Judah and Benjamin, along with people from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who had settled among them, for many had come over to him from Israel when they saw that the Lord his God was with him. They assembled in Jerusalem in the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa's reign. They sacrificed to the Lord 700 oxen and 7,000 sheep from the plunder they had brought back. They entered into a covenant to seek the Lord, the God of their ancestors, with all their heart and soul. Anyone who would not seek the Lord was to be put to death, regardless of age or gender. They took an oath to the Lord with loud acclamation, shouting, trumpets, and horns. All of Judah rejoiced at the oath because they had sworn it wholeheartedly. They sought God eagerly, and He was found by them, giving them rest on every side.

Asa also removed his grandmother Maachah from her position as queen mother because she had made a repulsive image for the worship of Asherah. Asa cut down her image, crushed it, and burned it in the Kidron Valley. Although he did not remove the high places from Israel, Asa's heart was fully committed to the Lord all his life. He brought into the temple of God the silver and gold and the articles that he and his father had dedicated. There was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa's reign.

In the thirty-sixth year of Asa's reign, Baasha, king of Israel, attacked Judah and fortified Ramah to prevent anyone from leaving or entering Asa's territory. Asa took silver and gold from the treasuries of the Lord's temple and his own palace and sent it to Ben-Hadad, king of Aram, who was ruling in Damascus. He asked Ben-Hadad to break his treaty with Baasha so that Baasha would withdraw from him. Ben-Hadad agreed and sent his commanders against the towns of Israel, conquering Ijon, Dan, Abel Maim, and all the store cities of Naphtali. When Baasha heard this, he stopped building Ramah and abandoned his work. Then King Asa brought all the men of Judah, and they carried away the stones and timber Baasha had been using. With these materials, he built up Geba and Mizpah.

At that time, Hanani the seer came to Asa, king of Judah, and said, "Because you relied on the king of Aram and not on the Lord your God, the army of the king of Aram has escaped from your hand. Were not the Cushites and Libyans a mighty army with great numbers of chariots and horsemen? Yet when you relied on the Lord, He delivered them into your hand. For the eyes of the Lord range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him. You have done a foolish thing, and from now on you will be at war." Asa was angry with the seer because of this; he was so enraged that he put him in prison. At the same time, Asa brutally oppressed some of the people.

The events of Asa's reign, from beginning to end, are written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel. In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa was afflicted with a disease in his feet. Though his disease was severe, even in his illness he did not seek help from the Lord but only from the physicians. Then in the forty-first year of his reign, Asa died and rested with his ancestors. They buried him in the tomb he had cut out for himself in the City of David. They laid him on a bier covered with spices and various blended perfumes, and they made a huge fire in his honor.

Jehoshaphat, Asa's son, succeeded him as king and strengthened himself against Israel. He stationed troops in all the fortified cities of Judah and set garrisons in Judah and in the towns of Ephraim that his father Asa had captured. The Lord was with Jehoshaphat because he followed the ways of his ancestor David and did not consult the Baals. He sought the God of his father and followed His commands rather than the practices of Israel. The Lord established the kingdom under his control, and all Judah brought gifts to Jehoshaphat, so he had great wealth and honor. His heart was devoted to the ways of the Lord; furthermore, he removed the high places and the Asherah poles from Judah.

In the third year of his reign, Jehoshaphat sent his officials to teach in the towns of Judah. With them were certain Levites and priests. They taught throughout Judah, taking with them the Book of the Law of the Lord; they went around to all the towns of Judah and taught the people. The fear of the Lord fell on all the kingdoms of the lands surrounding Judah, so they did not go to war against Jehoshaphat. Some Philistines brought Jehoshaphat gifts and silver as tribute, and the Arabs brought him flocks: 7,700 rams and 7,700 goats. Jehoshaphat became more and more powerful; he built forts and store cities in Judah and had large supplies in the towns of Judah. He also kept experienced fighting men in Jerusalem. Their enrollment by families was as follows: from Judah, commanders of units of 1,000; Adnah the commander, with 300,000 fighting men; next, Jehohanan the commander, with 280,000; next, Amasiah son of Zicri, who volunteered himself for the service of the Lord, with 200,000. From Benjamin: Eliada, a valiant soldier, with 200,000 men armed with bows and shields; next, Jehozabad, with 180,000 men armed for battle. These were the men who served the king, besides those he stationed in the fortified cities throughout Judah.

Jehoshaphat had great wealth and honor, and he allied himself with Ahab by marriage. Some years later, he went down to visit Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered many sheep and cattle for him and the people with him and urged him to attack Ramoth Gilead. Ahab, king of Israel, asked Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, "Will you go with me to fight against Ramoth Gilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am as you are, and my people as your people; we will join you in the war." But Jehoshaphat also said to the king of Israel, "First seek the counsel of the Lord." So the king of Israel brought together the prophets—400 men—and asked them, "Shall we go to war against Ramoth Gilead, or shall I refrain?" "Go," they answered, "for God will give it into the king's hand." But Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there no longer a prophet of the Lord here whom we can inquire of?" The king of Israel answered Jehoshaphat, "There is still one prophet through whom we can inquire of the Lord, but I hate him because he never prophesies anything good about me, but always bad. He is Micaiah son of Imlah." "The king should not say such a thing," Jehoshaphat replied. So the king of Israel called one of his officials and said, "Bring Micaiah son of Imlah at once."The prophets continued to encourage the king, saying, "Go to Ramoth Gilead and succeed; the Lord will give it into the king's hand." The messenger who went to summon Micaiah told him, "All the other prophets are promising success to the king. Let your words agree with theirs and speak favorably." But Micaiah replied, "As surely as the Lord lives, I will say only what my God tells me."

When Micaiah arrived, the king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth Gilead, or should I refrain?" Micaiah answered, "Attack and be victorious, for they will be given into your hand." The king said to him, "How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?" Then Micaiah said, "I saw all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd, and the Lord said, 'These people have no master. Let each one go home in peace.'"

The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "Didn't I tell you that he never prophesies anything good about me, but only bad?" Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on his throne with all the multitudes of heaven standing on his right and on his left. And the Lord said, 'Who will entice Ahab king of Israel into attacking Ramoth Gilead and going to his death there?' One suggested this, and another that. Finally, a spirit came forward, stood before the Lord, and said, 'I will entice him.' 'By what means?' the Lord asked. 'I will go and be a deceiving spirit in the mouths of all his prophets,' he said. 'You will succeed in enticing him,' said the Lord. 'Go and do it.'

"So now the Lord has put a deceiving spirit in the mouths of these prophets of yours. The Lord has decreed disaster for you." Then Zedekiah son of Kenaanah went up and slapped Micaiah in the face. "Which way did the spirit from the Lord go when he went from me to speak to you?" he asked. Micaiah replied, "You will find out on the day you go to hide in an inner room."

The king of Israel then ordered, "Take Micaiah and send him back to Amon the ruler of the city and to Joash the king's son, and say, 'This is what the king says: Put this fellow in prison and give him nothing but bread and water until I return safely.'" Micaiah declared, "If you ever return safely, the Lord has not spoken through me." Then he added, "Mark my words, all you people!"

So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramoth Gilead. The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will enter the battle in disguise, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.

Now the king of Aram had ordered his chariot commanders, "Do not fight with anyone, small or great, except the king of Israel." When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they thought, "This is the king of Israel." So they turned to attack him, but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the Lord helped him. God drew them away from him, for when the chariot commanders saw that he was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.

But someone drew his bow at random and hit the king of Israel between the sections of his armor. The king told the chariot driver, "Wheel around and get me out of the fighting. I've been wounded." The battle raged all day, and the king of Israel propped himself up in his chariot facing the Arameans until evening. Then at sunset, he died.

Jehoshaphat king of Judah returned safely to his palace in Jerusalem. Jehu the seer, the son of Hanani, went out to meet him and said to the king, "Should you help the wicked and love those who hate the Lord? Because of this, the wrath of the Lord is upon you. However, there is some good in you, for you have rid the land of the Asherah poles and have set your heart on seeking God."

Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem, and he went out again among the people from Beersheba to the hill country of Ephraim and turned them back to the Lord, the God of their ancestors. He appointed judges in the land, in each of the fortified cities of Judah. He told them, "Consider carefully what you do, because you are not judging for mere mortals but for the Lord, who is with you whenever you give a verdict. Now let the fear of the Lord be on you. Judge carefully, for with the Lord our God there is no injustice or partiality or bribery."

In Jerusalem also, Jehoshaphat appointed some of the Levites, priests, and heads of Israelite families to administer the law of the Lord and to settle disputes. And they lived in Jerusalem. He gave them these orders: "You must serve faithfully and wholeheartedly in the fear of the Lord. In every case that comes before you from your people who live in the cities—whether bloodshed or other concerns of the law, commands, decrees, or regulations—you are to warn them not to sin against the Lord; otherwise, his wrath will come on you and your people. Do this, and you will not sin.

"Amariah the chief priest will be over you in any matter concerning the Lord, and Zebadiah son of Ishmael, the leader of the tribe of Judah, will be over you in any matter concerning the king. And the Levites will serve as officials before you. Act with courage, and may the Lord be with those who do well."

After this, the Moabites and Ammonites with some of the Meunites came to wage war against Jehoshaphat. Some people came and told Jehoshaphat, "A vast army is coming against you from Edom, from the other side of the Dead Sea. It is already in Hazezon Tamar" (that is, En Gedi). Alarmed, Jehoshaphat resolved to inquire of the Lord, and he proclaimed a fast for all Judah. The people of Judah came together to seek help from the Lord; indeed, they came from every town in Judah to seek him.

Then Jehoshaphat stood up in the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem at the temple of the Lord in front of the new courtyard and said: "Lord, the God of our ancestors, are you not the God who is in heaven? You rule over all the kingdoms of the nations. Power and might are in your hand, and no one can withstand you. Our God, did you not drive out the inhabitants of this land before your people Israel and give it forever to the descendants of Abraham your friend? They have lived in it and have built in it a sanctuary for your Name, saying, 'If calamity comes upon us, whether the sword of judgment, or plague or famine, we will stand in your presence before this temple that bears your Name and will cry out to you in our distress, and you will hear us and save us.'

"But now here are men from Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir, whose territory you would not allow Israel to invade when they came from Egypt; so they turned away from them and did not destroy them. See how they are repaying us by coming to drive us out of the possession you gave us as an inheritance. Our God, will you not judge them? For we have no power to face this vast army that is attacking us. We do not know what to do, but our eyes are on you."

All the men of Judah, with their wives and children and little ones, stood there before the Lord. Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Jahaziel son of Zechariah, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Mattaniah, a Levite and descendant of Asaph, as he stood in the assembly. He said: "Listen, King Jehoshaphat and all who live in Judah and Jerusalem! This is what the Lord says to you: 'Do not be afraid or discouraged because of this vast army. For the battle is not yours, but God's. Tomorrow march down against them. They will be climbing up by the Pass of Ziz, and you will find them at the end of the gorge in the Desert of Jeruel. You will not have to fight this battle. Take up your positions; stand firm and see the deliverance the Lord will give you, Judah and Jerusalem. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged. Go out to face them tomorrow, and the Lord will be with you.'"

Jehoshaphat bowed down with his face to the ground, and all the people of Judah and Jerusalem fell down in worship before the Lord. Then some Levites from the Kohathites and Korahites stood up and praised the Lord, the God of Israel, with a very loud voice.

Early in the morning they left for the Desert of Tekoa. As they set out, Jehoshaphat stood and said, "Listen to me, Judah and people of Jerusalem! Have faith in the Lord your God and you will be upheld; have faith in his prophets and you will be successful." After consulting the people, Jehoshaphat appointed men to sing to the Lord and to praise him for the splendor of his holiness as they went out at the head of the army, saying: "Give thanks to the Lord, for his love endures forever."

As they began to sing and praise, the Lord set ambushes against the men of Ammon and Moab and Mount Seir who were invading Judah, and they were defeated. The Ammonites and Moabites rose up against the men from Mount Seir to destroy and annihilate them. After they finished slaughtering the men from Seir, they helped to destroy one another.When the people of Judah reached the watchtower in the wilderness, they saw the enemy's dead bodies lying on the ground; no one had survived. Jehoshaphat and his people collected a vast amount of riches and precious jewels from the fallen, more than they could carry. It took them three days to gather all the spoils because there was so much. On the fourth day, they assembled in the Valley of Berachah and blessed the Lord, which is why the place is called the Valley of Berachah to this day.

They returned to Jerusalem with joy, led by Jehoshaphat, because the Lord had given them victory over their enemies. They entered Jerusalem with musical instruments, praising the Lord. The surrounding kingdoms were in awe when they heard that the Lord had fought against Israel's enemies, and Jehoshaphat's kingdom was at peace because God had given him rest on all sides.

Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah for 25 years, starting at the age of 35. His mother was Azubah, daughter of Shilhi. He followed the ways of his father Asa and did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, although the high places were not removed, and the people had not fully committed their hearts to God.

The rest of Jehoshaphat's deeds are recorded in the book of Jehu son of Hanani, which is mentioned in the book of the kings of Israel. After Jehoshaphat, his son Jehoram became king. Jehoram had several brothers, and their father gave them gifts of silver, gold, and fortified cities, but the kingdom was given to Jehoram because he was the firstborn.

When Jehoram established his rule, he killed all his brothers and some of the princes of Israel. He was 32 years old when he began to reign and ruled for eight years in Jerusalem. He followed the ways of the kings of Israel, influenced by his wife, the daughter of Ahab, and did evil in the eyes of the Lord. However, the Lord did not destroy David's house because of the covenant He had made with David.

During Jehoram's reign, the Edomites revolted and set up their own king. Jehoram attacked them at night and defeated them, but the Edomites remained in rebellion. Libnah also revolted because Jehoram had abandoned the Lord. He built high places in Judah, leading the people into idolatry.

Elijah the prophet sent Jehoram a letter saying that because he had not followed the ways of his father Jehoshaphat or Asa, but instead led Judah into sin and killed his brothers, the Lord would strike his people, children, wives, and possessions with a great plague. Jehoram himself would suffer a painful disease of the bowels.

The Lord stirred up the Philistines and Arabians against Jehoram. They invaded Judah, took all his possessions, and captured his sons and wives, leaving only his youngest son, Jehoahaz. After this, Jehoram was struck with an incurable disease, and after two years, he died in great pain. The people did not honor him with a fire as they had for his ancestors. He was 32 when he began to reign and ruled for eight years, dying without being mourned. He was buried in the city of David but not in the royal tombs.

The people of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, Jehoram's youngest son, king because the raiders had killed all the older sons. Ahaziah was 42 years old when he began to reign and ruled for one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, daughter of Omri. He followed the ways of Ahab's house, influenced by his mother, and did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He joined Jehoram, son of Ahab, in a war against Hazael, king of Syria, and was wounded. While recovering in Jezreel, he visited Jehoram, son of Ahab, and was caught up in Jehu's rebellion against Ahab's house. Ahaziah was captured and killed by Jehu's men.

When Athaliah, Ahaziah's mother, saw her son was dead, she killed all the royal heirs of Judah. However, Jehoshabeath, daughter of King Jehoram and sister of Ahaziah, hid Ahaziah's son Joash and his nurse in a bedroom, saving him from Athaliah. Joash was hidden in the house of God for six years while Athaliah ruled the land.

In the seventh year, Jehoiada the priest strengthened himself and made a covenant with the captains of hundreds and the Levites. They gathered in Jerusalem and made a covenant with the king in the house of God, declaring that the king's son would reign as the Lord had promised. They organized a plan to protect the king, with a third of the priests and Levites guarding the doors, the king's house, and the gate of the foundation. The people were to stay in the courts of the Lord's house, and only the priests and ministering Levites were allowed inside. The Levites were to surround the king with weapons, ready to defend him.

Jehoiada the priest gave the captains of hundreds the spears, shields, and bucklers that had belonged to King David, which were kept in the house of God. He stationed all the people, each with their weapon in hand.Jehoiada the priest positioned guards around the temple, from one side to the other, near the altar and the temple, surrounding the king. They brought out the king's son, crowned him, gave him the royal testimony, and anointed him as king, proclaiming, "Long live the king!"

When Athaliah heard the commotion and the people praising the new king, she went to the temple. She saw the king standing by his pillar, surrounded by leaders and trumpeters, with people rejoicing and musicians playing. Athaliah tore her clothes and shouted, "Treason! Treason!"

Jehoiada the priest ordered the captains to remove her from the temple and kill anyone who followed her, but not to kill her in the temple. They seized her and killed her at the entrance of the Horse Gate near the king's house.

Jehoiada made a covenant between himself, the people, and the king to be the Lord's people. The people then destroyed the temple of Baal, broke its altars and idols, and killed Mattan, the priest of Baal. Jehoiada assigned duties to the priests and Levites as David had instructed, to offer burnt offerings with joy and singing.

He stationed guards at the temple gates to prevent anyone unclean from entering. He gathered the leaders and people, brought the king from the temple, and they entered the king's house, placing the king on the throne. The people rejoiced, and the city was peaceful after Athaliah was killed.

Joash was seven years old when he became king and reigned for forty years in Jerusalem. His mother was Zibiah from Beersheba. Joash did what was right in the Lord's eyes as long as Jehoiada the priest was alive. Jehoiada arranged two wives for him, and he had sons and daughters.

Later, Joash decided to repair the temple. He gathered the priests and Levites, instructing them to collect money from all Israel to repair the temple annually. However, the Levites did not act quickly. The king questioned Jehoiada about why the Levites had not collected the money as commanded by Moses for the tabernacle.

The sons of Athaliah had damaged the temple and used its sacred items for Baal worship. At the king's command, a chest was made and placed outside the temple gate. A proclamation was made throughout Judah and Jerusalem to bring the collection Moses had commanded. The people and leaders rejoiced and filled the chest with money.

The Levites brought the chest to the king's office daily, and when it was full, the king's scribe and the high priest's officer emptied it and returned it. They collected a large amount of money, which the king and Jehoiada used to hire workers to repair the temple. The workers restored and strengthened the temple, and the remaining money was used to make vessels for the temple.

Burnt offerings were made continually in the temple during Jehoiada's lifetime. Jehoiada lived to be 130 years old and was buried in the city of David among the kings for his good deeds toward God and the temple.

After Jehoiada's death, the leaders of Judah influenced the king, and they abandoned the temple, serving idols instead. God's wrath came upon Judah and Jerusalem for their sins. Prophets were sent to bring them back to the Lord, but they were ignored. Zechariah, son of Jehoiada, filled with the Spirit of God, warned them of their disobedience, but they conspired against him and stoned him to death by the king's command.

Joash forgot the kindness Jehoiada had shown him and killed his son. As Zechariah died, he said, "May the Lord see this and call you to account." At the end of the year, the Syrian army attacked Judah and Jerusalem, destroying the leaders and sending the spoils to the king of Damascus. The small Syrian army defeated a large host because Judah had forsaken the Lord.

Joash was severely wounded, and his servants conspired against him for killing Jehoiada's sons. They killed him in his bed, and he was buried in the city of David but not in the royal tombs. The conspirators were Zabad, son of Shimeath the Ammonitess, and Jehozabad, son of Shimrith the Moabitess. The details of his sons, the burdens placed on him, and the temple repairs are recorded in the book of the kings. Amaziah, his son, succeeded him as king.

Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king and reigned for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem. He did what was right in the Lord's eyes but not wholeheartedly. When his kingdom was secure, he executed the servants who had killed his father but spared their children, following the law of Moses that each person should die for their own sin.

Amaziah assembled the men of Judah and Benjamin, organizing them into military units. He found 300,000 capable men and hired 100,000 warriors from Israel for 100 talents of silver. A man of God warned him not to let the Israelite army join him, as the Lord was not with Israel. Amaziah dismissed the Israelite soldiers, who left angrily.

Amaziah then led his army to the Valley of Salt, defeating 10,000 men of Seir. Another 10,000 were captured and thrown from a cliff, killing them. Meanwhile, the dismissed Israelite soldiers raided Judah's cities, killing 3,000 people and taking much spoil.

After defeating the Edomites, Amaziah brought their gods back and worshiped them, angering the Lord.Amaziah began worshiping the gods of the people he had defeated, which angered the Lord. A prophet was sent to him, asking why he sought gods that couldn't save their own people. Amaziah dismissed the prophet, who then warned that God had decided to destroy him for his disobedience.

Amaziah then challenged Joash, the king of Israel, to meet face-to-face. Joash responded with a parable, warning Amaziah to stay home and not seek trouble. Ignoring the warning, Amaziah went to battle and was defeated. Joash captured Amaziah, broke down part of Jerusalem's wall, and took treasures from the temple and the king's house.

Amaziah lived 15 years after Joash's death. Eventually, a conspiracy formed against him, and he fled to Lachish, where he was killed. He was buried in Judah, and his son Uzziah became king.

Uzziah, who was 16 when he became king, reigned for 52 years. He did what was right in the Lord's eyes and sought God during Zechariah's guidance. God helped him prosper, and he successfully waged wars, built cities, and fortified Jerusalem. Uzziah's fame spread as he grew stronger.

However, Uzziah's pride led to his downfall. He entered the temple to burn incense, a duty reserved for priests. Confronted by the priests, Uzziah became angry, and leprosy appeared on his forehead. He was forced to live in isolation until his death, and his son Jotham took over his duties.

Jotham, who became king at 25, reigned for 16 years. He did what was right in the Lord's eyes but did not enter the temple. He built cities and towers, fought and defeated the Ammonites, and became powerful because he followed God's ways. After his death, his son Ahaz became king.

Ahaz, who began his reign at 20, did not follow the Lord. He made idols, sacrificed his children, and worshiped in high places. As a result, God allowed him to be defeated by the kings of Syria and Israel, who took many captives and caused great destruction.The leaders of the Ephraim tribe—Azariah, Berechiah, Jehizkiah, and Amasa—stood against those returning from battle. They said, "You must not bring these captives here. We have already sinned against the Lord, and adding more to our sins will bring greater wrath upon Israel." So, the armed men released the captives and the spoils before the leaders and the congregation.

The men named took the captives, clothed the naked, provided shoes, food, and drink, and anointed them. They transported the weak on donkeys to Jericho, the city of palm trees, and then returned to Samaria.

During this time, King Ahaz sought help from the kings of Assyria because the Edomites had attacked Judah and taken captives. The Philistines also invaded the lowlands and southern cities of Judah, capturing several towns and villages. The Lord humbled Judah because of Ahaz's unfaithfulness, as he led Judah into sin and rebellion against the Lord.

King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria came to Ahaz but did not help him. Ahaz took treasures from the Lord's temple, the royal palace, and the leaders' houses to give to the Assyrian king, but it was in vain. In his distress, Ahaz sinned even more against the Lord by sacrificing to the gods of Damascus, believing they would help him. However, these actions led to his downfall and the ruin of Israel.

Ahaz desecrated the temple, shut its doors, and built altars in every corner of Jerusalem. He established high places in every city of Judah to burn incense to other gods, provoking the Lord's anger. The rest of Ahaz's deeds are recorded in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel. Ahaz died and was buried in Jerusalem, but not in the tombs of the kings of Israel. His son Hezekiah succeeded him.

Hezekiah became king at 25 and reigned for 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Abijah, daughter of Zechariah. Hezekiah did what was right in the Lord's eyes, following the example of his ancestor David. In the first year of his reign, he reopened and repaired the doors of the Lord's temple. He gathered the priests and Levites, instructing them to consecrate themselves and the temple, removing all impurity.

Hezekiah reminded them that their ancestors had sinned and turned away from the Lord, leading to the current troubles. He urged them to renew their covenant with the Lord to turn away His fierce wrath. The Levites, including Mahath, Joel, Kish, Azariah, Joah, Eden, Shimri, Jeiel, Zechariah, Mattaniah, Jehiel, Shimei, Shemaiah, and Uzziel, consecrated themselves and cleansed the temple as commanded by the king.

The priests removed all unclean items from the temple and the Levites carried them to the Kidron Valley. They began the cleansing on the first day of the first month and completed it by the sixteenth day. They reported to Hezekiah that the temple, the altar of burnt offerings, and all related vessels were cleansed and ready for use.

Hezekiah gathered the city leaders and went to the temple, offering seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs, and seven goats as a sin offering for the kingdom, the sanctuary, and Judah. The priests, descendants of Aaron, offered these sacrifices on the altar. They sprinkled the blood of the bulls, rams, and lambs on the altar and laid hands on the goats for the sin offering.

The priests killed the goats and made atonement for all Israel, as commanded by the king. Hezekiah also set the Levites in the temple with musical instruments, as instructed by David, Gad the king's seer, and Nathan the prophet. The Levites played David's instruments, and the priests blew trumpets as the burnt offering began. The congregation worshipped, sang, and played music until the offering was completed.

After the offerings, Hezekiah and all present bowed in worship. Hezekiah and the leaders instructed the Levites to sing praises to the Lord with the words of David and Asaph. They sang joyfully and worshipped. Hezekiah invited the people to bring sacrifices and thank offerings to the temple. The congregation willingly brought burnt offerings, totaling seventy bulls, one hundred rams, and two hundred lambs, along with six hundred oxen and three thousand sheep as consecrated offerings.

The priests were too few to handle all the burnt offerings, so the Levites helped until the work was finished. The Levites were more diligent in consecrating themselves than the priests. The abundance of burnt offerings, peace offerings, and drink offerings set the temple service in order. Hezekiah and the people rejoiced at how quickly God had prepared them for this.

Hezekiah sent letters to all Israel and Judah, inviting them to come to Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of the Lord God of Israel. The king, his officials, and the congregation decided to keep the Passover in the second month because the priests had not sufficiently consecrated themselves, and the people had not gathered in Jerusalem. This decision pleased the king and the congregation, so they issued a decree to proclaim it throughout Israel.Hezekiah sent messengers throughout Israel and Judah, from Beersheba to Dan, inviting everyone to come to Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of the Lord God of Israel. This hadn't been done in a long time as prescribed. The messengers carried letters from the king and his officials, urging the people to return to the Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, promising that He would be merciful to those who had escaped the Assyrian kings.

They were told not to be stubborn like their ancestors who disobeyed God and faced desolation. Instead, they were to submit to the Lord and enter His sanctuary, which He had sanctified forever, to turn away His fierce wrath. If they returned to the Lord, their captors would show compassion, and they would be able to return to their land because the Lord is gracious and merciful.

The messengers traveled through Ephraim, Manasseh, and Zebulun, but many people mocked and ridiculed them. However, some from Asher, Manasseh, and Zebulun humbled themselves and went to Jerusalem. In Judah, God united the people to follow the king's command as instructed by the Lord. A large crowd gathered in Jerusalem to celebrate the Feast of Unleavened Bread in the second month.

They removed the altars in Jerusalem and threw them into the Kidron Valley. On the fourteenth day of the second month, they slaughtered the Passover lambs. The priests and Levites, feeling ashamed, consecrated themselves and brought burnt offerings to the Lord's house. They stood in their assigned places according to the Law of Moses, and the priests sprinkled the blood received from the Levites.

Since many in the congregation were not ceremonially clean, the Levites had to slaughter the Passover lambs for them. Many people from Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun had not purified themselves but still ate the Passover. Hezekiah prayed for them, asking the Lord to pardon everyone who sought God, even if they were not ceremonially clean. The Lord heard Hezekiah and healed the people.

The Israelites in Jerusalem celebrated the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days with great joy. The Levites and priests praised the Lord daily with loud instruments. Hezekiah encouraged the Levites who taught about the Lord, and they ate throughout the feast, offering peace offerings and confessing to the Lord God of their ancestors. The assembly decided to celebrate for another seven days, and they did so with gladness.

King Hezekiah provided a thousand bulls and seven thousand sheep for the congregation, and the officials gave a thousand bulls and ten thousand sheep. Many priests consecrated themselves. The entire assembly of Judah, along with the priests, Levites, and those from Israel and Judah, rejoiced. There was great joy in Jerusalem, unlike anything since the days of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel. The priests and Levites blessed the people, and their prayers reached heaven.

After the celebration, the Israelites went to the cities of Judah and destroyed the idols, altars, and high places in Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh. They returned to their own cities. Hezekiah organized the priests and Levites into divisions for their service, including burnt offerings and peace offerings, to minister, give thanks, and praise at the gates of the Lord's dwelling.

Hezekiah also allocated a portion of his possessions for the burnt offerings, including those for the Sabbaths, new moons, and appointed feasts as written in the Law of the Lord. He commanded the people in Jerusalem to provide for the priests and Levites so they could devote themselves to the Law of the Lord. The Israelites responded by bringing the firstfruits of their produce and tithes in abundance.

In the third month, they began to pile up the contributions and finished in the seventh month. When Hezekiah and the officials saw the heaps, they praised the Lord and His people Israel. Hezekiah questioned the priests and Levites about the heaps, and Azariah, the chief priest, explained that since the people began bringing offerings, they had plenty to eat and much left over because the Lord had blessed them.

Hezekiah ordered storerooms to be prepared in the Lord's house, and they faithfully brought in the offerings, tithes, and dedicated items. Cononiah the Levite was in charge, with his brother Shimei as the assistant. Other overseers included Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismachiah, Mahath, and Benaiah, under the direction of Cononiah and Shimei, as commanded by Hezekiah and Azariah, the ruler of the house of God.

Kore, son of Imnah the Levite, was in charge of distributing the freewill offerings of God and the most holy things. Assisting him were Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah in the priests' cities, distributing portions to their fellow priests and Levites according to their divisions, regardless of age. They also distributed portions to the males three years old and above who entered the Lord's house for their daily duties.

Hezekiah did what was good, right, and faithful before the Lord his God. In everything he undertook in the service of God's house, in obedience to the law and commands, he sought his God wholeheartedly and prospered.

After these events, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, invaded Judah and besieged the fortified cities, intending to conquer them. When Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib had come to fight against Jerusalem, he consulted with his officials and military leaders to stop the water supply outside the city, and they helped him. A large number of people gathered to block all the springs and the stream flowing through the land, saying, "Why should the kings of Assyria come and find plenty of water?"

Hezekiah strengthened himself, repaired all the broken sections of the wall, built towers, and constructed another wall outside. He reinforced the Millo in the City of David and made a large number of weapons and shields. He appointed military officers over the people and assembled them in the square at the city gate, encouraging them with these words: "Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or discouraged because of the king of Assyria and the vast army with him, for there is a greater power with us than with him. With him is only the arm of flesh, but with us is the Lord our God to help us and to fight our battles." The people gained confidence from Hezekiah's words.After this, Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, sent his servants to Jerusalem while he himself besieged Lachish with his full military force. He sent a message to Hezekiah, king of Judah, and all the people in Jerusalem, saying, "On what are you basing your confidence to remain under siege in Jerusalem? Isn't Hezekiah misleading you, telling you that the Lord will deliver you from the king of Assyria? Didn't Hezekiah remove the high places and altars, commanding Judah and Jerusalem to worship at one altar and burn incense on it? Don't you know what I and my ancestors have done to all the peoples of other lands? Were the gods of those nations able to deliver their lands from my hand? Who among all the gods of these nations that my ancestors destroyed has been able to save his people from me? How then can your God deliver you from my hand? Don't let Hezekiah deceive you or mislead you like this. No god of any nation or kingdom has been able to deliver his people from my hand or the hand of my ancestors. How much less will your God deliver you from my hand?"

Sennacherib's servants continued to speak against the Lord God and His servant Hezekiah. He also wrote letters ridiculing the Lord, the God of Israel, saying, "Just as the gods of the other nations did not rescue their people from my hand, so the God of Hezekiah will not rescue His people from my hand." They shouted in Hebrew to the people of Jerusalem who were on the wall, trying to terrify them and make them afraid so they could capture the city. They spoke about the God of Jerusalem as they did about the gods of the other peoples of the world, which are made by human hands.

King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, prayed and cried out to heaven about this. And the Lord sent an angel who annihilated all the fighting men, commanders, and officers in the camp of the Assyrian king. So Sennacherib withdrew in disgrace to his own land. When he went into the temple of his god, some of his own sons killed him with the sword. So the Lord saved Hezekiah and the people of Jerusalem from the hand of Sennacherib, king of Assyria, and from all others. He took care of them on every side. Many brought offerings to Jerusalem for the Lord and valuable gifts for Hezekiah, king of Judah. From then on, he was highly regarded by all the nations.

In those days, Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. He prayed to the Lord, who answered him and gave him a miraculous sign. But Hezekiah's heart was proud, and he did not respond to the kindness shown to him. Therefore, the Lord's wrath was on him and on Judah and Jerusalem. Then Hezekiah repented of the pride of his heart, as did the people of Jerusalem. So the Lord's wrath did not come upon them during Hezekiah's lifetime.

Hezekiah had very great wealth and honor. He made treasuries for his silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and all kinds of valuables. He also made storehouses for the harvest of grain, new wine, and olive oil, and stalls for all kinds of cattle and pens for the flocks. He built villages and acquired great numbers of flocks and herds, for God had given him very great riches. It was Hezekiah who blocked the upper outlet of the Gihon spring and channeled the water down to the west side of the City of David. He succeeded in everything he undertook.

However, when envoys were sent by the rulers of Babylon to ask him about the miraculous sign that had occurred in the land, God left him to test him and to know everything that was in his heart. The other events of Hezekiah's reign, including his acts of devotion, are written in the vision of the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel. Hezekiah rested with his ancestors and was buried on the hill where the tombs of David's descendants are. All Judah and the people of Jerusalem honored him when he died. And his son Manasseh succeeded him as king.

Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for fifty-five years. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, following the detestable practices of the nations the Lord had driven out before the Israelites. He rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had demolished, erected altars to the Baals, and made Asherah poles. He bowed down to all the starry hosts and worshiped them. He built altars in the temple of the Lord, of which the Lord had said, "My Name will remain in Jerusalem forever." In both courts of the temple of the Lord, he built altars to all the starry hosts. He sacrificed his children in the fire in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, practiced divination and witchcraft, sought omens, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the eyes of the Lord, arousing His anger. He took the image he had made and put it in God's temple, of which God had said to David and his son Solomon, "In this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my Name forever. I will not again make the feet of the Israelites leave the land I assigned to your ancestors, if only they will be careful to do everything I commanded them concerning all the laws, decrees, and regulations given through Moses." But Manasseh led Judah and the people of Jerusalem astray, so that they did more evil than the nations the Lord had destroyed before the Israelites.

The Lord spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they paid no attention. So the Lord brought against them the army commanders of the king of Assyria, who took Manasseh prisoner, put a hook in his nose, bound him with bronze shackles, and took him to Babylon. In his distress, he sought the favor of the Lord his God and humbled himself greatly before the God of his ancestors. And when he prayed to him, the Lord was moved by his entreaty and listened to his plea. So he brought him back to Jerusalem and to his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the Lord is God.

Afterward, he rebuilt the outer wall of the City of David, west of the Gihon spring in the valley, as far as the entrance of the Fish Gate and encircling the hill of Ophel; he also made it much higher. He stationed military commanders in all the fortified cities in Judah. He got rid of the foreign gods and removed the image from the temple of the Lord, as well as all the altars he had built on the temple hill and in Jerusalem, and threw them out of the city. Then he restored the altar of the Lord and sacrificed fellowship offerings and thank offerings on it and told Judah to serve the Lord, the God of Israel. The people, however, continued to sacrifice at the high places, but only to the Lord their God.

The other events of Manasseh's reign, including his prayer to his God and the words the seers spoke to him in the name of the Lord, the God of Israel, are written in the annals of the kings of Israel. His prayer and how God was moved by his entreaty, as well as all his sins and unfaithfulness and the sites where he built high places and set up Asherah poles and idols before he humbled himself, are all written in the records of the seers. Manasseh rested with his ancestors and was buried in his palace. And Amon, his son, succeeded him as king.

Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for two years. He did evil in the eyes of the Lord, as his father Manasseh had done. Amon worshiped and offered sacrifices to all the idols Manasseh had made. But unlike his father Manasseh, he did not humble himself before the Lord; Amon increased his guilt. His officials conspired against him and assassinated him in his palace. Then the people of the land killed all who had plotted against King Amon, and they made Josiah, his son, king in his place.

Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for thirty-one years. He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord and followed the ways of his ancestor David, not turning aside to the right or to the left. In the eighth year of his reign, while he was still young, he began to seek the God of his ancestor David. In the twelfth year, he began to purge Judah and Jerusalem of high places, Asherah poles, and idols. Under his direction, the altars of the Baals were torn down; he cut to pieces the incense altars that were above them and smashed the Asherah poles and the idols. These he broke to pieces and scattered over the graves of those who had sacrificed to them. He burned the bones of the priests on their altars, and so he purged Judah and Jerusalem. In the towns of Manasseh, Ephraim, and Simeon, as far as Naphtali, and in the ruins around them, he tore down the altars and the Asherah poles and crushed the idols to powder and cut to pieces all the incense altars throughout Israel. Then he went back to Jerusalem.In the eighteenth year of his reign, after purging the land and the temple, King Josiah sent Shaphan, Maaseiah, and Joah to repair the temple of the Lord. They delivered the money collected from the people to the high priest Hilkiah, who then gave it to the workers overseeing the temple repairs. The workers used the funds to buy materials and repair the temple faithfully.

During the repairs, Hilkiah found the Book of the Law given by Moses. He gave it to Shaphan, who read it to King Josiah. Upon hearing the words, Josiah tore his clothes in distress and commanded his officials to seek the Lord's guidance about the book's contents, fearing God's wrath for their ancestors' disobedience.

The officials consulted Huldah the prophetess, who confirmed that disaster would come upon the land due to their disobedience. However, because Josiah humbled himself before God, he would be spared from witnessing the impending calamity.

Josiah then gathered all the elders and people of Judah and Jerusalem, read the Book of the Covenant to them, and renewed the covenant with the Lord. He removed all idolatrous items from the land and led the people to serve the Lord faithfully.

Josiah also organized a grand Passover celebration, unlike any seen since the days of Samuel the prophet. He provided offerings for the people, priests, and Levites, ensuring everyone participated in the feast.

Later, when Necho, king of Egypt, marched to fight at Carchemish, Josiah confronted him despite Necho's warning that God had sent him. Josiah was wounded in battle and died, and his body was brought back to Jerusalem for burial.Josiah was buried in the tombs of his ancestors, and all of Judah and Jerusalem mourned for him. The prophet Jeremiah composed laments for Josiah, and these laments became a tradition in Israel, recorded in the book of Lamentations.

Josiah's deeds, both good and bad, are documented in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. After Josiah's death, the people made his son Jehoahaz king. Jehoahaz was 23 years old when he began to reign, but he only ruled for three months before the king of Egypt deposed him and imposed a heavy tribute on the land. The king of Egypt then made Jehoahaz's brother Eliakim king, renaming him Jehoiakim, and took Jehoahaz to Egypt.

Jehoiakim was 25 years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem, doing evil in the sight of the Lord. During his reign, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, captured him and took him to Babylon along with some of the temple's treasures. Jehoiakim's actions and abominations are also recorded in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. His son Jehoiachin succeeded him.

Jehoiachin was eight years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for three months and ten days in Jerusalem, also doing evil in the sight of the Lord. Nebuchadnezzar then took him to Babylon along with more temple treasures and made Zedekiah, Jehoiachin's brother, king over Judah and Jerusalem.

Zedekiah was 21 years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem, doing evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not humble himself before the prophet Jeremiah and rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar, who had made him swear allegiance to God. Zedekiah and the people, including the priests, committed many sins and defiled the temple.

Despite God's repeated warnings through his messengers, the people mocked and mistreated them until God's wrath was inevitable. Consequently, the king of the Chaldeans attacked, killing many and showing no mercy. He took all the valuable items from the temple and the king's house to Babylon, burned the temple, destroyed Jerusalem's walls, and took the survivors to Babylon as servants until the Persian kingdom rose to power.

This fulfilled the prophecy of Jeremiah, as the land enjoyed its sabbaths for 70 years while it lay desolate. In the first year of Cyrus, king of Persia, God stirred his spirit to proclaim throughout his kingdom that the Lord had given him all the kingdoms of the earth and charged him to build a house for Him in Jerusalem. Cyrus invited all of God's people to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple, offering them support with silver, gold, goods, and livestock.

The leaders of Judah and Benjamin, along with the priests and Levites, whose spirits God had moved, prepared to go and rebuild the temple. Their neighbors supported them with silver, gold, goods, livestock, and other valuable items. Cyrus also returned the temple vessels that Nebuchadnezzar had taken to Babylon, handing them over to Sheshbazzar, the prince of Judah.

The total number of gold and silver vessels was 5,400, and Sheshbazzar brought them all back to Jerusalem. The people who returned from captivity included the descendants of various families and towns, each returning to their own city. The list of returnees included leaders like Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, and others, along with their families and the priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants.The descendants of Shalmai, Hanan, Giddel, Gahar, Reaiah, Rezin, Nekoda, Gazzam, Uzza, Paseah, Besai, Asnah, Mehunim, Nephusim, Bakbuk, Hakupha, Harhur, Bazluth, Mehida, Harsha, Barkos, Sisera, Thamah, Neziah, and Hatipha were among those who returned. 

The descendants of Solomon's servants included the families of Sotai, Sophereth, Peruda, Jaalah, Darkon, Giddel, Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth of Zebaim, and Ami. In total, there were 392 Nethinims and descendants of Solomon's servants.

Some people from Telmelah, Telharsa, Cherub, Addan, and Immer couldn't prove their Israelite ancestry. This included the families of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda, totaling 652 people. Among the priests, the families of Habaiah, Koz, and Barzillai (who had married a daughter of Barzillai the Gileadite and took their name) couldn't find their genealogical records and were excluded from the priesthood. The governor told them not to eat the most holy food until a priest with Urim and Thummim could decide their status.

The entire assembly numbered 42,360, not including 7,337 servants and maids, and 200 singers. They had 736 horses, 245 mules, 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys. Some family leaders donated generously to the temple's construction, contributing 61,000 gold drachmas, 5,000 pounds of silver, and 100 priestly garments.

The priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants settled in their towns, and all Israel lived in their cities. In the seventh month, the Israelites gathered in Jerusalem. Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and his fellow priests, along with Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, built the altar of the God of Israel to offer burnt offerings as prescribed by Moses. Despite their fear of neighboring peoples, they offered burnt offerings morning and evening, celebrated the Feast of Tabernacles, and followed the daily offerings as required.

They began offering burnt offerings on the first day of the seventh month, even though the temple's foundation hadn't been laid. They paid masons and carpenters and provided food, drink, and oil to the people of Sidon and Tyre to bring cedar logs from Lebanon to Joppa, as authorized by Cyrus, king of Persia.

In the second month of the second year after their arrival in Jerusalem, Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the rest of the priests and Levites, along with all who had returned from captivity, began work on the temple. They appointed Levites aged 20 and older to oversee the work. Jeshua and his family, along with Kadmiel and the sons of Judah, supervised the workers. The Levites, including the sons of Henadad, joined them.

When the builders laid the temple's foundation, the priests in their robes, with trumpets, and the Levites, sons of Asaph, with cymbals, praised the Lord according to the instructions of King David. They sang in praise and thanks to the Lord, declaring His goodness and enduring mercy toward Israel. The people shouted with joy, but many older priests and Levites who had seen the first temple wept loudly. The noise of joy and weeping was so loud it could be heard from afar.

When the enemies of Judah and Benjamin heard that the returned exiles were rebuilding the temple, they approached Zerubbabel and the family leaders, offering to help. They claimed to worship the same God and had been sacrificing to Him since the days of Esarhaddon, king of Assyria. However, Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the other leaders refused their help, insisting they alone would build the temple as commanded by King Cyrus of Persia.

The local people then tried to discourage and intimidate the builders, hiring advisors to frustrate their plans throughout the reign of Cyrus until Darius became king of Persia. During the reign of Ahasuerus, they wrote an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem. In the days of Artaxerxes, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and their associates wrote a letter to the king in Aramaic, which was translated.

Rehum the commander and Shimshai the scribe wrote a letter against Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes, listing various officials and peoples who supported them. They warned the king that if Jerusalem was rebuilt and its walls restored, the city would not pay taxes, duties, or tolls, harming the royal revenue. They claimed to be loyal subjects and didn't want to see the king dishonored, so they urged him to search the records and find that Jerusalem had a history of rebellion and sedition, which led to its destruction.

King Artaxerxes responded, confirming the city's rebellious past and ordering the work to stop until he issued further commands. The letter was read to Rehum, Shimshai, and their associates, who then hurried to Jerusalem and forced the Jews to stop building by force. Thus, the work on the house of God in Jerusalem came to a halt.The construction of the temple in Jerusalem stopped until the second year of King Darius of Persia. During this time, the prophets Haggai and Zechariah encouraged the Jews in Judah and Jerusalem to continue building the temple in the name of the God of Israel. Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, son of Jozadak, resumed the construction with the help of the prophets.

Governor Tatnai and his companions questioned who had authorized the building of the temple and the wall. The Jewish elders responded that they were servants of the God of heaven and earth, rebuilding the temple that had been constructed many years ago by a great king of Israel. They explained that their ancestors had angered God, leading to their defeat by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, who destroyed the temple and exiled the people.

However, in the first year of King Cyrus of Babylon, he decreed the rebuilding of the temple and returned the gold and silver vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar. These were given to Sheshbazzar, whom Cyrus appointed as governor, and he laid the foundation of the temple, which had been under construction since then but was not yet finished.

The Jewish elders requested that King Darius search the royal archives in Babylon to confirm Cyrus's decree. King Darius ordered a search, and a scroll was found in the palace at Achmetha in the province of the Medes. The scroll confirmed that Cyrus had decreed the rebuilding of the temple, specifying its dimensions and that the expenses were to be covered by the royal treasury. The gold and silver vessels were to be returned to the temple in Jerusalem.

King Darius instructed Governor Tatnai and his companions to allow the Jews to continue their work without interference. He also decreed that the expenses for the construction be provided from the royal treasury and that the necessary animals and supplies for sacrifices be given to the priests daily. Anyone who altered this decree would be punished by having timber pulled from their house and being hanged on it, and their house would be made a dunghill. Darius prayed that God would destroy any king or people who tried to alter or destroy the temple.

Tatnai and his companions complied with King Darius's orders, and the Jewish elders continued building and prospered under the guidance of the prophets Haggai and Zechariah. They completed the temple according to the commands of God and the decrees of Cyrus, Darius, and Artaxerxes, kings of Persia.
