The temple was finished on the third day of the month of Adar in the sixth year of King Darius's reign.

The Israelites, including the priests, Levites, and those who had returned from captivity, joyfully dedicated the temple. They offered numerous sacrifices and set the priests and Levites in their divisions for temple service as prescribed in the book of Moses. They celebrated the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month, with the priests and Levites purified and offering the Passover lamb for all the returned exiles and their fellow priests. They also observed the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days with joy, as the Lord had made them joyful and turned the heart of the king of Assyria to support their work on the temple.

During the reign of King Artaxerxes of Persia, Ezra, a skilled scribe in the law of Moses, went up from Babylon to Jerusalem. The king granted him all his requests, and some Israelites, priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants accompanied him. They arrived in Jerusalem in the fifth month of the seventh year of King Artaxerxes's reign. Ezra had devoted himself to studying, practicing, and teaching the law of the Lord in Israel.

King Artaxerxes gave Ezra a letter authorizing him to lead any willing Israelites, priests, and Levites to Jerusalem. The letter also instructed Ezra to inquire about Judah and Jerusalem according to God's law and to carry silver and gold freely offered by the king and his counselors for the temple in Jerusalem. Ezra was to use the money to buy animals and offerings for the temple and to offer them on the altar.King Artaxerxes issued a decree allowing Ezra and his fellow Israelites to use the remaining silver and gold as they saw fit for the service of their God. He also instructed that any additional needs for the temple should be provided from the king's treasury. Artaxerxes commanded all treasurers beyond the river to fulfill any requests from Ezra, the priest and scribe, promptly. This included up to 100 talents of silver, 100 measures of wheat, 100 baths of wine, 100 baths of oil, and unlimited salt.

The king emphasized that everything commanded by the God of heaven should be done diligently to avoid any wrath against the king and his sons. He also declared that no taxes, tolls, or customs should be imposed on the priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, temple servants, or any ministers of the house of God.

Ezra was instructed to appoint magistrates and judges to govern the people beyond the river, teaching those who were unfamiliar with God's laws. Anyone who disobeyed these laws or the king's laws was to be punished swiftly, whether by death, banishment, confiscation of goods, or imprisonment.

Ezra praised the Lord, the God of their ancestors, for inspiring the king to beautify the house of the Lord in Jerusalem and for showing mercy to him before the king and his counselors. Strengthened by God's support, Ezra gathered leading men from Israel to accompany him.

Ezra listed the heads of families and their genealogies who traveled with him from Babylon during King Artaxerxes's reign. They camped by the river Ahava for three days, where Ezra reviewed the people and priests but found no Levites. He sent for leaders and men of understanding to bring ministers for the house of God. By God's grace, they brought a man of understanding from the descendants of Mahli, along with others, totaling 220 temple servants.

Ezra proclaimed a fast by the river Ahava to seek God's guidance and protection for their journey, as he was ashamed to ask the king for soldiers, having declared that God's hand was upon those who sought Him. They fasted and prayed, and God answered their prayers.

Ezra then entrusted twelve leading priests with the silver, gold, and vessels offered for the house of God, weighing them carefully. He reminded them that they and the offerings were holy to the Lord and instructed them to guard these items until they were weighed before the chief priests and Levites in Jerusalem.

They departed from the river Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month, and God protected them from enemies along the way. Upon arriving in Jerusalem, they rested for three days. On the fourth day, they weighed the silver, gold, and vessels in the house of God, recording the weights. The returned exiles offered burnt offerings to God, including bulls, rams, lambs, and goats.

They delivered the king's orders to the king's lieutenants and governors, who supported the people and the house of God.

After these events, the leaders informed Ezra that the Israelites, including priests and Levites, had not separated themselves from the local peoples and their abominations. They had intermarried with the Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites, Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, and Amorites, with the leaders and officials being the worst offenders.

Ezra was deeply distressed upon hearing this and tore his garments, pulled out his hair, and sat in shock. Those who trembled at God's words gathered around him. At the evening sacrifice, Ezra rose from his mourning, fell to his knees, and spread out his hands to God, confessing the people's sins and expressing shame for their iniquities, which had led to their current suffering.

Despite their sins, God had shown them mercy, allowing a remnant to return and rebuild the temple. Ezra acknowledged that they had forsaken God's commandments, which warned against mingling with the unclean peoples of the land."Do not give your daughters to their sons or take their daughters for your sons. Do not seek their peace or prosperity forever, so that you may be strong, enjoy the good of the land, and leave it as an inheritance for your children forever. 

After all the punishment we have faced for our evil deeds and great sins, you, our God, have punished us less than we deserve and have given us this deliverance. Should we then break your commandments again and intermarry with these people who commit abominations? Would you not be angry with us until you have destroyed us, leaving no remnant or escape? 

O Lord God of Israel, you are righteous. We are left as a remnant, as it is today. We stand before you in our sins, for we cannot stand before you because of them.

When Ezra prayed and confessed, weeping and throwing himself down before the house of God, a large assembly of men, women, and children from Israel gathered around him, weeping bitterly. Shechaniah, son of Jehiel, from the descendants of Elam, spoke up and said to Ezra, 'We have been unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign women from the peoples around us. But in spite of this, there is still hope for Israel. Let us make a covenant with our God to send away all these women and their children, according to the counsel of my lord and those who tremble at the command of our God. Let it be done according to the Law. Rise up; this matter is in your hands. We will support you, so take courage and do it.'

Ezra then made the leading priests, Levites, and all Israel take an oath to do what had been suggested, and they took the oath. Ezra withdrew from before the house of God and went to the room of Jehohanan, son of Eliashib. While he was there, he ate no food and drank no water because he continued to mourn over the unfaithfulness of the exiles.

A proclamation was then issued throughout Judah and Jerusalem for all the exiles to assemble in Jerusalem. Anyone who failed to appear within three days would forfeit all his property and be expelled from the assembly of the exiles. 

Within three days, all the men of Judah and Benjamin had gathered in Jerusalem. On the twentieth day of the ninth month, all the people were sitting in the square before the house of God, greatly distressed by the occasion and because of the rain. Then Ezra the priest stood up and said to them, 'You have been unfaithful; you have married foreign women, adding to Israel's guilt. Now honor the Lord, the God of your ancestors, and do his will. Separate yourselves from the peoples around you and from your foreign wives.'

The whole assembly responded with a loud voice, 'You are right! We must do as you say. But there are many people here and it is the rainy season, so we cannot stand outside. Besides, this matter cannot be taken care of in a day or two, because we have sinned greatly in this thing. Let our officials act for the whole assembly. Then let everyone in our towns who has married a foreign woman come at a set time, along with the elders and judges of each town, until the fierce anger of our God in this matter is turned away from us.' 

Only Jonathan son of Asahel and Jahzeiah son of Tikvah opposed this, supported by Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite. So the exiles did as was proposed. Ezra the priest selected men who were family heads, one from each family division, and all of them designated by name. On the first day of the tenth month, they sat down to investigate the cases, and by the first day of the first month, they finished dealing with all the men who had married foreign women.

Among the descendants of the priests, the following had married foreign women: from the descendants of Jeshua son of Jozadak and his brothers, Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah. They all gave their hands in pledge to put away their wives, and for their guilt, they each presented a ram from the flock as a guilt offering.

From the descendants of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah. From the descendants of Harim: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah. From the descendants of Pashhur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethanel, Jozabad, and Elasah.

Among the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also called Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer. From the musicians: Eliashib. From the gatekeepers: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.

And among the other Israelites: from the descendants of Parosh: Ramiah, Izziah, Malchijah, Mijamin, Eleazar, Malchijah, and Benaiah. From the descendants of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Elijah. From the descendants of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza. From the descendants of Bebai: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai. From the descendants of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Ramoth. From the descendants of Pahath-Moab: Adna, Kelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezalel, Binnui, and Manasseh. From the descendants of Harim: Eliezer, Ishijah, Malchijah, Shemaiah, Shimeon, Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah. From the descendants of Hashum: Mattenai, Mattattah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei. From the descendants of Bani: Maadai, Amram, Uel, Benaiah, Bedeiah, Keluhi, Vaniah, Meremoth, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Mattenai, and Jaasau. From the descendants of Binnui: Shimei, Shelemiah, Nathan, Adaiah, Machnadebai, Shashai, Sharai, Azarel, Shelemiah, Shemariah, Shallum, Amariah, and Joseph. From the descendants of Nebo: Jeiel, Mattithiah, Zabad, Zebina, Jaddai, Joel, and Benaiah. All these had married foreign women, and some of them had children by these wives.

The Book of Nehemiah

The words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah:

In the month of Kislev in the twentieth year, while I was in the citadel of Susa, Hanani, one of my brothers, came from Judah with some other men, and I questioned them about the Jewish remnant that had survived the exile, and also about Jerusalem. They said to me, 'Those who survived the exile and are back in the province are in great trouble and disgrace. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates have been burned with fire.'

When I heard these things, I sat down and wept. For some days I mourned and fasted and prayed before the God of heaven. Then I said:

'Lord, the God of heaven, the great and awesome God, who keeps his covenant of love with those who love him and keep his commandments, let your ear be attentive and your eyes open to hear the prayer your servant is praying before you day and night for your servants, the people of Israel. I confess the sins we Israelites, including myself and my father's family, have committed against you. We have acted very wickedly toward you. We have not obeyed the commands, decrees, and laws you gave your servant Moses.

Remember the instruction you gave your servant Moses, saying, "If you are unfaithful, I will scatter you among the nations, but if you return to me and obey my commands, then even if your exiled people are at the farthest horizon, I will gather them from there and bring them to the place I have chosen as a dwelling for my Name."

They are your servants and your people, whom you redeemed by your great strength and your mighty hand. Lord, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of this your servant and to the prayer of your servants who delight in revering your name. Give your servant success today by granting him favor in the presence of this man.'

I was cupbearer to the king.

In the month of Nisan in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when wine was brought for him, I took the wine and gave it to the king. I had not been sad in his presence before, so the king asked me, 'Why does your face look so sad when you are not ill? This can be nothing but sadness of heart.'

I was very much afraid, but I said to the king, 'May the king live forever! Why should my face not look sad when the city where my ancestors are buried lies in ruins, and its gates have been destroyed by fire?'

The king said to me, 'What is it you want?'

Then I prayed to the God of heaven, and I answered the king, 'If it pleases the king and if your servant has found favor in his sight, let him send me to the city in Judah where my ancestors are buried so that I can rebuild it.'

Then the king, with the queen sitting beside him, asked me, 'How long will your journey take, and when will you get back?' It pleased the king to send me, so I set a time.

I also said to him, 'If it pleases the king, may I have letters to the governors of Trans-Euphrates, so that they will provide me safe-conduct until I arrive in Judah? And may I have a letter to Asaph, keeper of the royal park, so he will give me timber to make beams for the gates of the citadel by the temple and for the city wall and for the residence I will occupy?' And because the gracious hand of my God was on me, the king granted my requests."With God's favor, I delivered the king's letters to the governors beyond the river. The king had also sent army officers and cavalry with me. When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about this, they were very upset that someone had come to help the Israelites.

After arriving in Jerusalem, I stayed there for three days. Then, at night, I took a few men with me and didn't tell anyone what God had put in my heart to do for Jerusalem. We had no animals with us except the one I was riding.

I went out at night through the Valley Gate toward the Dragon Well and the Dung Gate, inspecting the broken walls of Jerusalem and its burned gates. Then I moved on to the Fountain Gate and the King's Pool, but there was no room for my mount to get through. So I went up the valley by night, examining the wall. Finally, I turned back and re-entered through the Valley Gate.

The officials did not know where I had gone or what I was doing, because I had not yet told the Jews, the priests, the nobles, the officials, or any others who would be doing the work. Then I said to them, "You see the trouble we are in: Jerusalem lies in ruins, and its gates have been burned with fire. Come, let us rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, and we will no longer be in disgrace." I also told them about the gracious hand of my God on me and what the king had said to me.

They replied, "Let us start rebuilding." So they began this good work. But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard about it, they mocked and ridiculed us. "What is this you are doing?" they asked. "Are you rebelling against the king?"

I answered them by saying, "The God of heaven will give us success. We, his servants, will start rebuilding, but as for you, you have no share in Jerusalem or any claim or historic right to it."

Eliashib the high priest and his fellow priests went to work and rebuilt the Sheep Gate. They dedicated it and set its doors in place, building as far as the Tower of the Hundred, which they dedicated, and as far as the Tower of Hananel. The men of Jericho built the adjoining section, and Zaccur son of Imri built next to them.

The Fish Gate was rebuilt by the sons of Hassenaah. They laid its beams and put its doors and bolts and bars in place. Meremoth son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, repaired the next section. Next to him, Meshullam son of Berekiah, the son of Meshezabel, made repairs, and next to him, Zadok son of Baana also made repairs. The next section was repaired by the men of Tekoa, but their nobles would not put their shoulders to the work under their supervisors.

The Jeshanah Gate was repaired by Joiada son of Paseah and Meshullam son of Besodeiah. They laid its beams and put its doors with their bolts and bars in place. Next to them, repairs were made by men from Gibeon and Mizpah—Melatiah of Gibeon and Jadon of Meronoth—places under the authority of the governor of Trans-Euphrates. Uzziel son of Harhaiah, one of the goldsmiths, repaired the next section; and Hananiah, one of the perfume-makers, made repairs next to that. They restored Jerusalem as far as the Broad Wall. Rephaiah son of Hur, ruler of a half-district of Jerusalem, repaired the next section. Adjoining this, Jedaiah son of Harumaph made repairs opposite his house, and Hattush son of Hashabneiah made repairs next to him.

Malkijah son of Harim and Hasshub son of Pahath-Moab repaired another section and the Tower of the Ovens. Shallum son of Hallohesh, ruler of a half-district of Jerusalem, repaired the next section with the help of his daughters.

The Valley Gate was repaired by Hanun and the residents of Zanoah. They rebuilt it and put its doors with their bolts and bars in place. They also repaired a thousand cubits of the wall as far as the Dung Gate. The Dung Gate was repaired by Malkijah son of Rekab, ruler of the district of Beth Hakkerem. He rebuilt it and put its doors with their bolts and bars in place.

The Fountain Gate was repaired by Shallun son of Kol-Hozeh, ruler of the district of Mizpah. He rebuilt it, roofing it over and putting its doors and bolts and bars in place. He also repaired the wall of the Pool of Siloam, by the King's Garden, as far as the steps going down from the City of David. Beyond him, Nehemiah son of Azbuk, ruler of a half-district of Beth Zur, made repairs up to a point opposite the tombs of David, as far as the artificial pool and the House of the Heroes.

Next to him, the repairs were made by the Levites under Rehum son of Bani. Beside him, Hashabiah, ruler of half the district of Keilah, carried out repairs for his district. Next to him, the repairs were made by their fellow Levites under Binnui son of Henadad, ruler of the other half-district of Keilah. Next to him, Ezer son of Jeshua, ruler of Mizpah, repaired another section, from a point facing the ascent to the armory as far as the angle of the wall.

Baruch son of Zabbai zealously repaired another section, from the angle to the entrance of the house of Eliashib the high priest. Next to him, Meremoth son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, repaired another section, from the entrance of Eliashib's house to the end of it. The repairs next to him were made by the priests from the surrounding region. Beyond them, Benjamin and Hasshub made repairs in front of their house; and next to them, Azariah son of Maaseiah, the son of Ananiah, made repairs beside his house. Next to him, Binnui son of Henadad repaired another section, from Azariah's house to the angle and the corner, and Palal son of Uzai worked opposite the angle and the tower projecting from the upper palace near the court of the guard. Next to him, Pedaiah son of Parosh and the temple servants living on the hill of Ophel made repairs up to a point opposite the Water Gate toward the east and the projecting tower. Next to them, the men of Tekoa repaired another section, from the great projecting tower to the wall of Ophel.

Above the Horse Gate, the priests made repairs, each in front of his own house. Next to them, Zadok son of Immer made repairs opposite his house. Next to him, Shemaiah son of Shekaniah, the guard at the East Gate, made repairs. Next to him, Hananiah son of Shelemiah and Hanun, the sixth son of Zalaph, repaired another section. Next to them, Meshullam son of Berekiah made repairs opposite his living quarters. Next to him, Malkijah, one of the goldsmiths, made repairs as far as the house of the temple servants and the merchants, opposite the Inspection Gate, and as far as the room above the corner; and between the room above the corner and the Sheep Gate, the goldsmiths and merchants made repairs.

When Sanballat heard that we were rebuilding the wall, he became angry and was greatly incensed. He ridiculed the Jews, and in the presence of his associates and the army of Samaria, he said, "What are those feeble Jews doing? Will they restore their wall? Will they offer sacrifices? Will they finish in a day? Can they bring the stones back to life from those heaps of rubble—burned as they are?"

Tobiah the Ammonite, who was at his side, said, "What they are building—even a fox climbing up on it would break down their wall of stones!"

Hear us, our God, for we are despised. Turn their insults back on their own heads. Give them over as plunder in a land of captivity. Do not cover up their guilt or blot out their sins from your sight, for they have thrown insults in the face of the builders.

So we rebuilt the wall till all of it reached half its height, for the people worked with all their heart. But when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people of Ashdod heard that the repairs to Jerusalem's walls had gone ahead and that the gaps were being closed, they were very angry. They all plotted together to come and fight against Jerusalem and stir up trouble against it. But we prayed to our God and posted a guard day and night to meet this threat.

Meanwhile, the people in Judah said, "The strength of the laborers is giving out, and there is so much rubble that we cannot rebuild the wall."

Also, our enemies said, "Before they know it or see us, we will be right there among them and will kill them and put an end to the work."

Then the Jews who lived near them came and told us ten times over, "Wherever you turn, they will attack us."

Therefore I stationed some of the people behind the lowest points of the wall at the exposed places, posting them by families, with their swords, spears, and bows. After I looked things over, I stood up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, "Don't be afraid of them. Remember the Lord, who is great and awesome, and fight for your families, your sons and your daughters, your wives and your homes."

When our enemies heard that we were aware of their plot and that God had frustrated it, we all returned to the wall, each to our own work. From that day on, half of my men did the work, while the other half were equipped with spears, shields, bows, and armor. The officers posted themselves behind all the people of Judah who were building the wall. Those who carried materials did their work with one hand and held a weapon in the other.Each worker carried materials with one hand and held a weapon with the other. The builders had their swords strapped to their sides as they worked, and the trumpeter stayed with me. I told the nobles, officials, and the rest of the people, "The work is extensive and we are spread out along the wall. Whenever you hear the sound of the trumpet, join us there. Our God will fight for us."

We worked from dawn until the stars appeared, with half the men holding spears. I also instructed the people to stay inside Jerusalem at night to serve as guards and work during the day. None of us, including my brothers, servants, and guards, took off our clothes except for washing.

There was a great outcry from the people and their wives against their fellow Jews. Some said, "We need grain to eat and stay alive." Others said, "We have mortgaged our fields, vineyards, and homes to buy grain during the famine." Still others said, "We have borrowed money to pay the king's tax on our fields and vineyards. We are as good as our fellow Jews, but we have to sell our sons and daughters into slavery. Some of our daughters are already enslaved, and we can't do anything because our fields and vineyards belong to others."

I was very angry when I heard their complaints. After thinking it over, I confronted the nobles and officials, accusing them of charging interest to their own people. I called a large assembly and said, "We have bought back our fellow Jews who were sold to foreigners, but now you are selling your own people, only for them to be sold back to us!" They were silent and couldn't find anything to say.

I continued, "What you are doing is not right. Shouldn't you walk in the fear of our God to avoid the reproach of our enemies? I, my brothers, and my men are also lending the people money and grain. But let us stop charging interest. Give back to them immediately their fields, vineyards, olive groves, and houses, and also the interest you are charging them—one percent of the money, grain, new wine, and olive oil."

They agreed to give everything back and not demand anything more from the people. I summoned the priests and made the nobles and officials take an oath to do what they had promised. I also shook out the folds of my robe and said, "In this way, may God shake out of their house and possessions anyone who does not keep this promise." The whole assembly responded, "Amen," and praised the Lord. And the people did as they had promised.

From the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when I was appointed to be their governor in the land of Judah, until his thirty-second year—twelve years—neither I nor my brothers ate the food allotted to the governor. But the earlier governors—those preceding me—placed a heavy burden on the people and took forty shekels of silver from them in addition to food and wine. Their assistants also lorded it over the people. But out of reverence for God, I did not act like that. Instead, I devoted myself to the work on this wall. All my men were assembled there for the work; we did not acquire any land.

Furthermore, a hundred and fifty Jews and officials ate at my table, as well as those who came to us from the surrounding nations. Each day, one ox, six choice sheep, and some poultry were prepared for me, and every ten days an abundant supply of wine of all kinds. Despite all this, I never demanded the food allotted to the governor, because the demands were heavy on these people.

Remember me with favor, my God, for all I have done for these people.

When Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and the rest of our enemies heard that I had rebuilt the wall and not a gap was left in it—though up to that time I had not set the doors in the gates—Sanballat and Geshem sent me this message: "Come, let us meet together in one of the villages on the plain of Ono." But they were scheming to harm me; so I sent messengers to them with this reply: "I am carrying on a great project and cannot go down. Why should the work stop while I leave it and go down to you?"

Four times they sent me the same message, and each time I gave them the same answer. Then, the fifth time, Sanballat sent his aide to me with the same message, and in his hand was an unsealed letter in which was written: "It is reported among the nations—and Geshem says it is true—that you and the Jews are plotting to revolt, and therefore you are building the wall. Moreover, according to these reports, you are about to become their king and have even appointed prophets to make this proclamation about you in Jerusalem: 'There is a king in Judah!' Now this report will get back to the king; so come, let us meet together."

I sent him this reply: "Nothing like what you are saying is happening; you are just making it up out of your head." They were all trying to frighten us, thinking, "Their hands will get too weak for the work, and it will not be completed." But I prayed, "Now strengthen my hands."

One day I went to the house of Shemaiah son of Delaiah, the son of Mehetabel, who was shut in at his home. He said, "Let us meet in the house of God, inside the temple, and let us close the temple doors, because men are coming to kill you—by night they are coming to kill you."

But I said, "Should a man like me run away? Or should someone like me go into the temple to save his life? I will not go!" I realized that God had not sent him, but that he had prophesied against me because Tobiah and Sanballat had hired him. He had been hired to intimidate me so that I would commit a sin by doing this, and then they would give me a bad name to discredit me.

Remember Tobiah and Sanballat, my God, because of what they have done; remember also the prophet Noadiah and how she and the rest of the prophets have been trying to intimidate me.

So the wall was completed on the twenty-fifth of Elul, in fifty-two days. When all our enemies heard about this, all the surrounding nations were afraid and lost their self-confidence because they realized that this work had been done with the help of our God.

Also in those days, the nobles of Judah were sending many letters to Tobiah, and replies from Tobiah kept coming to them. For many in Judah were under oath to him, since he was the son-in-law to Shekaniah son of Arah, and his son Jehohanan had married the daughter of Meshullam son of Berekiah. Moreover, they kept reporting to me his good deeds and then telling him what I said. And Tobiah sent letters to intimidate me.

After the wall had been rebuilt and I had set the doors in place, the gatekeepers, the musicians, and the Levites were appointed. I put in charge of Jerusalem my brother Hanani, along with Hananiah the commander of the citadel, because he was a man of integrity and feared God more than most people do. I said to them, "The gates of Jerusalem are not to be opened until the sun is hot. While the gatekeepers are still on duty, have them shut the doors and bar them. Also appoint residents of Jerusalem as guards, some at their posts and some near their own houses."

The city was large and spacious, but there were few people in it, and the houses had not yet been rebuilt. So my God put it into my heart to assemble the nobles, the officials, and the common people for registration by families. I found the genealogical record of those who had been the first to return. This is what I found written there:

These are the people of the province who came up from the captivity of the exiles whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had taken captive. They returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each to their own town, in company with Zerubbabel, Joshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, and Baanah.

The list of the men of Israel:

The descendants of Parosh, 2,172
of Shephatiah, 372
of Arah, 652
of Pahath-Moab (through the line of Jeshua and Joab), 2,818
of Elam, 1,254
of Zattu, 845
of Zaccai, 760
of Binnui, 648
of Bebai, 628
of Azgad, 2,322
of Adonikam, 667
of Bigvai, 2,067
of Adin, 655
of Ater (through Hezekiah), 98
of Hashum, 328
of Bezai, 324The descendants of Hariph were 112. The people of Gibeon were 95. The men of Bethlehem and Netophah were 188. The men of Anathoth were 128. The men of Bethazmaveth were 42. The men of Kirjathjearim, Chephirah, and Beeroth were 743. The men of Ramah and Gaba were 621. The men of Michmas were 122. The men of Bethel and Ai were 123. The men of the other Nebo were 52. The descendants of the other Elam were 1,254. The descendants of Harim were 320. The descendants of Jericho were 345. The descendants of Lod, Hadid, and Ono were 721. The descendants of Senaah were 3,930.

The priests: the descendants of Jedaiah, from the house of Jeshua, were 973. The descendants of Immer were 1,052. The descendants of Pashur were 1,247. The descendants of Harim were 1,017.

The Levites: the descendants of Jeshua, of Kadmiel, and of the descendants of Hodevah were 74.

The singers: the descendants of Asaph were 148.

The gatekeepers: the descendants of Shallum, Ater, Talmon, Akkub, Hatita, and Shobai were 138.

The temple servants: the descendants of Ziha, Hashupha, Tabbaoth, Keros, Sia, Padon, Lebana, Hagaba, Shalmai, Hanan, Giddel, Gahar, Reaiah, Rezin, Nekoda, Gazzam, Uzza, Phaseah, Besai, Meunim, Nephishesim, Bakbuk, Hakupha, Harhur, Bazlith, Mehida, Harsha, Barkos, Sisera, Tamah, Neziah, and Hatipha.

The descendants of Solomon's servants: the descendants of Sotai, Sophereth, Perida, Jaala, Darkon, Giddel, Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth of Zebaim, and Amon. All the temple servants and the descendants of Solomon's servants were 392.

These were the people who came up from Telmelah, Telharesha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer, but they could not prove their family lineage or whether they were of Israel. The descendants of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda were 642. Among the priests: the descendants of Habaiah, Koz, and Barzillai, who had married a daughter of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by their name. These searched for their family records but could not find them, so they were excluded from the priesthood as unclean. The governor ordered them not to eat any of the most sacred food until a priest ministering with Urim and Thummim could be found.

The whole assembly together was 42,360, besides their 7,337 male and female servants, and they also had 245 male and female singers. They had 736 horses, 245 mules, 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys.

Some of the family heads contributed to the work. The governor gave to the treasury 1,000 darics of gold, 50 bowls, and 530 garments for priests. Some of the family heads gave to the treasury for the work 20,000 darics of gold and 2,200 minas of silver. The rest of the people gave 20,000 darics of gold, 2,000 minas of silver, and 67 garments for priests.

The priests, Levites, gatekeepers, musicians, temple servants, and some of the people, along with the rest of Israel, settled in their own towns. When the seventh month came and the Israelites had settled in their towns, all the people assembled as one in the square before the Water Gate. They told Ezra the teacher of the Law to bring out the Book of the Law of Moses, which the Lord had commanded for Israel.

So on the first day of the seventh month, Ezra the priest brought the Law before the assembly, which was made up of men and women and all who were able to understand. He read it aloud from daybreak till noon as he faced the square before the Water Gate in the presence of the men, women, and others who could understand. And all the people listened attentively to the Book of the Law.

Ezra the teacher of the Law stood on a high wooden platform built for the occasion. Beside him on his right stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Uriah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah; and on his left were Pedaiah, Mishael, Malkijah, Hashum, Hashbaddanah, Zechariah, and Meshullam. Ezra opened the book. All the people could see him because he was standing above them; and as he opened it, the people all stood up. Ezra praised the Lord, the great God; and all the people lifted their hands and responded, "Amen! Amen!" Then they bowed down and worshiped the Lord with their faces to the ground.

The Levites—Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodiah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, and Pelaiah—instructed the people in the Law while the people were standing there. They read from the Book of the Law of God, making it clear and giving the meaning so that the people understood what was being read.

Then Nehemiah the governor, Ezra the priest and teacher of the Law, and the Levites who were instructing the people said to them all, "This day is holy to the Lord your God. Do not mourn or weep." For all the people had been weeping as they listened to the words of the Law. Nehemiah said, "Go and enjoy choice food and sweet drinks, and send some to those who have nothing prepared. This day is holy to our Lord. Do not grieve, for the joy of the Lord is your strength."

The Levites calmed all the people, saying, "Be still, for this is a holy day. Do not grieve." Then all the people went away to eat and drink, to send portions of food and to celebrate with great joy, because they now understood the words that had been made known to them.

On the second day of the month, the heads of all the families, along with the priests and the Levites, gathered around Ezra the teacher to give attention to the words of the Law. They found written in the Law, which the Lord had commanded through Moses, that the Israelites were to live in temporary shelters during the festival of the seventh month and that they should proclaim this word and spread it throughout their towns and in Jerusalem: "Go out into the hill country and bring back branches from olive and wild olive trees, and from myrtles, palms, and shade trees, to make temporary shelters—as it is written."

So the people went out and brought back branches and built themselves temporary shelters on their own roofs, in their courtyards, in the courts of the house of God, and in the square by the Water Gate and the one by the Gate of Ephraim. The whole company that had returned from exile built temporary shelters and lived in them. From the days of Joshua son of Nun until that day, the Israelites had not celebrated it like this. And their joy was very great.

Day after day, from the first day to the last, Ezra read from the Book of the Law of God. They celebrated the festival for seven days, and on the eighth day, in accordance with the regulation, there was an assembly.

On the twenty-fourth day of the same month, the Israelites gathered together, fasting and wearing sackcloth and putting dust on their heads. Those of Israelite descent had separated themselves from all foreigners. They stood in their places and confessed their sins and the sins of their ancestors. They stood where they were and read from the Book of the Law of the Lord their God for a quarter of the day and spent another quarter in confession and in worshiping the Lord their God. Standing on the stairs of the Levites were Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Kenani. They cried out with loud voices to the Lord their God. And the Levites—Jeshua, Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabneiah, Sherebiah, Hodiah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—said: "Stand up and praise the Lord your God, who is from everlasting to everlasting. Blessed be your glorious name, and may it be exalted above all blessing and praise. You alone are the Lord. You made the heavens, even the highest heavens, and all their starry host, the earth and all that is on it, the seas and all that is in them. You give life to everything, and the multitudes of heaven worship you. You are the Lord God, who chose Abram and brought him out of Ur of the Chaldeans and named him Abraham. You found his heart faithful to you, and you made a covenant with him to give to his descendants the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Jebusites, and Girgashites.""You kept your promise to give the land to Abraham's descendants because you are righteous. You saw the suffering of our ancestors in Egypt and heard their cries at the Red Sea. You performed miracles against Pharaoh and his people because you knew they treated us arrogantly. You made a name for yourself that endures to this day. You parted the sea for our ancestors to cross on dry land, and you threw their pursuers into the depths like a stone in mighty waters. You led them by a pillar of cloud during the day and a pillar of fire at night to show them the way.

You came down on Mount Sinai and spoke to them from heaven, giving them just laws and true commandments. You made your holy Sabbath known to them and gave them laws through Moses. You provided bread from heaven for their hunger and water from a rock for their thirst. You promised them the land you swore to give them.

But our ancestors were arrogant and stubborn, ignoring your commandments. They refused to obey and forgot the miracles you performed among them. In their rebellion, they appointed a leader to return to their slavery. But you are a forgiving, gracious, and merciful God, slow to anger and full of kindness. You did not abandon them, even when they made a golden calf and said, 'This is your god who brought you out of Egypt,' committing great blasphemies.

In your great mercy, you did not forsake them in the wilderness. The pillar of cloud continued to lead them by day, and the pillar of fire by night. You gave them your good spirit to instruct them and did not withhold manna from their mouths or water for their thirst. For forty years, you sustained them in the wilderness; they lacked nothing, their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell.

You gave them kingdoms and nations, dividing them among the tribes. They took possession of the land of Sihon, the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og, king of Bashan. You made their descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and brought them into the land you promised their ancestors. They went in and took possession of the land, subduing its inhabitants, the Canaanites, and capturing fortified cities and fertile land. They enjoyed houses filled with all kinds of good things, wells already dug, vineyards, olive groves, and fruit trees in abundance. They ate, were satisfied, and delighted in your great goodness.

Despite this, they were disobedient and rebelled against you, casting your law behind their backs and killing your prophets who warned them to return to you. They committed great blasphemies. So you handed them over to their enemies, who oppressed them. But in their time of trouble, when they cried out to you, you heard from heaven and in your great mercy, you sent deliverers who rescued them from their enemies.

But as soon as they were at rest, they did evil again before you. So you abandoned them to their enemies, who ruled over them. Yet when they turned back and cried out to you, you heard from heaven and delivered them many times in your mercy. You warned them to return to your law, but they were arrogant and disobedient, sinning against your judgments. They turned their backs on you, stiffened their necks, and refused to listen.

For many years, you were patient with them. By your spirit, you warned them through your prophets, but they would not listen. So you handed them over to the peoples of the lands. Yet in your great mercy, you did not destroy them completely or abandon them, for you are a gracious and merciful God.

Now, our God, the great, mighty, and awesome God, who keeps his covenant of love, do not let all this hardship seem insignificant to you—the hardship that has come upon us, our kings, leaders, priests, prophets, ancestors, and all your people, from the days of the kings of Assyria until today. In all that has happened to us, you have remained righteous; you have acted faithfully, while we acted wickedly. Our kings, leaders, priests, and ancestors did not follow your law; they did not pay attention to your commands or the statutes you warned them to keep. Even while they were in their kingdom, enjoying your great goodness, in the spacious and fertile land you gave them, they did not serve you or turn from their evil ways.

But see, we are slaves today, slaves in the land you gave our ancestors so they could eat its fruit and the other good things it produces. Because of our sins, its abundant harvest goes to the kings you have placed over us. They rule over our bodies and our cattle as they please. We are in great distress.

In view of all this, we are making a binding agreement, putting it in writing, and our leaders, Levites, and priests are affixing their seals to it."The leaders of the people lived in Jerusalem, while the rest of the people cast lots to bring one out of every ten to live in Jerusalem, the holy city, and the other nine to live in other cities. The people praised all the men who willingly offered to live in Jerusalem. Here are the leaders who lived in Jerusalem: in the cities of Judah, everyone lived in their own property, including Israel, the priests, the Levites, the temple servants, and the descendants of Solomon's servants.

In Jerusalem, some of the descendants of Judah and Benjamin lived. From Judah's descendants: Athaiah, son of Uzziah, son of Zechariah, son of Amariah, son of Shephatiah, son of Mahalaleel, from the descendants of Perez; and Maaseiah, son of Baruch, son of Colhozeh, son of Hazaiah, son of Adaiah, son of Joiarib, son of Zechariah, son of Shiloni. The total number of Perez's descendants living in Jerusalem was 468 brave men.

From Benjamin's descendants: Sallu, son of Meshullam, son of Joed, son of Pedaiah, son of Kolaiah, son of Maaseiah, son of Ithiel, son of Jesaiah, and after him Gabbai and Sallai, totaling 928. Joel, son of Zichri, was their overseer, and Judah, son of Senuah, was second in command over the city.

From the priests: Jedaiah, son of Joiarib, Jachin, and Seraiah, son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, who was the ruler of the house of God. Their associates, who did the work of the temple, numbered 822. Adaiah, son of Jeroham, son of Pelaliah, son of Amzi, son of Zechariah, son of Pashur, son of Malchiah, and his associates, the leaders of families, numbered 242. Amashai, son of Azareel, son of Ahasai, son of Meshillemoth, son of Immer, and his associates, who were brave men, numbered 128. Their overseer was Zabdiel, son of Haggedolim.

From the Levites: Shemaiah, son of Hashub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, son of Bunni; and Shabbethai and Jozabad, who were in charge of the outside work of the house of God. Mattaniah, son of Mika, son of Zabdi, son of Asaph, was the leader who began the thanksgiving in prayer, and Bakbukiah was second among his associates, and Abda, son of Shammua, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun. The total number of Levites in the holy city was 284.

The gatekeepers: Akkub, Talmon, and their associates, who kept the gates, numbered 172. The rest of Israel, including the priests and Levites, lived in all the cities of Judah, each on their own property. The temple servants lived in Ophel, and Ziha and Gishpa were in charge of them.

The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi, son of Bani, son of Hashabiah, son of Mattaniah, son of Mika, from the descendants of Asaph, who were the singers responsible for the service of the house of God. The king had commanded that a daily portion be given to the singers. Pethahiah, son of Meshezabeel, from the descendants of Zerah, son of Judah, was the king's advisor in all matters concerning the people.

For the villages with their fields, some of the descendants of Judah lived in Kiriath Arba and its surrounding villages, in Dibon and its surrounding villages, in Jekabzeel and its surrounding villages, in Jeshua, Moladah, Beth Pelet, Hazar Shual, Beersheba and its surrounding villages, in Ziklag, Meconah and its surrounding villages, in En Rimmon, Zorah, Jarmuth, Zanoah, Adullam and their villages, in Lachish and its fields, and in Azekah and its surrounding villages. They lived from Beersheba to the Valley of Hinnom.

The descendants of Benjamin lived in Geba, Michmash, Aija, Bethel and its surrounding villages, in Anathoth, Nob, Ananiah, Hazor, Ramah, Gittaim, Hadid, Zeboim, Neballat, Lod, and Ono, the Valley of Craftsmen. Some of the Levites were in divisions in Judah and Benjamin.

These are the priests and Levites who returned with Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua: Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra, Amariah, Malluch, Hattush, Shekaniah, Rehum, Meremoth, Iddo, Ginnethon, Abijah, Mijamin, Maadiah, Bilgah, Shemaiah, Joiarib, Jedaiah, Sallu, Amok, Hilkiah, and Jedaiah. These were the leaders of the priests and their associates in the days of Jeshua.

The Levites: Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah, and Mattaniah, who was in charge of the thanksgiving songs, and his associates. Bakbukiah and Unni, their associates, stood opposite them in the services. Jeshua was the father of Joiakim, Joiakim was the father of Eliashib, Eliashib was the father of Joiada, Joiada was the father of Jonathan, and Jonathan was the father of Jaddua.

In the days of Joiakim, these were the leaders of the priestly families: from Seraiah's family, Meraiah; from Jeremiah's family, Hananiah; from Ezra's family, Meshullam; from Amariah's family, Jehohanan; from Malluch's family, Jonathan; from Shekaniah's family, Joseph; from Harim's family, Adna; from Meraioth's family, Helkai; from Iddo's family, Zechariah; from Ginnethon's family, Meshullam; from Abijah's family, Zichri; from Miniamin's family, Piltai; from Moadiah's family, Piltai; from Bilgah's family, Shammua; from Shemaiah's family, Jehonathan; from Joiarib's family, Mattenai; from Jedaiah's family, Uzzi; from Sallu's family, Kallai; from Amok's family, Eber; from Hilkiah's family, Hashabiah; from Jedaiah's family, Nethanel.

The leaders of the Levites in the days of Eliashib, Joiada, Johanan, and Jaddua were recorded in the book of the chronicles up to the reign of Darius the Persian. The leaders of the Levites were Hashabiah, Sherebiah, Jeshua, son of Kadmiel, and their associates, who stood opposite them to give praise and thanksgiving, as commanded by David, the man of God, one section opposite the other. Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, and Akkub were gatekeepers who guarded the storerooms at the gates.

These were in the days of Joiakim, son of Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor, and of Ezra the priest and scribe. At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, the Levites were sought out from all their places to bring them to Jerusalem to celebrate the dedication with gladness, thanksgiving, singing, cymbals, harps, and lyres. The singers gathered from the region around Jerusalem, from the villages of the Netophathites, from Beth Gilgal, and from the fields of Geba and Azmaveth, for the singers had built villages for themselves around Jerusalem. The priests and Levites purified themselves, the people, the gates, and the wall.

I brought the leaders of Judah up onto the wall and appointed two large choirs to give thanks. One went to the right on the wall toward the Dung Gate. Hoshaiah and half of the leaders of Judah followed them, along with Azariah, Ezra, Meshullam, Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, and Jeremiah, and some of the priests with trumpets, including Zechariah, son of Jonathan, son of Shemaiah, son of Mattaniah, son of Micaiah, son of Zaccur, son of Asaph, and his associates: Shemaiah, Azarel, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethanel, Judah, and Hanani, with the musical instruments of David, the man of God. Ezra the scribe led them. At the Fountain Gate, they went straight up the steps of the City of David, on the ascent to the wall, and passed above the house of David to the Water Gate on the east.

The second choir went in the opposite direction, and I followed them with half of the people on the wall, past the Tower of the Ovens to the Broad Wall, above the Gate of Ephraim, the Old Gate, the Fish Gate, the Tower of Hananel, the Tower of the Hundred, to the Sheep Gate, and they stopped at the Gate of the Guard. The two choirs that gave thanks then took their places in the house of God, along with me and half of the officials, as well as the priests: Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Micaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah with trumpets, and Maaseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, Malkijah, Elam, and Ezer. The singers sang under the direction of Jezrahiah.

On that day, they offered great sacrifices and rejoiced because God had given them great joy. The women and children also rejoiced, and the sound of rejoicing in Jerusalem could be heard far away. At that time, men were appointed to be in charge of the storerooms for the contributions, firstfruits, and tithes. They were to collect from the fields around the towns the portions required by the Law for the priests and Levites, for Judah was pleased with the ministering priests and Levites. They performed the service of their God and the service of purification, as did the singers and gatekeepers, according to the commands of David and his son Solomon. For long ago, in the days of David and Asaph, there had been directors for the singers and for the songs of praise and thanksgiving to God. So in the days of Zerubbabel and Nehemiah, all Israel contributed the daily portions for the singers and gatekeepers. They also set aside the portion for the other Levites, and the Levites set aside the portion for the descendants of Aaron.Nehemiah ensured that the daily portions were given to the singers and gatekeepers, and they dedicated holy items to the Levites, who in turn dedicated them to the descendants of Aaron. 

On that day, they read from the Book of Moses to the people and discovered that the Ammonites and Moabites should never be allowed into God's assembly because they did not help the Israelites with food and water but instead hired Balaam to curse them. However, God turned the curse into a blessing. Upon hearing this, the Israelites separated themselves from all foreigners.

Before this, Eliashib the priest, who was in charge of the storerooms of God's house, had allied with Tobiah and prepared a large room for him, which was previously used to store offerings, incense, temple articles, and tithes of grain, new wine, and oil for the Levites, singers, and gatekeepers, as well as the contributions for the priests. During this time, Nehemiah was not in Jerusalem, as he had returned to King Artaxerxes of Babylon in the thirty-second year of his reign. After some time, Nehemiah obtained permission from the king to return to Jerusalem, where he discovered the wrong Eliashib had done for Tobiah by preparing a room for him in the temple courts. Nehemiah was greatly displeased and threw all of Tobiah's belongings out of the room. He then ordered the rooms to be purified and restored the temple articles, along with the grain offerings and incense.

Nehemiah also realized that the portions for the Levites had not been given to them, so the Levites and singers had returned to their fields. He confronted the officials, asking why the house of God was neglected, and gathered the Levites and singers back to their posts. All of Judah then brought the tithes of grain, new wine, and oil into the storerooms. Nehemiah appointed Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites as treasurers over the storerooms, with Hanan son of Zaccur, son of Mattaniah, assisting them, as they were considered trustworthy. Their responsibility was to distribute the supplies to their fellow Levites.

Nehemiah prayed, asking God to remember him for his good deeds for the house of God and its services. 

During those days, Nehemiah saw people in Judah treading winepresses on the Sabbath, bringing in grain, loading donkeys with wine, grapes, figs, and all kinds of burdens, and bringing them into Jerusalem on the Sabbath. He warned them against selling food on that day. People from Tyre who lived in Jerusalem were also bringing in fish and all kinds of merchandise and selling them on the Sabbath to the people of Judah. Nehemiah confronted the nobles of Judah, asking why they were profaning the Sabbath, reminding them that their ancestors' actions had brought calamity upon them and the city. He warned that they were bringing more wrath upon Israel by desecrating the Sabbath.

Nehemiah ordered the gates of Jerusalem to be shut as evening approached before the Sabbath and not to be opened until after the Sabbath. He stationed some of his men at the gates to ensure no load was brought in on the Sabbath day. Once or twice, merchants and sellers of all kinds of goods spent the night outside Jerusalem, but Nehemiah warned them that if they did so again, he would take action against them. From then on, they did not come on the Sabbath. Nehemiah instructed the Levites to purify themselves and guard the gates to keep the Sabbath day holy. He prayed, asking God to remember him and show mercy according to His great love.

In those days, Nehemiah also saw Jews who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab. Their children spoke the language of Ashdod or the language of one of the other peoples and could not speak the language of Judah. Nehemiah rebuked them, cursed them, beat some of them, and pulled out their hair. He made them swear by God not to give their daughters in marriage to the sons of foreigners or take foreign daughters for their sons or themselves. He reminded them that even King Solomon of Israel sinned because of foreign women, despite being loved by God and made king over all Israel. Foreign women led him into sin, and Nehemiah questioned why they would commit such a great evil by marrying foreign women and being unfaithful to God.

One of the sons of Joiada, son of Eliashib the high priest, was a son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite, so Nehemiah drove him away. He prayed, asking God to remember them for defiling the priesthood and the covenant of the priesthood and the Levites. Nehemiah purified the priests and Levites from everything foreign and assigned them duties, each to his own task. He also made arrangements for the wood offering at appointed times and for the firstfruits. He prayed, asking God to remember him for good.

In the days of King Ahasuerus, who reigned over 127 provinces from India to Ethiopia, he held a great feast for all his officials and servants in the third year of his reign. The feast showcased the wealth and splendor of his kingdom for 180 days. After these days, the king held a seven-day feast in the garden courtyard of the king's palace for all the people present in Shushan, from the greatest to the least. The courtyard was decorated with white, green, and blue hangings, fastened with cords of fine linen and purple to silver rings and marble pillars. The couches were of gold and silver on a mosaic pavement of red, blue, white, and black marble. Drinks were served in golden vessels, each different from the other, and royal wine was abundant, in keeping with the king's generosity. The drinking was according to the law; no one was compelled to drink, for the king had instructed all the officials of his household to serve each person as they desired. Queen Vashti also held a feast for the women in the royal palace of King Ahasuerus.

On the seventh day, when King Ahasuerus was in high spirits from wine, he commanded the seven eunuchs who served him—Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas—to bring Queen Vashti before him wearing her royal crown, to display her beauty to the people and nobles, for she was lovely to look at. But Queen Vashti refused to come at the king's command delivered by the eunuchs. The king became furious, and his anger burned within him. He consulted the wise men who understood the times, for it was customary for the king to consult experts in law and justice. The seven nobles of Persia and Media who had special access to the king and were highest in the kingdom—Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan—were asked what should be done to Queen Vashti for not obeying the command of King Ahasuerus delivered by the eunuchs.

Memucan replied in the presence of the king and the nobles, saying that Queen Vashti had wronged not only the king but also all the nobles and the peoples of all the provinces of King Ahasuerus. Her conduct would become known to all women, causing them to despise their husbands and say that King Ahasuerus commanded Queen Vashti to be brought before him, but she did not come. This would lead to widespread disrespect and discord. Memucan suggested that if it pleased the king, a royal decree should be issued and written among the laws of Persia and Media, which cannot be repealed, that Vashti should never again enter the presence of King Ahasuerus, and her royal position should be given to someone better than she. The king's edict would be proclaimed throughout his vast realm, ensuring that all women would respect their husbands, from the least to the greatest.

The proposal pleased the king and the nobles, so the king did as Memucan proposed. He sent dispatches to all parts of the kingdom, to each province in its own script and to each people in their own language, proclaiming that every man should be ruler over his own household, using his native tongue.Hege, the king's chamberlain and keeper of the women, was given the task of providing the necessary items for their purification. The king was pleased with the idea of finding a new queen to replace Vashti, and he ordered it to be done.

In the palace of Shushan, there was a Jew named Mordecai, a descendant of Kish, a Benjamite, who had been taken from Jerusalem during the captivity led by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. Mordecai had raised his cousin Hadassah, also known as Esther, after her parents died. Esther was beautiful and had a kind nature.

When the king's decree was announced, many young women, including Esther, were brought to the palace and placed under the care of Hegai, the keeper of the women. Esther quickly gained Hegai's favor, and he provided her with the best treatments and seven maids from the king's household. He also gave her the best place in the women's quarters.

Mordecai had instructed Esther not to reveal her Jewish heritage, and she obeyed him. Every day, Mordecai would walk near the courtyard of the women's house to check on Esther's well-being.

When it was each maiden's turn to go to King Ahasuerus, they were given whatever they desired to take with them from the women's house. After spending the night with the king, they would return to a different part of the women's house, overseen by Shaashgaz, the king's chamberlain in charge of the concubines. They would not see the king again unless he specifically called for them by name.

When it was Esther's turn, she requested nothing except what Hegai had advised. She found favor in the eyes of everyone who saw her. Esther was taken to King Ahasuerus in the royal palace in the tenth month, Tebeth, during the seventh year of his reign. The king loved Esther more than all the other women, and she won his favor and approval. He placed the royal crown on her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.

To celebrate, the king held a great feast in Esther's honor and declared a holiday in the provinces, distributing gifts generously. Even after becoming queen, Esther continued to keep her Jewish identity a secret, as Mordecai had instructed.

During this time, Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate when he overheard two of the king's chamberlains, Bigthan and Teresh, plotting to assassinate King Ahasuerus. Mordecai informed Esther, who then reported it to the king in Mordecai's name. After an investigation, the plot was confirmed, and the two conspirators were hanged. This event was recorded in the king's chronicles.

Later, King Ahasuerus promoted Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, elevating him above all the other princes. All the king's servants at the gate bowed to Haman, as the king had commanded, but Mordecai refused to bow. When questioned by the other servants, Mordecai revealed that he was a Jew. This infuriated Haman, who decided not only to punish Mordecai but to destroy all the Jews in the kingdom.

In the first month, Nisan, of the twelfth year of King Ahasuerus's reign, Haman cast lots (Pur) to determine the best day to carry out his plan. He then approached the king, describing the Jews as a people with different laws who did not obey the king's commands, and suggested that it was not in the king's interest to tolerate them. Haman offered to pay ten thousand talents of silver to the king's treasury to fund the destruction of the Jews.

The king gave Haman his signet ring, authorizing him to do as he pleased with the people. On the thirteenth day of the first month, the king's scribes wrote Haman's orders to the governors and rulers of each province, in their own languages, sealing the letters with the king's ring. The letters decreed the destruction, killing, and annihilation of all Jews, young and old, women and children, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, Adar, and allowed the plundering of their possessions.

The decree was sent out swiftly, and the king and Haman sat down to drink, but the city of Shushan was bewildered.

When Mordecai learned of the decree, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went into the city, wailing loudly. He stopped at the king's gate, as no one in sackcloth was allowed to enter. In every province, there was great mourning among the Jews, with fasting, weeping, and many lying in sackcloth and ashes.

Esther's maids and chamberlains informed her of Mordecai's distress, and she was deeply troubled. She sent clothes for Mordecai to wear instead of sackcloth, but he refused. Esther then sent Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains, to find out what was troubling Mordecai.

Mordecai explained everything to Hatach, including the sum of money Haman had promised to pay for the destruction of the Jews. He gave Hatach a copy of the decree to show Esther and urged her to plead with the king for her people.

Esther replied that anyone who approached the king without being summoned would be put to death unless the king extended his golden scepter. She had not been called to the king for thirty days. Mordecai sent back a message, urging Esther not to think she would escape because she was in the king's house. He warned that if she remained silent, deliverance for the Jews would come from another place, but she and her family would perish. He suggested that perhaps she had become queen for such a time as this.

Esther asked Mordecai to gather all the Jews in Shushan to fast for her for three days and nights. She and her maids would do the same. She resolved to approach the king, even if it meant risking her life, saying, "If I perish, I perish." Mordecai did as Esther requested.Esther put on her royal robes and stood in the inner court of the king's palace, facing the throne room. When King Ahasuerus saw her, he was pleased and extended his golden scepter to her. Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter. The king asked her what she wanted, promising to grant her request even up to half of his kingdom. Esther invited the king and Haman to a banquet she had prepared.

At the banquet, the king again asked Esther what she desired. She requested that the king and Haman attend another banquet the next day, where she would reveal her petition. Haman left the banquet in high spirits but became furious when he saw Mordecai at the king's gate, refusing to bow. Haman's wife Zeresh and his friends suggested building a gallows to hang Mordecai, and Haman agreed.

That night, the king couldn't sleep and had the royal chronicles read to him. He discovered that Mordecai had saved his life by exposing a plot against him. The king asked what had been done to honor Mordecai and learned that nothing had been done. Just then, Haman entered the court to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai. The king asked Haman how to honor someone he delighted in. Thinking the king meant him, Haman suggested royal robes, a horse, and a public parade. The king ordered Haman to do all this for Mordecai.

Haman had to honor Mordecai publicly, which humiliated him. He returned home in mourning, and his wife and friends warned him that opposing Mordecai would lead to his downfall. While they were talking, the king's chamberlains arrived to bring Haman to Esther's second banquet.

At the banquet, the king again asked Esther what she wanted. She revealed that she and her people were to be destroyed and identified Haman as the enemy. The king, enraged, left the room. Haman begged Esther for his life, but when the king returned and saw Haman falling on Esther's couch, he thought Haman was attacking her. The king ordered Haman to be hanged on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai.

The king gave Haman's estate to Esther, and she revealed her relationship to Mordecai. The king gave Mordecai his signet ring, making him a high official. Esther pleaded with the king to revoke Haman's decree against the Jews. The king allowed Mordecai to write a new decree, permitting the Jews to defend themselves. This decree was sent out swiftly, and the Jews prepared to protect themselves.

Mordecai left the king's presence in royal garments, and the city of Shushan rejoiced.Mordecai wore a golden crown and fine linen robes, and the city of Shushan celebrated with joy. The Jews experienced light, gladness, joy, and honor. In every province and city where the king's decree reached, the Jews celebrated with feasts and happiness. Many people converted to Judaism out of fear of the Jews.

On the 13th day of the 12th month (Adar), the Jews' enemies hoped to overpower them, but the opposite happened—the Jews triumphed over those who hated them. They gathered in their cities across King Ahasuerus's provinces to defend themselves, and no one could stand against them because everyone feared them. Even the provincial rulers, lieutenants, deputies, and officers helped the Jews due to their fear of Mordecai, who had become very influential.

The Jews struck down their enemies with the sword, killing and destroying them. In Shushan, they killed 500 men, including Haman's ten sons. However, they did not take any plunder. The king informed Esther of the 500 men killed in Shushan and asked her what more she desired. Esther requested that the Jews in Shushan be allowed to continue defending themselves the next day and that Haman's ten sons be hanged. The king agreed, and the decree was issued.

The Jews in Shushan gathered again on the 14th day of Adar and killed 300 more men but took no plunder. Across the provinces, the Jews killed 75,000 of their enemies but did not take any plunder. They celebrated on the 14th and 15th days of Adar with feasting and joy. The Jews in the villages celebrated on the 14th day with gladness, feasting, and exchanging gifts.

Mordecai documented these events and sent letters to all the Jews in King Ahasuerus's provinces, instructing them to celebrate the 14th and 15th days of Adar annually. These days marked their rest from enemies and the transformation of their sorrow into joy. The Jews agreed to observe these days as Mordecai had written, commemorating their deliverance from Haman's plot.

Esther and Mordecai confirmed these days of Purim with authority, and letters were sent to all Jews in the 127 provinces of the kingdom, promoting peace and truth. The decree of Esther established these matters of Purim, and it was recorded in the book.

King Ahasuerus imposed a tribute on the land and the islands. The acts of his power and the greatness of Mordecai, whom the king advanced, were recorded in the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia. Mordecai was second to King Ahasuerus, respected among the Jews, and sought the welfare of his people, speaking peace to all his descendants.

In the land of Uz, there was a man named Job who was blameless, upright, feared God, and shunned evil. He had seven sons and three daughters, and his wealth included 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 female donkeys, and a large household, making him the greatest man in the East. His sons would hold feasts, and Job would offer burnt offerings for them, fearing they might have sinned.

One day, the sons of God presented themselves before the LORD, and Satan came among them. The LORD asked Satan where he had come from, and Satan replied that he had been roaming the earth. The LORD asked if Satan had considered Job, a blameless and upright man who feared God and shunned evil. Satan challenged Job's integrity, suggesting that Job was faithful only because of God's protection and blessings. The LORD allowed Satan to test Job by taking away his possessions but not harming him.

On a day when Job's children were feasting, messengers came to Job with news of disasters: the Sabeans had taken his oxen and donkeys and killed his servants, fire from heaven had burned his sheep and servants, the Chaldeans had taken his camels and killed his servants, and a great wind had collapsed the house where his children were, killing them all. Job mourned deeply but did not sin or blame God.Satan came before the LORD, and the LORD asked him where he had been. Satan replied that he had been roaming the earth. The LORD asked if Satan had considered Job, a blameless and upright man who feared God and avoided evil. Despite Satan's attempts to destroy him, Job maintained his integrity. Satan argued that Job would curse God if his health was affected. The LORD allowed Satan to test Job but not to take his life.

Satan afflicted Job with painful sores from head to toe. Job used a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself as he sat among the ashes. His wife told him to curse God and die, but Job rebuked her, saying they should accept both good and bad from God. Despite his suffering, Job did not sin with his words.

When Job's three friends—Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite—heard of his troubles, they came to comfort him. They were so shocked by his appearance that they wept, tore their robes, and sprinkled dust on their heads. They sat with him in silence for seven days and nights, seeing how great his suffering was.

Finally, Job spoke, cursing the day of his birth. He wished he had never been born or had died at birth, believing that death would have brought him peace. He lamented his existence and questioned why life was given to those in misery.

Eliphaz responded, reminding Job of his past encouragement to others and suggesting that Job's suffering was a result of his own actions. He argued that no one innocent ever perished and that those who sow trouble reap it. Eliphaz described a vision in which a spirit questioned whether humans could be more righteous than God. He advised Job to seek God, who performs great and unsearchable deeds, and to accept God's correction, as it ultimately leads to healing and deliverance.

Job replied, expressing the weight of his grief and the feeling that God's arrows were within him. He longed for God to end his life, finding comfort in the thought of being released from his suffering. Job questioned his strength and the hope of prolonging his life, feeling abandoned by his friends and forsaken by God.Job continued to express his deep sorrow and frustration. He compared his friends to unreliable streams that dry up when needed most. He felt abandoned and misunderstood by them. Job questioned why he was suffering so much and asked his friends to teach him if he had done wrong. He lamented the fleeting nature of life and the relentless pain he was enduring. Job felt that his days were passing quickly without hope and that he would soon be forgotten.

Bildad, one of Job's friends, responded by questioning how long Job would continue to speak in such a way. He argued that God does not pervert justice and suggested that Job's children had been punished for their sins. Bildad advised Job to seek God and live righteously, promising that God would restore his fortunes if he did so. He encouraged Job to learn from the wisdom of past generations.

Job replied, acknowledging God's immense power and wisdom. He felt that no human could be righteous before God and that it was futile to argue with Him. Job described God's control over nature and the universe, emphasizing that humans are insignificant in comparison. He expressed his despair, feeling that God was against him and that his suffering was undeserved.

Job continued to question why God was allowing him to suffer and asked for an explanation. He felt that God was treating him harshly and unfairly, despite knowing that he was not wicked. Job lamented his creation, wishing he had never been born. He felt that his life was filled with relentless pain and confusion, and he longed for an end to his suffering.Job continued to express his deep sorrow, wishing he had never been born. He lamented the shortness of his life and asked to be left alone to find some comfort before he died. He described the afterlife as a land of darkness and chaos.

Zophar, another of Job's friends, responded by criticizing Job's lengthy complaints. He accused Job of being arrogant and dishonest, suggesting that Job's suffering was less than he deserved. Zophar urged Job to seek God and repent, promising that doing so would bring peace and security.

Job replied, asserting that he was just as wise as his friends and did not deserve their mockery. He pointed out that even the natural world recognizes God's power and justice. Job lamented that the wicked often prosper while the righteous suffer. He emphasized that God is in control of everything, from the rise and fall of nations to the fate of individuals.

Job expressed his desire to speak directly to God and defend his innocence. He criticized his friends for their false accusations and urged them to listen to his reasoning. Job questioned why God was treating him as an enemy and asked for an explanation of his suffering. He acknowledged that human life is short and full of trouble, and he longed for relief from his pain.

Eliphaz, another friend, responded by questioning the value of Job's words and accusing him of undermining piety and prayer. He suggested that Job's own words condemned him and questioned Job's claim to special wisdom. Eliphaz reminded Job that even the wise and aged are not immune to suffering and that God's ways are beyond human understanding."Why are you letting your emotions get the best of you? Why do you speak against God and let such words come out of your mouth? What is man that he should be pure, or anyone born of a woman that he should be righteous? God doesn't even trust His holy ones, and even the heavens aren't pure in His sight. How much more impure is man, who drinks iniquity like water?

Listen to me, and I will share what I have seen, what wise men have passed down from their ancestors. The wicked suffer all their days, and the oppressor's years are hidden. Fear haunts them constantly, and even in prosperity, destruction awaits. They don't believe they will escape darkness; they are destined for the sword. They wander for food, knowing that darkness is near. Trouble and anguish terrify them, overpowering them like a king ready for battle. They stretch out their hands against God and defy the Almighty. They charge at Him with arrogance, covering their faces with fat and living in desolate cities and abandoned houses. They will not be rich, their wealth will not endure, and their prosperity will not last. They will not escape darkness; flames will consume them, and they will be swept away by the breath of God's mouth. Those who trust in vanity will be repaid with vanity. Their branches will wither before their time, and they will cast off their unripe fruit like a vine. The congregation of hypocrites will be desolate, and fire will consume the tents of bribery. They conceive trouble and give birth to evil, and their hearts plot deceit.
