So they were scattered because there was no shepherd, and they became food for all the wild animals. My sheep wandered over all the mountains and on every high hill. They were scattered over the whole earth, and no one searched or looked for them."

The Lord declares, "Because my flock lacks a shepherd and has become prey, I am against the shepherds. I will hold them accountable for my flock and stop them from feeding the flock. I will rescue my flock from their mouths, and it will no longer be food for them. I myself will search for my sheep and look after them. As a shepherd looks after his scattered flock, so will I look after my sheep. I will rescue them from all the places where they were scattered on a day of clouds and darkness. I will bring them out from the nations, gather them from the countries, and bring them into their own land. I will pasture them on the mountains of Israel, in the ravines, and in all the settlements in the land. I will tend them in a good pasture, and the mountain heights of Israel will be their grazing land. There they will lie down in good grazing land, and there they will feed in a rich pasture on the mountains of Israel. I myself will tend my sheep and have them lie down, declares the Lord God. I will search for the lost, bring back the strays, bind up the injured, and strengthen the weak, but the sleek and the strong I will destroy. I will shepherd the flock with justice."

The Lord continues, "I will judge between one sheep and another, and between rams and goats. Is it not enough for you to feed on the good pasture? Must you also trample the rest of your pasture with your feet? Is it not enough for you to drink clear water? Must you also muddy the rest with your feet? Must my flock feed on what you have trampled and drink what you have muddied with your feet?"

Therefore, the Lord God says, "I myself will judge between the fat sheep and the lean sheep. Because you shove with flank and shoulder, butting all the weak sheep with your horns until you have driven them away, I will save my flock, and they will no longer be plundered. I will judge between one sheep and another. I will place over them one shepherd, my servant David, and he will tend them; he will tend them and be their shepherd. I, the Lord, will be their God, and my servant David will be prince among them. I, the Lord, have spoken."

The Lord promises, "I will make a covenant of peace with them and rid the land of wild beasts so that they may live in the wilderness and sleep in the forests in safety. I will make them and the places surrounding my hill a blessing. I will send down showers in season; there will be showers of blessing. The trees will yield their fruit, and the ground will yield its crops; the people will be secure in their land. They will know that I am the Lord when I break the bars of their yoke and rescue them from the hands of those who enslaved them. They will no longer be plundered by the nations, nor will wild animals devour them. They will live in safety, and no one will make them afraid. I will provide for them a land renowned for its crops, and they will no longer be victims of famine in the land or bear the scorn of the nations. Then they will know that I, the Lord their God, am with them and that they, the Israelites, are my people, declares the Lord God. You are my sheep, the sheep of my pasture, and I am your God, declares the Lord God."

The Lord then speaks against Mount Seir, saying, "I am against you, Mount Seir, and I will stretch out my hand against you and make you desolate. I will lay waste your towns, and you will become desolate. Then you will know that I am the Lord. Because you harbored an ancient hostility and delivered the Israelites over to the sword at the time of their calamity, the time their punishment reached its climax, therefore as surely as I live, declares the Lord God, I will give you over to bloodshed, and it will pursue you. Since you did not hate bloodshed, bloodshed will pursue you. I will make Mount Seir a desolate waste and cut off from it all who come and go. I will fill your mountains with the slain; those killed by the sword will fall on your hills and in your valleys and all your ravines. I will make you desolate forever; your towns will not be inhabited. Then you will know that I am the Lord. Because you have said, 'These two nations and countries will be ours, and we will take possession of them,' even though I, the Lord, was there, therefore as surely as I live, declares the Lord God, I will deal with you according to the anger and envy you showed in your hatred of them, and I will make myself known among them when I judge you. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have heard all the contemptible things you have said against the mountains of Israel. You said, 'They have been laid waste and have been given over to us to devour.' You boasted against me and spoke against me without restraint, and I heard it."The Lord says, "When the whole world celebrates, I will make you desolate, Mount Seir. Just as you rejoiced when Israel was desolate, so will I make you desolate. All of Edom will know that I am the Lord."

The Lord continues, "Prophesy to the mountains of Israel. Tell them that because the enemy has claimed their ancient high places, they have become desolate and mocked by surrounding nations. But I, the Lord, am speaking in my jealousy and anger against these nations. They will bear their shame, but you, mountains of Israel, will flourish and bear fruit for my people, who are coming back. I will make you prosperous again, better than before, and you will know that I am the Lord. My people will live on you, and you will no longer be barren or cause them to fall."

The Lord also says, "When Israel lived in their land, they defiled it with their actions, so I scattered them among the nations. But for the sake of my holy name, which they profaned, I will bring them back to their land. I will cleanse them with clean water, give them a new heart and spirit, and they will follow my laws. They will live in the land I gave their ancestors, and I will be their God. I will save them from their impurities, bless their crops, and they will no longer suffer famine. They will remember their evil ways and be ashamed. This is not for their sake, but for my holy name."

The Lord declares, "On the day I cleanse you, I will rebuild your cities and make the desolate land like the Garden of Eden. The nations around you will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt and replanted. I will increase your population like a flock, and they will know that I am the Lord."

The Lord's hand was upon me, and He brought me to a valley full of dry bones. He asked if the bones could live, and I said only He knows. He told me to prophesy to the bones, and they came together, but had no breath. Then He told me to prophesy to the wind, and breath entered them, and they lived. The Lord said these bones are the people of Israel, who feel hopeless. He will open their graves, bring them to Israel, and put His spirit in them so they will live and know He is the Lord.

The Lord told me to take two sticks, one for Judah and one for Joseph, and join them together as one. This symbolizes the reunification of Israel. He will gather the Israelites from all nations and make them one nation in their own land.The Lord says, "When the whole world celebrates, I will make you desolate, Mount Seir. Just as you rejoiced when Israel was desolate, so will I make you desolate. All of Edom will know that I am the Lord."

The Lord continues, "Prophesy to the mountains of Israel. Tell them that because the enemy has claimed their ancient high places, they have become desolate and mocked by surrounding nations. But I, the Lord, am speaking in my jealousy and anger against these nations. They will bear their shame, but you, mountains of Israel, will flourish and bear fruit for my people, who are coming back. I will make you prosperous again, better than before, and you will know that I am the Lord. My people will live on you, and you will no longer be barren or cause them to fall."

The Lord also says, "When Israel lived in their land, they defiled it with their actions, so I scattered them among the nations. But for the sake of my holy name, which they profaned, I will bring them back to their land. I will cleanse them with clean water, give them a new heart and spirit, and they will follow my laws. They will live in the land I gave their ancestors, and I will be their God. I will save them from their impurities, bless their crops, and they will no longer suffer famine. They will remember their evil ways and be ashamed. This is not for their sake, but for my holy name."

The Lord declares, "On the day I cleanse you, I will rebuild your cities and make the desolate land like the Garden of Eden. The nations around you will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt and replanted. I will increase your population like a flock, and they will know that I am the Lord."

The Lord's hand was upon me, and He brought me to a valley full of dry bones. He asked if the bones could live, and I said only He knows. He told me to prophesy to the bones, and they came together, but had no breath. Then He told me to prophesy to the wind, and breath entered them, and they lived. The Lord said these bones are the people of Israel, who feel hopeless. He will open their graves, bring them to Israel, and put His spirit in them so they will live and know He is the Lord.

The Lord told me to take two sticks, one for Judah and one for Joseph, and join them together as one. This symbolizes the reunification of Israel. He will gather the Israelites from all nations and make them one nation in their own land. One king will rule over them, and they will no longer be divided into two kingdoms. They will no longer defile themselves with idols or detestable things. I will save them from their sinful places and cleanse them. They will be my people, and I will be their God. My servant David will be their king, and they will follow my laws and decrees. They will live in the land I gave to Jacob, where their ancestors lived, and they and their descendants will live there forever. I will make a covenant of peace with them, an everlasting covenant. I will establish my sanctuary among them forever. The nations will know that I, the Lord, make Israel holy when my sanctuary is among them forever."

The Lord spoke to me, saying, "Son of man, set your face against Gog of the land of Magog, the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, and prophesy against him. Tell him that I am against him and will turn him around, putting hooks in his jaws, and bring him out with his whole army. Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya will be with them, all with shields and helmets. Gomer and all its troops, and the house of Togarmah from the far north with all its troops, and many nations with you. Be prepared and get ready, you and all your hordes gathered about you, and take command of them. After many days, you will be called to arms. In future years, you will invade a land that has recovered from war, whose people were gathered from many nations to the mountains of Israel, which had long been desolate. They had been brought out from the nations, and now all of them live in safety. You and all your troops and the many nations with you will go up, advancing like a storm; you will be like a cloud covering the land."

The Lord says, "On that day, thoughts will come into your mind, and you will devise an evil scheme. You will say, 'I will invade a land of unwalled villages; I will attack a peaceful and unsuspecting people—all of them living without walls and without gates and bars. I will plunder and loot and turn my hand against the resettled ruins and the people gathered from the nations, rich in livestock and goods, living at the center of the land.' Sheba and Dedan and the merchants of Tarshish and all her villages will say to you, 'Have you come to plunder? Have you gathered your hordes to loot, to carry off silver and gold, to take away livestock and goods and to seize much plunder?'"

"Therefore, son of man, prophesy and say to Gog: 'This is what the Sovereign Lord says: In that day, when my people Israel are living in safety, will you not take notice of it? You will come from your place in the far north, you and many nations with you, all of them riding on horses, a great horde, a mighty army. You will advance against my people Israel like a cloud that covers the land. In days to come, Gog, I will bring you against my land, so that the nations may know me when I am proved holy through you before their eyes.'"

"This is what the Sovereign Lord says: 'Are you not the one I spoke of in former days by my servants the prophets of Israel? At that time they prophesied for years that I would bring you against them. This is what will happen in that day: When Gog attacks the land of Israel, my hot anger will be aroused, declares the Sovereign Lord. In my zeal and fiery wrath, I declare that at that time there shall be a great earthquake in the land of Israel. The fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, the beasts of the field, every creature that moves along the ground, and all the people on the face of the earth will tremble at my presence. The mountains will be overturned, the cliffs will crumble, and every wall will fall to the ground. I will summon a sword against Gog on all my mountains, declares the Sovereign Lord. Every man's sword will be against his brother. I will execute judgment on him with plague and bloodshed; I will pour down torrents of rain, hailstones, and burning sulfur on him and on his troops and on the many nations with him. And so I will show my greatness and my holiness, and I will make myself known in the sight of many nations. Then they will know that I am the Lord.'"

"Son of man, prophesy against Gog and say: 'This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am against you, Gog, chief prince of Meshech and Tubal. I will turn you around and drag you along. I will bring you from the far north and send you against the mountains of Israel. Then I will strike your bow from your left hand and make your arrows drop from your right hand. On the mountains of Israel, you will fall, you and all your troops and the nations with you. I will give you as food to all kinds of carrion birds and to the wild animals. You will fall in the open field, for I have spoken, declares the Sovereign Lord. I will send fire on Magog and on those who live in safety in the coastlands, and they will know that I am the Lord. I will make known my holy name among my people Israel. I will no longer let my holy name be profaned, and the nations will know that I, the Lord, am the Holy One in Israel. It is coming! It will surely take place, declares the Sovereign Lord. This is the day I have spoken of.'"

"Then those who live in the towns of Israel will go out and use the weapons for fuel and burn them up—the small and large shields, the bows and arrows, the war clubs and spears. For seven years they will use them for fuel. They will not need to gather wood from the fields or cut it from the forests because they will use the weapons for fuel. And they will plunder those who plundered them and loot those who looted them, declares the Sovereign Lord."

"On that day, I will give Gog a burial place in Israel, in the valley of those who travel east of the sea. It will block the way of travelers because Gog and all his hordes will be buried there. So it will be called the Valley of Hamon Gog. For seven months, the Israelites will be burying them in order to cleanse the land. All the people of the land will bury them, and the day I display my glory will be a memorable day for them, declares the Sovereign Lord. People will be continually employed in cleansing the land. They will spread out across the land and, along with others, they will bury any bodies that are lying on the ground. After the seven months, they will carry out a more detailed search. As they go through the land, anyone who sees a human bone will leave a marker beside it until the gravediggers bury it in the Valley of Hamon Gog. Also, a town called Hamonah will be there. And so they will cleanse the land."

"Son of man, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Call out to every kind of bird and all the wild animals: 'Assemble and come together from all around to the sacrifice I am preparing for you, the great sacrifice on the mountains of Israel. There you will eat flesh and drink blood. You will eat the flesh of mighty men and drink the blood of the princes of the earth as if they were rams and lambs, goats and bulls—all of them fattened animals from Bashan. At the sacrifice I am preparing for you, you will eat fat till you are glutted and drink blood till you are drunk. At my table, you will eat your fill of horses and riders, mighty men and soldiers of every kind,' declares the Sovereign Lord."

"I will display my glory among the nations, and all the nations will see the punishment I inflict and the hand I lay on them. From that day forward, the people of Israel will know that I am the Lord their God. And the nations will know that the people of Israel went into exile for their sin because they were unfaithful to me. So I hid my face from them and handed them over to their enemies, and they all fell by the sword. I dealt with them according to their uncleanness and their offenses, and I hid my face from them."

"Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will now restore the fortunes of Jacob and will have compassion on all the people of Israel, and I will be zealous for my holy name. They will forget their shame and all the unfaithfulness they showed toward me when they lived in safety in their land with no one to make them afraid. When I have brought them back from the nations and have gathered them from the countries of their enemies, I will be proved holy through them in the sight of many nations.""They will know that I am the LORD their God, who sent them into exile among the nations, but now I have brought them back to their own land, leaving none behind. I will no longer hide my face from them, for I have poured out my spirit on the house of Israel, declares the Lord GOD."

In the twenty-fifth year of our exile, at the beginning of the year, on the tenth day of the month, fourteen years after the city was struck down, the hand of the LORD was upon me, and he brought me to Israel. In visions from God, he took me to the land of Israel and set me on a very high mountain, where I saw a structure like a city to the south. There, a man whose appearance was like bronze stood with a linen cord and a measuring rod in his hand, at the gate.

The man said to me, "Son of man, look with your eyes, hear with your ears, and pay attention to everything I show you, for you have been brought here so that I might show it to you. Tell the house of Israel everything you see."

I saw a wall surrounding the temple area. The measuring rod in the man's hand was six long cubits, each cubit being a cubit and a handbreadth. He measured the wall; it was one rod thick and one rod high. Then he went to the gate facing east, climbed its steps, and measured the threshold of the gate; it was one rod deep. Each alcove was one rod long and one rod wide, and the space between the alcoves was five cubits. The threshold of the gate next to the portico facing the temple was one rod deep.

He measured the portico of the gate; it was eight cubits deep and its jambs were two cubits thick. The portico of the gate faced the temple. Inside the east gate were three alcoves on each side; all three had the same measurements, and the faces of the projecting walls on each side had the same measurements. He measured the width of the entrance to the gateway; it was ten cubits, and the length of the gateway was thirteen cubits. In front of each alcove was a wall one cubit high, and the alcoves were six cubits square.

Then he measured the gateway from the roof of one alcove to the roof of the opposite one; the distance was twenty-five cubits from one door to the opposite door. He measured the projecting walls to be sixty cubits high. The gateway extended around to the projecting walls. From the front of the entrance gate to the front of the portico of the inner gate was fifty cubits. The alcoves and their projecting walls inside the gateway were surmounted by narrow windows all around, as was the portico; the windows were all around inside. The projecting walls were decorated with palm trees.

Then he brought me into the outer court. There I saw some rooms and a pavement that had been constructed all around the court; there were thirty rooms along the pavement. It abutted the sides of the gateways and was as wide as they were long; this was the lower pavement. Then he measured the distance from the inside of the lower gateway to the outside of the inner court; it was a hundred cubits on the east side as well as on the north.

Next, he measured the length and width of the north gate leading into the outer court. Its alcoves—three on each side—its projecting walls and its portico had the same measurements as those of the first gateway; it was fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. Its openings, its portico, and its palm tree decorations had the same measurements as those of the gate facing east. Seven steps led up to it, with its portico opposite them. There was a gate to the inner court facing the north gate, just as there was one on the east. He measured from one gate to the opposite one; it was a hundred cubits.

Then he led me to the south side, and I saw a gate facing south. He measured its jambs and its portico, and they had the same measurements as the others. The gateway and its portico had narrow windows all around, like the other gateways; it was fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. Seven steps led up to it, with its portico opposite them. It had palm tree decorations on the projecting walls on each side. The inner court also had a gate facing south, and he measured from this gate to the outer gate on the south side; it was a hundred cubits.

Then he brought me into the inner court through the south gate, and he measured the south gate; it had the same measurements as the others. Its alcoves, projecting walls, and portico had the same measurements as the others. The gateway and its portico had windows all around, like the other gateways; it was fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. The porticoes of the gateways around the inner court were twenty-five cubits wide and five cubits deep. Its portico faced the outer court; palm trees decorated its jambs, and eight steps led up to it.

Then he brought me to the inner court on the east side, and he measured the gateway; it had the same measurements as the others. Its alcoves, projecting walls, and portico had the same measurements as the others. The gateway and its portico had windows all around, like the other gateways; it was fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. Its portico faced the outer court; palm trees decorated its jambs, and eight steps led up to it.

Then he brought me to the north gate and measured it; it had the same measurements as the others. Its alcoves, projecting walls, and portico had the same measurements as the others. The gateway and its portico had windows all around, like the other gateways; it was fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. Its portico faced the outer court; palm trees decorated its jambs, and eight steps led up to it.

A room with a doorway was by the portico in each of the inner gateways, where the burnt offerings were washed. In the portico of the gateway were two tables on each side, on which the burnt offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings were slaughtered. By the outside wall of the portico, as one goes up to the entrance of the north gateway, were two tables, and on the other side of the portico were two tables. So there were four tables on one side of the gateway and four on the other—eight tables in all—on which the sacrifices were slaughtered. There were also four tables of dressed stone for the burnt offerings, each a cubit and a half long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit high. On them were placed the utensils for slaughtering the burnt offerings and the other sacrifices. Hooks, a handbreadth long, were attached all around the inside of the room, and on the tables was the flesh of the offerings.

Outside the inner gate, within the inner court, were two rooms, one at the side of the north gate and facing south, and another at the side of the south gate and facing north. He said to me, "The room facing south is for the priests who guard the temple, and the room facing north is for the priests who guard the altar. These are the sons of Zadok, who are the only Levites who may draw near to the LORD to minister before him."

Then he measured the court; it was square—a hundred cubits long and a hundred cubits wide. And the altar was in front of the temple. He brought me to the portico of the temple and measured the jambs of the portico; they were five cubits wide on either side. The width of the entrance was fourteen cubits, and its projecting walls were three cubits wide on either side. The portico was twenty cubits wide and twelve cubits deep, and ten steps led up to it. There were pillars by the jambs, one on each side.

Then he brought me to the main hall and measured the jambs; they were six cubits wide on each side. The entrance was ten cubits wide, and the projecting walls on each side of it were five cubits wide. He also measured the main hall; it was forty cubits long and twenty cubits wide. Then he went into the inner sanctuary and measured the jambs of the entrance; each was two cubits wide. The entrance was six cubits wide, and the projecting walls on each side of it were seven cubits wide. And he measured the length of the inner sanctuary; it was twenty cubits, and the width was twenty cubits across the end of the main hall. He said to me, "This is the Most Holy Place."

Then he measured the wall of the temple; it was six cubits thick, and each side room around the temple was four cubits wide. The side rooms were on three levels, one above another, thirty on each level. There were ledges all around the wall of the temple to serve as supports for the side rooms, so that the supports were not inserted into the wall of the temple. The side rooms all around the temple were wider at each successive level. The structure surrounding the temple was built in ascending stages, so that the rooms widened as one went upward. A stairway went up from the lowest floor to the top floor through the middle floor.The structure of the temple increased in width from the lowest chamber to the highest. The foundation of the side chambers was six large cubits high. The wall of the side chamber was five cubits thick. The space between the chambers was twenty cubits wide all around the temple. The doors of the side chambers faced the remaining space, with one door facing north and another facing south. The remaining space was five cubits wide all around.

The building in front of the separate area at the west end was seventy cubits wide, with a wall five cubits thick and a length of ninety cubits. The entire temple, including the separate area and the building with its walls, measured one hundred cubits long. The width of the temple and the separate area toward the east was also one hundred cubits.

He measured the length of the building facing the separate area, including the galleries on both sides, which was one hundred cubits. The inner temple and the porches of the court were also measured. The doorposts, narrow windows, and galleries on three levels were covered with wood from the ground up to the windows, which were also covered. The walls inside and outside the temple were measured, and they were decorated with cherubim and palm trees, with a palm tree between each cherub. Each cherub had two faces: a human face toward the palm tree on one side and a young lion's face toward the palm tree on the other side. This decoration was all around the temple.

From the ground to above the door, cherubim and palm trees were carved on the walls of the temple. The doorposts of the temple were square, and the appearance of the sanctuary was the same as the rest of the temple. The wooden altar was three cubits high and two cubits long, with corners and walls made of wood. He said to me, "This is the table that stands before the LORD."

The temple and the sanctuary had two doors, each with two folding leaves. The doors were decorated with cherubim and palm trees, similar to the walls, and had thick planks on the porch's exterior. There were narrow windows and palm trees on both sides of the porch and the side chambers of the temple, with thick planks.

He then brought me to the outer court, toward the north, into a chamber facing the separate area and the building to the north. The chamber was one hundred cubits long and fifty cubits wide. Opposite the twenty cubits of the inner court and the pavement of the outer court, there were galleries on three levels. In front of the chambers was a ten-cubit-wide walkway, with a one-cubit-wide path, and their doors faced north.

The upper chambers were shorter because the galleries were higher than the lower and middle levels of the building. The building had no pillars like those in the courts, so it was narrower at the top than at the lower and middle levels. The wall opposite the chambers, toward the outer court, was fifty cubits long. The chambers in the outer court were fifty cubits long, and the area in front of the temple was one hundred cubits long. The entrance to these chambers was on the east side, as one entered from the outer court.

The chambers in the wall of the court toward the east, opposite the separate area and the building, had a similar appearance to the chambers facing north. They were the same length and width, with similar exits and doors. The doors of the chambers facing south had a door at the head of the way, directly before the wall toward the east, as one entered them.

He said to me, "The north and south chambers facing the separate area are holy chambers where the priests who approach the LORD will eat the most holy offerings. They will place the most holy offerings, grain offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings there, for the place is holy. When the priests enter, they must not go out into the outer court without changing their holy garments, for they are holy. They must put on other garments before approaching the people."

After measuring the inner house, he brought me out through the east gate and measured the area around it. He measured the east side with a measuring reed, five hundred reeds. He measured the north side, five hundred reeds. He measured the south side, five hundred reeds. He turned to the west side and measured five hundred reeds. He measured all four sides, and it had a wall around it, five hundred reeds long and five hundred reeds wide, to separate the holy from the common.

Afterward, he brought me to the gate facing east. I saw the glory of the God of Israel coming from the east. His voice was like the sound of many waters, and the earth shone with His glory. The vision was like the one I had seen when He came to destroy the city and by the river Chebar. I fell on my face, and the glory of the LORD entered the temple through the east gate. The Spirit lifted me and brought me into the inner court, where the glory of the LORD filled the temple.

I heard Him speaking to me from the temple, and the man stood beside me. He said, "Son of man, this is the place of my throne and the place for the soles of my feet, where I will dwell among the Israelites forever. The house of Israel will no longer defile my holy name, neither they nor their kings, by their idolatry and the corpses of their kings at their high places. When they placed their threshold next to my threshold and their doorposts beside my doorposts, with only a wall between me and them, they defiled my holy name by their detestable practices. So I destroyed them in my anger. Now let them put away their idolatry and the corpses of their kings far from me, and I will dwell among them forever.

"Son of man, describe the temple to the house of Israel, so they may be ashamed of their sins. Let them measure the pattern. If they are ashamed of all they have done, show them the design of the temple, its layout, exits, entrances, and all its regulations and laws. Write these down before them so they may follow its design and all its regulations.

"This is the law of the temple: The entire area on top of the mountain will be most holy. This is the law of the temple.

"These are the measurements of the altar in cubits (the cubit being a cubit and a handbreadth): The base shall be a cubit high and a cubit wide, with a rim one span wide around its edge. This will be the height of the altar. From the base on the ground to the lower ledge, it will be two cubits high and one cubit wide. From the lower ledge to the upper ledge, it will be four cubits high and one cubit wide. The altar hearth will be four cubits high, with four horns projecting upward from the hearth. The altar hearth will be twelve cubits long and twelve cubits wide, square at its four corners. The upper ledge will be fourteen cubits long and fourteen cubits wide, with a rim half a cubit wide and a base one cubit wide all around. The steps of the altar will face east."

He said to me, "Son of man, this is what the Sovereign LORD says: These are the regulations for the altar on the day it is built, for offering burnt offerings and sprinkling blood on it. You are to give a young bull as a sin offering to the Levitical priests of the family of Zadok, who come near to minister before me, declares the Sovereign LORD. You are to take some of its blood and put it on the four horns of the altar, the four corners of the upper ledge, and all around the rim."Apply the blood to the four horns of the altar, the four corners of the ledge, and the surrounding border to cleanse and purify it. Burn the bull used for the sin offering outside the sanctuary. On the second day, offer a flawless goat as a sin offering to cleanse the altar, just as you did with the bull. After cleansing, offer a flawless young bull and a ram from the flock. Present them before the LORD, and the priests will sprinkle salt on them and offer them as burnt offerings. For seven days, prepare a goat each day for a sin offering, along with a flawless young bull and a ram. Purify the altar and consecrate it for seven days. After these days, on the eighth day and onward, the priests will offer your burnt offerings and peace offerings on the altar, and I will accept you, declares the Lord GOD.

Then he took me back to the east-facing outer sanctuary gate, which was shut. The LORD told me, 'This gate will remain shut because the LORD, the God of Israel, has entered through it. Only the prince may sit in it to eat bread before the LORD; he will enter and exit through the porch of this gate.'

He then led me to the north gate of the house, where I saw the glory of the LORD filling the house, and I fell on my face. The LORD said to me, 'Son of man, pay close attention to all the ordinances and laws of the house of the LORD. Note the entrance and exits of the sanctuary. Tell the rebellious house of Israel that their abominations are enough. They have brought foreigners, uncircumcised in heart and flesh, into my sanctuary, defiling it while offering my bread, fat, and blood, breaking my covenant. They have not kept charge of my holy things but appointed others to oversee my sanctuary.

No foreigner, uncircumcised in heart or flesh, shall enter my sanctuary. The Levites who strayed from me when Israel went astray will bear their punishment. They will serve in my sanctuary, managing the gates and offering sacrifices for the people. Because they led Israel into sin, they will bear their shame and not come near me to serve as priests. They will be responsible for the temple's maintenance and all its work.

However, the Levitical priests, the sons of Zadok, who remained faithful when Israel went astray, will minister to me. They will stand before me to offer sacrifices. They will enter my sanctuary and approach my table to serve me. When they enter the inner court, they will wear linen garments, not wool, to avoid sweating. They will wear linen turbans and trousers. When they go to the outer court, they will change out of their holy garments to avoid sanctifying the people with them. They will not shave their heads or let their hair grow long but will keep it trimmed. They will not drink wine when entering the inner court. They will marry only virgins from Israel or widows of priests. They will teach my people to distinguish between the holy and the common, the clean and the unclean. They will serve as judges, following my laws and statutes, and keep my Sabbaths holy. They will not defile themselves by touching a dead person, except for close family members. After being cleansed, they will wait seven days before re-entering the sanctuary to minister.

Their inheritance is me; they will not own land in Israel. They will eat the grain, sin, and guilt offerings, and everything dedicated to the LORD. The first fruits of all kinds and the first of your dough will belong to the priests, bringing a blessing to your house. They will not eat anything found dead or torn by wild animals.

When you divide the land for inheritance, set aside a holy portion for the LORD, measuring 25,000 by 10,000 reeds. This will include the sanctuary and its surrounding area. The priests will have a portion for their houses and the sanctuary. The Levites will have a portion for their chambers. The city will have a portion measuring 5,000 by 25,000 reeds for the whole house of Israel. The prince will have land on both sides of the holy portion and the city's property, extending from the west to the east border. The princes will no longer oppress my people but will distribute the land fairly among the tribes of Israel.

The LORD says, 'O princes of Israel, stop your violence and oppression. Execute justice and righteousness. Use honest scales, an honest ephah, and an honest bath. The ephah and bath will be the same size, each containing a tenth of a homer. The shekel will be twenty gerahs, with a maneh equaling sixty shekels. This is the offering you will give: a sixth of an ephah from a homer of wheat and barley, a tenth of a bath of oil from a cor, and one lamb from every two hundred from the pastures of Israel for grain, burnt, and peace offerings to make atonement for the people. All the people will give this offering to the prince in Israel. The prince will provide the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and drink offerings for the festivals, new moons, Sabbaths, and all appointed feasts of Israel. He will prepare the sin offerings, grain offerings, burnt offerings, and peace offerings to make atonement for the house of Israel.'"The Lord GOD says: On the first day of the first month, take a young bull without blemish and cleanse the sanctuary. The priest will take some of the blood from the sin offering and put it on the doorposts of the house, the four corners of the altar, and the posts of the inner court gate. Do this again on the seventh day of the month for anyone who has sinned unintentionally or out of ignorance, to make atonement for the house.

On the fourteenth day of the first month, celebrate the Passover, a seven-day feast where unleavened bread is eaten. On that day, the prince will prepare a bull as a sin offering for himself and all the people. For the seven days of the feast, he will offer seven bulls and seven rams without blemish as burnt offerings to the LORD, along with a daily sin offering of a young goat. He will also prepare a grain offering of an ephah for each bull and ram, and a hin of oil for each ephah.

In the seventh month, on the fifteenth day, he will do the same for the seven-day feast, offering the same sacrifices and grain offerings.

The Lord GOD says: The inner court gate facing east will be closed on the six working days but open on the Sabbath and the new moon. The prince will enter through the porch of that gate and stand by the gatepost while the priests prepare his burnt and peace offerings. He will worship at the threshold of the gate, and then leave, but the gate will remain open until evening. The people will worship at the gate on Sabbaths and new moons.

On the Sabbath, the prince will offer six lambs and a ram without blemish as burnt offerings. The grain offering will be an ephah for the ram and as much as he can give for the lambs, along with a hin of oil for each ephah. On the new moon, he will offer a young bull, six lambs, and a ram, all without blemish, with the same grain and oil offerings.

When the prince enters, he will use the porch of the gate and exit the same way. When the people come to worship during the festivals, those entering through the north gate will leave by the south gate, and vice versa. No one will return through the gate they entered. The prince will be among them, entering and exiting with the people.

During the festivals, the grain offering will be an ephah for each bull and ram, and as much as he can give for the lambs, with a hin of oil for each ephah. If the prince makes a voluntary burnt or peace offering, the east-facing gate will be opened for him, and he will offer his sacrifices as on the Sabbath. After he leaves, the gate will be closed.

Every morning, a year-old lamb without blemish will be offered as a daily burnt offering to the LORD. A grain offering of a sixth of an ephah and a third of a hin of oil will be prepared each morning as a perpetual ordinance.

The Lord GOD says: If the prince gives a gift from his inheritance to his sons, it will belong to them. If he gives a gift to a servant, it will revert to the prince in the year of liberty, but his sons' inheritance will remain theirs. The prince must not take the people's inheritance by force, but give his sons their inheritance from his own property, so the people are not displaced.

He then took me through the entrance beside the gate to the priests' holy chambers facing north. There was a place on the west side where the priests would boil the guilt and sin offerings and bake the grain offerings, so they wouldn't have to take them out to the outer court and sanctify the people.

He led me to the outer court and showed me four small courts, one in each corner. Each court was 40 cubits long and 30 cubits wide, with rows of stone around them and places for boiling under the rows. He said, "These are the kitchens where the temple ministers will boil the sacrifices for the people."

Afterward, he brought me back to the temple entrance, where I saw water flowing eastward from under the temple threshold. The water flowed from the south side of the temple, past the altar. He led me out through the north gate and around to the east-facing outer gate, where I saw water trickling from the south side.

He measured a thousand cubits eastward and led me through ankle-deep water. He measured another thousand cubits and led me through knee-deep water. Another thousand cubits brought us to waist-deep water. After another thousand cubits, the water was too deep to cross, a river to swim in.

He asked, "Son of man, do you see this?" Then he led me back to the riverbank, where I saw many trees on both sides. He said, "These waters flow eastward, down to the desert and into the sea, making the salty water fresh. Wherever the river flows, there will be many fish and living creatures. Fishermen will stand along the shore from En Gedi to En Eglaim, spreading their nets. The fish will be as abundant as those in the Great Sea. However, the swamps and marshes will not become fresh; they will remain salty.

Fruit trees of all kinds will grow along both sides of the river. Their leaves will not wither, nor will their fruit fail. They will bear new fruit every month because the water from the sanctuary flows to them. Their fruit will be for food and their leaves for healing."

The Lord GOD says: These are the borders by which you will divide the land among the twelve tribes of Israel, with Joseph receiving two portions. You will inherit it equally, as I promised your ancestors. This land will be your inheritance.You will divide this land among the tribes of Israel. Foreigners living among you who have children will be treated as native-born Israelites and will share the inheritance with you. They will receive their inheritance in the tribe where they live, declares the Lord GOD.

Here are the names of the tribes and their portions of land:

- From the northern end, along the way to Hethlon, to Hamath, and Hazarenan, the border of Damascus northward, to the coast of Hamath: a portion for Dan.
- Next to Dan, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Asher.
- Next to Asher, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Naphtali.
- Next to Naphtali, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Manasseh.
- Next to Manasseh, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Ephraim.
- Next to Ephraim, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Reuben.
- Next to Reuben, from the east side to the west side: a portion for Judah.

In the middle of Judah's portion, you will set aside a special offering to the LORD, measuring 25,000 reeds in length and 10,000 in width. The sanctuary will be in the center of this area. This holy offering will be for the priests, the sons of Zadok, who remained faithful when the Israelites went astray. The Levites will have a portion next to the priests' land, measuring 25,000 by 10,000 reeds. This land is holy and cannot be sold or exchanged.

The remaining 5,000 reeds in width will be for the city, its dwellings, and suburbs. The city will measure 4,500 reeds on each side, with suburbs extending 250 reeds in each direction. The rest of the land, 10,000 reeds eastward and westward, will be for food for those who serve the city. All the tribes of Israel will contribute to the city's service.

The remaining land will be for the prince, located on either side of the holy offering and the city's property. The sanctuary will be in the center of this area. The prince's land will extend from the border of Judah to the border of Benjamin.

The rest of the tribes will receive their portions as follows:

- Benjamin: from the east side to the west side.
- Simeon: next to Benjamin, from the east side to the west side.
- Issachar: next to Simeon, from the east side to the west side.
- Zebulun: next to Issachar, from the east side to the west side.
- Gad: next to Zebulun, from the east side to the west side, extending southward to Tamar and the waters of Meribah Kadesh, to the river and the Great Sea.

This is the land you will divide among the tribes of Israel for inheritance, declares the Lord GOD.

The city gates will be named after the tribes of Israel:

- North side: Reuben, Judah, Levi.
- East side: Joseph, Benjamin, Dan.
- South side: Simeon, Issachar, Zebulun.
- West side: Gad, Asher, Naphtali.

The city will measure 18,000 reeds in circumference, and its name from that day will be "The LORD is there."

In the third year of King Jehoiakim's reign, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, besieged Jerusalem. The Lord delivered Jehoiakim into his hand, along with some of the temple's treasures, which Nebuchadnezzar took to the land of Shinar and placed in the house of his god.

Nebuchadnezzar ordered Ashpenaz, the chief of his eunuchs, to bring some of the Israelites from the royal family and nobility—young men without physical defect, handsome, skilled in wisdom, knowledgeable, and capable of serving in the king's palace. They were to be taught the language and literature of the Chaldeans. The king assigned them a daily portion of his food and wine for three years, after which they would serve the king.

Among these were Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah from Judah. The chief eunuch gave them new names: Daniel became Belteshazzar, Hananiah became Shadrach, Mishael became Meshach, and Azariah became Abednego.

Daniel resolved not to defile himself with the king's food and wine, so he asked the chief eunuch for permission to abstain. God granted Daniel favor with the chief eunuch, who was concerned that Daniel and his friends might look worse than the other young men, endangering his own life. Daniel proposed a ten-day test, during which they would eat only vegetables and drink water. At the end of the ten days, they looked healthier than the others, so the steward continued to provide them with vegetables.

God gave these four young men knowledge and skill in all learning and wisdom, and Daniel could understand visions and dreams. At the end of their training, they were presented to King Nebuchadnezzar, who found them ten times better than all the magicians and enchanters in his kingdom. Daniel remained in the king's service until the first year of King Cyrus.

In the second year of Nebuchadnezzar's reign, he had troubling dreams that disturbed his sleep. He summoned magicians, enchanters, sorcerers, and Chaldeans to interpret his dreams.The Chaldeans spoke to the king in Aramaic, saying, "O king, live forever! Tell your servants the dream, and we will interpret it." The king replied, "I can't remember the dream. If you don't tell me the dream and its interpretation, you'll be torn apart, and your houses will be destroyed. But if you do, you'll receive gifts, rewards, and great honor. So, tell me the dream and its interpretation."

They responded again, "Let the king tell his servants the dream, and we will interpret it." The king said, "I know you're stalling because you see that I can't remember the dream. If you don't tell me the dream, there's only one penalty for you. You've conspired to tell me misleading and wicked things, hoping the situation will change. So, tell me the dream, and I'll know you can interpret it."

The Chaldeans answered, "No one on earth can do what the king asks! No king, lord, or ruler has ever asked such a thing from any magician, astrologer, or Chaldean. What the king asks is too difficult. No one can reveal it to the king except the gods, and they do not live among humans."

This made the king so angry and furious that he ordered the execution of all the wise men of Babylon. So, the decree was issued, and they began looking for Daniel and his friends to put them to death.

Daniel spoke with wisdom and tact to Arioch, the commander of the king's guard, who had gone out to execute the wise men of Babylon. He asked Arioch, "Why did the king issue such a harsh decree?" Arioch explained the matter to Daniel. At this, Daniel went to the king and asked for time so that he might interpret the dream for him.

Then Daniel returned to his house and explained the matter to his friends Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah. He urged them to plead for mercy from the God of heaven concerning this mystery so that he and his friends might not be executed with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.

During the night, the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision. Then Daniel praised the God of heaven and said, "Praise be to the name of God forever and ever; wisdom and power are his. He changes times and seasons; he deposes kings and raises up others. He gives wisdom to the wise and knowledge to the discerning. He reveals deep and hidden things; he knows what lies in darkness, and light dwells with him. I thank and praise you, God of my ancestors: You have given me wisdom and power, and you have made known to me what we asked of you; you have made known to us the dream of the king."

Then Daniel went to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to execute the wise men of Babylon, and said to him, "Do not execute the wise men of Babylon. Take me to the king, and I will interpret his dream for him."

Arioch took Daniel to the king at once and said, "I have found a man among the exiles from Judah who can tell the king what his dream means." The king asked Daniel (also called Belteshazzar), "Are you able to tell me what I saw in my dream and interpret it?"

Daniel replied, "No wise man, enchanter, magician, or diviner can explain to the king the mystery he has asked about, but there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries. He has shown King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen in days to come. Your dream and the visions that passed through your mind as you were lying in bed are these:

"As Your Majesty was lying there, your mind turned to things to come, and the revealer of mysteries showed you what is going to happen. As for me, this mystery has been revealed to me, not because I have greater wisdom than anyone else alive, but so that Your Majesty may know the interpretation and that you may understand what went through your mind.

"Your Majesty looked, and there before you stood a large statue—an enormous, dazzling statue, awesome in appearance. The head of the statue was made of pure gold, its chest and arms of silver, its belly and thighs of bronze, its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of baked clay. While you were watching, a rock was cut out, but not by human hands. It struck the statue on its feet of iron and clay and smashed them. Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were all broken to pieces and became like chaff on a threshing floor in the summer. The wind swept them away without leaving a trace. But the rock that struck the statue became a huge mountain and filled the whole earth.

"This was the dream, and now we will interpret it to the king. Your Majesty, you are the king of kings. The God of heaven has given you dominion and power and might and glory; in your hands, he has placed all mankind and the beasts of the field and the birds in the sky. Wherever they live, he has made you ruler over them all. You are that head of gold.

"After you, another kingdom will arise, inferior to yours. Next, a third kingdom, one of bronze, will rule over the whole earth. Finally, there will be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron—for iron breaks and smashes everything—and as iron breaks things to pieces, so it will crush and break all the others. Just as you saw that the feet and toes were partly of baked clay and partly of iron, so this will be a divided kingdom; yet it will have some of the strength of iron in it, even as you saw iron mixed with clay. As the toes were partly iron and partly clay, so this kingdom will be partly strong and partly brittle. And just as you saw the iron mixed with baked clay, so the people will be a mixture and will not remain united, any more than iron mixes with clay.

"In the time of those kings, the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that will never be destroyed, nor will it be left to another people. It will crush all those kingdoms and bring them to an end, but it will itself endure forever. This is the meaning of the vision of the rock cut out of a mountain, but not by human hands—a rock that broke the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold to pieces.

"The great God has shown the king what will take place in the future. The dream is true, and its interpretation is trustworthy."

Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell prostrate before Daniel and paid him honor and ordered that an offering and incense be presented to him. The king said to Daniel, "Surely your God is the God of gods and the Lord of kings and a revealer of mysteries, for you were able to reveal this mystery."

Then the king placed Daniel in a high position and lavished many gifts on him. He made him ruler over the entire province of Babylon and placed him in charge of all its wise men. Moreover, at Daniel's request, the king appointed Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego administrators over the province of Babylon, while Daniel himself remained at the royal court.

King Nebuchadnezzar made an image of gold, sixty cubits high and six cubits wide, and set it up on the plain of Dura in the province of Babylon. He then summoned the satraps, prefects, governors, advisers, treasurers, judges, magistrates, and all the other provincial officials to come to the dedication of the image he had set up. So, the satraps, prefects, governors, advisers, treasurers, judges, magistrates, and all the other provincial officials assembled for the dedication of the image that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up, and they stood before it.

Then the herald loudly proclaimed, "Nations and peoples of every language, this is what you are commanded to do: As soon as you hear the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, pipe, and all kinds of music, you must fall down and worship the image of gold that King Nebuchadnezzar has set up. Whoever does not fall down and worship will immediately be thrown into a blazing furnace."

Therefore, as soon as they heard the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, and all kinds of music, all the nations and peoples of every language fell down and worshiped the image of gold that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.

At this time, some astrologers came forward and denounced the Jews. They said to King Nebuchadnezzar, "May the king live forever! Your Majesty has issued a decree that everyone who hears the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, pipe, and all kinds of music must fall down and worship the image of gold, and that whoever does not fall down and worship will be thrown into a blazing furnace. But there are some Jews whom you have set over the affairs of the province of Babylon—Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego—who pay no attention to you, Your Majesty. They neither serve your gods nor worship the image of gold you have set up."Nebuchadnezzar, furious, ordered Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego to be brought before him. He asked them if it was true that they did not serve his gods or worship the golden statue he had set up. He warned them that if they did not bow down when they heard the music, they would be thrown into a blazing furnace. The three men replied that their God could save them, but even if He did not, they would not serve Nebuchadnezzar's gods or worship the statue.

Enraged, Nebuchadnezzar ordered the furnace to be heated seven times hotter than usual and commanded his strongest soldiers to bind Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego and throw them into the furnace. The furnace was so hot that the flames killed the soldiers who took them up. The three men, bound, fell into the furnace.

Nebuchadnezzar was astonished and asked his counselors if they had thrown three men into the fire. They confirmed it. He then exclaimed that he saw four men walking around in the fire, unharmed, and the fourth looked like a divine being. Nebuchadnezzar approached the furnace and called for Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego to come out. They emerged unscathed, without even the smell of fire on them.

Nebuchadnezzar praised their God for sending an angel to rescue them and decreed that anyone who spoke against their God would be punished severely. He then promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in Babylon.

Later, Nebuchadnezzar had another troubling dream and called for all the wise men of Babylon to interpret it, but they could not. Finally, Daniel, also known as Belteshazzar, came before him. Nebuchadnezzar described his dream of a great tree that provided for all creatures but was ordered to be cut down by a heavenly messenger, leaving only the stump bound with iron and bronze.

Daniel interpreted the dream, explaining that the tree represented Nebuchadnezzar himself, who had grown powerful. However, he would be driven away from people to live like an animal until he acknowledged that God rules over human kingdoms. The stump meant his kingdom would be restored once he recognized God's sovereignty.

A year later, as Nebuchadnezzar boasted about his achievements, a voice from heaven declared that his kingdom was taken from him. He was driven away to live like an animal until he acknowledged God's rule. After this period, Nebuchadnezzar's sanity was restored, and he praised and honored God, recognizing His eternal dominion.Nebuchadnezzar praised and honored the King of Heaven, acknowledging that all His works are true and His ways just. He recognized that those who walk in pride can be humbled by God.

King Belshazzar held a grand feast for a thousand of his nobles and drank wine with them. He ordered the golden and silver vessels taken from the temple in Jerusalem to be brought so that he, his nobles, wives, and concubines could drink from them. They drank wine and praised the gods of gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.

Suddenly, fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the wall of the king's palace. Belshazzar was terrified and called for the astrologers, Chaldeans, and soothsayers to interpret the writing. He promised that whoever could read and interpret it would be clothed in scarlet, given a gold chain, and made the third ruler in the kingdom. However, none of the wise men could interpret the writing, which greatly troubled the king.

The queen suggested that Belshazzar call for Daniel, who had the spirit of the holy gods and had previously demonstrated wisdom and understanding. Daniel was brought before the king, who asked if he could interpret the writing. Daniel declined the king's rewards but agreed to interpret the writing.

Daniel reminded Belshazzar of how God had given Nebuchadnezzar a kingdom, majesty, glory, and honor, but when Nebuchadnezzar became proud, he was deposed and lived like an animal until he acknowledged God's sovereignty. Daniel then rebuked Belshazzar for not humbling himself despite knowing all this and for using the sacred vessels to praise false gods.

Daniel interpreted the writing: "MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN." He explained that "MENE" meant God had numbered the days of Belshazzar's kingdom and brought it to an end, "TEKEL" meant Belshazzar had been weighed and found wanting, and "PERES" meant the kingdom would be divided and given to the Medes and Persians.

Belshazzar honored Daniel with scarlet clothing, a gold chain, and proclaimed him the third ruler in the kingdom. That very night, Belshazzar was killed, and Darius the Mede took over the kingdom.

Darius appointed 120 princes to govern the kingdom and three presidents to oversee them, with Daniel being the foremost. Daniel's exceptional spirit made him stand out, and Darius considered setting him over the entire realm. This made the other presidents and princes jealous, and they sought to find fault in Daniel but could not because he was faithful and without error.

They conspired to use Daniel's faith against him by convincing Darius to issue a decree that anyone who prayed to any god or man other than the king for thirty days would be thrown into the lions' den. Darius signed the decree, which could not be altered according to the law of the Medes and Persians.

Despite knowing the decree, Daniel continued to pray to God three times a day. His enemies caught him praying and reported it to the king. Darius was distressed but could not change the decree. Daniel was thrown into the lions' den, but Darius expressed hope that Daniel's God would save him. The den was sealed with a stone and the king's signet.

Darius spent a sleepless night fasting and hurried to the den at dawn. He called out to Daniel, who replied that God had sent an angel to shut the lions' mouths because he was found innocent before God and the king.King Darius was overjoyed and ordered Daniel to be lifted out of the lions' den. Daniel was unharmed because he trusted in his God. The king then commanded that the men who had falsely accused Daniel, along with their families, be thrown into the lions' den, where they were immediately killed.

Darius issued a decree to all people and nations, declaring that everyone should respect the God of Daniel, who is the living God and whose kingdom will never be destroyed. He praised God for rescuing Daniel from the lions.

Daniel continued to prosper during the reigns of Darius and Cyrus the Persian.

In the first year of King Belshazzar of Babylon, Daniel had a dream with visions. He saw four great beasts rising from the sea, each different from the others. The first was like a lion with eagle's wings, which were plucked off, and it stood like a man with a human heart. The second beast was like a bear, raised on one side with three ribs in its mouth, told to devour much flesh. The third beast was like a leopard with four wings and four heads, given dominion. The fourth beast was terrifying, with iron teeth and ten horns. A smaller horn with eyes and a mouth speaking great things emerged, uprooting three of the original horns.

Daniel saw thrones set up and the Ancient of Days, with white garments and hair like wool, sitting on a fiery throne. Thousands served Him, and the court was in session with books opened. The fourth beast was slain and its body destroyed. The other beasts lost their dominion but were allowed to live for a time.

Daniel saw one like the Son of Man coming with the clouds of heaven to the Ancient of Days, receiving everlasting dominion and a kingdom that all people would serve.

Daniel was troubled by the visions and asked for their meaning. He was told that the four beasts represented four kings, but the saints of the Most High would eventually possess the kingdom forever. The fourth beast represented a kingdom that would devour the earth, with ten kings arising from it. Another king would rise, subduing three kings, speaking against the Most High, and oppressing the saints until judgment was passed in favor of the saints, who would then possess the kingdom.

In the third year of King Belshazzar's reign, Daniel had another vision. He saw a ram with two horns, one higher than the other, pushing west, north, and south, unstoppable. Then a goat with a prominent horn between its eyes came from the west, attacking and defeating the ram. The goat's horn was broken, replaced by four notable horns. From one of these horns, a smaller horn grew, becoming very powerful and challenging the host of heaven.

Daniel heard a conversation about how long the vision concerning the daily sacrifice and desolation would last, and was told it would be for 2,300 days, after which the sanctuary would be cleansed.

Gabriel appeared to Daniel, explaining that the vision referred to the end times. The ram represented the kings of Media and Persia, and the goat the king of Greece. The broken horn and the four that replaced it symbolized four kingdoms arising from Greece. A fierce king would arise in the latter time, powerful but not by his own power, causing great destruction and succeeding in his endeavors.In the first year of Darius, son of Ahasuerus, of Median descent, who was made king over the Chaldean realm, I, Daniel, understood from the scriptures, according to the word of the Lord given to Jeremiah the prophet, that the desolation of Jerusalem would last seventy years. So, I turned to the Lord God and pleaded with Him in prayer and petition, in fasting, and in sackcloth and ashes.

I prayed to the Lord my God and confessed: "Lord, the great and awesome God, who keeps His covenant of love with those who love Him and keep His commandments, we have sinned and done wrong. We have been wicked and have rebelled; we have turned away from Your commands and laws. We have not listened to Your servants the prophets, who spoke in Your name to our kings, our princes, and our ancestors, and to all the people of the land.

"Lord, You are righteous, but this day we are covered with shame—the people of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem and all Israel, both near and far, in all the countries where You have scattered us because of our unfaithfulness to You. We and our kings, our princes, and our ancestors are covered with shame, Lord, because we have sinned against You. The Lord our God is merciful and forgiving, even though we have rebelled against Him; we have not obeyed the Lord our God or kept the laws He gave us through His servants the prophets. All Israel has transgressed Your law and turned away, refusing to obey You.

"Therefore, the curses and sworn judgments written in the Law of Moses, the servant of God, have been poured out on us because we have sinned against You. You have fulfilled the words spoken against us and against our rulers by bringing on us great disaster. Under the whole heaven, nothing has ever been done like what has been done to Jerusalem. Just as it is written in the Law of Moses, all this disaster has come on us, yet we have not sought the favor of the Lord our God by turning from our sins and giving attention to Your truth. The Lord did not hesitate to bring the disaster on us, for the Lord our God is righteous in everything He does; yet we have not obeyed Him.

"Now, Lord our God, who brought Your people out of Egypt with a mighty hand and who made for Yourself a name that endures to this day, we have sinned, we have done wrong. Lord, in keeping with all Your righteous acts, turn away Your anger and Your wrath from Jerusalem, Your city, Your holy hill. Our sins and the iniquities of our ancestors have made Jerusalem and Your people an object of scorn to all those around us.

"Now, our God, hear the prayers and petitions of Your servant. For Your sake, Lord, look with favor on Your desolate sanctuary. Give ear, our God, and hear; open Your eyes and see the desolation of the city that bears Your Name. We do not make requests of You because we are righteous, but because of Your great mercy. Lord, listen! Lord, forgive! Lord, hear and act! For Your sake, my God, do not delay, because Your city and Your people bear Your Name."

While I was speaking and praying, confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel and making my request to the Lord my God for His holy hill—while I was still in prayer, Gabriel, the man I had seen in the earlier vision, came to me in swift flight about the time of the evening sacrifice. He instructed me and said to me, "Daniel, I have now come to give you insight and understanding. As soon as you began to pray, a word went out, which I have come to tell you, for you are highly esteemed. Therefore, consider the word and understand the vision:

"Seventy 'sevens' are decreed for your people and your holy city to finish transgression, to put an end to sin, to atone for wickedness, to bring in everlasting righteousness, to seal up vision and prophecy and to anoint the Most Holy Place. Know and understand this: From the time the word goes out to restore and rebuild Jerusalem until the Anointed One, the ruler, comes, there will be seven 'sevens,' and sixty-two 'sevens.' It will be rebuilt with streets and a trench, but in times of trouble. After the sixty-two 'sevens,' the Anointed One will be put to death and will have nothing. The people of the ruler who will come will destroy the city and the sanctuary. The end will come like a flood: War will continue until the end, and desolations have been decreed. He will confirm a covenant with many for one 'seven.' In the middle of the 'seven,' he will put an end to sacrifice and offering. And at the temple, he will set up an abomination that causes desolation, until the end that is decreed is poured out on him."

In the third year of Cyrus king of Persia, a revelation was given to Daniel (who was called Belteshazzar). Its message was true and it concerned a great war. The understanding of the message came to him in a vision. At that time, I, Daniel, mourned for three weeks. I ate no choice food; no meat or wine touched my lips; and I used no lotions at all until the three weeks were over.

On the twenty-fourth day of the first month, as I was standing on the bank of the great river, the Tigris, I looked up and there before me was a man dressed in linen, with a belt of fine gold from Uphaz around his waist. His body was like topaz, his face like lightning, his eyes like flaming torches, his arms and legs like the gleam of burnished bronze, and his voice like the sound of a multitude. I, Daniel, was the only one who saw the vision; those who were with me did not see it, but such terror overwhelmed them that they fled and hid themselves. So I was left alone, gazing at this great vision; I had no strength left, my face turned deathly pale and I was helpless. Then I heard him speaking, and as I listened to him, I fell into a deep sleep, my face to the ground.

A hand touched me and set me trembling on my hands and knees. He said, "Daniel, you who are highly esteemed, consider carefully the words I am about to speak to you, and stand up, for I have now been sent to you." And when he said this to me, I stood up trembling.

Then he continued, "Do not be afraid, Daniel. Since the first day that you set your mind to gain understanding and to humble yourself before your God, your words were heard, and I have come in response to them. But the prince of the Persian kingdom resisted me twenty-one days. Then Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me, because I was detained there with the king of Persia. Now I have come to explain to you what will happen to your people in the future, for the vision concerns a time yet to come."

While he was saying this to me, I bowed with my face toward the ground and was speechless. Then one who looked like a man touched my lips, and I opened my mouth and began to speak. I said to the one standing before me, "I am overcome with anguish because of the vision, my lord, and I feel very weak. How can I, your servant, talk with you, my lord? My strength is gone and I can hardly breathe."

Again, the one who looked like a man touched me and gave me strength. "Do not be afraid, you who are highly esteemed," he said. "Peace! Be strong now; be strong."

When he spoke to me, I was strengthened and said, "Speak, my lord, since you have given me strength."

So he said, "Do you know why I have come to you? Soon I will return to fight against the prince of Persia, and when I go, the prince of Greece will come; but first I will tell you what is written in the Book of Truth. (No one supports me against them except Michael, your prince. And in the first year of Darius the Mede, I took my stand to support and protect him.)

"Now then, I tell you the truth: Three more kings will arise in Persia, and then a fourth, who will be far richer than all the others. When he has gained power by his wealth, he will stir up everyone against the kingdom of Greece. Then a mighty king will arise, who will rule with great power and do as he pleases. After he has arisen, his empire will be broken up and parceled out toward the four winds of heaven. It will not go to his descendants, nor will it have the power he exercised, because his empire will be uprooted and given to others."The kingdom will be taken away and given to others. The king of the south will be strong, but one of his princes will be even stronger and will rule over a vast territory. After some years, the daughter of the king of the south will marry the king of the north to form an alliance, but it won't last. She, her attendants, and her father will be betrayed. However, a relative of hers will rise to power, lead an army, and defeat the king of the north, taking their gods and treasures back to Egypt.

The king of the south will return to his land, but his sons will prepare for war and gather a large army. One of them will invade and pass through, but the king of the south will retaliate with a great army. Despite initial success, he will not maintain his strength. The king of the north will return with an even larger army and wealth after several years. Many will rise against the king of the south, but they will fail.

The king of the north will capture fortified cities, and the forces of the south will not be able to resist. He will do as he pleases and will stand in the glorious land, consuming it. He will try to make an alliance by giving his daughter in marriage, but she will not support him. He will then turn his attention to the coastlands and conquer many, but a commander will put an end to his arrogance. He will return to his land but will stumble and fall.

A tax collector will rise in his place but will be destroyed in a short time. A despicable person will take over the kingdom through deceit and flattery. He will defeat powerful forces and break the prince of the covenant. He will act deceitfully, becoming strong with a small group of people. He will invade the richest parts of the province and distribute the spoils among his followers, planning his strategies against strongholds.

He will muster his strength and courage against the king of the south with a great army. The king of the south will also prepare for battle with a mighty army but will be betrayed by those who eat at his table. Both kings will plot against each other, but their plans will not succeed. The king of the north will return to his land with great wealth and will oppose the holy covenant.

At the appointed time, he will invade the south again, but this time it will not be as successful. Ships from the west will oppose him, and he will retreat in anger, turning against the holy covenant. He will favor those who abandon the covenant and will desecrate the temple, stopping the daily sacrifices and setting up the abomination that causes desolation.

Those who act wickedly against the covenant will be corrupted by flattery, but the people who know their God will stand firm and take action. The wise among the people will instruct many, but they will face persecution by sword, flame, captivity, and plunder for many days. When they fall, they will receive some help, but many will join them insincerely. Some of the wise will stumble, but this will refine and purify them until the end.

The king will do as he pleases, exalting and magnifying himself above every god and speaking against the God of gods. He will succeed until the time of wrath is completed. He will not regard the gods of his ancestors or the desire of women, but will honor a god of fortresses with gold, silver, precious stones, and costly gifts. He will attack the strongest fortresses with the help of a foreign god and will reward those who acknowledge him, making them rulers over many and distributing land for a price.

At the end time, the king of the south will engage him in battle, but the king of the north will respond with a whirlwind of chariots, horsemen, and many ships. He will invade many countries, including the glorious land, but Edom, Moab, and the leaders of Ammon will escape. He will extend his power over many countries, including Egypt, and will control its treasures. Libyans and Cushites will follow him.

News from the east and north will alarm him, and he will set out in great rage to destroy many. He will pitch his royal tents between the seas at the beautiful holy mountain, but he will meet his end with no one to help him.

At that time, Michael, the great prince who protects your people, will arise. There will be a time of distress unlike any before, but your people will be delivered—everyone whose name is found written in the book. Many who sleep in the dust of the earth will awake, some to everlasting life and others to shame and everlasting contempt. The wise will shine like the brightness of the heavens, and those who lead many to righteousness will shine like the stars forever.

But you, Daniel, close up and seal the words of the scroll until the end of time. Many will go here and there to increase knowledge.
